[["name", "new_7/1010.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/passaic/paterson/2017/01/15/paterson-consider-privatizing-emergency-dispatch-services/96558654/"], ["text", "Paterson to consider privatizing emergency dispatch services\nCity Council to take up measure Tuesday to circulate a request for proposals.\nPost to Facebook\nPaterson to consider privatizing emergency dispatch services City Council to take up measure Tuesday to circulate a request for proposals. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2iAW7Ci\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nPaterson to consider privatizing emergency dispatch services\nJoe Malinconico, Paterson Press 8:46 p.m. ET Jan. 15, 2017\nThe Police Department accounts for more than half of Paterson's overtime spending during the first eight months of the fiscal year.\n(Photo: File photo)\nPATERSON \u2014 After years of complaints and criticism aimed at the city\u2019s 911 telecommunications system, Paterson is looking at the possibility of privatizing its emergency dispatch services.\nThe City Council on Tuesday is scheduled to vote whether to ask private companies to submit proposals for the contract.\nBut some officials oppose privatization. They say an outside company would lack the requisite familiarity with Paterson to handle the dispatching work. Also, they say they prefer keeping city residents on the payroll to do the dispatching instead of using municipal funds to pay a company from outside of Paterson.\nThe consideration of 911 privatization comes at a time when Paterson is in the process of buying more than $1.3 million in new equipment for what would become a consolidated telecommunications operation, one that would combine those functions of the police, fire and public works departments.\nThe city's police director, Jerry Speziale, said he is looking to make changes in his department\u2019s communication division to free up officers so they can be reassigned to street duty. At present, Speziale said, more than six officers work in communications.\nIn addition to the possibility of privatization, Speziale said the city is considering using only civilians in the dispatch room. He said the proposals from the private companies would give the city some basis for evaluating its options.\n\u201cIt\u2019s all about finding what\u2019s most cost-effective and efficient,\u201d the police director said.\nCouncil President William McKoy and Councilman Michael Jackson, the chairman of the public safety committee, both said they oppose hiring a private company.\n\u201cWe need people who know the city and care about the city,\u201d McKoy said.\n\u201cI wouldn\u2019t support anything to bring in another outside contractor to our city,\u201d Jackson said.\nCritics of the privatization proposal said the problems with the 911 system \u2014\u00a0including complaints from the public about not getting timely responses from emergency personnel when they call \u2014\u00a0likely would be addressed through the new telecommunications equipment.\nCouncilman Kenneth Morris said he wouldn\u2019t want to make any changes in the current system unless a cost-benefit analysis showed that it was in the city\u2019s best interest. Morris also said he would not want to lay off any of the people currently working as dispatchers.\nMayor Jose \"Joey\" Torres said the city decided to review the privatization at the request of the state\u00a0Department of Community Affairs, which monitors Paterson's finances as one of the conditions of the annual transition aid award from the state.\n\"At the end of the day, they can't impose it because it's something that has to be voted on by the governing body,\" he said.\nTorres said he has yet to decide\u00a0whether he supports the move. \"What we are doing now is just making an assessment.\u00a0We want to see what the numbers are,\" he said.\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1011.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/new-jersey/2017/01/13/young-and-old-share-homes-afford-north-jersey/95108024/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nYoung and old share homes to afford North Jersey\nThe two women are four decades apart in age but sharing a home in Bergen County to solve their separate housing problems\nPost to Facebook\nYoung and old share homes to afford North Jersey The two women are four decades apart in age but sharing a home in Bergen County to solve their separate housing problems Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2iqBbxE\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n3\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nYoung and old share homes to afford North Jersey\nColleen Diskin , Staff Writer, @ColleenDiskin Published 12:01 a.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017 | Updated 7:07 a.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017\nJoan Grzenda, left, and Alyssa Camacho in the kitchen of Grzenda's home. Grzenda, 66, was debating giving up her longtime home after retiring but found a home-sharing match in Camacho, 26.\n(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\nThe two women are four decades apart in age \u2013 one a recent retiree worried about the high cost of living in the home where she raised her daughter, the other a 20-something working two jobs while trying to finish school in one of the most expensive rental markets in the country.\nA computer likely wouldn't spit out these two profiles as a potential roommate match.\nNevertheless, Joan\u00a0Grzenda, 66, and Alyssa Camacho, 26, are amicably sharing a three-bedroom home in Bergen County (they prefer not to name the town) in an arrangement that, for now, has solved each of their very different housing problems.\nBefore the two were introduced six months ago through an Englewood-based home-sharing program,\u00a0Grzenda\u00a0was an empty-nester not yet ready to be uprooted from the home she's owned for 23 years, although the taxes and upkeep were becoming too heavy a financial load.\nCamacho's worries were more immediate \u2013 she was technically homeless, having spent several months on the couches of family members and even spending a few nights sleeping in her car.\n\"This really helps us both,\"\u00a0Grzenda\u00a0said. \"Alyssa needed a place to live, and I needed some more time before having to figure out whether I'm going to try to stay in my house or look to move somewhere more affordable.\"\nMore millennials buying homes without parents' help\nHome-sharing is far from a new concept, but as North Jersey's population grows older, the region's high cost of living has turned the phrase into something of a buzzword among advocates looking to ease the pressures of older homeowners who either can't afford or don't want to downsize into an easier-to-manage apartment or condo.\nThere can be downsides: Because these arrangements are informal, there is no lease\u00a0nor the\u00a0legal protections\u00a0offered by one\u00a0-- a necessity in order not to violate the rules many towns have about renting rooms in single-family homes.\nBut proponents say the concept of sharing, instead of renting, can also help younger people like Camacho, who work or go to school in North Jersey but can't afford\u00a0the\u00a0region's typical\u00a0rents\u00a0-- about $1,200 a month for\u00a0a one-bedroom apartment, according to a 2016 study by the National Low Income Housing Coalition.\n\"Lack of affordable housing choices is a problem for all generations,\" said Julia\u00a0Stoumbos, program officer for the Henry and Marilyn\u00a0Taub\u00a0Foundation, a Teaneck-based philanthropy that funds programs that assist both older and low-income residents.\nMany advocates for the aging say home-sharing\u00a0could be\u00a0an option for older North\u00a0Jerseyans\u00a0grappling with property taxes that are among the highest in the country.\nThose same advocates, however, recognize that such arrangements will only be successful if homeowners \u2013 and those seeking to\u00a0share a home \u2013 get assistance on how to find a good match.\nAlyssa Camacho has her own bedroom and bathroom in Joan Grzenda's home.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\nRather than being the makings of a lighthearted situation comedy,\u00a0a la \"The Golden Girls\" hit television series of the 1980s, home-sharing\u00a0arrangements can be fraught with challenges, particularly if the homeowner and home-seeker\u00a0are used to different lifestyles.\nOpening up your home to a \"friend of a friend of a friend' or answering an ad on craigslist can bring regrets, as Micki\u00a0Shilan, 82, of Teaneck can attest.\nAt present, all is well in\u00a0Shilan's\u00a0home, which she has been sharing\u00a0for about three years with the son of a good friend. The man, who is in his 60s, is so quiet and respectful that\u00a0Shilan\u00a0hardly knows he's there.\nBut\u00a0Shilan\u00a0had several bad experiences before she found her current situation, including one in which a former female roommate pulled a knife on her.\n\"There's been quite a few that were just terrible,\" said\u00a0Shilan, who never sought the\u00a0help of a home-sharing service. \"I have some stories to tell.\"\nHer\u00a0stories\u00a0are\u00a0why advocates like\u00a0Stoumbos\u00a0think there needs to be more formal guidance and support for those interested in home-sharing. But such services are hard\u00a0to find in Bergen and Passaic counties\nHomesharing\u00a0Inc., a Bridgewater-based non-profit that serves all or parts of seven New Jersey counties, expanded its territory two years ago to\u00a0include a sliver\u00a0of\u00a0Passaic County \u2013 Clifton and Little Falls. The only non-profit\u00a0providing such help in Bergen\u00a0is the Women's Rights Information Center in Englewood.\nFor years, the Englewood center,\u00a0which offers an array of assistance programs to women in distress,\u00a0has been quietly helping to place those who are homeless, or on the verge, with those\u00a0who are struggling to afford\u00a0their longtime homes.\nSusan\u00a0Bendes, a part-time center employee who runs the program,\u00a0said she typically makes\u00a0one or two matches\u00a0a month. In each, she spends\u00a0a lot of time talking to both the homeowner and the home-seeker about the nitty-gritty details of sharing space: How late is OK to use the kitchen? Is it OK to leave clothes in the dryer overnight? Whose job is it to take out the garbage? How about playing music? Watching TV? Smoking? Keeping pets?\nThe more she can get both individuals talking about their living habits,\u00a0the better the chance that a match will not only be made but last for a while. The living agreement form she asks both parties to sign is six pages long.\n\"It's hard for people to live together when they are related, much less when they don't know each other,\"\u00a0Bendes\u00a0said. \"I really try to make sure the expectations are clear, and that there aren't any surprises after someone moves in.\"\nGrzenda and Camacho say they've gotten along despite having very different tastes.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\nWhile they may be strangers in the beginning, both home-seeker and homeowner need to develop trust, as well as good rapport, since these are informal living agreements, Bendes said.\n\"This is not one person renting space in a home to another,\"\u00a0she said.\u00a0 \"These are two people who have decided to share the expenses of living together. It's important that everyone understands that distinction.\"\nIn their short time together,\u00a0Grzenda\u00a0and Camacho, who were matched by\u00a0Bendes, say they haven't really argued over anything despite having different tastes in everything from food to television programs.\n\"I'm almond milk, she's whole milk,\" said\u00a0Grzenda. \"I'm big on my vegetables while Alyssa, if she ever bought vegetables, they would rot before she got around to eating them.\"\nIn truth, because of their separate work schedules, the two are rarely home at the same time. Camacho's two jobs keep her working Monday through Saturday, often until 9 p.m. So most nights, Camacho arrives home to make dinner hours after\u00a0Grzenda, who is retired but still works three to four days a week as a substitute teacher,\u00a0 has already eaten. Culturally, they are both products of their separate generations.\u00a0Grzenda\u00a0has a couple of favorite prime-time\u00a0programs she considers \"must-see,\" while Camacho live-streams shows on the X-Box in her room.\nCamacho has her own bedroom and bathroom on the second floor,\u00a0the first time she's ever\u00a0had\u00a0that much space\u00a0to herself, and said she\u00a0gets\u00a0along well\u00a0with\u00a0Grzenda\u00a0and her dog and two cats.\n\"From the first moment I met Joan, I felt comfortable with her,\" Camacho said.\n\"I think it's because I have a daughter about her age,\"\u00a0Grzenda\u00a0added. \"I know what it's like, and I try not to get too involved in her life because it's her life.\"\nIn\u00a0making home-sharing matches,\u00a0Bendes\u00a0said it's important that\u00a0both individuals\u00a0are\u00a0looking\u00a0for the same type of relationship. Some want it to be\u00a0businesslike arrangement, where each person is respectful of the other but they don't interact much in\u00a0each other's lives, while others want company and companionship.\nThe Englewood agency has been offering free home-sharing assistance since the\u00a01970s, and in that time\u00a0matches have been made between\u00a0young\u00a0and\u00a0old, old\u00a0and\u00a0old, and even families with young children looking to help make ends meet by finding someone to live in a spare bedroom.\u00a0The program also serves men seeking home-shares.\nIt\u00a0is one of\u00a0a handful\u00a0of\u00a0non-profits in the state that offer such\u00a0assistance to potential home-sharers. The largest is\u00a0Homesharing\u00a0Inc., which started in 1984 in Somerset and Hunterdon counties\u00a0and\u00a0now has 1,700\u00a0active home-sharing matches\u00a0in\u00a0seven\u00a0counties, said executive director Lisa Blum.\nThe agency is open to the idea of expanding again to serve clients in Bergen and in the rest of Passaic County, Blum said. At the same time, the\u00a0Taub\u00a0Foundation has recently begun\u00a0exploring whether there is a need to provide seed money for more home-sharing assistance in the Bergen-Passaic area as part of a multi-town initiative to make the suburbs more \"age friendly,\"\u00a0Stoumbos\u00a0said.\nBesides the financial incentive of sharing living costs, senior homeowners\u00a0struggling to keep up with chores like snow-shoveling, yard work and grocery shopping could\u00a0\u00a0build a shared-chore arrangement into a home-share, thus curing some of their other housing headaches,\u00a0Stoumbos\u00a0said.\nBendes\u00a0thinks it is wise for senior advocates to start marketing the idea of home-sharing to seniors struggling to get by on their own.\n\"I know the idea makes a lot of seniors nervous or scared,\"\u00a0Bendes\u00a0said. \"It's hard to live together. I won't sugarcoat it. It's not easy.\"\nBut,\u00a0she added,\u00a0\"Seniors might find that it's a very helpful thing for them and a way to stay in their own home, which is what a lot of people want to do.\"\n271 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 3 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2iqBbxE\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1013.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/new-jersey/2017/01/15/booker-join-trump-protest-groups-mlk-breakfast/96621678/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nBooker to join Trump protest group's MLK breakfast\nSen. Cory Booker will\u00a0speak at\u00a0a Martin Luther King Day breakfast hosted by the Rev. Al Sharpton's group.\nPost to Facebook\nBooker to join Trump protest group's MLK breakfast Sen. Cory Booker will\u00a0speak at\u00a0a Martin Luther King Day breakfast hosted by the Rev. Al Sharpton's group. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jNXPxP\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n1\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nBooker to join Trump protest group's MLK breakfast\nHerb Jackson , Washington Correspondent, @HerbNJDC 7:34 p.m. ET Jan. 15, 2017\nSen. Cory Booker\n(Photo: ASSOCIATED PRESS)\nSen. Cory Booker will\u00a0speak at\u00a0a Martin Luther King Day breakfast\u00a0in Washington on Monday organized by the Rev. Al Sharpton's National Action Network, the group that led a pre-inauguration protest march calling for ractial justice \u00a0over the weekend.\nThe appearance comes days after Booker attracted national attention by breaking with Senate tradition to appear at a hearing to argue against the confirmation of a fellow senator under consideration for a cabinet post. Booker, a Democrat from Newark, joined\u00a0with civil rights icon Rep. John Lewis, D-Georgia, to urge the Senate Judiciary Committee to reject the nomination of Sen. Jeff Sessions of Alabama to be attorney general.\nThough Booker spoke for a little more than five minutes on a panel of six witnesses at the end of a two-day hearing on Sessions, his appearance fueled speculation Booker is positioning himself for a possible presidential run in 2020.\nA \"We Will Not Be Moved\" march and rally at the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial in Washington on Saturday mixed calls for justice and voting rights with opposition to Trump .\n\"We come not to appeal to Donald Trump, because he's made it clear what his policies are and what his nominations are,\" Sharpton said, according to The Associated Press. \"We come to say to the Democrats in the Senate and in the House and to the moderate Republicans to 'Get some backbone. Get some guts.' We didn't send you down here to be weak-kneed.\"\nSince taking the oath of office in 2013, Booker has been a leading advocate in the Senate for criminal justice reform, including a reduction in criminal sentences for drug crimes. He argues that the war on drugs helps to fuel other crime and economic despair in urban areas because of disproportionate enforcement against minorities and laws that make people with criminal records ineligible for many safety net programs, including food and housing assistance.\nThe justice reform effort was gaining bipartisan support, but Sessions, who has argued against legalizing marijuana and could be in a position to have the Justice Department crack down on states that have,\u00a0was a leading opponent. Booker also questioned Sessions' record on protecting voting rights and the rights of gay and lesbian people. At a forum in December, Booker said Sessions' nomination was a \"chilling sign\" for the chances of reform happening.\nIn addition to Sharpton and Booker, speakers at the breakfast Monday include Gov. Terry McAuliffe of Virginia and\u00a0Mayor Muriel Bowser of Washington.\n2 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jNXPxP\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1017.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/politics/2017/01/15/mlk-march-newark-call-racial-economic-equality/96448924/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nAt MLK march in Newark, a call for racial, economic equality\nMore than 100 marchers walked through the streets of Newark on Sunday to commemorate the civil rights activist's birthday.\nPost to Facebook\nAt MLK march in Newark, a call for racial, economic equality More than 100 marchers walked through the streets of Newark on Sunday to commemorate the civil rights activist's birthday. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jNMxd0\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nAt MLK march in Newark, a call for racial, economic equality\nJohn Brennan , Staff Writer, @BergenBrennan Published 6:47 p.m. ET Jan. 15, 2017 | Updated 9 hours ago\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nThe Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. statue in Newark on Sunday.\u00a0\nDanielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com\nFullscreen\nWilla Cofield speaks during Sunday's rally about her experience of having a cross burned on her lawn twice by the Ku Klux Klan when she lived in North Carolina. Threats such as those did not deter her, and she continues to advocate for civil rights at age 88.\u00a0\nDanielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com\nAssemblyman William Payne, center, at the rally. Payne's Amistad legislation established the Amistad Commission to incorporate African-American history into the curriculum for all New Jersey schools.\u00a0\nDanielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com\nLawrence Hamm of the People's Organization for Progress speaks during a rally in protest of President-elect Donald Trump in Newark on Sunday.\u00a0\nDanielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com\nLawrence Hamm of the People's Organization for Progress speaks next to the Martin Luther King Jr. statue during Sunday's rally.\u00a0\nDanielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com\nAbout 100 people showed up to rally in protest of President-elect Donald Trump and in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. Day in Newark on Sunday.\u00a0\nDanielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com\nAbout 100 people showed up to rally in protest of President-elect Donald Trump and in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. Day in Newark on Sunday.\u00a0\nDanielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com\nAbout 100 people showed up to march in protest of President-elect Donald Trump and in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. Day in Newark on Sunday.\u00a0\nDanielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com\nProtesters march down Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. boulevard to protest President-elect Donald Trump in Newark on Sunday.\u00a0\nDanielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com\nAbout 100 people showed up to march in protest of President-elect Donald Trump and in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. Day in Newark on Sunday.\u00a0\nDanielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com\nProtesters marched toward downtown Newark in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. Day and in protest of President-elect Donald Trump on Sunday.\u00a0\nDanielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com\nAbout 100 people showed up to march in protest of President-elect Donald Trump and in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. Day in Newark on Sunday.\u00a0\nDanielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com\nLike this topic? You may also like these photo galleries:\nReplay\nLast Slide Next Slide\nWilla Cofield speaks during the rally of her experience of having a cross burned on her lawn twice by the Ku Klux Klan when she lived in North Carolina. Threats such as those did not deter her, and she continues to advocate for black civil rights at the age of 88.\n(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\nMore than 100 marchers walked together through the streets of Newark on Sunday to commemorate the birthday of the civil rights activist Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.\n\"He would have been 88 years old today, and it's amazing that he didn't get to live half that long,\" said Lawrence Hamm, whose People's Organization for Progress organized the\u00a0Dr. Martin Luther King\u00a0Jr. March and\u00a0Rally for Equality, Justice, Peace and\u00a0Democracy, which\u00a0kicked off in front of the statue of King outside\u00a0the Essex County Hall of Records.\nKing died in 1968 at the age of 39, and Hamm noted that while King is known for his civil rights efforts, he also spoke out against poverty, the Vietnam War\u00a0and what he saw as other social ills.\nThe march has been taking place annually in mid-January since 1983, Hamm said.\n\"But I think I am reading your minds when I say I believe that today's birthday celebration has an extra-special meaning,\" Hamm said, referring to the imminent inauguration of President-elect Donald Trump.\nHamm said the presidential campaign had produced \"an intensification of all types of intolerance and hatred,\" whereas he said King \"believed all people should live together as brothers and sisters.\"\nA sixth-grader when the Voting Rights Act became law in 1965, Hamm said he was old enough to remember when as a child he was chased out of a swimming pool set aside for white children. He also noted that New Jersey was one of only nine out of 36 states that did not approve the 13th Amendment to abolish slavery in 1865, as an example of the state's not having always been supportive of civil rights.\nLawrence Hamm of the People's Organization for Progress speaks during a rally in protest of President-elect Donald Trump in Newark on Sunday.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\nThe tone of the event\u00a0was decidedly progressive, with the crowd at times calling out traditional chants, like\u00a0\"No Justice, No Peace\" and carrying signs saying,\u00a0\"We demand jobs at a living wage.\"\nHamm was a delegate for Bernie Sanders at the Democratic National Convention last summer, and the chairman of Sanders' state primary campaign. Assemblyman John Wisniewski, D-Middlesex, who has announced a bid for governor this fall,\u00a0also attended. Wisniewski, the only elected official to speak before the march, called for a $15 minimum wage, free college tuition\u00a0and full access to quality health care for all.\n\"We want to remember the life and legacy of Dr. King, and I wonder what he would say today,\" Wisniewski said as he touched the King statue. \"He probably would say, 'Don't build me a statue.' He didn't want things of brick and steel, of brick and mortar. His whole thing was changing people's minds, changing people's hearts.\"\nWilla Cofield, a New Jersey resident since 1969, said she always knew how old King was because she was born three months earlier. Cofield recalled a time more than a half-century ago in a small town in North Carolina when her husband, an African-American, decided to run for a local office.\nProtesters march down Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. boulevard to protest President-elect Donald Trump in Newark on Sunday.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\n\"There was a lot of whispering around, and one night my neighbor called and said to look out the window to the backyard,\" Cofield said. \"It was a burning cross.\"\nCofield said her efforts for civil rights got her fired for \"insubordination\" after 12 years as a teacher.\u00a0Upon returning from filing a lawsuit to get her job back \u2014\u00a0the process took three years \u2014\u00a0she said she had returned to find a 17-foot burning cross, this time\u00a0on her front lawn.\n\"It was terrible,\" Cofield said.\nYet Cofield seemed less fearful than many in the crowd\u00a0about the new administration.\n\"We've had other discouraging things happen before, so\u00a0I think we'll be all right,\" Cofield said. \"It will help mobilize others who need to have a voice.\"\nAbout 100 people showed up to march in protest of President-elect Donald Trump and in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. Day in Newark, NJ on Sunday, January 15, 2017.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1038.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/bergen/garfield/2017/01/15/essex-county-sheriff-garfield-man-faces-weapons-charges/96613044/"], ["text", "Essex County Sheriff: Garfield man faces weapons charges\nZsaahid Muhammed, 23, of Garfield, was arrested in Irvington, the Essex County Sheriff\u2019s Department reported.\nPost to Facebook\nEssex County Sheriff: Garfield man faces weapons charges Zsaahid Muhammed, 23, of Garfield, was arrested in Irvington, the Essex County Sheriff\u2019s Department reported. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jMQD51\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nEssex County Sheriff: Garfield man faces weapons charges\nOwen Proctor , Staff Writer @OwenProctor1 Published 12:38 p.m. ET Jan. 15, 2017 | Updated 11 hours ago\nZsaahid Muhammed, 23, of Garfield, was arrested Friday in Irvington on weapons and drug charges.\n(Photo: Courtesy of Essex County Correctional Facility)\nAn Irvington vehicle stop led to the arrest of Zsaahid Muhammed, 23, of Garfield, on weapons and narcotics charges, the Essex County Sheriff\u2019s Department reported Saturday.\nThe patrol division was conducting \u201cquality of life operations\u201d in the area of Irvington Park on Friday night, when it ran a records check on a passing 2015 Nissan Sentra\u2019s temporary registration tag, authorities\u00a0said.\n\u201cWhen the tag proved to be not on file, the suspect vehicle was pulled over at Lyons Avenue and Normandy Place,\u201d Essex County Sheriff Armando Fontoura said in a press release. \u201cNeither the driver of the Nissan, later identified as Vandervort Wilson, 23, of Bloomfield, nor his passenger, Zsaahid Muhammed, also 23, of Garfield, could produce either personal identification for themselves or papers for the vehicle.\u201d\nDuring questioning, the sheriff\u2019s officers detected a strong odor of alcohol on Muhammed, authorities said.\n\u201cWhen Muhammed was asked to step out of the vehicle, our officers observed an open bottle of vodka at his feet and a large bulge in his pants pocket,\u201d Fontoura stated.\u00a0\u201cDuring a pat-down search for officer safety, Muhammed was found to be in possession of a .22-caliber, Taurus semi-automatic handgun, fully loaded with illegal hollow point bullets, and 20 plastic jars, filled with \u2018crack\u2019 cocaine.\u201d\nSheriff\u2019s officers arrested Muhammed and charged him with the unlawful possession of a weapon, possession of a defaced weapon, possession of hollow point bullets and possession of a controlled dangerous substance, authorities said.\u00a0He was also issued summonses for the possession of an open alcoholic beverage container in a motor vehicle and possession of a controlled dangerous substance\u00a0in a motor vehicle.\nMuhammed was held\u00a0at the Essex County Correctional Facility, where he awaited a bail hearing on the charges.\nThe driver, Vandervort, was issued summonses for displaying a fictitious registration tag, driving while suspended and driving an uninsured motor vehicle. He was released on his own recognizance.\nEmail: proctor@northjersey.com\n21 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jMQD51\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1073.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/world/2017/01/14/ringling-bros-circus-close-after-146-years/96606060/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nRingling Bros. circus to close after 146 years\nAfter 146 years, the curtain is coming down on \"The Greatest Show on Earth.\" The owner said the show will close in May.\nPost to Facebook\nRingling Bros. circus to close after 146 years After 146 years, the curtain is coming down on \"The Greatest Show on Earth.\" The owner said the show will close in May. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jKEuh6\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n3\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nRingling Bros. circus to close after 146 years\nTAMARA LUSH, ASSOCIATED PRESS Published 10:53 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017 | Updated 22 hours ago\nRingling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey performers begin a show Saturday, Jan. 14, 2017, in Orlando, Fla. The Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus will end the \"The Greatest Show on Earth\" in May, following a 146-year run of performances. Kenneth Feld, the chairman and CEO of Feld Entertainment, which owns the circus, told The Associated Press, declining attendance combined with high operating costs are among the reasons for closing.\n(Photo: Chris O'Meara, AP)\nELLENTON, Fla. \u00a0\u2014 After 146 years, the curtain is coming down on \"The Greatest Show on Earth.\" The owner of the\u00a0Ringling\u00a0Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus told The Associated Press that the show will close forever in May.\nThe iconic American spectacle was felled by a variety of factors, company executives say. Declining attendance combined with high operating costs, along with changing public tastes and prolonged battles with animal rights groups all contributed to its demise.\n\"There isn't any one thing,\" said Kenneth Feld, chairman and CEO of Feld Entertainment. \"This has been a very difficult decision for me and for the entire family.\"\nAnimal rights groups applaud Ringling Bros. closing\nThe company broke the news to circus employees Saturday night after shows in Orlando and Miami.\nRingling\u00a0Bros. has two touring circuses this season and will perform 30 shows between now and May. Major stops include Atlanta, Washington, Philadelphia, Boston and Brooklyn. The final shows will be in Providence, Rhode Island, on May 7 and in Uniondale, New York, at the Nassau County Coliseum on May 21.\nIn this Feb. 28, 1945 photo, Elizabeth Wallenda pauses on an aerial ladder during rehearsal for her return to the Wallenda troupe's high wire act with the Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Circus.\n\u00a0(Photo: Earl Shugars/AP)\nThe circus, with its exotic animals, flashy costumes and death-defying acrobats, has been a staple of entertainment in the United States since the mid-1800s. Phineas Taylor Barnum made a traveling spectacle of animals and human oddities popular, while the five\u00a0Ringling\u00a0brothers performed juggling acts and skits from their home base in Wisconsin. Eventually, they merged and the modern circus was born. The sprawling troupes traveled around America by train, wowing audiences with the sheer scale of entertainment and exotic animals.\nRingling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey acrobats ride camels during a performance Saturday, Jan. 14, 2017, in Orlando, Fla. The Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus will end the \"The Greatest Show on Earth\" in May, following a 146-year run of performances. Kenneth Feld, the chairman and CEO of Feld Entertainment, which owns the circus, told The Associated Press, declining attendance combined with high operating costs are among the reasons for closing.\n\u00a0(Photo: Chris O'Meara, AP)\nBy midcentury, the circus was routine, wholesome family entertainment. But as the 20th century went on, kids became less and less enthralled. Movies, television, video games and the internet captured young minds. The circus didn't have savvy product merchandising tie-ins or Saturday morning cartoons to shore up its image.\n\"The competitor in many ways is time,\" said Feld, adding that transporting the show by rail and other circus quirks \u2014 such as providing a traveling school for performers' children\u2014 are throwbacks to another era. \"It's a different model that we can't see how it works in today's world to justify and maintain an affordable ticket price. So you've got all these things working against it.\"\nThe Feld family bought the\u00a0Ringling\u00a0circus in 1967. The show was just under 3 hours then. Today, the show is 2 hours and 7 minutes, with the longest segment \u2014 a tiger act \u2014 clocking in at 12 minutes.\n\"Try getting a 3- or 4-year-old today to sit for 12 minutes,\" he said.\nFeld and his daughter Juliette Feld, who is the company's chief operating officer, acknowledged another reality that led to the closing, and it was the one thing that initially drew millions to the show: the animals.\u00a0Ringling\u00a0has been targeted by activists who say forcing animals to perform is cruel and unnecessary.\nA Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey clown balances a hat on his nose during a pre show for fans Saturday, Jan. 14, 2017, in Orlando, Fla.\n\u00a0(Photo: Chris O'Meara, AP)\nIn May of 2016, after a long and costly legal battle, the company removed the elephants from the shows and sent the animals to live on a conservation farm in Central Florida. The animals had been the symbol of the circus since Barnum brought an Asian elephant named Jumbo to America in 1882. In 2014, Feld Entertainment won $25.2 million in settlements from groups including the Humane Society of the United States, ending a 14-year fight over allegations that circus employees mistreated elephants.\nBy the time the elephants were removed, public opinion had shifted somewhat. Los Angeles prohibited the use of bull-hooks by elephant trainers and handlers, as did Oakland, California. The city of Asheville, North Carolina nixed wild or exotic animals from performing in the municipally owned, 7,600-seat U.S. Cellular Center.\nIn this Tuesday, Jan. 10, 2017 photo, Chairman and CEO of Feld Entertainment, Kenneth Feld, poses for a photo, in Ellenton, Fla. Feld Entertainment, which owns The Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus told The Associated Press declining attendance combined with high operating costs are among the reasons for closing. Feld said when the company removed elephants from the shows in May of 2016, ticket sales declined more dramatically than expected.\n\u00a0(Photo: Tamara Lush, AP)\nAttendance has been dropping for 10 years, said Juliette Feld, but when the elephants left, there was a \"dramatic drop\" in ticket sales. Paradoxically, while many said they didn't want big animals to perform in circuses, many others refused to attend a circus without them.\n\"We know now that one of the major reasons people came to\u00a0Ringling\u00a0Bros. was getting to see elephants,\" she said. \"We stand by that decision. We know it was the right decision. This was what audiences wanted to see and it definitely played a major role.\"\nA Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey acrobat jumps on a high wire during a performance Saturday, Jan. 14, 2017, in Orlando, Fla.\n\u00a0(Photo: Chris O'Meara, AP)\nThe Felds say their existing animals \u2014 lions, tigers, camels, donkeys, alpacas, kangaroos and llamas \u2014 will go to suitable homes. Juliette Feld says the company will continue operating the Center for Elephant Conservation.\nSome 500 people perform and work on both touring shows. A handful will be placed in positions with the company's other, profitable shows \u2014 it owns Monster Jam, Disney on Ice and Marvel Live, among other things \u2014 but most will be out of a job. Juliette Feld said the company will help employees with job placement and resumes. In some cases where a circus employee lives on the tour rail car (the circus travels by train), the company will also help with housing relocation.\nKenneth Feld became visibly emotional while discussing the decision with a reporter. He said over the next four months, fans will be able to say goodbye at the remaining shows.\nIn recent years,\u00a0Ringling\u00a0Bros. tried to remain relevant, hiring its first African American ringmaster, then its first female ringmaster, and also launching an interactive app. It added elements from its other, popular shows, such as motorbike daredevils and ice skaters. But it seemingly was no match for Pokemon Go and a generation of kids who desire familiar brands and YouTube celebrities.\n\"We tried all these different things to see what would work, and supported it with a lot of funding as well, and we weren't successful in finding the solution,\" said Kenneth Feld.\n779 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 3 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jKEuh6\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/108.html"], ["url", "https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2014/01/09/the-record-nails-christie-story/"], ["text", "The Record nails Christie story\nThe inside track on Washington politics.\nBe the first to know about new stories from PowerPost. Sign up to follow, and we\u2019ll e-mail you free updates as they\u2019re published.\nYou\u2019ll receive free e-mail news updates each time a new story is published.\nYou\u2019re all set!\nBy Erik Wemple January 9, 2014 Follow @ErikWemple\nChris Christie (Chris Usher/Associated Press)\nMartin Gottlieb, editor of the (Bergen, N.J.) Record, has a lot of great things to say about his employer. Though his newsroom has had to deal with a bit of shrinkage over the years, it\u2019s still robust, with a head count of about 200. While newspaper owners in recent decades have sold out to big chains, says Gottlieb, his people have stayed firm, sticking with the industry. Stephen Borg is the fourth generation of his family to serve as publisher of the Record, the northern New Jersey paper that\u2019s often referred to as the Bergen Record. And committed, local ownership has its benefits, says Gottlieb.\nAmid the now-legendary shutdown of access lanes to the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee, N.J. in September, Borg got something of a tip. Says Gottlieb: \u201cOur publisher gets a call from a friend of his saying it\u2019s been taking me hours to get into New York.\u201d Gottlieb passed along the information to the assignment desk; from there, it reached John Cichowski, author of the paper\u2019s \u201cRoad Warrior\u201d column, which got its founding inspiration from the Washington Post\u2019s \u201cDr. Gridlock.\u201d\nBackup at the George Washington Bridge? Whoop-dee-doo, thought Cichowski at first. \u201cA tie-up of the George Washington Bridge is not really news,\u201d Cichowski told the Erik Wemple Blog. Cichowski has been doing \u201cRoad Warrior\u201d for more than 10 years, and there are a lot of traffic jams on New Jersey highways. In this case, however, Cichowski started gathering indications that this wasn\u2019t just a one-off situation. \u201cIt happened more than once, and I started getting e-mails from people, and naturally you do an appropriate kind of phone call\u201d in such a circumstance, says Cichowski. He got this feedback from police in Fort Lee: \u201cOur town is a mess and not only is it a mess but it\u2019s been that way for a couple of days.\u201d\nStory!\nOn Friday, Sept. 13, Cichowski turned in this thoroughly reported column: \u201c Closed tollbooths a commuting disaster .\u201d Gottlieb proudly notes that reporting for the column served notice to the Port Authority\u2019s executive director that there was a traffic disaster in Fort Lee. The piece carried this quote from Fort Lee Mayor Mark Sokolich: \u201cI\u2019ve asked the Port for an explanation, but they haven\u2019t responded. I thought we had a good relationship. Now I\u2019m beginning to wonder if there\u2019s something I did wrong. Am I being sent some sort of message?\u201d\nThat\u2019s prescient. Gov. Chris Christie this morning (and afternoon) held a press conference apologizing for the Fort Lee scandal, which reached a new level of outrage this week following the Record\u2019s reporting on smoking-gun messages among Christie staffers and loyalists in which they plot and discuss the lane closures. That news break came under the byline of Shawn Boburg, a staff writer at the Record who has been reporting on the Port Authority since 2011.\nAt the time that the bridge backups emerged as a news story, Boburg was pursuing followups to another investigative project on the Port Authority, a bistate agency with a rich history of power and cronyism. In a Sept. 8 piece, Boburg reported that the Port Authority had sold the naming rights to the World Trade Center decades ago for $10 to one of its executives : \u201cUntil his death this year, the former executive, Guy Tozzoli, earned millions primarily by licensing the name through the group, the World Trade Centers Association. And the Port Authority is among the hundreds of licensees around the world paying thousands of dollars each year for the privilege of using the words \u2018World Trade Center.'\u201d\nOnce he finished off the WTC-naming-rights story, Boburg hopped on the toll-lanes investigation. About a dozen public-records requests pushed the story forward, says Boburg, who describes an interesting dynamic in prying documents from the Port Authority. Since it\u2019s a bistate entity filled with political appointees of various loyalties, it\u2019s tough to get records requests through the thicket. That same dynamic, however, ensures that some of the records being sought formally get leaked informally. \u201cThere were documents leaked to us several times that would be responsive [to public document requests] if they had actually supplied the documents,\u201d says Boburg, noting that the formal response from the Port Authority has been to seek more time to fulfill the requests.\nAfter the Record blew open the story yesterday morning, news outlets everywhere scrambled to match the story \u2014 and to acquire the documents that the Record had acquired. An attribution in the New York Times reads like this : \u201cThe documents were obtained by The New York Times and other news outlets Wednesday.\u201d A similar attribution appears in The Post . Boburg: \u201cI don\u2019t know this but I believe they also obtained them. . . . All I know is that we had them first.\u201d\nThe work of Chichowski and Boburg, says publisher Borg, is part of a \u201cserious\u201d news operation that is the jewel of a diversified media corporation. The North Jersey Media Group consists of the Record, 46 weekly community newspapers with a combined circulation of 500,000, printing operations with customers such as USA Today and Investor\u2019s Business Daily,\u00a0 (201) Magazine and others. The newspaper\u2019s staffing has weathered the decade-long industry decline by losing just 10 percent of its newsroom staff from its peak, says Borg, and there are \u201cno future staff reductions planned.\u201d\nopinions\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1080.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/world/2017/01/15/evolution-greatest-show-earth/96610866/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nThe evolution of 'The Greatest Show on Earth'\nFrom New York to London and beyond, the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey\u00a0Circus\u00a0has performed for millions of fans during its 146-year reign.\nPost to Facebook\nThe evolution of 'The Greatest Show on Earth' From New York to London and beyond, the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey\u00a0Circus\u00a0has performed for millions of fans during its 146-year reign. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jM1BYD\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nThe evolution of 'The Greatest Show on Earth'\nASSOCIATED PRESS Published 5:33 a.m. ET Jan. 15, 2017 | Updated 23 hours ago\nIn the 1882 file image at an unknown location, American showman P.T. Barnum is shown. In his lifetime, Barnum was an entrepreneur, museum owner, politician, journalist, impressario and creator of his circus \"The Greatest Show on Earth\" in 1871. The Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus will end \"The Greatest Show on Earth\" in May 2017, following a 146-year run of performances.\n(Photo: AP file photo)\nELLENTON, Fla. \u2014 From New York to Wisconsin to London and beyond, the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey\u00a0Circus\u00a0has performed for millions of fans during its 146-year reign as one of the world's biggest big tops.\nThe show, which is closing down permanently because of declining ticket sales, has its roots in a spectacle that began two decades before the U.S. Civil War \u2014 equal parts freak show, zoo and museum. In 1881 it officially became the\u00a0circus\u00a0that generations grew up watching and saw many evolutions over the years, most recently with its decision to retire its elephant acts.\n___\n\u2014 1841 \u2014 Phineas Taylor Barnum buys Scudder's American Museum in New York City and renames it Barnum's American Museum, which was something of a zoo, museum, lecture hall and freak show. It was filled with artifacts and items from around the world. The museum later burned down. Barnum also took his show on the road as \"P.T. Barnum's Grand Traveling American Museum.\"\n\u2014 1881 \u2014 Barnum partners with James A. Bailey and James L. Hutchinson for \"P.T. Barnum's Greatest Show On Earth, And The Great London\u00a0Circus, Sanger's Royal British Menagerie and The Grand International Allied Shows United,\" later shortened to the \"Barnum & London\u00a0Circus.\"\n\u2014 1882 \u2014 The Ringling Brothers \u2014 Alf, Al, Charles, John and Otto \u2014 performed their first vaudeville-style show in Mazomanie, Wisconsin.\n\u2014 1884 \u2014 The Ringling Brothers\u00a0Circus\u00a0begins as a traveling performance.\n\u2014 1887 \u2014 The official Ringling touring show became the \"Ringling Bros. United Monster Shows, Great Double\u00a0Circus, Royal European Menagerie, Museum, Caravan, and Congress of Trained Animals.\"\n\u2014 1895 \u2014 The Ringlings decided to branch out to New England, which was already the territory of P.T. Barnum. According to the Wisconsin Historical Society, the two circuses \"agreed to divide the U.S. rather than compete head-to-head. The Ringlings established their headquarters in Chicago while Barnum and Bailey stayed in New York.\"\n\u2014 1907 \u2014 After the death of James Bailey, the Ringlings buy Barnum and Bailey. They keep the circuses separate, and the Wisconsin Historical Society wrote that by the 1910s the Ringling Bros.\u00a0Circus\u00a0had more than 1,000 employees, 335 horses, 26 elephants, 16 camels and other assorted animals that traveled on 92 railcars. The Barnum and Bailey\u00a0Circus\u00a0was roughly the same size.\n\u2014 1919 \u2014 The two circuses merged and became known as \"Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Combined Shows.\"\n\u2014 1927 \u2014 John Ringling moves\u00a0circus\u00a0headquarters to Sarasota, Florida.\n\u2014 1967 \u2014 Irvin Feld, a music and entertainment promoter, buys The Ringling\u00a0circus\u00a0and formally acquires it in a ceremony held at the Colosseum in Rome.\nIn this July 19, 1978 file photo, actor Charlton Heston is shown with Ringling Bros. and Barnum and Bailey Circus clown Prince Paul during the City of Hope's Celebrity Circus opening in Inglewood, Calif.\n\u00a0(Photo: AP/Mclendon file photo)\n\u2014 1985 \u2014 Kenneth Feld, Irvin's son, becomes the owner of Feld Entertainment and the\u00a0circus\u00a0after his father dies.\n\u2014 2016 \u2014 Feld Entertainment announces it will retire elephants from its\u00a0circus\u00a0shows. The animals are moved to its Center for Elephant Conservation in Polk County, Florida.\n\u2014 2017 \u2014 Feld Entertainment announces that it will close the Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey\u00a0Circus.\n13 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jM1BYD\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1089.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/2017/01/14/martin-luther-king-jr-events-north-jersey/96564526/"], ["text", "Martin Luther King Jr. events in North Jersey\nPrayer services, marches, will be among events to celebrate MLK weekend of January 14-16, 2017\nPost to Facebook\nMartin Luther King Jr. events in North Jersey Prayer services, marches, will be among events to celebrate MLK weekend of January 14-16, 2017 Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2iv7tYp\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nMartin Luther King Jr. events in North Jersey\nMonsy Alvarado , Staff Writer, @MonsyAlvarado Published 2:56 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017 | Updated 23 hours ago\nThe Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.\n(Photo: .FILE PHOTO)\nOn Monday, the nation will mark the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.'s 88th birthday with discussions,\u00a0prayer services and marches.\u00a0Following are some events scheduled in\u00a0North Jersey to celebrate the life and legacy of the slain civil rights leader:\nSunday Jan. 15, 2017\nMontclair\n11 a.m.: A Martin Luther King Day Jr. Service and Celebration at the Union Baptist Church of Montclair, 12-14 Midland Avenue.\n1 p.m. to 4 p.m.:\u00a0Eyewitness to History: The African-American Experience. Crane House and Historic YWCA, 110 Orange Road.Two-hundred years of black history in Montclair and New Jersey can be explored in the exhibit.\nMonday January 16, 2017\nEnglewood\n9 a.m.: The city\u2019s 47th annual Martin Luther King Jr. Day march followed by church service. The march starts at the steps of City Hall and then\u00a0participants will walk to Ebenezer Baptist Church at 214 4th St. The church program starts at 10 a.m.\nRidgewood\n10 a.m.: \u201cTogether in Hope\u201d an interfaith service at the Ridgewood Methodist Church, 100 Dayton St.. Followed by an 11:30 a.m.\u00a0rally in Van Neste Park.\nPaterson\n10 a.m.:\u00a0Annual Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Day Program at the Canaan Baptist Church, 535 East 22nd St. Guest preacher Rev. Steven Eugene Carter, pastor at the Mount Ararat Baptist Church, Brooklyn New York.\nHackensack\n12 p.m.: Martin Luther King Jr. Day of Service Celebration by the Fellowship of Black Churches Hackensack & Vicinity. The service will be held at Mount Olive Baptist Church, 260 Central Ave. Guest Speaker Dr. Lance Watson, pastor of St. Paul\u2019s Baptist Church, Richmond, Virginia.\nBloomfield\n4 p.m.: The township will hold its 15th annual MLK Holiday Observance program entitled \u201cWhere do we go from here\u2026Chaos or Community?\u201d at the New Light Baptist Church, 89-91 Dewey St. Keynote speaker Dr. Annie Ellis Williams, a professor of Women\u2019s and Gender studies at New Jersey City University.\nTeaneck\n6:30 p.m. to 8:30 p.m.: \u00a0Tara Dowdell of MSNBC, and Fox 5 News will be speaker at the 88th birthday celebration to honor King at St. Anastasia Church of Teaneck. \u00a0Anthony Johnson, of Channel 7 Eyewitness News will be moderator. The event was organized by the Bergen County Martin Luther King Jr. Birthday Committee.\n52 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2iv7tYp\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1100.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/what-the-world-learned-this-year_us_581cbe28e4b0e80b02c980ab"], ["text", "Here's What We Learned During This Miserable, Endless Election Year\nLesson one: Things can always get worse.\n11/07/2016 06:46 am ET | Updated Nov 07, 2016\n840\nHoward Fineman Global Editorial Director, The Huffington Post\nJason Linkins Eat The Press Editor, The Huffington Post\nLauren Weber The Morning Email Editor, The Huffington Post\nThe Huffington Post\nRemember Jeb Bush? You know, he was the guy, with the... thing?\u00a0And our dear friend Martin O\u2019 Malley! He held an event in Iowa in a blizzard. One guy showed up \u2015 and he\u00a0 wasn\u2019t really feeling it , as it turned out.\nSo much has happened since we launched First To Last in January 2015. American politics as we understood it seems to have fallen apart. Jeb Bush folded like a Hoberman sphere ; Donald Trump stepped out from a puff of brimstone to sell America a monorail . Hillary Clinton , like The Dude in \u201cThe Big Lebowski,\u201d abides.\nWe\u2019ve seen Bernie Sanders \u2015 who maybe didn\u2019t think he was going to be in this race too long \u2015 hang on through the entire primary, and influence the Democratic Party . We learned, the hard way, that winners don\u2019t finish third. (Sorry, Marco Rubio .) And somehow, Wikileaks has gone from plumbing the secrets of the Deep State to being as obsessed with dumb campaign minutiae and horse-race politics as the establishment media it rebelled against. Who knew Julian Assange was destined to become Woke Mark Halperin? Seems a disappointment.\nSeriously, what have we learned? Here are our Dirty Dozen takeaways. No time to be clever, people, the apocalypse is nigh. (Hey, that\u2019s also Trump\u2019s pitch to America!)\nRANK\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1101.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-tv-schedule-why-not_us_58136bdae4b0990edc30a33e"], ["text", "Trump TV Is Gonna Be Yugely Big League, Etc.\nEspecially with this killer programming lineup!\n10/31/2016 06:43 am ET | Updated Jan 03, 2017\n690\nHoward Fineman Global Editorial Director, The Huffington Post\nJason Linkins Eat The Press Editor, The Huffington Post\nLauren Weber The Morning Email Editor, The Huffington Post\nThe Huffington Post\nLet\u2019s be honest: You know you\u2019d be curious about Trump TV \u2015 the presumed fallback venture for GOP candidate Donald Trump if he loses the election . We certainly would be. Trump, a car crash that learned how to walk and wear suits, is addicted to attention, and the media is addicted to giving him attention. None of that will change if he loses to Hillary Clinton . Trump himself said this week that he has \u201c no interest in Trump TV ,\u201d but Trump says a lot of things, so it\u2019s worth at least speculating about what the network would look like.\nThe enterprise would definitely have potential, at least for the Trump base and America\u2019s most committed hate-watchers. As a streaming and cable TV star, Trump would be second to none. He\u2019d be capable of gobbling the Kardashians\u2019 lunch, dinner and the next day\u2019s elevenses . How could he not? As the poet Patricia Lockwood has said, Trump is \u201c human meth \u201d \u2015 a singularly galvanizing and destructive blend of Triumph the Insult Comic Dog, Beavis and Butt-Head, Michael Moore, Alex Jones, George Wallace, Benito Mussolini and Vince the ShamWow Guy.\nAnd if you think about it, he\u2019s made it this far based on little more than a skill set gleaned from years in the reality-teevee trenches and a lifelong fascination with television. So it really could work.\nBut even Donald Trump can\u2019t be on the air all the time \u2015 not even on his own network. He\u2019d need a programming schedule of shows, just like on any other channel. And so on this week\u2019s First To Last, we\u2019ve put one together. The only thing we really can\u2019t account for is whether Vladimir Putin would be a contributor or a competitor. (Both, probably.)\nRANK\nTV SHOW\nPhotos: Getty, Associated Press\nEditor\u2019s note: Donald Trump regularly incites political violence and is a serial liar , rampant xenophobe , racist , misogynist and birther who has repeatedly pledged to ban all Muslims \u2014 1.6 billion members of an entire religion \u2014 from entering the U.S.\nMore:\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1102.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/first-to-last-senate-party-control_us_580a5589e4b02444efa32374"], ["text", "And Now For Something Refreshingly Normal: Which Party Will Control The Senate?\nBecause who wants to read more about the presidential race right now anyways.\n10/24/2016 06:50 am ET | Updated Oct 24, 2016\n620\nJason Linkins Eat The Press Editor, The Huffington Post\nLauren Weber The Morning Email Editor, The Huffington Post\nHoward Fineman Global Editorial Director, The Huffington Post\nThe Huffington Post\nOne of the most amazing things about this election cycle has been watching the gaudy spectacle of the presidential race absorb all of the media\u2019s oxygen and resolve, leaving little energy left to focus on the many other races that will be decided on election night. That\u2019s right! There are Senate races galore. Even House races. Probably some ballot initiatives, too. It\u2019s not all Donald Trump versus Hillary Clinton in the Terrordome of American politics.\nAnd to be honest, we\u2019re missing out whenever our attention strays too far from the down ticket battles. The competition looks to be tight \u2015 many of our august political augurs are looking at a potentially split Senate, with our mostly forgotten vice presidential candidates potentially looming as long-term tie-breakers and deal makers (as president of the Senate, the vice president can be called on to cast votes in a deadlock).\nNot to mention the fact that in the U.S.\u00a0Senate, 51 votes is often not enough. Trump and Clinton may have designs on and desires for the Supreme Court \u2015 but neither of them is good enough to necessarily avoid dying at the hands of the Senate filibuster.\nRight now, Democrats are telling their contributors and voters that they had better step up now because come 2018, they have a raft of people up for re-election, and are going to be very exposed. And let\u2019s remember our history: Should Hillary win, she\u2019ll face a problem that continually bedevils the party holding the White House \u2015 in their first midterm election, their legislators tend to get creamed.\nSo the stakes are high. But there\u2019s something else that you can only find when you start glancing at the down ticket races \u2015 blessed normalcy. The arguments over issues, the wrangling of party machers, even all the Beltway-centric cocktail party chatter as to whether the relatively quiet Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R) will continue to preside over the upper house, or if Congress\u2019 most loquacious microphone fiend, Chuck Schumer, takes over \u2015 it all feels like a serene reminder of the time before rejected horseman of the apocalypse Trump turned American politics into a deranged arrangement.\nWe never thought that we\u2019d find a soothing tonic in a battle between Evan Bayh and Todd Young over an Indiana Senate seat, but here we are. And on this week\u2019s first to last, we revisit the barnburner Senate match-ups that could end up shaping our near future.\nFLORIDA: MARCO RUBIO (R, incumbent) vs. PATRICK MURPHY (D)\nThis could be the surprise of election night, with most polls\u00a0saying it\u2019s at a dead heat . Rubio has still refused to unendorse Trump ( why, we don\u2019t know ), and Murphy is holding strong, despite the fact that national Democrats have pulled their resources out of the race . Murphy is a somewhat damaged candidate \u2015 early on in the race the Rubio camp made hay over several significant examples of resume inflation . But the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee\u2019s decision to leave Murphy to his own devices has some people puzzled .\nNEW HAMPSHIRE: KELLY AYOTTE (R, incumbent) vs. MAGGIE HASSAN (D)\nThings are looking grim for Ayotte in the latest WaPo poll , which has her down 8 points. Ayotte\u2019s whole Trump is-or-isn\u2019t a role model thing right before the leaked tape probably didn\u2019t help. The Boston Globe has pointed out\u00a0that New Hampshire tends to vote for\u00a0 Democratic senators during presidential election years , a trend to which the state seems to be reverting.\nPENNSYLVANIA: PAT TOOMEY (R, incumbent) vs. KATIE McGINTY (D)\nTrumpians thought they had a chance in Pa., what with all that Deer Hunter country. He\u2019s probably going to lose, but moderate Republicans who feel guilty voting for Clinton could split their tickets and save Toomey.\nINDIANA: EVAN BAYH (D) vs. TODD YOUNG\nMiddle-of-the-road Evan Bayh wanted it both ways: he works as a lobbyist in D.C. and then returns home to run as an outsider. But the Chamber of Commerce , with which he once worked, has made him its number-one target. To the dismay of liberals, Bayh kept $10 million from his PAC in 2008 rather than give it to the Democratic Party. He\u2019s now spent it all, but could still lose to sharp young conservative Rep. Young.\nILLINOIS: MARK KIRK (R, incumbent) vs. TAMMY DUCKWORTH (D)\nDuckworth is killing the fundraising game, outraising Kirk 3-to-1 over the summer . Will all those ad buys pay off? She leads in the polls but savvy Illinois Democrats worry that Kirk has a way of surviving by shuckin\u2019 and jivin.\u2019 He plays \u201cmoderate\u201d with the best of them.\nMISSOURI: ROY BLUNT (R, incumbent) vs. JASON KANDER (D)\nIn the last two weeks according to Nate Silver, the chances that upstart Kander ends up taking this election from Sen. Blunt has risen over 22 points. 22 POINTS . Blunt is suffering from both edges of the Trump effect \u2015 an outsider new to politics is running against him (he\u2019s just a democrat) and Trump is imploding. Plus, one of the most genius ads of the election cycle hasn\u2019t hurt Kander\u2019s rise either. And Sen. Al Franken, a leader in the Dems take-back-the-Senate drive, has been touting presciently Kander for a year.\nWISCONSIN: RON JOHNSON (R, incumbent) vs. RUSS FEINGOLD (D)\nAnother former senator trying a comeback, Feingold is a better bet than Bayh. It\u2019s another state the Trump forces targeted, but Feingold has more than enough anti-establishment juice to survive, or even thrive, in this era. He could also be a next-generation Bernie in 2020 if he wins.\nNEVADA: JOE HECK (R) vs. CATHERINE CORTEZ MASTO (D)\nThis is a race to replace the irreplaceable, irrepressible, inimitable and \u2015 to his many detractors \u2015 annoying Harry Reid. With its right wing casino crowd and mass of Hispanic voters, Nevada is on the fault line of politics. If Hispanic turnout gives Hillary Clinton a victory, it could sweep in Cortez Masto, too.\nNORTH CAROLINA: RICHARD BURR (R, incumbent) vs. DEBORAH ROSS (D)\nIn North Carolina, incumbent Sen. Richard Burr is holding off his Democratic challenger \u2015 but perhaps only just. In a familiar story, Burr\u2019s prospects are being weighed down by his party\u2019s presidential standardbearer. As a recent NPR report details , whether or not you disavow or embrace Trump has a distinctive damned-if-you-do-or-don\u2019t flavor. Trump\u2019s flame-out has helped Ross add to her campaign coffers, but the word is that Burr has enough cash on hand to last out the cycle.\nMore:\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1103.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/why-hillary-clinton-lost_us_57dc4bece4b04a1497b491b6"], ["text", "Why Hillary Lost: A Premature Obit\nThe blame game has already begun. Here's where Democrats will point the finger if she loses.\n09/19/2016 06:05 am ET | Updated Sep 20, 2016\n9.4k\nHoward Fineman Global Editorial Director, The Huffington Post\nJason Linkins Eat The Press Editor, The Huffington Post\nLauren Weber The Morning Email Editor, The Huffington Post\nThe Huffington Post\nOn the high, crenelated ramparts of Castle Clinton, a chill breeze is stirring \u2015 a faint but gnawing sense that the White Walkers are coming, wearing \u201cMAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN\u201d baseball caps on their skinless noggins.\nIf Donald Trump does sack the fortress, no one who lost the battle will want to admit it was Hillary Clinton \u2019s fault. It will have had nothing to do with, say, \u201ctransparency\u201d or calling bearded villagers \u201cdeplorables\u201d or the Iraq War vote or the simple fact that middle-of-the-road Clintonism ran out of gas as a public philosophy.\nNo, other individuals, groups and forces will have to be blamed.
