[["name", "new_7/1104.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/world/2017/01/15/what-happens-between-now-and-may-circus/96609252/"], ["text", "What happens between now and May for circus?\nWhat happens between now and Ringling's closure in May?\u00a0\nPost to Facebook\nWhat happens between now and May for circus? What happens between now and Ringling's closure in May?\u00a0 Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jKRCmp\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nWhat happens between now and May for circus?\nTAMARA LUSH, Associated Press Published 12:22 a.m. ET Jan. 15, 2017 | Updated 1:38 a.m. ET Jan. 15, 2017\nA Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey clown takes a selfie with Jennifer and Kevin Fox, of Fort Pierce, Fla., during a pre show for fans Saturday, Jan. 14, 2017, in Orlando, Fla. The Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus will end the \"The Greatest Show on Earth\" in May, following a 146-year run of performances.\n(Photo: Chris O'Meara, AP)\nELLENTON, Fla. \u2014 The owners of\u00a0Ringling\u00a0Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus announced Saturday that they will close the 146-year-old show in May.\nKenneth Feld, the chairman and CEO of Feld Entertainment, which owns the circus, said declining attendance combined with high operating costs are the reasons for closing.\nHere's where things stand with the iconic show:\nWHEN IS THE CIRCUS' FINAL SHOW?\nRingling\u00a0Bros. has two touring circuses this season: \"Circus Extreme\" and \"Out of This World.\" The final show for \"Circus Extreme\" will be in Providence, Rhode Island, on May 7, and the other will close after a performance in Uniondale, New York, at the Nassau County Coliseum on May 21.\n___\nWHAT HAPPENS BETWEEN NOW AND MAY?\nThe two touring circuses will perform a total of 30 shows over the next four months. Most of the shows will be held in the South or the East Coast. Major stops include Atlanta, Washington, Philadelphia, Boston and Brooklyn. Tickets can still be purchased online and at venues.\n___\nWHAT WILL HAPPEN TO THE EMPLOYEES?\nThe Feld family has owned the circus for 49 years, and employs some 500 people for the show. Those employees were told about the closure on Saturday night, after shows in Orlando and Miami. A handful will be placed in positions with the company's other shows \u2014 it owns Monster Jam, Disney on Ice and Marvel Live, among other things \u2014 but most will be out of a job. Chief Operating Officer Juliette Feld said the company will help employees with job placement and resumes. In some cases where a circus employee lives on the tour rail car (the circus travels by train), the company will also help with housing relocation.\n___\nWHAT WILL HAPPEN TO THE ANIMALS?\nIn May of 2016,\u00a0Ringling\u00a0retired all of its elephants to a property in central Florida. Forty elephants live at the Center for Elephant Conservation in Polk County. But the circus still has other animals, such as lions, tigers, camels, donkeys, alpacas, kangaroos and llamas.\nJuliette Feld says homes will be found for the animals, but the company will continue operating the Center for Elephant Conservation.\n___\nWHAT WILL HAPPEN TO THE COSTUMES AND PROPS?\nThe Feld family hasn't decided what it will do with the enormous warehouse filled with circus costumes and props. Kenneth Feld says the company will continue to work with the Circus Museum at The\u00a0Ringling\u00a0in Sarasota. That museum holds memorabilia dating to the 1800s, when John\u00a0Ringling\u00a0and his family founded\u00a0Ringling\u00a0Bros and Barnum and Bailey Circus.\nIn this March 27, 1955 file photo, a policeman calmly directs a parade of elephants across the busy intersection of Fifth Avenue and 57th Street in New York. The parade heralds the arrival of the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus for the season.\n\u00a0(Photo: Jacob Harris/AP file photo)\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1106.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/twelve-fascinating-house-races-to-watch-in-2016_us_57d31114e4b00642712d8153"], ["text", "12 Fascinating House Races To Watch In 2016\nThere\u2019s more going on than just Clinton vs. Trump.\n09/12/2016 06:46 am ET | Updated Sep 12, 2016\n250\nJason Linkins Eat The Press Editor, The Huffington Post\nLauren Weber The Morning Email Editor, The Huffington Post\nHoward Fineman Global Editorial Director, The Huffington Post\nThe Huffington Post\nWith less than two months to go before America faces its judgment day on Nov. 8, it seems a fitting time to remind everybody that there is more to this election cycle than just the ongoing battle between the two presidential candidates. There are actually hundreds of races happening, including many for this thing called \u201cThe House Of Representatives.\u201d You remember those folks, right? Well, they\u2019re all up for re-election as well.\nThere are a lot of things that we can\u2019t say about the House races. One thing we can\u2019t say is that there are big changes afoot \u2015 despite the fact that Congress\u2019 approval rating eternally hovers between \u201cgallbladder infection\u201d and \u201cplague of frogs,\u201d incumbent members enjoy a staggeringly high rate of re-election (because it\u2019s always some other person\u2019s congressional representative cocking things up). We can\u2019t use the term \u201cbarnburner\u201d to describe many of these races because we\u2019ve only got scant polling data to examine.\nStill, these races matter, and many of them are fascinating in their own right. There are fresh faces, enduring rivalries and big money. In some cases, there are interesting changes in the political landscape. In others, there are old figures reaching for one last shot in politics. And there\u2019s always the possibility that the House somehow flips control from the GOP to the Democrats , right? Actually, probably not.\nLook at it this way: These races are going to happen one way or another. On this week\u2019s First To Last, we\u2019ll share the House races that fascinate us the most.\nRANK\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1108.html"], ["url", "http://www.bergencounty.com/family/sharing-the-arts-together-performing-arts-club-for-special-needs-children-helps-them-shine-on-stage-1.1647873"], ["text", "Courtesy of Sharing the Arts buy or license this photo\nLiz Matejka-Grossman and Kathy Sheehy met back in 2005. They each have a daughter with special needs, and both moms wanted \u201ca true ballet experience for the girls, one that was also in a forgiving environment,\u201d Sheehy says.\nMatejka-Grossman, a former professional ballerina, joined with Sheehy and started a ballet class in her living room. The program was much needed so it kept expanding. The end result is Sharing the Arts (sharingthearts.com).\nAccording to the website, its mission \u201cis to enhance the lives of individuals with special needs through the performing arts. Classes are led by teachers with support staff to provide redirection and assistance. Pre-teen through college-age volunteers serve as assistants, demonstrators, mentors, as well as friends in the class.\u201dThe programs offered include preballet/ jazz, hip-hop, vocal, acting and musical theater. Saturday classes are run through the Ridgewood Community School, and volunteers come from all over, including Ramapo High School, Indian Hills High School, Immaculate Heart Academy, Ridgewood High School and Glen Rock High School.\nMatejka-Grossman emphasizes the importance of having peer role models. One excellent example of this is the Sharing the Arts clubs that have arisen at area high schools, including Ridgewood, Glen Rock and Glen Ridge.\nAt Ridgewood High School, the special needs participants come from all over, including New York City and the Delaware Water Gap, while the volunteers are Ridgewood High School students.\n\u201cThe musical productions allow the kids to have a typical experience and find common ground with volunteers. Everyone can come together,\u201d Matejka- Grossman says. \u201cIt has definitely changed the lives of the kids. It is also great for volunteers. Some of them have gone on to medical school or to become teachers in special education.\u201d\nSheehy emphasizes that \u201cit is the real collaboration between students, volunteers and staff at the high school that make it all work. It is very grassroots. A lot of people help along the way, and it is a labor of love.\u201d\nJennifer Landa, a faculty adviser for the Sharing the Arts club at Ridgewood High School, is very enthusiastic about the program, which is exceptionally popular among the students. The club \u2013 usually consisting of 30 volunteers or more \u2013 started approximately five years ago. The students in that program were already learning to work with younger kids, and this was a natural extension of that.\n\u201cThe volunteers pick a show, edit a junior version, assign roles, choreograph, stage scenes, and make sure everyone has a chance to shine,\u201d Landa says. \u201cThey mount a full production with costumes, lights, microphones, and they do an amazing job. Each participant has a partner, and this is probably the coolest part of the whole thing. It is wonderful to see the volunteers develop a strong bond with the participants.\u201d\nLanda notes that a few students who were participants have grown up and are now in high school and have become volunteers themselves. The show is always done right before Thanksgiving, and it has turned into a huge homecoming of alumni volunteers.\n\u201cGraduates come to the show, sometimes even before they come home,\u201d Sheehy says. \u201cVolunteers have been shaped by the experience, whether it is deciding to follow a certain course of study in college or just learning to think more broadly.\u201d\nFor her part, Landa acknowledges that the program has really changed her life. \u201cThese kids are amazing \u2013 how rich their lives are, and I\u2019ve realized how much we need to listen to them,\u201d she says.\nIn the spring, the Sharing the Arts club at Ridgewood High School also does a four-week workshop.\nMatejka-Grossman describes the Sharing the Arts club as \u201can all-inclusive theater production.\u201d And that does seem to be the best way to describe it. Everyone is included. Everyone has a chance to shine.\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1110.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-hillary-clinton-debate_us_57c9b1a3e4b078581f12d834"], ["text", "How To Beat Donald Trump In A Debate\nA few ideas Hillary Clinton could put to good use this fall.\n09/05/2016 06:00 am ET | Updated Sep 05, 2016\n5k\nHoward Fineman Global Editorial Director, The Huffington Post\nJason Linkins Eat The Press Editor, The Huffington Post\nLauren Weber The Morning Email Editor, The Huffington Post\nThe Huffington Post\nSurely there are worse tasks than debating Donald Trump. It\u2019s just hard to imagine what they are. As an expert in heavy lifts \u2015 try having Bill Clinton as a husband \u2015 Hillary Rodham Clinton has no peer in politics. But even she is going to have her hands full in the three-debate series scheduled to begin on Sept. 26.\nTrump\u2019s only debate \u201closs\u201d in the Republican nominating race came in the one debate he didn\u2019t attend. (He was pummeled for not showing up.) In the rest, he was the giant tangerine bowling ball knocking over hapless pins, collecting the spare by taking out the 10 pin on the far right named Ted Cruz.\nSo far, only in a court of law \u2015 under threat of prosecution for perjury \u2015 has Trump ever played by the higher rules of human discourse and told the truth, however reluctantly. The rest of the time,\u00a0he says what he wants, attacks at will, disregards decorum and regards honesty as the currency of wimps.\nHow do you attack Trump and, just as important, defend yourself? Here, based on covering and kibitzing about presidential debates for lo these many years, is our First to Last cheat sheet.\nRANK\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1112.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/stages-of-a-trump-statement_us_57ae1c7be4b069e7e5053ea1"], ["text", "The 9 Stages Of A Trump Statement\nIt takes time to drain what you say of any meaning.\n08/15/2016 06:50 am ET | Updated Aug 15, 2016\n5.3k\nHoward Fineman Global Editorial Director, The Huffington Post\nJason Linkins Eat The Press Editor, The Huffington Post\nLauren Weber The Morning Email Editor, The Huffington Post\nThe Huffington Post\nWe deal with a lot of tough things in life\u00a0\u2015\u00a0grief and various addictions, among other things \u2015 in stages. The same is true when Donald Trump makes one of his patented inflammatory, fantastical or threatening statements.\nAfter one of these remarks, the bilious billionaire, his aides and the Republican Party run through a series of syntactical and spin-doctoring steps in a Houdini-like effort to escape the submerged steamer trunk into which he had locked himself (and them).\u00a0\nAt the end of the process, most fair-minded observers conclude that Trump never really escapes, and that he is running out of oxygen somewhere in the deep waters off the coast of American politics.\nBut not Trump! With powers of self-delusion far beyond those of mortal men and strategy from his own The Art of the Deal, he views his utterances as merely the opening bid in a never-ending negotiation over meaning. And the meaning is what he says it is, or isn\u2019t, or may be, or what you want to hear, or don\u2019t to hear.\nAnd for The Donald, any publicity is good publicity, and any accusation \u2015 no matter how outrageous or phony \u2015 sticks. \u00a0\nYou\u2019d think that this method \u2015 the destruction of the meaning of meaning \u2015 could not\u00a0work. Americans are sensible, clear-eyed people, right? Surely they see his rhetoric for what it is: a verbal three-card Monte game in hell.\u00a0\nSo it won\u2019t work, right? Right?\nRANK\nSTEP\nPhotos: Getty, Associated Press\nEditor\u2019s note: Donald Trump regularly incites political violence and is a serial liar ,\u00a0 rampant xenophobe , racist , misogynist and birther who has repeatedly pledged to ban all Muslims \u2015 1.6 billion members of an entire religion \u2015 from entering the U.S.\nMore:\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1114.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-pence-awkward_us_57893b54e4b03fc3ee50d780"], ["text", "8 Ways Trump And Pence Could Be A Really Awkward Pairing\nDid Trump vet this guy?\n07/18/2016 06:25 am ET | Updated Jul 18, 2016\n500\nJason Linkins Eat The Press Editor, The Huffington Post\nLauren Weber The Morning Email Editor, The Huffington Post\nHoward Fineman Global Editorial Director, The Huffington Post\nThe Huffington Post\nIn the immediate wake of Donald Trump choosing Indiana Gov. Mike Pence (R) as his running mate, the consensus that quickly congealed among the political commentariat was that Trump had finally done something boring and conventional. Hashtag sad!\nWell. First of all,\u00a0political reporters should probably not always be asking politicians to provide them with entertainment \u2015 that whole \u201cMay you live in interesting times\u201d thing is supposed to be a curse, remember?\nBut more importantly, a Trump-Pence pairing could actually be quite exciting, because it turns out that the two men, in terms of policy, have some pretty big disagreements. We\u2019re talking about\u00a0core\u00a0differences, with the governor\u2019s record diverging from what Trump has verbalized in the past year in numerous, non-trivial ways.\u00a0\nThat\u2019s not to say there was an easier choice Trump could have made. If he was looking for a sturdy, establishment type to serve as a helpmate, it was inevitable that he\u2019d end up paired with someone who didn\u2019t share a lot of his views. But Pence is still an odd pick, all things considered. Chris Christie\u2019s rambunctious sycophancy might have smoothed over any of the differences he and Trump had during the primaries. And while Newt Gingrich\u2019s positions sometimes clashed with Trump\u2019s, the former speaker\u2019s penchant for silver-tongued glibness might have helped him artfully flip-flop around those deviations.\nIt makes you wonder \u2015 was Trump even aware of Pence\u2019s policy preferences as he staged his low-key \u201cApprentice\u201d act to determine his campaign partner? According to CNN\u2019s Dana Bash, maybe not:\u00a0\nScoop: @realDonaldTrump was so unsure about @mike_pence that around midnight last night he asked top aides if he could get out of it\n\u2014 Dana Bash (@DanaBashCNN) July 15, 2016\nHoo, boy! Well, they\u2019re stuck with each other now. On this week\u2019s First To Last, we\u2019ll run down the top policy arguments these new awkward bedfellows are going to have to hash out in the next few days.\nRANK\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1116.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/world/2017/01/15/animal-rights-groups-applaud-ringling-bros-closing/96609448/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nAnimal rights groups applaud Ringling Bros. closing\nAnimal rights groups wasted no time in weighing in on the announcement that the Ringling Bros. and Barnum and Bailey Circus is closing.\nPost to Facebook\nAnimal rights groups applaud Ringling Bros. closing Animal rights groups wasted no time in weighing in on the announcement that the Ringling Bros. and Barnum and Bailey Circus is closing. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jKLMRK\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nAnimal rights groups applaud Ringling Bros. closing\nNorthJersey 12:34 a.m. ET Jan. 15, 2017\nIn this May 1, 2016 file photo, Asian elephants perform for the final time in the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus in Providence, R.I. The Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus will end \"The Greatest Show on Earth\" in May 2017, following a 146-year run. Declining attendance combined with high operating costs, along with changing public tastes and prolonged battles with animal rights groups all contributed to its demise.\n(Photo: Bill Sikes, AP file photo)\nELLENTON, Fla. \u00a0\u2014 Animal rights groups wasted no time in weighing in on the announcement that the\u00a0Ringling\u00a0Bros. and Barnum and Bailey Circus is closing in May.\nIn a statement sent Saturday night, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals said it \"heralds the end of what has been the saddest show on earth for wild animals, and asks all other animal circuses to follow suit, as this is a sign of changing times.\"\nPETA and other groups have long opposed the circus and its performing animals.\nWayne Pacelle, the president and CEO of the Humane Society of the United States, said the circus has changed \"a great deal over a century and a half, but not fast enough ... I know this is bittersweet for the Feld family, but I applaud their decision to move away from an institution grounded on inherently inhumane wild animal acts.\"\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jKLMRK\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1123.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/new-jersey/2017/01/14/protest-paramus-mall-pushes-15-minimum-wage/96408008/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nProtest at Paramus mall pushes for $15 minimum wage\nActivists staged a rally at the entrance to Westfield Garden State Plaza in support of the $15 minimum wage\nPost to Facebook\nProtest at Paramus mall pushes for $15 minimum wage Activists staged a rally at the entrance to Westfield Garden State Plaza in support of the $15 minimum wage Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2ixoSQi\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n9\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nProtest at Paramus mall pushes for $15 minimum wage\nJoan Verdon , Staff Writer, @JoanVerdon Published 5:41 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017 | Updated 6:36 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nThe protesters stood in snow and freezing temperatures for over an hour to raise awareness of the fight for a $15 minimum wage in New Jersey.\nKevin Ha of Norwood was one of the activists rallying on Saturday at the Westfield Garden State Plaza. Protesters were demanding a $15-per-hour minimum wage.\n(Photo: Viorel Florescu/NorthJersey.com)\nStory Highlights\nNew Jersey's minimum wage is $8.44\nA group of activists stood in snow and freezing temperatures at the entrance to New Jersey\u2019s largest mall Saturday afternoon to draw attention to the hottest issue facing the retail industry, low-income workers\u00a0and state lawmakers \u2013 the fight for a\u00a0$15 minimum wage.\nThree dozen protesters from a coalition of groups held banners and signs, sang songs, chanted slogans, listened to speeches, waved to passing cars, and even engaged in political discourse with motorists on a street corner at the southwest entrance to Westfield Garden State Plaza in Paramus.\n\u201cWhy aren\u2019t you working? Go to work,\u201d yelled a woman who rolled down her window while the car she was a passenger in was parked at the light at the intersection of Passaic Street and the Garden State Parkway exit ramp.\n\u201cIt\u2019s Saturday,\u201d responded one protester. \u201cWe do work,\u201d yelled another. \u201cAnd we want a living wage.\u201d\nPump your own gas? Many willing if it means $15 minimum wage\nSigns of support\nMost of the drivers heading to the mall on Saturday, however, demonstrated support for the rally,\u00a0honking to show solidarity and giving protesters the thumbs-up sign.\nOrganizers said they staged the protest to keep pressure on the state\u2019s lawmakers to either get\u00a0a $15 minimum wage question on the ballot\u00a0or to pass legislation that could be signed into law by Gov. Chris Christie\u2019s successor.\nIn August, Christie vetoed legislation that gradually would have raised New Jersey's minimum wage to $15 an hour by 2021. That bill, if signed by the governor, would have made New Jersey the third state in the country, after California and New York, to raise the hourly wage to $15. The current minimum wage in New Jersey is $8.44 an hour.\nThe state's Democratic lawmakers have made raising the minimum wage a key part of their legislative agenda for the past four years but have been met by strong opposition from\u00a0Christie. Democrats now are expected to wait until after the gubernatorial election in November to pass minimum wage legislation\u00a0in the hopes that a Democrat will be elected to succeed\u00a0Christie.\nActivists outside the state's largest mall, Westfield Garden State Plaza in Paramus, demanding an increase in the minimum wage.\n\u00a0(Photo: Viorel Florescu/NorthJersey.com)\nRetail opposition\nRetail organizations are strongly opposed to the $15-an-hour campaign, saying it raises wages too much, too quickly.\n\u201cWe\u2019re more than willing to have a discussion about increasing the minimum wage,\u201d said John Holub, president of the New Jersey Retail Merchants Association, but \"it has to be a reasonable amount, phased in over a period of time.\"\nRetailers\u00a0operate on \"incredibly small margins,\" Holub said, and can't absorb dramatic cost increases, especially at a time when they are struggling with weak spending and online competition. \"We're still continuing to scratch and claw our way out of the recession,\" he said\nThe protest was\u00a0organized by the group 15NowNJ\u00a0and co-sponsored by the Socialist Alternative, Green Party of New Jersey, New Jersey Democratic Socialists of America, Black Lives Matter Paterson and Red Party of New Jersey organizations.\nDebra Lamego, 36, a Kearny resident who works as a sales associate at the mall, was among the protesters Saturday. Lamego, who makes $9.99 an hour, did not want to say at which store she works because it could jeopardize her employment. She said most retail workers support the $15 wage campaign but \u201care afraid to speak up because they fear for their jobs.\u201d\n\u201cI feel that we have to continuously remind people that this issue isn\u2019t going to go away,\u201d she said.\u00a0\u201cIf we keep at it, and keep pressuring our local officials, we can make the changes we need.\u201d\nMore protests planned\nBrian Powers of 15NowNJ said the mall location was chosen for the protest, because, like past protest sites, it is a place \"where a lot of people are working for under minimum wage.\" He said the group plans to hold \u00a0more protests throughout the year and will have an organizing meeting next month in New Brunswick.\nPowers said two of the leading Democratic contenders for governor, Phil Murphy and John Wisniewski, have committed to signing minimum wage legislation if elected.\n\u201cIf we can push the Legislature to pass the bill once we have a new governor, we can anticipate the new governor signing it,\"\u00a0Powers said.\nProtest leaders said they are confident that there is widespread support for a $15 minimum wage in New Jersey. Ed Fanning, chairman of the Bergen County Green Party, said New Jerseyans are very willing to sign petitions for minimum wage increases compared to other issues. \"Most people you ask \u2013 complete strangers on the streets \u2013 are very willing to sign to support it,\" he said.\n768 CONNECT TWEET 5 LINKEDIN 9 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2ixoSQi\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1145.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-republican-national-convention_us_57642e3ce4b0fbbc8bea3826"], ["text", "All The Folks Who Would Need To Come Together To Stop Trump At The Convention\nIt would take a village to pull off the heist.\n06/20/2016 06:44 am ET | Updated Jun 20, 2016\n980\nJason Linkins Eat The Press Editor, The Huffington Post\nLauren Weber The Morning Email Editor, The Huffington Post\nHoward Fineman Global Editorial Director, The Huffington Post\nThe Huffington Post\nAs more and more Republican elites come to the realization that they\u2019re stuck with Donald Trump -- a rabid Teddy Ruxpin doll with Skrewdriver\u2019s debut album wedged inside it -- as their nominee, the dream of blocking his ascension continues to flit about fitfully in their collective subconscious. But the hour of doom draws ever closer, and staging a contested convention at this late date is going to be a difficult stunt to pull off .\nNevertheless, hope springs eternal. And this week, The Washington Post\u2019s Ed O\u2019Keefe reported that the desire to supplant Trump at the convention is now shared by a growing number of convention delegates themselves. As O\u2019Keefe reports, \u201cDozens of Republican convention delegates are hatching a new plan to block Donald Trump at this summer\u2019s party meetings, in what has become the most organized effort so far to stop the businessman from becoming the GOP nominee.\u201d\nTo pull it off, multiple groups of people will have to work in concert. They\u2019ll need to have at least some of the GOP\u2019s elite personages blessing the effort. They\u2019ll also need a candidate of their own. But first things first: On this week\u2019s \"First To Last,\" we cast this caper movie, running down who will have to be part of this high-wire act.\nRANK\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1148.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-campaign-mess_us_575b04e8e4b0e39a28ad83d1"], ["text", "Trump\u2019s Campaign Strategy Is An Off-Track Mess\nLet\u2019s count up all the red flags for Beltway Republicans.\n06/13/2016 10:47 am ET | Updated Jun 13, 2016\n930\nJason Linkins Eat The Press Editor, The Huffington Post\nLauren Weber The Morning Email Editor, The Huffington Post\nThe Huffington Post\nBy the time you read this, presumptive GOP nominee and anthropomorphic zeppelin disaster Donald Trump will be a handful of days into the three-week deadline imposed by Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) to \u201cfix\u201d his campaign, or else ... what, exactly? That\u2019s the thing. There is no \u201cor else.\u201d Unless you believe the GOP can pull off some sort of convention heist , Corker\u2019s demand is a toothless one.\nHere\u2019s the thing: Even if Trump were a soulful, honey-tongued angel of decorum -- heck, even if he weren't the sort of person who thinks that an unfolding national tragedy is an apt time to wrongheadedly gloat -- there would still be a lot to \u201cfix\u201d in such a short time.\nBeyond the too-casual racism, the blanket ignorance of policy and the stunning tone-deafness of his actions,\u00a0 multiple reports out this week paint a clear picture of a campaign \u00a0with\u00a0 insufficient infrastructure \u00a0and\u00a0 strategies for the general election that are -- if we\u2019re being charitable -- dafter than a drunken mallard. On this week\u2019s First To Last, we round up the many ways the Trump organization is bafflingly unready for primetime.\nRANK\nREASON\nPhotos: Getty, Associated Press\nEditor's note: Donald Trump regularly incites political violence and is a serial liar ,\u00a0 rampant xenophobe , racist , misogynist and birther who has repeatedly pledged to ban all Muslims -- 1.6 billion members of an entire religion -- from entering the U.S.\nMore:\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1154.html"], ["url", "http://archive.northjersey.com/news/special-reports/about-the-record-s-coverage-of-christie-and-the-gwb-scandal-1.665326"], ["text", "\u00a9 2017 North Jersey Media Group\nJanuary 9, 2014, 3:45 PM\nLast updated: Friday, February 14, 2014, 3:51 PM\nAbout The Record's coverage of Christie and the GWB scandal\nThe Record\nSince John Cichowski, The Record's Road Warrior columnist, broke the story of the massive traffic tie-ups at the George Washington Bridge last Sept. 13, the story about four days of politically-motivated gridlock on the streets of Fort Lee has morphed into the nation's most compelling political drama, with the popularity and Presidential prospects of New Jersey's magnetic governor, Chris Christie, hanging in the balance.\n\u00a0\nNo one has reported the story more fully than The Record. Last Jan. 8th, the mess at the bridge exploded into a continuing national news event when Shawn Boburg reported exclusively that a top aide to Christie helped plan the closing of two access lanes to the bridge at a time when Fort Lee's Democratic mayor was balking at endorsing the governor for re-election.\n\u00a0\nAnd, as the story went national, no one kept the event more local than The Record, whose Linh Tat revealed-- also on Jan. 8-- that the blocked roads prevented EMS units from responding quickly to calls concerning a missing 4-year-old and a 91-year-old woman suffering from cardiac arrest, who subsequently died in the hospital.\n\u00a0\nFor half a year, the news breaks, front pages and expert analysis by The Record's team of columnists and editorial writers have kept coming, online and in print.\n\u00a0\nPlease follow our coverage present and past through this topic page-- the most complete and dynamic resource anywhere on the biggest political story of the moment.\n\u00a0\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1161.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/2017/01/14/donald-trumps-first-100-days-discussed-montclair-public-library/96404906/"], ["text", "Donald Trump\u2019s first 100 days discussed at Montclair Public Library\nCindy C. A. Pereira, Correspondent 1:21 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nJonathan Alter, Stephen Engelberg and Thomas Johnson took part in a discussion on Donald Trump at the Montclair Public Library.\n(Photo: Photo/Cindy C. A. Pereira)\nDonald Trump\u2019s upcoming first 100 days as president was discussed at the Montclair Public Library as part of their Open Book/Open Mind Series on Jan.\u00a08.\nJonathan Alter, NBC/MSNBC News correspondent and bestselling biographer of Obama and FDR, and Stephen Engelberg, editor-in-chief of ProPublica were in conversation with Thomas Johnson, Executive Editor of Bloomberg Politics.\nThe incoming\u00a0president has expressed opinions about the fate of Obamacare, climate change, wealth inequity and much more. The panel dissected a handful of these topics to an audience that filled the room to capacity.\nNotably, more than once, President Nixon was referenced in making comparisons to the current state of affairs. The Nixon parallel was also an example of the country\u2019s ability to survive and overcome.\nLocals to be present or protest Trump inauguration\nOne of the first topics was Vladimir Putin. Engelberg, whose first beat was the CIA, expressed his feeling toward Trump\u2019s handling and opinion of the CIA, as relates to Russia\u2019s tampering with the recent US election. He said he was feeling dumbfounded.\n\u201cWe have a president that before being elected is telling the intelligence the right answer. From a policy level it\u2019s incomprehensible,\u201d said Engelberg. \"What really upset me was the partisan reaction when we learned this happened\u2026People are willing to put their party ahead of their country.\u201d\nAlter implied that the question of the media\u2019s role both in disseminating non-newsworthy stories around the topic of Hillary Clinton\u2019s emails while the FBI had information on this newsworthy event may have been more decisive in the election.\nOn the question of how ordinary citizens can engage long before the next election, Alter said, \u201cIf you are in New Jersey\u00a0and politically inclined you can join Blue Wave NJ, you can give non-profits like ProPublica money, but everybody needs to enlist to resist\u2026 these are not ordinary times.\u201d\nAlter said objectivity and balance are not number one in journalism. He stated that at the time the press was given protection by the constitution, the constitution was protecting an institution that went for truth and accuracy first and then fairness and balance. He talked about the role of television during the campaign saying, \u201cRatings were so connected to popularity. We are not supposed to be popular.\u201d\nJohnson asked specifically about what actions we should expect in the first 100 days. Engelberg responded by mentioning the complexities of Obamacare. He said, \u201cThe notion this thing can be quickly rewritten on the back of an envelope in the caucus room is absolutely frightening.\u201d\nAfter breaking down the elements of Obamacare that could not be dissolved with any immediacy he did say that some action would need to happen \u201cAfter they made so much of a fuss about repealing Obamacare.\u201d\n\u201cLegislatively it only takes 50 votes to repeal Obamacare but it takes 60 to replace it,\u201d said Alter.\nHe said Republicans would be wary about having the requisite votes to repeal it but insufficient votes to replace it. On that note he added, eliciting laughter, \u201cAs a practical matter they will replace Obamacare with\u2026Obamacare. Very little will change within the next four years.\u201d\nIn searching for more potential changes in the first 100 days, Alter said, \u201cThey will try to reopen negotiations on NAFTA.\u201d He also noted that the Secretary of State is vulnerable as he represents the United States. Alter said that even one Tweet from Trump undermining the Secretary of State would be disastrous.\nEngleberg, when the topic of Trump being instrumental in addressing infrastructure issues came up, commiserated about the state of Penn Station or Laguardia Airport for example. \u201cIt\u2019s scandalous, it\u2019s ridiculous, it\u2019s beneath us, but this has nothing to do with his [Trump\u2019s] notion of tax credits.\u201d He cautioned, \u201cPrivate companies are not going to invest in rebuilding a sewer system.\u201d Engleberg said they would be interested in new infrastructure.\nAlter said Trump was not that ideological and it was entirely possible he would cut a deal with Sen. Chuck Schumer. \u201cThey will try to cut corporate income tax,\u201d he opined.\nEngelberg added, \u201cI do think a reasonably fair tax bill that allows repatriation of billions of dollars offshore\u2026 potentially Trump could pull that off.\u201d\nAlter noted that it had been tried before and ultimately failed saying, \u201cUnless you can figure out a way to keep them in the United States\u2026\u201d\nThe question of whether Democrats would try to block Republicans as the Republicans have done throughout the Obama Administration came up. Alter said, \u201cI think he [Schumer] wants to get things done. He can negotiate with Trump\u2026\u201d\nWithin that context the subject of the Supreme Court nominations up. Previously one senator could put a hold on a nomination of lower courts but the rules have changed. Supreme Court nominations now require a super majority. Alter expressed concern over Justice Ginsberg\u2019s health and longevity and said, \u201cI just hope she stays healthy because two justices would really change things.\u201d\nIn attempting to answer the question of how Trump got elected to begin with, the popular vote being 2.9 million votes in favor of Clinton was mentioned seemingly as an implied argument that it was not a clear win.\nHowever, Alter endeavored to relate a few more concrete reasons why people may have gravitated toward Trump. He listed Trump\u2019s assertion that he loves the poorly educated and suggested Trump may be a poor person\u2019s idea of what a rich person is. Ultimately after telling a personal anecdote about his own mother in politics, Alter added \u201c People will not\u00a0vote for a woman simply because she is a woman.\u201d\nThe issue of fake news was brought up in the context of reaching what Alter called the convincible middle by disseminating relevant and accurate news. He said, \u201cWe are segregating as a country about where we are getting our information.\u201d\nAs for what the average citizen can do in the current political environment, the general audience was encouraged to go out and organize based on their individual interests. \u201cMany organizations are doing plenty of good work,\u201d said Alter, and then he specified Planned Parenthood and environmental groups as some examples.\nAlter also said mobilizing resentment can start in fourth grade. His example was kids labeling Trump\u2019s Tweets as bullying.\nAs for the role of journalists, they were cautioned to stay vigilant and tell stories in a way that holds people accountable.\n1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jJuK6A\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1165.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/essex/2017/01/14/locals-present-protest-trump-inauguration/96263874/"], ["text", "Locals to be present or protest Trump inauguration\nPeople from Montclair and neighboring towns will make their way to the nation's capital next weekend.\nPost to Facebook\nLocals to be present or protest Trump inauguration People from Montclair and neighboring towns will make their way to the nation's capital next weekend. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jIRvHS\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n1\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nLocals to be present or protest Trump inauguration\nRicardo Kaulessar , The Montclair Times Published 9:33 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017 | Updated 12:08 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nPeople from Montclair and neighboring towns who will be making their way to Washington D.C. for presidential inauguration on Friday, Jan. 20, and the Women's March on Washington on Saturday, Jan. 21.\nBloomfield resident Teka Lark-Lo will be attending the Women's March on Washington on Jan. 21.\n(Photo: Image courtesy of Teka Lark-Lo)\nWashington, D.C., will be buzzing with\u00a0activity next weekend.\nThere will be the inauguration of Donald Trump as the 45th president of the United States on Friday, Jan. 20, and the Women's March on Washington on Saturday, Jan. 21.\nSome of the buzz will be coming from people from Montclair and neighboring towns who will be making their way to the nation's capital for one of the two historic events.\nBergen Democrats say transparency will rise despite one-party control\nOne of them is longtime Montclair resident and Republican Eugene Byrne, who told The Montclair Times that he will be attending what he believes is his 7th Republican presidential inauguration dating back to Richard Nixon being sworn in on January 1969.\nByrne said he will be attending with a friend and he looks forward to the opportunity.\n\"We will be celebrating the fact that Hillary Clinton will not be president,\" affirmed Byrne.\nBloomfield resident Teka Lark-Lo, a writer and is the founder of Blk Grrl Book Fair, told The Times that she\u00a0cannot wait to go down to D.C. with her boyfriend for the protest march.\n\"Number one, it is about being part of history and making a difference,\" Lark-Lo said. \"Number two, I hope to gain new friends and new allies.\"\nSeeing the next president\nByrne said he will be going to the inauguration, and\u00a0also one of the inauguration galas that will be held later that evening. He plans to leave from New Jersey by train and arrive there the day before.\nHe said that he has a ticket to stand in an area on the Capitol Grounds.\nByrne said he has enjoyed the experience of being there in-person for the inaugurations, recalling\u00a0Ronald Reagan's\u00a0inauguration in 1981 as his favorite.\n\"That was the one where it was announced that the prisoners were released and there was this a huge cheer,\" Byrne said. He was referring to 52 Americans who had been held hostage in Iran for 444 days, and were released while Reagan was giving his inaugural address.\nAlso planning to attend the inauguration is U.S. Congressman Rodney Frelinghuysen, who represents New Jersey\u2019s 11th Congressional District, which covers 54 municipalities in Essex, Morris, Passaic and Sussex Counties, including the northern part of Montclair.\nFrelinghuysen said in a statement to The Times:\u00a0\u201cI have attended every Presidential inauguration \u2013 Republican and Democrat \u2013 since 1995. \u00a0To be an eyewitness to the orderly transfer of authority under our Constitution is quite an honor.\u201d\nOne person who will not be able to witness the inauguration is Steve Rogers, who serves on the Nutley Board of Commissioners, and was an adviser to the Trump presidential campaign. Rogers\u00a0was also the first New Jersey elected official to publicly endorse Donald Trump.\nRogers told The Times that he will be the keynote speaker at an inauguration gala in Mahwah being held on the same day as the inauguration. He said this is one of many that will held in states across the country to accommodate people who are not able to attend.\n\"I opted to stay up here and speak on the 20th,\" Rogers said. \"I was invited, and I opted not to go because there was many, many grassroots citizens who were not able to go.\n\"So I thought it was kind of a nice gesture to them, to say, 'Hey, you know you were with us during the campaign, and now we're going to be with you for the inauguration.\"\nSeething at the next president\nTeka Lark-Lo said she knew people who took issue with how the protest was organized and understood those concerns. However, she hoped people will attend and see the large picture.\n\"We can\u2019t all agree on the same things, but we need to come together to rally people, and to combat this incoming administration,\" Lark-Lo said.\nLark-Lo said that she feels like she is a \"patriot\" in participating in the protest.\n\"Being a patriot means standing up for yourself,\" Lark-Lo said.\nShe said some of the issues that she looks forward to hearing about at the protest include universal childcare.\nMontclair resident Colleen Daly Martinez will also be going to the protest with her husband, who works at Montclair State University, and her daughter, who is a student at Hillside School.\n\"I think the day after the election, people started talking about this march,\" Martinez said. \"I was immediately very interested, and I talked my husband about bringing our kid. We are excited about going.\"\nMartinez said she felt it was important to attend to make their voices known about issues that they are passionate about such as preserving women's reproductive health, but also it being a learning experience for her daughter.\n\"I want her to have a good experience to see how people organize and stand up,\" Martinez said.\nBlueWaveNJ, the Montclair-based progressive policy group, has been organizing members to attend the Washington, D.C., protest, and\u00a0related protests happening the same day in Trenton and in New York City, according to Cary Chevat, one of the founders of BlueWaveNJ.\nChevat said at least 800 people have already been signed up by BlueWave to board buses from Montclair to go to the various protests, with the bulk of them going to Washington, D.C.\nEmail: kaulessar@northjersey.com\n4 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jIRvHS\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1172.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/bergen/glen-rock/2017/01/13/grewal-apolgizes-closed-inauguration-we-fumbled/96539802/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nGrewal apologizes for closed inauguration: 'We fumbled it'\nBergen County Prosecutor Gurbir S. Grewal struck a conciliatory tone on Friday in a conversation with The Record Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2iut97b\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n3\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nGrewal apologizes for closed inauguration: 'We fumbled it'\nSteve Janoski , Staff Writer, @SteveJanoski Published 9:48 p.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017 | Updated 9:04 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nGrewal apologized for the media freeze-out at his Thursday inauguration ceremony, and said reporters who arrived at Bergen Community College should have been let in.\nNewly-sworn in Bergen County Prosecutor Gurbir S. Grewal  at Glen Rock High School after speaking about the opioid epidemic on Friday, Jan. 13, 2017.\n(Photo: Michael Karas/Northjersey.com)\nGLEN ROCK \u2013 Bergen County Prosecutor\u00a0Gurbir\u00a0S. Grewal struck a conciliatory tone on Friday in a conversation with The Record, apologizing for closing his inauguration ceremon y to the public and media and talking about his plans for the county Prosecutor\u2019s Office.\nGrewal, an Indian-American Sikh who is the first South Asian to hold the county prosecutor position, acknowledged the event should have been open to reporters, and said his office handled it \u201cnot as well as we should have.\u201d\nReporters who showed up at Bergen Community College to cover the event Thursday afternoon should have been let in, he said.\nInstead, a Bergen County sheriff\u2019s officer posted at the campus entrance told a reporter and photographer the event was closed to the press. The Prosecutor\u2019s Office had deemed\u00a0it private, the officer said, but gave no reason why. Then the officer demanded the reporter and photographer leave the property.\n\u201cWe fumbled it,\u201d Grewal said. \u201cHad it been brought to my attention right away, we would have tried to handle it differently.\u201d\nIn an interview Friday after an appearance at Glen Rock High School, where he spoke to students about the dangers of opioid addiction , Grewal said his office anticipated a closed ceremony since it began planning it last month. Similar events the prosecutor has attended as a guest were similarly private, he said.\nGurbir S. Grewal sworn in as Bergen County prosecutor\nMany state officials, including state\u00a0senators,\u00a0General\u00a0Assembly members, municipal police chiefs\u00a0and county prosecutors from across the state attended the ceremony in the college\u2019s 300-seat Ciccone Theatre.\nGrewal, a Democrat, served as acting prosecutor for nearly a year after Gov.\u00a0Chris Christie appointed him in\u00a0January 2016. But a unanimous confirmation vote in the state Senate in November allowed him to shed the \u201cacting\u201d title. He will serve a five-year term as the agency\u2019s head.\nChristie was supposed to attend, but he canceled about 9 a.m. Thursday. Grewal said his office was told the governor was ill.\nThe decision to make the ceremony private was made\u00a0well before\u00a0the governor committed to coming, Grewal said.\nPlans\u00a0\nGrewal, a Glen Rock resident, provided a copy of his inauguration speech to The Record on Friday morning. He sat down with a reporter that afternoon to speak about his plans for the Prosecutor\u2019s Office, which employs about 265 people, including 105 detectives and 60 prosecutors.\nAs head of that agency, Grewal will exercise significant power \u2013 the Prosecutor\u2019s Office regularly conducts complex criminal investigations, oversees municipal police departments\u00a0and puts together regional task forces.\nGrewal said he wants to further increase collaboration with municipal police forces, starting with the expansion of a program that \u201cloans\u201d municipal officers to the Prosecutor\u2019s Office for six- to 12-month terms.\nThis gives those officers, of which there will be about a dozen this year, a greater breadth of experience, he said, and it develops trust between the county office and local police forces.\n\u201cIt helps the municipalities develop points of contact with us, and it helps municipalities better train their detectives,\u201d he said.\nGrewal, a father of three, also wants to tackle the county\u2019s burgeoning opioid abuse problems, which he called \u201ca public health issue.\u201d The prosecutor said he would\u00a0address this through collaborative programs like Operation Helping Hand, which sought to get drug offenders arrested last\u00a0summer\u00a0into a county detox program.\nHe also will continue giving presentations to local students on opioid addiction \u2014 the office did 50 presentations last year that reached 10,000 students, he said. He said he hopes to work with schools to increase the number\u00a0of parents who attend the presentations.\nGrewal talked about being the first Sikh in the prosecutor position,\u00a0and said\u00a0he felt\u00a0his successes and his failures would reflect on his community.\nHe said he\u00a0hoped\u00a0to\u00a0break\u00a0some of the stereotypes of those who follow his religion.\n\u201cIt\u2019s a burden, but it\u2019s something I embrace,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a challenge, but I\u2019m enjoying it. And it\u2019s good for law enforcement.\u201d\n25 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 3 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2iut97b\n"]]

Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2iuLhh2\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n2\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nFort Lee Police Chief voices concerns over Pal Park project\nCheryl O'Brien , Staff Writer, @CherylDaleNews Published 12:30 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017 | Updated 12:30 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nSite of the proposed 17-story building with 154 residential units and 180 parking spaces in Palisades Park.\n(Photo: Cheryl O'Brien/NorthJersey.com)\nPALISADES PARK\u2014\u00a0\u00a0In a letter\u00a0submitted\u00a0to the borough zoning\u00a0board,\u00a0Fort\u00a0Lee Police Chief Keith\u00a0Bendul\u00a0voiced\u00a0concern\u00a0for\u00a0public safety relating to a\u00a0proposed\u00a0luxury high-rise building near wetlands on\u00a0the Fort Lee line.\nCapt. Stephen Gallagher presented\u00a0the\u00a0letter, which was obtained by The Record,\u00a0to the\u00a0borough\u00a0Board of Adjustment on\u00a0Bendul\u2019s\u00a0behalf in October. The letter\u00a0details\u00a0Bendul\u2019s\u00a0concern over\u00a0traffic flow\u00a0at the proposed development and safety concerns\u00a0for neighborhood children who walk to\u00a0a nearby\u00a0school.\n\u201cAt this point my approach is I\u2019m in a wait-and-see posture,\u201d\u00a0Bendul\u00a0said Friday. \u201cI need to see what the decision is and what the plans are.\u201d\nThe board has not responded to the letter, according to\u00a0Bendul.\nBerkeley Palisades Park, the developer, is seeking to build a 17-story building with 154 residential units and 180 parking spaces on an area of wetlands known as Long Swamp on East\u00a0Edsall\u00a0Boulevard and 14th Street. The developer is seeking a waiver to build 14 stories above the lobby and parking. The allowed maximum height\u00a0for the zone is eight stories.\u00a0Testimony\u00a0on the proposal will resume Monday .\nThe proposal\u00a0entails\u00a0developing a section of 14th\u00a0Street extending south from\u00a0Edsall\u00a0Boulevard that\u00a0would\u00a0run\u00a0parallel to the\u00a0building.\u00a0The two access points to the proposed\u00a0street\u00a0are\u00a0at\u00a0East and West\u00a0Edsall\u00a0Boulevard.\u00a0Emergency and fire vehicles\u00a0from Palisades Park would pass by Lewis F.\u00a0Cole Middle School in Fort Lee\u00a0en\u00a0route to the development,\u00a0Bendul\u00a0said.\n\u201cThe increased risk for having multiple emergency vehicles driving at accelerated speed through a school zone during drop-off or pickup times or during school events is very concerning,\u201d\u00a0Bendul\u00a0said in the letter.\nFort Lee residents who\u00a0are opposed\u00a0the development are expected to attend Monday\u2019s meeting, including\u00a0Uta\u00a0Gore, a leader of the opposition.\u00a0Gore\u00a0lives in the Carriage House, a multistory building next to the proposed development. She posted flyers in the elevator of her building urging\u00a0residents\u00a0to attend the\u00a0meeting.\nIn an interview at her apartment Thursday, Gore\u00a0echoed\u00a0Bendul\u2019s\u00a0concerns\u00a0for the development\u2019s impact on traffic in the area. Many children walk to and from Lewis F. Cole Middle School each day,\u00a0she said,\u00a0and increased traffic on Stillwell Avenue and side streets will pose a danger.\nGore is also concerned about the impact on wildlife that inhabits the wetlands.\n\u201cThe state should buy the property and protect it,\u201d she said.\nThe parcel on which the development is proposed to be built is a narrow strip of land sandwiched between gullied bedrock and dead trees backed by wetlands. On Thursday, Gore pointed out a red-tailed hawk soaring overhead and a woodpecker bobbing along a branch. Deer,\u00a0tree frogs\u00a0and other types of birds such as warblers are spotted here and will be threatened by\u00a0construction, Gore said.\n\u201cThese are my concerns, but it\u2019s mostly for human beings,\u201d she said. \u201cPeople love living here. To put a building right on top of this is ridiculous.\u201d\nCONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 2 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2iuLhh2\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1176.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-sanders-debate_us_57489626e4b0dacf7ad4e580"], ["text", "The Trump-Sanders Debate: Ah, What Might Have Been\nWe'll miss out on another great opportunity to entertain ourselves to death.\n05/30/2016 06:01 am ET\nJason Linkins Eat The Press Editor, The Huffington Post\nLauren Weber The Morning Email Editor, The Huffington Post\nHoward Fineman Global Editorial Director, The Huffington Post\nThe Huffington Post\nAs further proof that 2016 is perhaps the most insane campaign year since\u00a0--\u00a0oh ... 1876, or 1824, or maybe even 1800 (check 'em out)\u00a0--\u00a0Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders have been talking, with some seriousness, about debating each other before the June 7 California primary.\nBut it seems this is not going to happen: Friday afternoon, Donald Trump put out a barely coherent statement in which he announced he was declining to participate in any such event:\u00a0\nWas this Trump statement written on ayahuasca? pic.twitter.com/xfFMsujSbb\n\u2014 Matt Ford (@fordm) May 27, 2016\nA debate between a \"presumptive\" nominee of one party (Trump) and the second-place candidate in the other party (Sanders) is definitely an idea without precedent. But let's face it, it nevertheless befits the random, demolition-derby tenor of American politics today. And at first glance, it has some obvious appeal to both Trump and Sanders: Some debate-stage \"presidential-ness\" practice for The Messhugah-Don, and more free air time for the Birken-Stalker. And both men love the idea of erasing Hillary Clinton from the picture.\nBut the calculus would have been more complicated for the three remaining candidates -- and for the other major players in this pre-convention phase of the 2016's political psychodrama.\nIn all likelihood, most of them are feeling relieved that Donald bailed on the debate. On this week's First to Last, we run down how all the prominent characters on the main stage might have gained or lost in what could have been another election-season sideshow.\u00a0\nRANK\nTRAIT\nPhotos: Getty, Associated Press\nEditor\u2019s note:\u00a0Donald Trump regularly\u00a0 incites political violence \u00a0and is a\u00a0 serial liar ,\u00a0 rampant xenophobe ,\u00a0 racist ,\u00a0 misogynist \u00a0\nand\u00a0 birther \u00a0who has repeatedly pledged to ban all Muslims \u2014 1.6 billion members of an entire religion \u2014 from entering the U.S.\nMore:\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1180.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/bernie-sanders-hillary-clinton-convention_us_573f3f7fe4b045cc9a70d454"], ["text", "Here's What Bernie Sanders Should Ask For At The Convention\nIce cream is a good starting point.\n05/23/2016 06:50 am ET\nJason Linkins Eat The Press Editor, The Huffington Post\nLauren Weber The Morning Email Editor, The Huffington Post\nHoward Fineman Global Editorial Director, The Huffington Post\nThe Huffington Post\nSooner or later, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton is going to clinch the Democratic nomination outright . At that point, it\u2019ll be time for another round of hard choices, because in order to move forward, she\u2019ll have to knit the fractious Democratic coalition back together . And she\u2019ll have to close the deal with Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) before the July convention in Philadelphia. What to do, what to do? Besides maybe electing Debbie Wasserman-Schultz's primary opponent , Tim Canova. (Which wouldn't be a bad idea , to be honest .)\nIt starts by acknowledging that Sanders has helpfully revealed a lot about the concerns of the younger revelers in the Democratic ranks. As a candidate who's often depicted as being too rooted in the 1990s, Clinton has a lot to gain from the insights of this new generation of voters whom Sanders has encouraged to become involved in politics. It\u2019s a big prize, but it won\u2019t -- and shouldn\u2019t -- be freely given. So it\u2019s time for some concessions.\nHere at First To Last, we\u2019ve written out a menu of friendly gestures, ranging from fun and good cheer to serious offers that could define Clinton\u2019s campaign and point the way toward a shared future between both candidates\u2019 camps. The best thing about all these suggestions is that America wins in every instance. So much winning. By Jove, maybe everyone will be bored of winning, who knows. Feel free to add your own in the comments!\nRANK\n"]]

clear\nDonna M Rolando , Staff Writer, @Dmmrolando 11:42 p.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017\nHawthorne makes brine solution with computerized equipment\nDirector of Public Works Robert Scully in front of a Hawthorne Department of Public Works truck with a 9,000-gallon tank used to distribute the brine solution on the roads in preparation for ice and snow on Thursday.\n(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\nBrine made with 23-percent salt solution\nBrine should be applied to road surface three days before a storm\nThe salt solution keeps roadways clean for storms up to 2 inches of snow\nHAWTHORNE \u2013\u00a0Keeping roadways clean and safe during winter months in the Northeast requires a bit of science, impeccable timing and\u00a0a real close eye on the weather.\nRobert Scully pays more than the usual attention to\u00a0weather \u2013 even for a public works director.\u00a0He's the man behind keeping the borough's roadways clear of snow and ice.\nScully, among other things, uses\u00a0brine to\u00a0fight slippery icy roads, but the salt-water solution requires impeccable timing to make it work.\nThe secret to cleaning roads down to the blacktop, Scully said, is spraying them with a 23 percent salt concentration\u00a0three days before a storm. He said the spraying\u00a0will\u00a0keep up to 2 inches of snow from sticking to the asphalt.\nThe borough\u00a0makes it's own\u00a0brine salt-water solution, which it now sells to the county and other municipalities.\nThe program, which started over a year ago, is what borough officials consider a success. Mayor Richard\u00a0Goldberg\u00a0said the township\u00a0recently renewed contracts\u00a0to sell brine for 15 cents a gallon to\u00a0Ridgewood and Passaic County. Hawthorne also\u00a0is under contract to brine all\u00a0county roads in Hawthorne for roughly $600 per snow event.\nSelling the brine to other municipalities is a way to recoup the $73,000 cost of the borough\u2019s initial investment in the computerized mobile brine-making unit, Goldberg said.\nThe prospects of serving other towns could be expanded even further with the addition of a storage tank\u00a0under consideration by the\u00a0Borough Council, Goldberg said.\nBecause 15 cents a gallon is minimal, he said, selling brine to other towns is more of a shared service than a profit-making venture.\nThe financial picture is made rosier by the savings of about 30 percent that comes from using less salt on the roads, Scully said. In recent years, towns have run up against a shortage of road salt, so brine helps with this.\nSince brine is applied before a storm, Goldberg added, \u201cwe can do it during the workday without involving overtime,\u201d for another potential savings.\n\u201cWe\u2019re covering our costs plus a little more. We don\u2019t make enough that it impacts the budget,\u201d Borough Administrator Eric\u00a0Maurer said.\nIn 2016, Maurer said, the borough sold 13,200 gallons\u00a0to Ridgewood\u00a0for $792 and\u00a09,875 gallons to the\u00a0county\u00a0for $592.\nThe back of a Hawthorne Department of Public Works truck with a 9,000-gallon tank used to distribute the brine solution on the roads in preparation for ice and snow.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\nYet saving money is not the true reason for the starting the brine program, borough officials said.\n\u201cThe big impetus is to improve the quality of our roads and the safety,\u201d Maurer said, noting that clearing the way for school buses was a big issue.\nAs a result of the brine, there are no more icy roads, Maurer said.\u00a0\u201cResidents, particularly on the hills, will recognize the difference.\"\nFor\u00a0brine\u00a0to have the best results, Scully said, his crews must spray the roads within three days of a snow event\u00a0\u2013\u00a0no sooner. Because any rainfall will defeat their effort,\u00a0timing\u00a0is important, he\u00a0said.\n\u201cWe\u2019re proactive. We don\u2019t wait until snow comes and try to get rid of it,\u201d Scully saud.\n\u201cIt\u2019s sort of an art in terms of when you use it and don\u2019t use it,\u201d\u00a0Maurer said.\nMotorists will know that brine has\u00a0been applied\u00a0by the rows of parallel lines\u00a0trucks leave on\u00a0the asphalt. As cars travel over the road, they help to spread out the brine. \u201cIt\u2019s more effective [than salt],\u201d he said.\nDirector of Public Works Robert Scully uses the computer screen on the mobile brine unit to check the levels of brine solution and water that will be mixed in with salt.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey)\nOn Friday, with possible\u00a0snow in the forecast, Scully was busy revving up brine-making operations\u00a0at the\u00a0Department of Public Works facility on\u00a0Goffle\u00a0Road. At a digital programming screen, he\u00a0began\u00a0with making sure\u00a0the brine producer\u00a0was set for maximum effectiveness \u2013 usually a 23.3 percent salt concentration. The mixing of a batch takes place in a giant metal vat at a rate of 160 gallons a minute. Only when the solution reaches the desired concentration does it hit the next stage, which is percolation.\nThe brine solution eventually makes its way to a 900-gallon tank on the back of a truck for easy distribution, but even then, computer sensors are guiding every step. The truck will stick to the goal of 50 gallons of brine per lane mile regardless of whether there\u2019s traffic.\n\u201cIt\u2019s all speed sensitive to the roadway,\u201d Scully explained. \u201cWe never go over 20 to 25 mph while brining. The truck knows what\u2019s going on in relation to the roadway.\u201d Hawthorne has 50 miles of roadways.\nA row of evenly spaced applicators creates the lines drivers see on the road\u00a0and are joined by a curbside nozzle for more complete coverage.\nDirector of Public Works Robert Scully looks into the brine tank as it is cleaned with water in preparation for the brine solution that will be made to coat the roads for this weekend's possible storm.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey)\nThe new storage tank will speed up the operation, making it so that trucks from Ridgewood or Passaic County don\u2019t have to wait to get their fill of the brine solution, he said.\nDoes it create potholes? Scully considers the impact on the environment to be less severe than salt operations because the concentration of salt is so reduced.\nAlthough brine-making is in many ways a science, Scully put it simply:\u00a0\u201cIt works.\u201d\n7 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2iuPukV\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1200.html"], ["url", "http://www.bergencounty.com/shopping/protecting-yourself-from-the-evil-eye-1.1436806"], ["text", "Protecting yourself from the evil eye\nMichael Lamendola/Partner Story \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\nPhoto Courtesy of Matimoo buy or license this photo\nFor thousands of years, civilizations around the world have believed that the magical curse of the evil eye can cause serious harm or misfortune and, in response, have created special charms and amulets to provide protection from its malevolent glare.\n\u201cCertain charms and amulates can ward off the evil eye and provide good luck ,\u201d says Stacey Talieres, owner of Matimoo (in Greek, Mati means eye and Mou means my), a designer and retailer of such bracelets, available at Bella Salon in Fort Lee, Ora by D\u2019Amore Jewelers in Cliffside Park, Ambience in Edgewater, Marcia\u2019s Attic Kids in Englewood and The Rebecca Collection in Bernardsville. They are also available on matimoo.com and Amazon.com.\nThe symbol\u2019s history\nMany believe the evil eye symbol has the ability to cause injury and death, especially to pregnant women, children and animals. Belief in the eye is prevalent in Jewish, Islamic, Buddhist, Hindu and Christian religions.\n\u201cPeople in Greece are infatuated with the eye, but here\u2019s the thing \u2013 Jewish people will say \u2018it\u2019s the Jewish eye\u2019, Turkish people will say \u2018it\u2019s the Turkish eye\u2019,\u201d says Talieres. \u201cYou can\u2019t specify origin to a particular culture or religion. It\u2019s a universal belief.\u201d\nMeasures to repel the evil eye vary around the world. The tactics range from the use of certain hand gestures to the display of ritual drawings or objects. Widely used is the adornment of amulets, charms or talismans, which represent some form of the eye itself. The staring eye returns the malicious gaze back only to the individual or sorcerer who sent it. It does not cause harm to others who encounter it.\nA symbol and a guardian\nTalieres says she realized the eye\u2019s power when she was in a serious car accident. She walked away without a scratch but the car was practically destroyed. Hanging from her rearview mirror was her evil eye, which she always kept in her car. After the impact of the accident, she looked up and there it was \u2013 fully intact.\n\u201cAt that very moment, I realized it had done its job protecting me,\u201d she says. \u201cI often reflect back to that day and how fortunate I was to survive.\u201d\nHer husband, Mike, believes in the powers of the eye as well, but was never comfortable with wearing anything incorporating the symbol. The options on the market were clunky and cumbersome and many were not fashionable at all. So Talieres, who held a a high ranking job in the fashion retail business, put her knowledge to work and created her own, simplistic and practical line of Mati bracelets. Earlier this year, as Matimoo took off, she quit her job in retail and focused on the power of the Mati full time.\n\u201cIn reality, you sometimes don\u2019t need a $1,000 item to make you feel good,\u201d says Talieres, whose bracelets come in seven different color choices. They are fully adjustable and each one contains a unique eye charm. They sell for just $8.95. \u201cThe mystique of having a statement piece adorned with diamonds isn\u2019t going to buy you extra protection.\u201d\nThere are several components in the manufacturing process of each Matimoo bracelet.\nOne step is the selection of the perfect evil eye bead which must meet quality and aesthetic standards, and also possess individuality and character. Band colors include turquoise, neon pink, neon yellow, black, white red and blue \u2013 red being the top seller. A high quality cord with a wax coating ensures durability. Each bracelet comes with a set of two eyes: one traditional blue and white bead, which sits front and center and on the back side of your wrist sits another metal bead with the evil eye etched in.\n\u201cYou might see variations between the eyes and that\u2019s okay,\u201d says Talieres. \u201cEach eye is meant to have a bit of its own identity.\u201d\nPaying it forward\nAs Talieres feels the eye has protected her, she believes it will watch over all of her customers too. Talieres donates a portion of Matimoo\u2019s sales should go to a cancer charity in honor of her father\u2019s own death by the disease. Bracelets have been donated to a New York City police precinct to help protect the officers on their beat and Matimoo is a participant of Robin\u2019s Racers Vendor Event to aid Making Strides Against Breast Cancer.\n\u201cThat\u2019s really our whole mission, and the mission of the evil eye symbol, to help people,\u201d says Talieres. \u201cOur mission at Matimoo is to be able to impact lives throughout many different landscapes.\u201d\nTo order your very own Matimoo bracelet or to find out more about the evil eye, visit matimoo.com . Matimoo may be contacted by calling 201-605-1432 or email hi@matimoo.com .\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1203.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/passaic/paterson/2017/01/13/paterson-art-factory-files-lawsuit-after-getting-150-summonses/96558686/"], ["text", "Paterson Art Factory files lawsuit after getting 150 summonses\nJOE MALINCONICO, PATERSON PRESS 9:24 p.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017\nPaterson community improvements director David Gilmore, left, and Art Factory owner David Garsia discuss November's site inspection.\n(Photo: Paterson Press Staff Photo)\nPATERSON \u2013 The owner of the Art Factory complex in Paterson\u2019s Great Falls historic district has filed a lawsuit accusing the city of harassment after its inspectors issued 150 summonses two months ago.\nThe summonses are for alleged illegal occupancy violations for the dozens of small businesses \u2013 many of the art-related \u2013 that rent space at the Spruce Street site, a former industrial complex built in the mid-19th century. The city maintains that each of those tenants should have gotten a certificate of occupancy before opening for business.\nBut Michael Rubin, the lawyer representing the owner of the complex, says the city is off-base in its assertion that each tenant in the complex needs a separate certificate of occupancy. He also said municipal officials were overly aggressive in issuing so many violations, especially because the complex is fulfilling local officials\u2019 goal of revising old industrial sites.\n\u201cWho gives 150 summonses to a building that is accomplishing what the city wants to see happen in its historic district?\u201d Rubin wondered.\nRubin said his client, David Garsia, filed the lawsuit last month.\nOfficials said Garsia has been running the complex in violation of the zoning regulations for the area.\n\u201cEvery one of the violations is valid,\u201d said Paterson\u2019s Community Improvements Director David Gilmore, the officials who worked on the summonses. \u201cIt has nothing to do with harassment whatsoever. Everybody who\u2019s in violation is entitled to a ticket.\u201d\nGilmore maintained that each tenant at the complex needs a separate certificate of occupancy. \u201cIt seems to be the common excuse whenever people get caught doing something wrong that they claim harassment,\u201d Gilmore added. \u201cIf they just followed the law, we wouldn\u2019t be knocking on their door.\u201d\nThe city forced the Art Factory complex to shut down in December 2015 \u2013 days before it was going to host a Christmas Party that was supposed to attract hundreds of guests \u2013 because of fire safety violations.\nCity fire officials said those problems were addressed within weeks and the Art Factory was then allowed to reopen. But the shutdown drew attention to the complex and some officials expressed relief that the fire safety problems were found before a tragedy happened.\nGarsia owes more than $600,000 in property taxes on the Art Factory, according to city officials.\n46 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jGuO71\n"]]

Morales was charged with theft of services and is being held in the Middlesex County Jail without bail.\n\"Lester Morales was responsible for operating his company, Do it Right Trucking, but unfortunately he was doing it wrong by racking up more than $1 million in unpaid tolls and administrative fees,\" said Colonel Rick Fuentes, superintendent of the New Jersey State Police, in a release. \"Our detectives will work closely with our partners from the Middlesex County Prosecutor's Office and New Jersey Turnpike Authority to ensure justice is served.\"\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2iupxBP\n"]]

PRS contacted each licensed and active chiropractor within Bergen County. PRS asked each chiropractor in an exclusive peer-review online survey which chiropractors they would recommend, other than themselves, across the county. Each chiropractor was allowed to recommend up to three colleagues. Once the ballots were complete, each nominee was carefully evaluated on the basis of the survey results, the legitimacy of their license and their current standing with the State Board of Chiropractic Examiners. Chiropractors who received the highest number of votes in chiropractic medicine are reflected in the following Top Chiropractor list for 2015.
