[["name", "new_7/1228.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/crime/2017/01/13/amtrak-supervisor-pleads-guilty-20k-fraud-case/96561784/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nAmtrak supervisor pleads guilty in $20K fraud case\nDonald Harper Sr., 47, of Somerset, admitted to billing Amtrak for 27.75 regular hours and 192.25 overtime hours in 20, while not actually being at Amtrak work sites between October 2014 and October 2015.\nPost to Facebook\nAmtrak supervisor pleads guilty in $20K fraud case Donald Harper Sr., 47, of Somerset, admitted to billing Amtrak for 27.75 regular hours and 192.25 overtime hours in 20, while not actually being at Amtrak work sites between October 2014 and October 2015. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2iueMPS\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nAmtrak supervisor pleads guilty in $20K fraud case\nLisa Marie Segarra , Staff Writer, @lisamarie_lynn 8:07 p.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017\n.\n(Photo: Getty Images)\nA former Amtrak supervisor pleaded guilty to fraudulently billing Amtrak for hours that he did not work.\nDonald Harper Sr., 47, of Somerset, admitted to billing Amtrak for 27.75 regular hours and 192.25 overtime hours, while not actually being at Amtrak work sites between October 2014 and October 2015. The total losses are reported at over $20,000. Harper is charged with one count of converting to his own use federal government funds.\nHarper was employed form February 1990 to October 2015. he supervised 19 other employees on the Signals side of the Communications and Signals Department of Amtrak's New York Division, according to the United States Attorney District\u00c2\u00a0of New Jersey's office.\u00c2\u00a0Harper was to supervise employees working on the Positive Train Control installation project during the summer of 2015. The project is mandated by Congress and puts advanced technological components in place that could automatically stop or slow a train to prevent accidents or derailments.\nThe charges carries a maximum penalty of one year in prison and a fine of $250,000, or twice the gain or loss resulting from the offense, whichever is greater. Harper's sentencing is scheduled for March 20.\nAccording to Attorney District of New Jersey's office, he is also required to pay full restitution of $20,346 as per the terms of his plea agreement.\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2iueMPS\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1229.html"], ["url", "http://www.bergencounty.com/education/don-t-fear-the-future-parents-guide-to-the-technology-integrated-classroom-for-the-smartphone-generation-1.1649078"], ["text", "SHIRONOSOV/GETTY IMAGES/ISTOCKPHOTO buy or license this photo\nWhether parents grasp it or not, modern technology is changing the landscape of education.\nSmartphones and tablets are becoming a mainstay in and out of classrooms. Although these gadgets are sometimes viewed merely as entertainment or for keeping in touch with friends, they can also be used as learning tools to supplement students\u2019 education with classroom- friendly apps.\nComputers, too, are becoming smaller, cheaper and easier to use at school. Some Bergen County districts are moving away frompermanent computer labs toward providing each student their own portable device to use in school and at home.\nGone are the days when pen and paper ruled the land. Now, computers can do almost any task, from writing an essay to submitting it digitally. Overall, it makes sense to use technology as a learning tool, since most children are already tech-literate. A device-friendly classroom has the potential to let students learn better, faster, and more efficiently.\nSMARTPHONES\nThe power of smartphones and tablets lies in the capability to take them anywhere, ready at a moment\u2019s notice. On top of that, apps are available to facilitate nearly any task, from research, to organization, to collaborating with classmates on group projects.\nStudents can download anything from an interactive periodic table app to a graphing calculator. Apps can help them remember when homework is due or create an instant bibliography by scanning a book\u2019s barcode. They can also make room in their backpack by foregoing a dictionary, thesaurus, notebook, language dictionary, flashcards and calendar.\nWhen classrooms allow for the use of smart devices, students can access online research materials or take notes, using the power of the cloud to their advantage.\nBut it\u2019s important that children know and respect the rules of each teacher\u2019s classroom before using a cell phone during class. There are also apps and parental controls that allow parents to keep tabs on their children \u2013 just make sure to give them enough personal space as well.\nLET\u2019S GET PERSONAL\nSome Bergen County schools have already experimented with a technologyintensive classroom experience by distributing iPads, MacBooks or Chromebooks \u2013 essentially Google-powered laptops \u2013 to students. Results have been promising. In the past, schools have relied on computer labs or a limited number of classroom machines, in addition to students\u2019 home computers, for all technological aspects of the curriculum.\nNow students as early as fourth grade have been supplemented with personal devices from local districts, including Allendale, Franklin Lakes, Mahwah, Midland Park, Oakland, Ramsey, Waldwick and Wyckoff.\nBenefits of schools using this one-to-one initiative include filesharing between teachers and students and tracking progress. While the computers haven\u2019t yet completely replaced textbooks, some schools, including Midland Park, have online versions available to students.\nAnother benefit of each student having a computer is that teachers can provide online materials to supplement classroom learning. Notes and lectures can be posted to allow greater collaboration inside and outside the classroom.\nTeachers can easily post and share PowerPoint slides, class notes, web links, syllabi and much more to give students instant access to the entire cache of resources on the cloud, not to mention eliminating the clutter of paper in a messy backpack. Now students can no longer try blaming the dog for eating their homework.\nMore districts are looking into providing personal computers for students, typically only requiring a waiver and nominal fee to cover insurance. So don\u2019t be surprised if your son or daughter comes home from school with a shiny new gadget in their possession.\nAlthough it may seem overwhelming at times, this new use of technology is nothing to fear. Kids are already embracing the latest advancements on a daily \u2013 if not hourly \u2013 basis, so for them, providing a high-tech classroom experience is only natural.\nIn the coming years, who knows what the landscape of education will look like? It is an ever-evolving realm, but rest assured, this generation of kids will use technology to the fullest, becoming better educated than ever.\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1256.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/new-jersey/2017/01/13/christie-silent-new-jersey-calls-ny-sports-radio-talk-cowboys-and-trump/96558052/"], ["text", "Green: Introducing the Trump Tracker\nChristie, silent in New Jersey, calls in to N.Y. sports radio to talk Cowboys and Trump\nDustin Racioppi , State House Bureau, @dracioppi Published 5:26 p.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017 | Updated 6:54 p.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017\nGovernor Christie and Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones before a 2013 NFL football game between the Giants and the Cowboys in Arlington, Texas.\n(Photo: Associated Press)\nGov. Chris Christie, who has refused to take questions from reporters in New Jersey about the\u00a0George Washington Bridge lane-closure trial, his diminished\u00a0role in the Trump transition and his sweeping plan to combat drug abuse, called in to sports-talk radio Friday afternoon for a breezy 20-minute conversation about football, politics and his future.\nThe conversation ended on an awkward note, though, when Christie was denied \"a little friendly advice\" on how he sounds on the radio.\nChristie selects campaign donor as new ethics watchdog\nHe had been listening to WFAN-660 AM on his way to his youngest daughter's basketball game, Christie\u00a0said, when he felt the urge to call\u00a0host Mike Francesa to talk about the Dallas Cowboys. Francesa turned the focus of the conversation to Christie's relationship with President-elect Donald Trump, which some news outlets have reported has soured in recent weeks.\nChristie, who was ousted as the transition's chairman days after Trump won the election, said reports of a falling-out are \"crazy.\" He said he had been offered \"multiple jobs\" in the new administration, but there was \"about one\" that he really wanted. He didn't say what that job was.\nWhat Trump offered \"weren't jobs that I wanted,\" Christie said. \"There were some that I got offered that were just not worth leaving the governorship for.\"\nWith one year left in office, Christie said, the offer had to be \"a really great job.\"\nListen to the full interview:\u00a0\nMike Francesa with Governor Chris Christie\nOne job Christie has been rumored to be in line for is Francesa's. After 30 years in the afternoon slot at WFAN, the \"sports pope\" is retiring at the end of the year. Christie regularly appears on the station's morning show as a co-host and is set to leave office in January 2018.\nChristie said he has three criteria for whatever his next job may be:\u00a0\"One, I want to\u00a0have fun. Two, I want to make money. And three, I want to be able to spend more time with my kids. That's the way\u00a0I'll look at whatever job it is.\"\nFrancesa asked Christie if he would be open to taking his position.\n\"I'm going to have wide open ears,\" Christie said. \"You don't throw your hat in the ring for that kind of thing. You just see what happens.\"\nWith one year left in his term, Christie said he still looks forward to being governor every day, but conceded\u00a0\"you also count days because it's\u00a0inevitable now.\"\n\"Everyone's going to start running for the job,\" he said.\nAt the end of the conversation, Christie asked Francesa if he would listen to him on the morning show next week. Francesa, who does not get along with morning host Craig Carton,\u00a0said no.\n\"Come on! Why not?\" Christie said.\n\"There's some things I will never do. I don't ever listen in the morning. If you want to come on this show, you're always welcome,\" Francesa told Christie.\n\"Wouldn't you listen to give me a little critique? Come on, a little critique, a little friendly advice,\" Christie said.\nFrancesa again said no.\n\"So you won't even listen when I'm on?\" Christie said.\n\"No. Not even. Sorry,\" Francesa said. \"Some things will never happen.\"\n1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 2 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2itIsgd\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1265.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/transportation/2017/01/15/bridges-roads-and-rail-all-need-funds-repair/95917398/"], ["text", "Search\nBridges, roads and rail all need funds for repair\nTrump has proposed large scale investment in infrastructure to rebuild the nation's roads and bridges and put thousands back to work.\nJohn E Seasly , Staff Writer, @jseasly\nIn this series on:\nHealth coverage for 700,000 at stake in New Jersey\nTSA screening wait times and Homeland Security funds top list of questions\nRepairing, upgrading rail will affect thousands of commuters\nImmigration issues dominated Trump's campaign\nBlue state in a red Capitol: How will N.J. fare?\nShare This Story\nEmail\nComment\nAbout this series:\u00a0The Record and NorthJersey.com are launching the \u201cTrump Tracker,\u201d a four-year series that will follow 14\u00a0issues important to North Jersey taxpayers, residents and companies \u2013 big and small \u2014\u00a0that could be affected by actions taken by President Donald J. Trump\u2019s administration.\nThe intent is not to characterize whether the actions move a particular issue in a positive or negative direction. Rather, it will chart the results of policies created, modified or discontinued over the next four years and how they affect life in New Jersey.\nThe \"Trump Tracker\" will measure changes and trends on such issues as healthcare, immigration, transportation, job creation, the military, political influence, energy and the environment, regulations, the Newark seaport, infrastructure, passenger rail, taxes, homeland security and the social safety net.\nWe will update certain topics at least once every three months, offering insights of the new administration, its policies, actions and the trickle-down effects on New Jersey.\n**********\nPresident-elect Donald Trump has proposed large-scale investment in infrastructure to rebuild the nation's roads and bridges and put thousands back to work. Will more money flow to New Jersey\u00a0for transportation projects?\nCommuters board a NJ Transit train in this file photo.\n(Photo: Tariq Zehawi/NorthJersey.com)\nAs Trump prepares to assume the nation's highest office, the state's\u00a0infrastructure is in desperate need of some of the $1 trillion Trump has promised toward\u00a0improvements for road, rail and bridges.\nOn the campaign trail, Trump promised $1 trillion in infrastructure spending in the next 10 years, with much of it going toward\u00a0transportation projects. He also promised that none of the increased spending would come from increased taxes.\nHow Trump would do this, in theory, is by getting private companies to spend the money.\nHis plan is to offer $137 billion in tax credits to construction projects that generate some kind of revenue, such as toll roads and bridges. These credits, his economists say, would generate $167 billion in investment by private companies that could then use the money to borrow up to $1 trillion toward further projects.\nWhile many of Trump's plans are likely to face extreme opposition from Democrats, infrastructure spending is one of the few ideas that might gain support.\nIn an interview in December, Senate Minority Leader Charles\u00a0Schumer, D-N.Y.,\u00a0said he was in favor of heavy infrastructure investment and open to a spending bill.\n\"He's mentioned a trillion dollars. I told him that sounded good to me,\" he said.\nTransportation Trust Fund\nIn 2016, New Jersey's Transportation Trust Fund nearly went broke\nIn 2016,\u00a0the New Jersey's Transportation Trust Fund nearly went broke and\u00a0Gov. Chris Christie temporarily shut\u00a0down construction on most state-funded transportation projects. The work resumed after the approval of the 23 cents-per-gallon gas tax increase, which went into effect in November and which voters dedicated solely to transportation projects on the Nov. 8 ballot.\nThe gas tax increase\u00a0offers a mild but temporary solution to some of the state's infrastructure problems. Gas tax revenues and new borrowing will increase from $1.2 billion to $1.6 billion a year, but $334 million of the $400 million in new revenue will go toward paying off old debts.\nNew Jersey received an infrastructure grade of D+ in 2016 from the American Society of Civil Engineers, which was highly critical of the state's roads, bridges, levees and public transit systems.\nBridges\nBridges, roads and levees across the state are decaying\nNearly one in 10 of New Jersey's 6,657 bridges is structurally deficient, meaning a bridge has one or more structural defects that need attention. More than 40 percent of the state roadway system is either rough, distressed or cracked, and costs drivers nearly $2,000 per year, according to 2012 data. Of the 10 levees inspected by the Army Corps of Engineers, half were deemed unacceptable and the other half were only minimally acceptable.\nPublic transportation\nThe system is near capacity and expansion will require federal funds\nNew Jersey's public transit systems, in particular, are under enormous strain as ridership between New Jersey and New York has continued to increase. With trains and buses nearing capacity, major expansions are needed to keep up with demand. Projects like a new Port Authority Bus Terminal or the Gateway Project, which would expand capacity and add two\u00a0rail tracks under the Hudson River, require massive investments of federal funding.\nMore Topics\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1273.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/new-jersey/2017/01/13/immigration-issues-dominated-trumps-campaign/95917498/"], ["text", "Immigration issues dominated Trump's campaign\nIn New Jersey, 1 in 5 residents foreign born; half of those are naturalized citizens\nMonsy Alvarado , Staff Writer, @MonsyAlvarado\nIn this series on:\nHealth coverage for 700,000 at stake in New Jersey\nTSA screening wait times and Homeland Security funds top list of questions\nRepairing, upgrading rail will affect thousands of commuters\nBridges, roads and rail all need funds for repair\nBlue state in a red Capitol: How will N.J. fare?\nShare This Story\nEmail\nComment\nAbout this series:\u00a0The Record and NorthJersey.com have launched\u00a0the \u201cTrump Tracker,\u201d a four-year series that will follow 14\u00a0issues important to North Jersey taxpayers, residents and companies \u2013 big and small \u2013\u00a0that could be affected by actions taken by President Donald\u00a0Trump\u2019s administration.\nThe intent is not to characterize whether the actions move a particular issue in a positive or negative direction. Rather, it will chart the results of policies created, modified or discontinued over the next four years and how they affect life in New Jersey.\nThe Trump Tracker will measure changes and trends on such issues as health care, immigration, transportation, job creation, the military, political influence, energy and the environment, regulations, the Newark seaport, infrastructure, passenger rail, taxes, homeland security and the social safety net.\nWe will update certain topics at least once every three months, offering insights into\u00a0 the new administration, its policies, its\u00a0actions\u00a0and the trickle-down effects on New Jersey.\n**********\nPresident-elect Donald Trump's campaign focused largely on immigration and\u00a0reforming the country's\u00a0policies pertaining to the approximately 11 million immigrants living in the country without legal status. He vowed to build a wall at the Mexican border to prevent immigrants from entering the country illegally. He also pledged to deport millions of undocumented immigrants with criminal convictions and to reverse policies put in place by President Barack Obama that shield from deportation unauthorized\u00a0immigrants who came to the country as children. He also said he would ban Muslim refugees from entering the country.\nA border patrol agent riding along the iron fence that separates Douglas, Arizona, and Agua Prieta, Mexico, along the international border in 2006.\n(Photo: AP FILE PHOTO)\nNew Jersey is home to a diverse population, with more than\u00a01 in 5 residents being foreign born, and half of thosebeing naturalized U.S. citizens, according to a report by the American Immigration Council. The Garden State is also home to approximately 500,000 people who don't have legal resident status, according to the Pew Hispanic Center. The forced removal of immigrants living in the country illegally would cause New Jersey to lose $25.9 billion in annual economic activity, according to a report by New Jersey Policy Perspective.\nThose who support Trump's proposed immigration\u00a0policies argue that immigration laws mustbe upheld and that people\u00a0living in the country illegally should not receive benefits such as work authorizations.\nBorder Protection\n'The Wall'\nThere's\u00a0about 400 miles along the U.S.-Mexican\u00a0border\u00a0where new fencing could be erected, and during the campaign, Trump vowed to build a wall that Mexico would pay for. Last week, news outlets reported that Trump intends to ask Congress for the initial funds to build the wall. Trump has also talked about increasing aerial surveillance programs at the border and adding more Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents. New Jersey is home to\u00a0immigrants\u00a0who have crossed the border fleeing violence, and seeking economic and education opportunities, including children who have crossed the border unaccompanied.\nDeferred Action for Childhood Arrivals Close\n23,000 New Jersey residents approved for 'DACA' Waiver\nMore than 800,000 immigrants\u00a0who came to the United States as children and\u00a0live in the country without legal permission have received this temporary waiver from deportation. The immigration policy was created in 2012\u00a0through an executive order by President Barack Obama and could be rescinded\u00a0under the\u00a0Trump administration. About\u00a023,000 New Jersey residents have been approved for the waiver, which has allowed them go to college and to work.\nRefugees\nMany fleeing violence of Syrian civil war\nTrump called for a ban on refugees from countries like Syria and Libya because he fears that terrorists could try to sneak in through the refugee\u00a0program. Last year, President Obama\u00a0pledged to increase the number of refugees that the U.S. accepts by 30 percent this year. The U.S. has been preparing to take in 110,000 refugees, including many\u00a0from\u00a0Syria, where a 5-year-old civil war has led 4.8 million\u00a0people to flee the country.\nMass deportation of immigrants with criminal records\nAn estimated 2 to 3 million face removal\nDays after winning the election,\u00a0Trump, in an interview with \"60 Minutes,\" said he would prioritize the deportation of 2 to 3 million immigrants living in the country without permission who have criminal records. Under Obama's administration, more than 2.7\u00a0million\u00a0\"removals\" occurred between fiscal year 2009 and 2014, according to Department of Homeland Security statistics. After Trump's\u00a0win, advocates who help immigrant detainees reported receiving calls from those worried about their future.\nVisas for tech workers\n65,000 workers admitted into U.S. annually\nThe H-1B visa program \u2013\u00a0which allows foreign\u00a0workers, including scientists, engineers and computer programmers,\u00a0to enter the United States for employment \u2013\u00a0could be curbed under a Trump administration. The U.S. admits an annual 65,000 workers and 20,000 graduate students with the visas. Once someone has obtained the visa, it can be renewed. Alabama Sen. Jeff Sessions, whom Trump has tapped as his attorney general, has been a critic of the visa program and has introduced legislation to limit the number of visas available to\u00a0outsourcing companies. Trump has said he opposes outsourcing workers and wants to ensure that available jobs are offered to American workers first. Critics of the visa program\u00a0say it replaces skilled workers in the United States with foreigners who get paid less.\nSanctuary cities\nPassaic, North Bergen among several in N.J.\nTrump said he wants to withhold federal\u00a0funding from\u00a0sanctuary cities \u2013\u00a0communities that\u00a0limit cooperation with federal immigration authorities that could lead to the deportation of unauthorized immigrants living in their towns. According to the Immigrant Legal Resource Center, Union, Burlington, Ocean and Middlesex counties have such \"sanctuary'' policies. Other places that have been described as sanctuary cities in New Jersey include Passaic and North Bergen, which have large immigrant populations.\nMore Topics\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1276.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/alec-baldwins-trump-takes-on-obamacare_us_587b13ece4b0e58057ff4126?ir=Entertainment"], ["text", "Alec Baldwin's Trump Takes On Obamacare And Golden Showers On 'SNL'\n\"Yes, this is really happening. I'm becoming president.\"\n01/15/2017 08:39 am ET\n34k\nMary Papenfuss Trends reporter, The Huffington Post\nAlec Baldwin stepped into Donald Trump\u2019s shoes again for \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d to present his own version of the president-elect\u2019s recent press conference \u00a0and talk about inauguration entertainment, golden showers and his sons, \u201cBeavis\u201d and \u201cButthead.\u201d\nBaldwin as Trump begins in the cold open with a serious warning: \u201cLet me answer the question that\u2019s on everyone\u2019s mind: Yes this is real life, this is really happening. On January 20th, I, Donald J. Trump will become the 45th president of the United States. Then two months later Mike Pence will become the 46th.\u201d\nHe says he\u2019s excited to move into the White House, and will even have a \u201clittle\u201d pet: Paul Ryan.\n\u2014 Saturday Night Live (@nbcsnl) January 15, 2017\n\u201cWho is excited for my Inauguration Day?\u201d he asks. \u201cWe have got some of the biggest performers in the world lined up. Because I\u2019m a major wiz at jobs,\u201d he gushes.\nWhen a reporter tells him people \u201ccould die\u201d if he eliminates Obamacare without a replacement, leaving 20 million people without health insurance, Baldwin\u2019s Trump answers: \u201cListen, sweetheart, I\u2019m about to be president. We\u2019re all going to die.\u201d\nHe also announces that he has\u00a0\u201c turned over all my business to my two sons, Beavis and Butthead.\u201d\u00a0Gesturing to SNL cast members Mikey Day and Alex Moffat, playing Donald Jr.\u00a0and Eric, Baldwin adds: \u201cLook at those two little American psychos.\u201d He refuses to take a question from a reporter from the \u201cfailing pile of garbage\u201d BuzzFeed or from \u201cover-rated fake news\u201d CNN, though insists repeatedly: \u201cI respect the press.\u201d\u00a0\nThe last question comes from shirtless Vladimir Putin look-alike Beck Bennett (claiming to be Wolf Blitzer) who asks Trump if he\u2019s \u201cvery very sure\u201d Russia hacked the American presidential election, while he holds up a small video labeled \u201cpee pee tape.\u201d\n\u201cIt was China,\u201d Baldwin responds. \u201cNo, it was Canada. OK, It was Meryl Streep.\u201d\u00a0He wraps it up with the sendoff: \u201cThanks for peeing here.\u201d\nBefore the Trump skewering, \u201cSNL\u201d re-aired a 1978 episode featuring Carrie Fisher not long after she rocked the first \u201cStar Wars\u201d movie as Princess Leia. She opened the show dressed as Leia. Musical guests were the Blues Brothers: Dan Aykroyd and the late great John Belushi.\nTina Fey returned to 8H* with a special message for Felicity Jones. #SNL\n*as a hologram pic.twitter.com/LqqSQrSpM2\n\u2014 Saturday Night Live (@nbcsnl) January 15, 2017\nSaturday night\u2019s episode was hosted by \u201cRogue One\u201d actress Felicity Jones, who was joined in the opening monologue by an ersatz \u201chologram\u201d of Tina Fey as Princess Leia. Fey warned Jones:\u00a0\u201cNo matter how the show goes, the president of the United States will say that it\u2019s sad and overrated,\u201d adding: \u201cIt\u2019s fine, no one cares.\u201d\nRelated Coverage\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1279.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/nicole-kidman-clarifies-her-support-for-donald-trump-in-new-interview_us_587a79fbe4b0e58057ff29aa?ir=Entertainment"], ["text", "Nicole Kidman Clarifies Her Controversial 'Support' For Donald Trump In New Interview\n\"I was trying to stress that I believe in democracy.\"\n01/14/2017 03:15 pm ET\nCole Delbyck Entertainment Writer, The Huffington Post\nJB Lacroix via Getty Images\nNot so fast.\u00a0\nNicole Kidman \u00a0is clarifying her controversial comments encouraging all Americans to accept President-elect\u00a0 Donald Trump \u00a0in a new interview.\u00a0\nThe \u201cLion\u201d actress came under fire this week \u00a0for declaring that it\u2019s time to support the reality-TV-host-turned-politician now that he\u2019s been elected because \u201cthat\u2019s what the country\u2019s based on.\u201d\nMany considered Kidman\u2019s statements to be dismissive of the potential problems of a Trump presidency, especially in light of her \u201cHours\u201d co-star Meryl Streep\u2019s Golden Globes\u00a0 appeal to\u00a0\u201csafeguard the truth\u201d \u00a0during this political moment.\n\u201cI was trying to stress that I believe in democracy and the American Constitution, and it was that simple,\u201d she told Access Hollywood on Saturday.\u00a0\nWhen asked to comment further on the backlash, the Oscar-actress refused to elaborate on her stance. \u201cI\u2019m out of it now,\u201d she added. \u201cThat\u2019s what I said and it\u2019s that simple.\u201d\nSpeaking with the BBC in her initial interview, Kidman explained that she was \u201creticent to start commenting politically\u201d and prefers to keep her opinions about U.S. and Australian politics to herself. Kidman, who was born in Hawaii,\u00a0is a dual citizen of both countries.\u00a0\nHowever, the actress maintained that her passion for advocating for women\u2019s rights like the fight against ovarian and breast cancer remains resolute.\u00a0\n\u201cI\u2019m issue-based,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m very, very committed to women\u2019s issues.\u201d\nKidman is currently starring in \u201cLion,\u201d which is in theaters now.\u00a0\nAlso on HuffPost\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1284.html"], ["url", "http://m.huffpost.com/us/entry/us_587a79fbe4b0e58057ff29aa/amp?ir=Entertainment"], ["text", "Nicole Kidman Clarifies Her Controversial 'Support' For Donald Trump In New Interview\n\"I was trying to stress that I believe in democracy.\"\n1 day ago\nJB Lacroix via Getty Images\nNot so fast.\u00a0\nNicole Kidman \u00a0is clarifying her controversial comments encouraging all Americans to accept President-elect\u00a0 Donald Trump \u00a0in a new interview.\u00a0\nThe \u201cLion\u201d actress came under fire this week \u00a0for declaring that it\u2019s time to support the reality-TV-host-turned-politician now that he\u2019s been elected because \u201cthat\u2019s what the country\u2019s based on.\u201d\nMany considered Kidman\u2019s statements to be dismissive of the potential problems of a Trump presidency, especially in light of her \u201cHours\u201d co-star Meryl Streep\u2019s Golden Globes\u00a0 appeal to\u00a0\u201csafeguard the truth\u201d \u00a0during this political moment.\n\u201cI was trying to stress that I believe in democracy and the American Constitution, and it was that simple,\u201d she told Access Hollywood on Saturday.\u00a0\nWhen asked to comment further on the backlash, the Oscar-actress refused to elaborate on her stance. \u201cI\u2019m out of it now,\u201d she added. \u201cThat\u2019s what I said and it\u2019s that simple.\u201d\nSpeaking with the BBC in her initial interview, Kidman explained that she was \u201creticent to start commenting politically\u201d and prefers to keep her opinions about U.S. and Australian politics to herself. Kidman, who was born in Hawaii,\u00a0is a dual citizen of both countries.\u00a0\nHowever, the actress maintained that her passion for advocating for women\u2019s rights like the fight against ovarian and breast cancer remains resolute.\u00a0\n\u201cI\u2019m issue-based,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m very, very committed to women\u2019s issues.\u201d\nKidman is currently starring in \u201cLion,\u201d which is in theaters now.\u00a0\nAlso on HuffPost\n1 Celebrity Photos: December 2016\nMichael Simon\n2 Celebrity Photos: December 2016\nMichael Simon\n3 Celebrity Photos: December [["name", "new_7/1292.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/toby-keith-donald-trump-inauguration-concert_us_587bb96be4b0b3c7a7b1db20?ir=Entertainment"], ["text", "Toby Keith Won't Apologize For Performing At Donald Trump's Inauguration Celebration\nThe country star stands by his decision to play at the event.\n01/15/2017 02:33 pm ET\n6.1k\nJulia Brucculieri Entertainment Writer, The Huffington Post\nCountry music star Toby Keith will perform \u00a0at Donald Trump\u2019s \u201cMake America Great Again! Welcome Celebration\u201d concert on Jan. 19 (the eve of Inauguration Day), and he isn\u2019t sorry about it one bit.\u00a0\n\u201c I don\u2019t apologize for performing for our country or military,\u201d Keith said in a statement to Entertainment Weekly, after hearing some criticism for his decision. \u201cI performed at events for previous presidents [George W.] Bush and [Barack] Obama and over 200 shows in Iraq and Afghanistan for the USO.\u201d\nKeith will be joined at the celebratory concert by 3 Doors Down,\u00a0Lee Greenwood, The Piano Guys and the Frontmen of Country, according to an announcement posted on the\u00a0 Presidential Inaugural Committee site .\nBroadway star Jennifer Holliday was also slated to perform but backed out . On Saturday, in a letter published by The Wrap, Holliday apologized to the LGBTQ community for agreeing to perform in the first place, calling the initial decision a \u201clapse of judgement.\u201d\nA handful of other celebrities, including Welsh singer Charlotte Church , have also turned down invitations to perform at any of Trump\u2019s inaugural celebrations.\nRebecca Ferguson, Season 7 runner-up of the British \u201cX Factor,\u201d said she would only perform if she could sing the song \u201cStrange Fruit,\u201d which she said \u201cspeaks to all the disregarded and down trodden black people in the United States.\u201d\u00a0\nMeanwhile, \u201cAmerica\u2019s Got Talent\u201d star Jackie Evancho will be performing \u00a0at the inauguration ceremony on Jan. 20.\u00a0\nAlso on HuffPost\nPresidential Inaugurations Over The Years\nPresidential Inaugurations Over The Years\n1\nof\n50\nA painting depicting the inauguration of George Washington as the first president of the United States in 1789.\nShare this slide:\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1312.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/greatest-show-on-earth-shutting-down-after-146-years_us_587afc04e4b0e58057ff3e90?ir=Entertainment"], ["text", "'Greatest Show On Earth' Shutting Down After 146 Years\nHigh costs, falling ticket sales and animals rights battles have brought down the curtain.\n01/15/2017 12:58 am ET | Updated 18 hours ago\n3.1k\nMary Papenfuss Trends reporter, The Huffington Post\nGustavo Caballero/Getty Images\nDeath-defying bicycle stunts highlight a circus performance of the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey this week in Miami.\nRingling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus is permanently closing \u201cThe Greatest Show on Earth\u201d in May after 146 years entertaining millions of Americans.\nThe iconic razzmatazz under the big top was felled by dropping attendance,\u00a0high operating costs, fickle public tastes and battles with animal rights activists.\u00a0\n\u201cI have made the difficult business decision that Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey will hold its final performances in May of this year,\u201d circus CEO Kenneth Feld of Feld Entertainment\u00a0 said in a statement .\n\u201cThe circus and its people have continually been a source of inspiration and joy to my family and me, which is why this was such a tough business decision to make. We are extremely grateful to the millions of families who have made Ringling Bros. part of their lives for generations.\u201d\n. @RinglingBros will hold its final performances in May of this year. Details: https://t.co/Z4iQLxI0Sh #RinglingBros\n\u2014 Ringling Bros. (@RinglingBros) January 15, 2017\nLast year, the circus retired its elephants to its conservation farm in Florida amid continuing protests about animals in the show. But once the elephants were gone, the demand for tickets dropped even more dramatically, according to Feld.\nCompany officials told workers Saturday night after shows in Orlando and Miami.\nRingling Bros. has two touring circuses that will perform 30 shows between now and May. Stops will include Atlanta, Philadelphia, Boston, Brooklyn and Washington, D.C. The final shows will be in Providence, Rhode Island, on May 7 and in Uniondale, New York, at the Nassau County Coliseum on May 21.\nGustavo Caballero/Getty Images\nNot so happy any longer. Workers in Miami were told Saturday night that the show is closing forever in May.\nIt\u2019s been a long, colorful road of clowns, trapeze artists in sparkly spandex, dancing elephants and surly tigers. Phineas Taylor Barnum went on the road in the mid-1800s with his traveling spectacle of animals and human oddities, and the five Ringling brothers began performing juggling acts and skits from their home base in Baraboo, Wisconsin, in 1884. They merged in 1919 to tour together as \u201cThe Greatest Show on Earth.\u201d The Ringling family ran the circus until 1967 then sold it to Feld Entertainment.\nTechnology brought competition from movies and TV, video games and the internet, and animal activists and members of the public became increasingly concerned about treatment of the animals on the road and in the acts.\n\u201cThe competitor in many ways is time ,\u201d Feld told The Associated Press, adding that transporting the show by rail and other circus quirks \u2014 such as providing a traveling school for performers\u2019 children \u2014 are throwbacks to another era that couldn\u2019t compete with modern fare. \u201cIt\u2019s a different model that we can\u2019t see how it works in today\u2019s world to justify and maintain an affordable ticket price. So you\u2019ve got all these things working against it.\u201d\nThe Felds say their existing animals \u2014 lions, tigers, camels, donkeys, alpacas, kangaroos and llamas \u2014 will go to suitable homes. Feld\u2019s daughter, Chief Operating Officer Juliette Feld, said the company will continue operating the Center for Elephant Conservation.\nFeld Entertainment will also continue to produce its other, profitable, shows\u2014 Monster Jam, Disney on Ice and Marvel Live\u00a0\u2014 and will attempt to place some circus workers in those operations.\n\u00a0\nCORRECTION: An earlier version of this post misstated that the Ringling brothers began performing in Wisconsin in 1984. They began in 1884.\nRelated Coverage\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1320.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/new-jersey/governor/2017/01/15/guadagno-launch-campaign-governor-tuesday/96615218/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nGuadagno to launch campaign for governor on Tuesday\nThe lieutenant governor, who filed the papers last week, will declare her candidacy for the Republican Party nomination at 11 a.m.\nPost to Facebook\nGuadagno to launch campaign for governor on Tuesday The lieutenant governor, who filed the papers last week, will declare her candidacy for the Republican Party nomination at 11 a.m. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2iA6d6v\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n1\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nGuadagno to launch campaign for governor on Tuesday\nDustin Racioppi , State House Bureau, @dracioppi Published 2:13 p.m. ET Jan. 15, 2017 | Updated 11 hours ago\nLt. Gov. Kim Guadagno\n(Photo: File photo)\nLt. Gov. Kim Guadagno will formally launch her campaign for governor Tuesday in Monmouth County, according to sources familiar with the planning.\nGuadagno, who filed paperwork to run for governor last week, will declare her candidacy for the Republican Party nomination at 11 a.m. at La Playa, a waterfront Mexican restaurant in Keansburg, the sources said.\nGuadagno, who lives in nearby Monmouth Beach, has spent the last seven years working mostly in the shadow of Governor Christie. As the state's first lieutenant governor, she was charged with cutting red tape and economic growth. She also serves as secretary of state.\nGubernatorial candidates start 2017 sparring in primary race\nMuch of Guadagno's tenure has been spent traveling the state to welcome new businesses or meeting with companies to bring them to New Jersey \u00e2\u0080\u0093\u00c2\u00a0or keep them from leaving. She is known for her personal touch with business leaders, often giving out her cell phone number and giving them a direct line to the State House.\nAlthough she has low name recognition with most voters, according to polls, she is among the most recognized in the field of candidates in both parties. Guadagno will enter the race with significant support from about three dozen lawmakers and party leaders and has the advantage of having served as one of the top elected officials in the state.\nIn the party primary, Guadagno will compete for the nomination against Assemblyman Jack Ciattarelli of Somerset County, Nutley Commissioner Steve Rogers and Ocean County business man Joseph Rullo.\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2iA6d6v\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1328.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/entertainment/movies/2017/01/15/geremy-jasper-story-underdog-jersey-girl/96456202/"], ["text", "Hillsdale's Geremy Jasper at Sundance with story of underdog Jersey girl\nKara Yorio , Staff Writer, @karayorio 7:32 p.m. ET Jan. 15, 2017\nHillsdale native Geremy Jasper is bringing \"Patti Cake$\" to Sundance Film Festival. Wochit\nPoster for Hillsdale native Geremy Jasper's \"Patti Cake$.\"\n(Photo: Jeong Park)\nPatricia Dombrowski is an aspiring rapper from New Jersey, a woman in a male-dominated industry on a journey to find her artistic voice. The lead character in Hillsdale native Geremy Jasper\u2019s feature film debut \u201cPatti Cake$\u201d breaks the mold of what a rapper is and could be, according to Jasper. It\u2019s no laughable fish-out-of-water story.\n\u201cThe film isn\u2019t like \u2018Oh, isn\u2019t it funny that this Jersey girl wants to be a rapper too?\u2019\u201d said the Pascack Valley High School graduate, who wrote and directed the film and created the original music. \u201cIt\u2019s not that at all. It\u2019s like \u2018Wow, she's really good.\u2019 The film is about a real poet, or artist, who doesn\u2019t really know that\u2019s who she is but is finding her voice throughout this huge, surreal adventure that she goes on.\u201d\n\u201cPatti Cake$\u201d is being hailed as a film to watch at Robert Redford\u2019s influential\u00a0Sundance Film Festival, which opens in Park City, Utah, on Thursday. Jasper was named one of the 10 directors to watch this year by Variety, and the film is getting a lot of buzz.\nTV:\u00a0West Milford HS grad to star in TV's 'Street Science'\nThe week before the festival, Trevor Groth, its director of programming, told the Park Record newspaper of Park City\u00a0that he expects \u201cPatti Cake$\u201d and its title character, played by Australian actress Danielle Macdonald,\u00a0to be one of the highlights.\n\u201cShe\u2019s really such a singular character that you haven\u2019t seen on film before,\u201d Groth said. \u201cYou just fall in love with her and root for her.\u201d\nThe longshot from the Garden State is in good company.\n\u201cI feel like Patti is [part of] a long lineage of underdog N.J. musicians,\u201d he said before listing many, including Frank Sinatra, Bruce Springsteen, Patti Smith and Naughty by Nature. \u201cAnd now Patti Dombrowski.\u201d\nHillsdale native Geremy Jasper says his film \"Patti Cake$\" reflects his growing up in a family that modeled and valued strong, independent women.\n\u00a0(Photo: Jeremiah Zagar)\nThe film premieres on Jan.\u00a023. Later that week, Jasper will be part of a Sundance panel discussion entitled \u201cAre We All the Other: Transcending Boundaries in Storytelling,\u201d about \u201ctraversing boundaries of genre, gender, race\u00a0and class in creating their work.\u201d It is presented by Women at Sundance and the Sundance Institute Diversity Initiatives.\nFor Jasper, though, writing a strong female character wasn\u2019t a stretch. \u00a0He grew up in a family that modeled and valued strong, independent women.\n\u201cIt\u2019s a family basically of all guys except for my mother [Lois], who is a very strong, very, very cool lady,\u201d he said. \u00a0\u201cShe\u2019s got a very strong personality and she doesn\u2019t take any crap from anybody and definitely knows who she is.\u201d\nHis dad, Jeff, concurs.\n\u201cShe\u2019s a feminist from whenever,\u201d said Jeff, known to local sports fans as the highly successful\u00a0longtime coach of the Pascack Valley High School girls basketball team. \u201cShe\u2019s just that kind of woman. Independent. Opinionated.\u00a0My mother was like that. My wife is exactly like that. I coach my team, and always have, exactly the same way. They\u2019re just great athletes, who happen to be girls, playing basketball.\u201d\nIt was not only Lois, but also Jeff\u2019s players who influenced Geremy.\n\u201cBeing raised around these female athletes from the time that I was born, they were always sort of a phenomenon growing up and were my heroes growing up\u00a0\u2013\u00a0all the players on my dad\u2019s team(s),\u201d Geremy Jasper said.\n\u201cI think that had a big influence on why writing a film about someone like Patti just came so naturally to me and was interesting to me. You think of hip-hop as a male-dominated art form, genre, you would say the same thing about basketball, at least back in the day. It\u2019s changed a lot now thanks to people like my dad.\u201d\nJasper with his dad, Jeff.\n\u00a0(Photo: Courtesy of Jeff Jasper)\nJasper grew up around sports but also with a love of cartooning and music. Some might think that to be an arts-obsessed kid in a sports-centric family would be difficult, but that\u2019s not how it was with the Jaspers.\n\u201cIt was cool,\u201d he said. \u201cMy parents are pretty amazing. They were always supportive of what I wanted to do and what my interests were. So there was never much, never much rebelling I could do. I could be pretty wild in my day, but it didn\u2019t really faze them as long as I wasn\u2019t being nasty.\u201d\nHe found rap and hip-hop in elementary school and became obsessed, by his own admission, trying to spit out his own rhymes in the fifth grade talent show. Later, his act would get slightly more controversial.\n\u201cIt was the '90s, so I was wearing my mom\u2019s dresses onstage, then I would take it off and be in my underwear,\u201d he said. \u201cWe got thrown off the stage and I got in a lot of trouble with the vice principal and there was a lot of controversy. But [my parents] were always cool and knew that I was the eccentric one in the family and that the Jaspers have a long line of eccentrics in the family tree, so they knew how to deal with me.\u201d\nJasper with his mom, Lois.\n\u00a0(Photo: Courtesy of Jeff Jasper)\nSaid Jeff, \u201cDid he cross the line maybe on occasion? I think his mother would say he did. I\u2019m going to say he probably never did. He\u2019s been a sense of joy forever.\u201d\nGeremy was an athlete too, though. All-county football and quite a good basketball player in his own right, his dad points out. But after his junior year, he decided he wanted to stop playing basketball.\n\u201cNow, you can imagine how that could play in my life,\u201d the elder Jasper said, laughing.\nLois, whom the son told first, told him to go have the conversation with his dad.\n\u201cHe was so prepared,\u201d said Jeff. \u201cCertainly I wasn\u2019t going to stop him, but I did want to know what was his substitute, what was he going to do. He said, \u2018I\u2019ve got my music.\u00a0I\u2019ve got the band. I\u2019ve got ideas. I need to write and to read.\u2019 I was like, \u2018Wow, that\u2019s a lot better.\u2019\n\u201cHe always had a vision. He always had a path, and he was willing to work for it.\u201d\nAll these years later, Geremy, now 41, is still working hard to bring his visions to fruition and is getting quite a bit of attention for it. He has played in bands, recorded, toured and now found a love for film and throwing himself into it as he has everything else along the way.\n\u201cAs you could imagine, I can\u2019t be prouder of what he\u2019s done,\u201d Jeff Jasper said. \u201cHe had his dream and he just pursued it, so that\u2019s the thing to me that makes me just really stand up and take notice of him. It\u2019s not the accolades that have come or the fact that all these other people, the critics or whoever, they think that he\u2019s incredibly talented. We know he\u2019s always been talented.\u201d\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1364.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/columnists/mike-kelly/2017/01/12/kelly-why-trumps-latest-dilemma-crisis-journalism/96511178/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nKelly: Why Trump's latest dilemma is a crisis for journalism\nA decade ago, I knew a highly respected journalist with a long list of awards, including a Pulitzer Prize, who abruptly switched careers.\nPost to Facebook\nKelly: Why Trump's latest dilemma is a crisis for journalism A decade ago, I knew a highly respected journalist with a long list of awards, including a Pulitzer Prize, who abruptly switched careers. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2ipUWW8\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n5\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nKelly: Why Trump's latest dilemma is a crisis for journalism\nMike Kelly , Record Columnist, @MikeKellyColumn Published 7:47 p.m. ET Jan. 12, 2017 | Updated 13 hours ago\nMike Kelly\n(Photo: .)\nA decade ago, I knew a highly respected journalist with a long list of awards, including a Pulitzer Prize, who abruptly switched careers.\u00a0He left the newspaper where he built his sterling reputation as an investigative reporter and stepped into politics.\u00a0But he did not run for office.\u00a0Nor did he leave his investigative talents behind.\nThis former investigative reporter became a political operative. His mission:\u00a0to conduct what has come to be known as \u201copposition research\u201d \u2013 collecting unflattering or embarrassing information on opponents.\nHe doubled his salary. In case you wondered.\nI thought of this career switch in the wake of the recent revelations of salacious and unverified reports that President-elect Donald Trump supposedly cavorted with prostitutes in Russia and also engaged in real estate deals that could have been perceived as bribes.\u00a0The man behind these revelations is another former journalist who made the same career switch as the investigative reporter I knew. He became an opposition researcher. He was paid handsomely.\u00a0They all are.\nUSA TODAY:\u00a0 Trump team ponders changes for White House press corps\nThe information about Trump \u2013\u00a0while never verified, and denied extensively and forcefully by the president-elect and his aides \u2013\u00a0was nevertheless deemed so important by U.S. intelligence officials \u2013 including the heads of the CIA, the FBI and the National Security Agency \u2013\u00a0that it was included in recent briefings with Trump and President Barack Obama.\u00a0It did not matter that this information might be false. Truthful or not, the intelligence chiefs felt it had taken on a life of its own and could place Trump in a compromised position in future dealings with foreign nations, especially Russia.\nKeep in mind that intelligence briefings with presidents \u2013 and president-elects \u2013 are not supposed to be gossip sessions.\u00a0They are designed to focus on deeply serious matters such as specific terrorist threats to America, the latest nuclear gambit by North Korea, or suspicious activity by Iran, China or other nations that\u00a0yearn to flex their muscles.\u00a0This may be the first time in U.S. history that American spy chiefs found themselves assessing the threat level of Russian prostitutes. Somewhere, James Bond must be laughing.\nConsider the larger context, though. With U.S. intelligence agencies already finding conclusive proof that Russia was behind a Bond-like scheme to hack into the computers of the Democratic National Committee and disrupt the 2016 presidential election, you can understand why American officials might be concerned about these additional revelations, even if they had not been proved. Like it or not, we now live in a world where fact and fiction co-exist on the Internet and \u201cfake news\u201d is now part of America\u2019s political dialogue.\nBut an uncomfortable question lurked on the fringes of this latest story:\u00a0How did these allegations first surface?\nThe answer is disturbing.\u00a0A former journalist for The\u00a0Wall Street Journal, with substantial credentials as an investigative reporter, had switched careers \u2013 just like the journalist I knew \u2013 and was now running a high-priced private firm that specialized in \u201copposition research.\u201d\nThe firm was hired by wealthy Republicans to dig up dirt on Trump \u2013 and came up with the story of the Russian prostitutes.\u00a0Later, with all sorts of warning flags about its lack of verification, the story was passed\u00a0to Democrats and the Hillary Clinton campaign. It was then circulated widely among journalists who covered Washington and the presidential campaign.\nIn other words, this information \u2013 truthful or not \u2013 was essentially passed into the public sphere.\u00a0 Just like high school gossip, it was only a matter of time before it leaked to a wider audience.\nThere are many additional details to this story \u2013 for instance, the role of a former British spy with extensive contacts in Russia who was hired to\u00a0help the former-Journal-reporter-turned-opposition-researcher find compromising information about Trump.\u00a0But let\u2019s return to the chief foot soldier in this caper \u2013 the former journalist and what his career switch means for the media as a whole.\nWhat was his motive?\u00a0And what sort of ethical lines did he draw when he left journalism but took his investigative skills into politics?\nI\u2019ve been lucky.\u00a0I never really wanted to be anything besides a journalist and storyteller.\u00a0I also know, however, that some of the same journalistic skills that I take for granted in shaping the stories I write could be seen as extremely valuable in other fields, commanding perhaps a ridiculously high salary.\nI know, for instance, how to search public records \u2013 how to find all manner of information that most people prefer to remain hidden, such as arrest records, college grades and unlisted phone numbers.\u00a0Hearing once how I tracked the whereabouts of a fugitive who had eluded law enforcement officials for years, a former FBI agent said, \u201cYou should have been a cop.\u201d\nI laughed heartily.\u00a0Me with a gun and handcuffs?\u00a0No way.\u00a0But the point is that journalists often develop the same skills used by all manner of investigators, including those who catch crooks.\u00a0In modern politics, with its reliance on negative TV advertising and opposition research, those skills translate into big paychecks.\nNow those skills are at the root of the latest crisis in journalism \u2013 and politics.\nTrump and his allies have accused some of America\u2019s most notable media outlets of irresponsibly reporting the unproven and deeply salacious claims about Trump and Moscow prostitutes.\u00a0Whether this becomes a political crisis remains to be seen.\u00a0Like it or not, it\u2019s already a crisis for journalism and, more broadly, how America traffics in information now.\nFor journalists, however, the questions strike at some of our most basic pillars. How do we remain credible as responsible storytellers\u00a0if we can easily switch careers and slip into the big-bucks world of opposition research?\u00a0As journalists, we continually remind ourselves of our ethical stake in trying to verify what we report.\u00a0We\u2019re not perfect \u2013 certainly, this columnist has made his share of mistakes. But the standards are clear, especially at The Record and most other news organizations.\u00a0If you knowingly traffic in false information \u2013 or invent facts \u2013 you will likely get fired.\u00a0On the spot. Think of it as a summary execution on a battlefield.\nWhat about opposition research that routinely traffics falsehoods and invented facts?\u00a0No one has been fired yet for the latest allegations about Trump.\u00a0Don\u2019t hold your breath.\nI\u2019m not a fan of Trump.\u00a0Regular readers of this column should know that.\u00a0But fair is fair.\u00a0And as I watched him conduct a surreal news conference in which he juggled pronouncements about serious national policy issues such as health care with the allegations about the Russian prostitutes, I wondered what sort of presidency he had inherited \u2013 and, frankly, what it meant for America.\nTrump is hardly innocent.\u00a0Remember the recording of him bragging about groping women?\u00a0Or the radio interview in which he chortled about his daughter\u2019s body?\u00a0Or those tabloid headlines years ago about his alleged sexual prowess? The man walks a dangerous line.\nSurely\u00a0many Trump critics are cheering this latest dilemma for him. But just think back to the false allegations against Hillary Clinton, and you\u2019ll see the danger of cheering when your side wins and complaining when you lose.\nTruth inspires and uplifts.\nLies drag us all down.\nJournalism needs to remind itself of its better angels \u2013 and the right path.\u00a0It needs to do this soon.\nEmail Mike Kelly at:\u00a0 kellym@northjersey.com\nTwitter:\u00a0@MikeKellyColumn\nPresident-elect Donald Trump speaks during a news conference in the lobby of Trump Tower in New York on Wednesday.\n\u00a0(Photo: Evan Vucci/AP)\n21 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 5 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2ipUWW8\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1366.html"], ["url", "http://www.usatoday.com/videos/news/nation-now/2017/01/13/naked-woman-steals-police-truck/96545372/"], ["text", "Naked woman steals police truck\nAs a police officer seeks to help a distraught, naked woman, she steals his truck.\nPost to Facebook\nNaked woman steals police truck As a police officer seeks to help a distraught, naked woman, she steals his truck. [["name", "new_7/1383.html"], ["url", "http://m.huffpost.com/us/entry/us_587baa63e4b0b3c7a7b1d6cf/amp?ir=Entertainment"], ["text", "Mark Ruffalo, Michael Moore And More Celebrities To Lead Anti-Trump Rally In New York\nThe event is scheduled to take place on the eve of Trump's inauguration.\n14 hours ago\nAndrew Toth via Getty Images\nMark Ruffalo, Michael Moore and other celebrities will lead an anti-Trump rally in NYC this week.\u00a0\nMark Ruffalo , Michael Moore , Alec Baldwin and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio , among other high-profile figures, will lead an anti-Donald Trump rally on the eve of the president-elect\u2019s inauguration, The Associated Press reports.\u00a0\nOrganizers told the AP that they\u2019re expecting thousands of people to attend the event in New York City, which is being put together by Greenpeace and activist organization MoveOn.\u00a0\nOn Saturday, Moore announced the news on Twitter, encouraging his followers to come to the event. According to his tweet, the rally will take place right in front of Trump International Hotel.\n\u201cWe are sending a message to Washington that we will fight, at every step, discrimination and harmful policies, today, tomorrow and every day,\u201d Ruffalo said in a statement obtained by the AP , adding that participants \u201care coming together to stand up for one another, as we will do every day, to protect the values we hold dear.\u201d\nMoore, Ruffalo and Baldwin have all been vocal about their opposition to Trump and his policies. The stars often use social media to speak out against the former \u201cApprentice\u201d host.\u00a0\nRuffalo also hit the streets in New York City to protest Trump\u2019s presidency after the election results were announced back in November.\u00a0\nAnd of course, Baldwin has been mocking Trump with his spot-on impression on \u201cSaturday Night Live.\u201d This weekend, the actor took on Trump\u2019s recent\u00a0 press conference \u00a0and talked about inauguration entertainment, golden showers and Trump\u2019s sons, \u201cBeavis\u201d and \u201cButthead.\u201d\nThe former \u201c30 Rock\u201d star also confirmed he\u2019ll be stepping back into Trump\u2019s shoes for \u201cSNL\u201d on the day after the inauguration .\nAlso on HuffPost\nPresidential Inaugurations Over The Years\n1\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1391.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/columnists/charles-stile/2017/01/15/christie-leans-left-nj-but-keeps-door-open-right/96561684/"], ["text", "Christie leans left in N.J. but keeps door open on right\nCharles Stile , Political Columnist, @PoliticalStile 6:04 a.m. ET Jan. 15, 2017\nThe case of two Chris Christies.\nGovernor Christie during last Tuesday's State of the State Speech, with Assembly Speaker Vincent Prieto, left, Speaker of the New Jersey General Assembly and Steve Sweeney, right. (AP Photo/Mel Evans)\n(Photo: Mel Evans, AP)\nIt was the week of two Chris Christies.\nOn Monday, the neo-liberal Chris Christie was back on the job, creating 20 new judgeships and signing off on their\u00a0$9.3 million tab. He praised\u00a0the state Judiciary that he once bashed as an unaccountable, elite enclave of liberal activism.\nOn Tuesday, in his State of the State speech, he called for an Obamcare-style health insurance mandate, praised the expansion of Medicaid\u00a0and vowed a crusade against the scourge of drug addiction.\nGOVERNOR:\u00a0Christie, silent in New Jersey, calls in to N.Y. sports radio to talk Cowboys and Trump\nBut on Wednesday morning, Christie swerved to the right. He was back in 2016 presidential campaign mode, on the couch at \u201cFox and Friends\u201d running damage control for President-elect Donald J. Trump, and defending Jeff Sessions, the attorney general nominee who has come under fierce criticism from the nation\u2019s largest civil rights groups.\n\u201cJeff Sessions is \u2026 a really, really good person who has a great career in public service and who I have complete confidence in as the backbone to do what\u2019s necessary as attorney general. All of the rest of this stuff is just theater,\u2019\u2019 Christie told the show hosts. \u201cHe\u2019s going to do a good job as attorney general.\u201d\nIt\u2019s the new duality of Chris Christie in his lame-duck year as governor. Christie appears to be trying to regain traction and redeem his credibility on the Jersey home front, treading down the center-left lane of Main Street, collaborating with and \u2013 at times\u00a0\u2013 backslapping the Democrats he once disdained.\nAnd then there is still the national Chris Christie, still trying to wedge his foot in the door of the new Trump administration, a door that appeared to be slammed in his face. On television last week, he cast himself as the stand-by-your-man loyalist, despite his reputation as a being a Party of One, a poor team player who is largely out for his own interest.\nChristie is well-regarded as a skilled political actor who knows how to play to the audience in front of him. But his split personality last week\u00a0reflects, to a certain extent, a new kind of career anxiety for the once-surefooted Christie. Not since his\u00a0first political career debacle \u2013 being bounced off the Morris County Board of Chosen Freeholders\u00a0after one tumultuous term \u2013 has Christe faced such an uncertain future.\nHe rebounded after that freeholder term, raising money for George W. Bush\u2019s campaign in 2000, for which Bush rewarded him by raising him out of the abyss, and naming him U.S. attorney for New Jersey, a job that would catapult him to prominence. From there, Christie carefully climbed to the State House\u00a0and, then, methodically set his sights on the White House.\nBut now\u00a0he\u2019s a lame duck, no longer one of the promising Republican stars cheered by the Koch brothers and celebrated by Henry Kissinger. He\u2019s a\u00a0scandal-scarred, sixth-place finisher in the 2016 contest, facing hostile glares from New Jersey residents who resented his absenteeism. After the November election, he was dumped from the Trump transition team and denied an escape from Trenton.\nGov. Chris Christie appears to be trying to work with a Democratic state and keep his hand in with the Trump administration, just in case.\n\u00a0(Photo: Kevin R. Wexler/NorthJersey.com)\nNow, at 54 years old, Christie might not be entirely sure where to go next.\n\u201cHe doesn\u2019t know where his political future lies, which is a first for him in 15 years, at least,\u2019\u2019 said Patrick Murray, director of the Monmouth University poll and a political analyst. \u201cHe has always been pretty certain what the trajectory [was] he was going to take. And that all collapsed beneath him.\u201d\nThe split personality was on full display during Christie\u2019s State of the State speech. The early part of the speech was a recitation of his conservative talking points \u2013 the cutting of 10,000 state jobs without layoffs, negotiating a one-cent cut in the sales tax while scuttling the tax on estates, and the expansion of charter schools under his watch.\nYet\u00a0he sharply veered to the left of center, boasting of his 2013 decision to accept the federal government\u2019s offer to vastly expand Medicaid, a cornerstone of President Barack Obama\u2019s Affordable Care Act, which Republicans in Congress are moving to repeal. He then called on legislative leaders to swiftly enact\u00a0a law mandating insurance companies to provide coverage for the first six months of drug treatment. Conservatives despise government mandates.\n\u201cMiddle-class families living the nightmare of addiction of a loved one do not deserve the double dose of agony \u2013 denial by an insurance company leading to the death of a loved one,\u2019\u2019 he said.\nAnd with his vow to spend his final year\u00a0in office crusading against the opioid epidemic \u2013 by creating a clearinghouse website, re-designating more treatment beds for young adults,\u00a0and expanding campus housing for students in recovery \u2013 Christie was embracing policies that liberal Democrats advocated more than a generation ago.\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1403.html"], ["url", "http://www.usatoday.com/videos/sports/2017/01/14/future-attendance-watch-russell-wilson-play-atlanta/96596058/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nFuture in attendance to watch Russell Wilson play in Atlanta\nAtlanta-based rapper Future was in attendance at the Georgia Dome on Saturday to perhaps troll Seahawks quarterback Russell Wilson, who is married to Future's ex-fiancee, Ciara.\nPost to Facebook\nFuture in attendance to watch Russell Wilson play in Atlanta Atlanta-based rapper Future was in attendance at the Georgia Dome on Saturday to perhaps troll Seahawks quarterback Russell Wilson, who is married to Future's ex-fiancee, Ciara. [["name", "new_7/1406.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/sports/columnists/bob-klapisch/2017/01/15/klapisch-cant-wait-clint-frazier-show/96621736/"], ["text", "Klapisch: I can't wait for the Clint Frazier show\nYankees' top prospect is brash and ready for prime time\nPost to Facebook\nKlapisch: I can't wait for the Clint Frazier show Yankees' top prospect is brash and ready for prime time Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jNZgMT\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nKlapisch: I can't wait for the Clint Frazier show\nBob Klapisch , Columnist, @BobKlap Published 8:56 p.m. ET Jan. 15, 2017 | Updated 7 hours ago\nClint Frazier.\n(Photo: associated press)\nEvery year before spring training I make a list of players who\u2019ve caught my attention and will be worth a closer look when camp opens. No. 1 on the current power rankings is Clint Frazier, the Yankees\u2019 can\u2019t-miss prospect who\u2019s blessed with bat speed, charisma and a Look At Me ego. The kid is ready to conquer the universe.\nFrazier recently spoke to the New York Post on a variety of subjects, including his excitement about becoming a Yankee (he was acquired in the deal that sent Andrew Miller to the Indians), the Stadium\u2019s short porch (Frazier bats righty with opposite-field power) and making a quick leap from Class-AAA (where he\u2019ll start the season) to the Bronx.\n\u201cI can\u2019t wait to pound the ball into those right-field seats,\u201d Frazier told the Post\u2019s Kevin Kernan. Bravo, I already love him. Frazier has the personality of a young Reggie and could be the face of the Yankees\u2019 renaissance in 2018.\nSo here we go.\n\u201cI play like my hair is on fire,\u201d Frazier said. \u201cIt\u2019s fiery, like my personality. It\u2019s big hair, and I try to make my personality big. I think it represents me because it\u2019s different, I\u2019m different, it\u2019s unique to who I am. It makes me one of a kind.\u2019\u2019\nKlapisch: What can the Mets expect from Matt Harvey?\nThe words, the urgency, jump out at you \u2014 clearly Frazier craves the attention. Hopefully he\u2019s smart enough to know hype isn\u2019t free. Tell the world you\u2019re ready to be great and you immediately become a target. Frazier better be ready to back it up, but one way or another his career arc will be fascinating.\nAnd here\u2019s another caveat Frazier will soon realize. The day he walks into the Yankees clubhouse he becomes part of Joe Girardi\u2019s matrix. The manager is as serious and corporate as Joe Maddon is hip. \"Watch what you say\" is the first lesson Girardi imparts to his younger players.\nJoe Girardi.\n\u00a0(Photo: associated press)\nGary Sanchez plays by those rules. So do Dellin Betances and Luis Severino. Frazier won\u2019t just have to cut his big red hair; he might have to lower the temperature on those quotes, as well. It\u2019s been a long time since any Yankee sounded like Reggie, which is why Frazier\u2019s new friendship with Jackson is too good to be true: One channels the other.\nMr. October mentored Frazier this fall during the Instructional League, cautioning him to cut down on his swing. Only 22, Frazier is prone to trying too hard. But scouts say the kid\u2019s power is real: He swatted 16 home runs in 463 at-bats at Class-AA and Class-AAA last year. GM Brian Cashman described Frazier\u2019s bat speed as \u201clegendary.\u201d\nThe downside? There were 122 strikeouts, more than one in every four at-bats, which Frazier will address in his first full season in the Yankees\u2019 organization. But he\u2019s already enjoying the attention.\nIn just the last few weeks Frazier has traded tweets with Bryce Harper about having to trim his hair, per Yankees rules. Frazier told Harper, \u201cit\u2019s worth it to one day wear those pinstripes my man #Roadto28.\u201d\nFrazier said he was referring to his own locks, not Harper\u2019s, but it nevertheless appeared he was recruiting the Nationals\u2019 slugger, who\u2019ll be a free agent after 2018. That\u2019s quite a conversation, considering Harper out-ranked Frazier in every way \u2014 performance, service time and star power.\nStill, I don\u2019t think Frazier intentionally overstepped his bounds. He\u2019s just refreshingly unafraid to engage. Good for him. Baseball needs more players who speak their minds. These days, by the time they\u2019ve worked their way through the farm system, most young stars have been turned into media-trained bots \u2014 they don't say or think anything that hasn\u2019t already been stamped into their frontal lobes.\nBut not Frazier. During the interview with the Post, Frazier said,\u00a0\u201cI do swing for the fences. I talk a big game, I better back it up soon. I think I know how to excite people. I made a joke on Twitter the other day that I am my own hype man, I don\u2019t need somebody else to hype me up. My competitive nature fuels me.\u201d\nThere was more.\n\u201cI know I can bring a lot to the table,\u201d Frazier said. \u201cI want my table to be full of polished parts.\u201d\nAnd this.\n\u201cThe mentality I bring to the game is \u2018I\u2019m going to get this done.\u2019 \u201d\nPrediction: This is going to be fun.\nBet the house on this, too: Girardi is already cringing.\nA last thought on Wally Backman\nMets fans seem divided on Backman\u2019s indictment of Sandy Alderson, whom he accused of blackballing his efforts to find a job in professional baseball in the U.S. Backman is headed to Mexico to manage in 2017, but only because he\u2019s sure the Mets\u2019 GM has sabotaged him within the industry.\nWhile I don\u2019t believe Alderson would go that far \u2014 and he certainly didn\u2019t call 29 other teams to denounce Backman \u2014 there\u2019s been enough bad-mouthing going on. It didn\u2019t have to come from Alderson, but other teams were still aware of the differences between the GM and Backman. The net effect has been the same.\nToo bad, because Backman\u2019s players have always sworn by him. He worked hard and was mostly successful in his seven years with the Mets. And despite his rogue past, Backman stayed out of trouble while in the Mets\u2019 employ.\nWhat doomed him was that 80s-era personality \u2014 raw and unfiltered \u2014 which always made Alderson uncomfortable. That shouldn\u2019t be enough to keep Backman out of work, though. He deserves better.\n"]]
