[["name", "new_7/1423.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/politics/2017/01/13/green-introducing-trump-tracker/96538234/"], ["text", "Green: Introducing the Trump Tracker\nRick Green, Editor Published 12:47 p.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017 | Updated 16 hours ago\nx\nShare\nNorthJersey.com and The Record are tracking 14 issues that impact North Jersey residents as the Trump presidency begins. Wochit\nRick Green, Editor of The Record\n(Photo: FILE)\nThe eyes of the world will be on Washington, D.C., on Friday\u00a0 when Donald J. Trump becomes the nation\u2019s 45th president.\nAfter a contentious campaign cycle and a post-election/pre-inauguration period that only can be described as intriguing, one fact is certain after noon next Friday: A new administration, touching the everyday lives of all Americans, rolls into action.\nHere\u2019s the question we are asking at The Record and NorthJersey.com: What effects will this new Trump administration have on the lives and livelihoods of New Jersey\u2019s residents, taxpayers, businesses \u2013 big and small \u2013 and its children?\nTo help answer that question, we have launched a four-year series we call \u201cTrump Tracker.\u201d We're rolling out the pieces of the series digitally in the days leading up to the inauguration.\nIts aim is simple: We will follow 14 issues critical to all corners of New Jersey that could be affected by the decisions, actions and efforts of President Trump\u2019s administration.\nRAIL:\u00a0Repairing, upgrading rail would impact thousands of commuters\nUsing government data, public records and other research from a wide array of experts and sources, it will measure changes and trends on health care, immigration, transportation, job creation, the military, New Jersey\u2019s political influence, energy and the environment, regulations, the Newark seaport, infrastructure, passenger rail, taxes, homeland security and the state\u2019s social safety net.\nWhy now, you may ask?\nObviously, a Trump White House comes at a momentous chapter in American history \u2013 with swirling questions about foreign alliances, national security and international hotspots, as well as an uncertain economy, climate change and the repeal and replacement of the Affordable Care Act. These (and others) are important areas that deserve close monitoring.\nIt also casts the appropriate spotlight not on Candidate Trump and the campaign\u2019s exhausting and controversial political gamesmanship, but on President Trump \u2013 his leadership, decisions and the actions of his administration.\nAdditionally, the tracker\u2019s debut coincides with the national conversation of \u201cfake news\u201d and readers\u2019 suspicion of reporters, not to mention President-elect Trump\u2019s tirades against many in the media. I view this series as smart, insightful and much-needed analysis that only an independent news organization can produce. It will be done in a fair, unbiased manner built around well-sourced data and expert analysis.\nThe presidency of Donald J. Trump undoubtedly will impact life for all who call New Jersey home \u2013 just as the exiting Obama administration and its predecessors did.\nI invite you to journey with us as we watch these next four years unfold and track how new, modified or discontinued policies affect all of us.\nThanks for reading The Record and North Jersey.com.\nRick Green is editor and vice president of news. He can be reached at green@northjersey.com. Follow him on Twitter at @NewJerseyRAG.\n164 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 5 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jF7TJw\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1425.html"], ["url", "http://archive.northjersey.com/opinion/opinion-guest-writers/still-unknown-why-was-ft-lee-mayor-targeted-1.1330664"], ["text", "Last updated: Sunday, May 10, 2015, 11:08 AM\nKelly: Still unknown: Why was Ft. Lee mayor targeted?\nBuy this photo\nCARMINE GALASSO / STAFF PHOTOGRPAHER\nFort Lee Mayor Mark Sokolich speaking outside city during a press conference Friday, May 1, 2015, after indictments were announced by the U.S. Attorney in the GWB investigation.\nBy Mike Kelly\nThe Record\nMike Kelly is a Record columnist. Contact him at kellym@northjersey.com.\nTHEY KEPT lists of names on computerized spreadsheets as if they were charting stock tips. They made phone calls after hours. They even consulted a lawyer to check whether they violated ethics rules.\nAn in-depth look at the scandal over the lane closures at the George Washington Bridge and related aftershocks. Click here to launch .\nThis was the heart of an intense political strategy within Governor Christie's 2013 reelection campaign \u2013 a none-too-subtle attempt to persuade Democratic political figures across the state to support the governor. Now that strategy figures as a prominent story line in the federal criminal charges against two key Christie allies in the George Washington Bridge traffic scandal.\nThe indictment, released nine days ago, charges that two key Christie allies \u2013 along with a third co-conspirator who has agreed to testify against them \u2013 wanted to punish the Democratic mayor of Fort Lee, Mark Sokolich, for his refusal to endorse Christie's Republican campaign.\nGWB scandal archive:\u00a0 Click here to read all of The Record's past coverage\nThis alleged punishment turned out to be paralyzing traffic gridlock that suddenly swamped Fort Lee for parts of five days in September 2013 \u2013 including the first day of school \u2013 when two of three access lanes from the borough's already crowded local streets to the George Washington Bridge were shut down without warning.\nWhat made him so important?\nThat story has been told over and over \u2013 and even joked about. But one question remains unresolved: Why did the Christie campaign seem so desperate to gain the support of Mayor Sokolich anyway? What made him so important to Christie's reelection? So much that he had to be punished?\nSokolich is hardly a Democratic power broker. Before the traffic scandal, he was barely known outside of his town and the largely Democratic wards of eastern Bergen County. What's more, Fort Lee is not exactly a Democratic machine capable of even tilting a countywide election, much less a statewide gubernatorial race.\nRoughly half of the borough's 36,000 residents are registered to vote. And only 41 percent are Democrats. Almost half list themselves as unaffiliated with any political party.\nIn 2009, in winning the governor's race, Christie lost Fort Lee by about 1,800 votes to the unpopular Democratic incumbent, Jon Corzine. But only about 8,000 Fort Lee voters \u2013 about 44 percent \u2013 bothered to go to the polls.\nSmall player in elections\nThe point here is that Fort Lee was not exactly voter-rich territory where a party's ward leader could order large blocks of voters to support one candidate or another \u2013 and thus affect a statewide election. So why would Christie's campaign staff four years later focus so much attention on obtaining an endorsement by the borough's mayor?\nThe overall strategy by the Christie reelection campaign was not only to win across the state by a wide margin in 2013 over the hapless Democratic challenger, Barbara Buono, but to demonstrate that Christie could attract plenty of bipartisan support. The idea here was not to prove anything significant to New Jersey's Republican leaders. They already knew Christie was a powerful candidate. The goal was to show the national Republican Party that Christie could attract a wide array of support, including Democrats. And if he could do this in a Democratic-leaning state like New Jersey, imagine what he could do if he ran for president.\nThat's an expansive strategy. And by Election Day, thanks to the efforts of Christie's campaign staff and their spreadsheets and after-work phone calls, 60 Democratic figures across New Jersey had publicly endorsed Christie for governor.\nIt wasn't a huge number of Democrats. But it was hardly small either.\nThis brings us back to the mystery of the courtship of Mark Sokolich. The federal indictments of the two Christie allies, William Baroni, the former deputy executive director of the Port Authority, and Bridget Anne Kelly, the former deputy chief of staff for the governor \u2013 as well as the plea agreement to testify against them from their alleged co-conspirator, Port Authority official David Wildstein \u2014 do not shed any light on why Sokolich was targeted for an endorsement and then punished for not coming through.\nSeeking endorsements\nThe indictment merely charges that Kelly (who is not related to this columnist) \"sought\" endorsements from Democratic officials and that several weeks before the traffic gridlock she conspired with Baroni and Wildstein to \"punish Mayor Sokolich by deliberately causing significant traffic problems in Fort Lee through a reduction in the number of the local access lanes \u2014 all under the false pretense of a traffic study.\"\nIt's worth noting that Kelly and Baroni emphatically deny that they concocted any such plan to punish Sokolich. The indictment claims, however, that Kelly sent the now-famous \"time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee\" email to Wildstein after allegedly confirming in mid-August 2013 that Sokolich turned down several overtures from Christie's campaign to endorse the governor.\nIf that scenario is true \u2013 and Kelly's lawyer says they intend to prove it's not \u2013 it still leaves open the question of why Sokolich was so important anyway. And why carry out such a harsh retribution by causing massive traffic jams?\nPunishment worsens\nAs traffic problems worsened in Fort Lee during those five gridlocked days in September 2013, so did the alleged punishment.\nAccording to the indictment, Baroni, Kelly and Wildstein reportedly agreed not to respond to Sokolich's calls for help to the Port Authority and to the governor's office. And in what turned out to be one of the more bizarre twists of the story, Wildstein derided Sokolich in an email as \"this little Serbian.\" In case anyone wonders, Sokolich is hardly little. Nor is he Serbian. He's 6-foot-3 and his ancestors come from Croatia.\nAgain, all this raises the question: Why all the fuss over poor Mark Sokolich?\nSokolich says he has no idea. He quips that he figured he would spend time \"dedicating Little League fields\" as the borough's mayor, not wondering why he is the target of an alleged political feud that seems to defy logic or even common sense.\nAdding to the mystery, he also claimed in an interview last year with this columnist that he was never asked point blank to endorse Christie, only that one of the governor's aides gently inquired on several occasions whether \"this was something\" he \"might consider.\" And perhaps just as significant, Sokolich said he was never threatened with retribution if he declined to endorse Christie.\nFinally, there is this: Christie ended up winning Fort Lee anyway. His margin was hardly a landslide \u2013 only about 800 votes.\nBut it was a victory nonetheless.\nTags:\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1429.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/watchdog/2017/01/07/gwb-guards-say-harsh-working-conditions-hurt-security/95346884/"], ["text", "x\nShare\nThe men and women employed as unarmed security guards at the George Washington Bridge, the busiest span in the world and a prime terror target that connects New Jersey and New York, say dangerous and unsanitary conditions threaten their work \u2014 and the bridge. Wochit\nA security booth at the foot of the George Washington Bridge on the New York side. Photographed in Fort Washington Park in December.\n(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\nOne guard was almost hit by a suicide jumper falling from 200 feet above.\nAnother was told to wear an adult diaper after complaining about working too far from a restroom.\nA third guard, working the night shift in a secluded park, locked herself in her booth because she felt threatened by a group of men loitering nearby.\nThose challenges and others are part of the daily routine, say the men and women employed as unarmed security guards to watch for and report suspicious activity at the George Washington Bridge, the busiest span in the world and a prime terror target that connects New Jersey and New York.\nAt a time when New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo warns about the \u201cgrowing threat\u201d of terrorism at the region\u2019s transportation and infrastructure assets, guards and security professionals say poor working conditions at the bridge\u00a0interfere with their job of keeping the region\u2019s commuters safe. A shooting that took the lives of several people\u00a0at the Fort Lauderdale airport in Florida on Friday put into stark relief the need to secure transportation facilities.\n\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\nWORKING CONDITIONS: Security guards at the George Washington Bridge say they have to relieve themselves in bottles, cups or even on the bridge itself\n\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0\nWith about 100 million vehicles crossing the George Washington Bridge\u00a0each year, if attackers were to disable or destroy it, millions of people would be forced to take detours of one hour or longer, putting additional strain on the region's existing bridges and tunnels. The effect could be devastating for the regional economy as well as for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which relies upon the bridge to generate a large share of its income. The agency projects operating income at the bridge this year of $633 million \u2014\u00a0more than 20 percent of its $3.1 billion operating budget.\nThe private security guards, who work for Summit Security Services, help to guard\u00a0the bridge not only from terrorist attacks, but also work to prevent suicides. Summit also has guards at the PATH rail system that links North Jersey with New York City, the Bayonne and Goethals bridges, the Holland Tunnel and several Port Authority office buildings. They number about 400 across all the Port Authority facilities.\nEight current and former guards at the bridge\u00a0\u2014\u00a0six men and two women \u2014\u00a0spoke to The Record on condition of anonymity, fearing retribution from Summit and, in some cases, from their own union. Some had worked in security all their lives. At least half worked at the bridge for more than five years. Several said that simply complaining to a supervisor is enough to provoke retaliation.\n\u201cYou complain and you lose your job,\u201d said one current guard.\nAmong their concerns:\nSecurity vehicles are poorly maintained and some equipment is faulty. Hand-held radios, for example, are sometimes held together with tape.\nUnlike police officers, who patrol in pairs, the guards said they are on their own, often patrolling unlit, secluded areas armed only with a radio to call for help.\nObjects, including people jumping from the bridge, sometimes fall near their guard booths or where they patrol.\nThe 30-square-foot security booths (about 5-by-6-feet) often lack proper heating in the winter or cooling in the summer.\nJohn Cohen, a former counter terrorism coordinator at the Department of Homeland Security, said that\u00a0having highly-trained police officers and well-equipped\u00a0security personnel at sites\u00a0is \u201ccritically important.\u201d\n\u201cThe value that comes from employing additional police officers and security personnel is in part influenced by how well they are trained, how qualified they are to be in those positions, how well they are equipped \u2014\u00a0and all that plays a role in ensuring that they are a productive part of the security apparatus used to protect locations like the George Washington Bridge.\u201d\nWorking conditions can hamper the ability of anyone - whether uniformed officer or security guard - tasked with protecting the public.\n\"It seems to me to be self-evident that if people's work conditions are horrible and degrading they tend not to be very good at the function they are assigned,\" said\u00a0Daniel Benjamin, a former State Department terrorism coordinator who hasn't assessed the situation at the bridge, but\u00a0spoke in general terms about the importance of keeping security personnel focused on their duties.\nThe guards earn between $32,000 and $35,000. Port Authority Police officers, by contrast, are among the highest paid in the region, with officers typically earning $108,000 after six years of service, in addition to generous benefits and a pension.\nStill, the unarmed guards are considered a critical part of security for the agency, said John Bilich, the agency\u2019s deputy chief security officer. While the higher-paid and better-trained police officers perform more demanding work, Bilich said the guards\u2019 principal role is to \u201cobserve and report.\u201d\nMaki Haberfeld, a professor of police science at John Jay College of Criminal Justice in New York City, said that because of a lack of resources, agencies often cut costs, particularly at infrastructure assets.\n\u201cI don\u2019t see them looking for the best equipped and the best trained security guards,\u201d Haberfeld said.\nHaberfeld, who trains New York Police Department officers in counterterrorism, said that the Port Authority puts most of its security resources into its airports, bus terminals and the PATH rail system.\nThat makes sense because these areas are highly trafficked by pedestrians and are perceived as softer targets than a bridge, which can be difficult to monitor as well as to escape from should a terrorist wish to do so. But, Haberfeld said, the very fact that the bridge does not receive the same amount of attention, makes it more vulnerable.\n\u201cI can assure you, if tomorrow there is an attack on a major bridge in London, you are going to see a major deployment on the George Washington Bridge,\u201d Haberfeld said. \u201cWe always react to the last war.\u201d\nIndeed, after Friday's attack in Ft. Lauderdale, security was increased at Port Authority airports, officials said.\nA security booth, at the bottom left of photo, sits at the foot of the George Washington Bridge on the New York side. Photographed in Fort Washington Park on Wednesday, December 14, 2016.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\nThe Port Authority\u2019s director of security operations, Mike DeGidio, said the agency has a vested interest in making sure guards are happy because it ensures that they perform their duties well. But DeGidio said the agency is unaware of any concerns about work conditions at the bridge.\nHe said that Summit meets frequently with Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union to talk about guards\u2019 work conditions.\n\u201cWe have not gotten any complaints or concerns about their safety,\u201d DeGidio said.\nThe guards told a different story.\nIn addition to fears of falling bodies and a lack of proper access to bathrooms, guards said that their vehicles were often in a state of poor repair. They cited dirty cars that would shut down without warning, vehicles driven with warning lights illuminated, and one vehicle in which the rubber top\u00a0on the brake pedal was missing making it easy for a person's foot to slip off the brake.\n\"I've never seen a company that is so reckless,\" said one veteran guard referring to Summit, a Long Island-based firm with revenues of $147 million in 2015, which calls itself\u00a0one of the largest privately held security contractors in the country. According to Summit's website, the firm provides security and investigative\u00a0services to hundreds of companies and government agencies across the country, including armed guard services\u00a0for the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and fraud investigations for state and city governments.\nAnother veteran guard, who was put in touch with The Record by his union to provide a counterpoint to the criticisms, did not deny the work environment at the bridge was difficult. But he said that his colleagues should stop complaining.\n\"I am a person who likes a challenge,\" he said.\nSecurity Challenge\nSince 9/11, the Port Authority has spent more than $1 billion shoring up its defenses. Annually, security accounts for almost one-quarter of the agency\u2019s operating budget. This year, security costs are expected to reach $707 million.\nThe agency employs 1,800 police officers who are supported by an additional 1,000 unarmed guards.\nAs terrorism shifts\u00a0towards a rise in attacks by people acting independently of terrorist organizations, private guards are becoming an increasingly important part of security.\n\u201cParts of our critical infrastructure, including seaports, airports and even bridges that have a high concentration of motor vehicle traffic\u00a0are all potential targets in this new age we find ourselves in,\u201d Cohen said.\nCohen, now a professor at Rutgers School of Criminal Justice, said traditional counterterrorism capabilities are not designed to detect this new brand of terrorist. So the role of police officers and private security guards becomes even more important.\nCohen said a highly visible security presence, including unarmed officers, can deter attackers conducting surveillance.\nBut the use of private contractors is not always successful.\nSummit\u2019s predecessors, FJC Security, lost a similar contract following several security slips, including employing an illegal immigrant\u00a0who had assumed a murdered man\u2019s identity, as a Newark airport supervisor, and allowing three parachutists to jump from the top of 1 World Trade Center.\nThis video was filmed by parachutists who jumped from 1 World Trade Center. The Record does not endorse and is not affiliated with nycbasejump.\nJust two months after Summit took over the contract, in May 2014, a thrill-seeking teenager from Weehawken got past several Summit guards and climbed to the top of 1 World Trade Center. In response, the Port Authority gave the trade center contract to another security firm and reduced Summit\u2019s contract by $37 million.\nAlthough private guards have had their share of lapses \u2014\u00a0two guards at the George Washington Bridge were fired in 2009 after being caught sleeping on the job \u2014\u00a0the Port Authority Police Department is not immune from criticism.\nLast month, the Port Authority filed disciplinary charges against one-third of the PATH rail system\u2019s police force \u2014 44 officers \u2014 who were accused of taking hours-long breaks when they were supposed to be patrolling stations.\nDaniel Sepulveda, Summit\u2019s vice president of security, declined to answer questions regarding when Summit began its work with the Port Authority, how many employees work for the agency or at the George Washington Bridge, or when the most recent contract was signed, citing \u201csafety and security\u201d reasons.\nRegarding working conditions cited by the guards, including concerns over falling objects and lack of bathroom access, Sepulveda said:\n\u201cThree years ago we were contacted by\u00a0[the Occupational Safety and Health Administration] because a claim was submitted at the GWB site. Summit cooperated fully with the investigation of the allegations, and the fine was substantially reduced. None of the conditions you refer to existed,\u00a0then or now.\u201d\nSepulveda also suggested that guards with complaints consult their collective bargaining agreement for answers.\nGuards, who pay about $60 a month in union dues, say that Local 32BJ has failed to protect them from harassment, deal with grievances quickly or take their complaints seriously. They say that it took the union about two years to resolve an issue over unpaid vacation from 2014.\n\u201cIt\u2019s like the Boston Tea Party,\u201d said one guard. \u201cYou are being taxed, but you have no representation.\u201d\nA security booth at the base to the right of the George Washington Bridge in New York.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\nOf the 48 guards who have worked the site over the last three years, 10 have been fired, according to a spokeswoman for Local 32BJ, who called the rate \u201cslightly above average.\u201d\nSix guards were reinstated after the union intervened.\nOne guard filed a charge against Local 32BJ with the National Labor Relations Board in December 2015, alleging that the union breached its duty of fair representation by failing to process grievances related to unused vacation pay, vehicle safety, harassment and overtime.\nThe NLRB dismissed the complaint in March 2016, finding that the union had taken some actions related to the complaints and that the guard failed to provide evidence that the union \u201cacted in an arbitrary and capricious manner.\u201d\nUnion official Kevin Brown, who helped unionize the guards about 10 years ago, denied many of the allegations, emphasizing that guards do not complain about pay and benefits because the union has helped them achieve better levels of both. The guards earn $17 an hour.\nBrown added that before the guards unionized there were no relief guards provided for bathroom breaks.\n\u201cWorkers had to [urinate] into a paper bag in the booth,\u201d Brown said. (A guard said Brown was only half right. He said that guards used paper bags for solid waste.)\n\u201cThe bottom line is this is still a good job and it wouldn\u2019t be a good job if it wasn\u2019t for all the things we\u2019ve done there,\u201d Brown said.\nThe union directed The Record to speak to a current guard at the bridge, who said some of his colleagues \u201cexaggerate a lot of things.\u201d\nThe guard, a longtime employee who did not wish to be identified because he, too, feared retaliation from Summit, said that people jumping off the bridge and landing in the parks is rare, happening only once a year at most.\n\u201cThe problem is,\u201d the guard added, \u201csome people, they complain for everything.\u201d\nOne female guard who spoke to The Record said she was sick of complaining.\nWhen she was regularly posted in a desolate spot during the 11 p.m. to 7 a.m. shift, she often called a Port Authority supervisor to report groups of men congregating in the park, which was supposed to be closed overnight.\nSometimes the supervisor would send out a Port Authority police patrol to check it out. But mostly, she said, she was left on her own.\nShe soon learned that when she saw a group of men overnight, the only thing to do was to lock herself in her booth and wait for them to leave. Sometimes, she waited hours before she could resume her patrols.\n\u201cI just don\u2019t feel safe,\u201d the security guard said.\nA security booth on the Hudson River at the foot of the George Washington Bridge on the New York side.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\n190 CONNECT TWEET 9 LINKEDIN 21 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jecZML\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/145.html"], ["url", "https://blackberryid.blackberry.com//bbid/login/?callbackuri=aHR0cHM6Ly9hcHB3b3JsZC5ibGFja2JlcnJ5LmNvbS93ZWJzdG9yZS9teXdvcmxkL3NlY3VyZS9sb2dpbi8%3D&authtype=d2Vic3RvcmU%3D&locale=ZW4%3D&userdata=dXJsPS9jb250ZW50LzE5MTQzLyZjb3VudHJ5Y29kZT1VUyZsYW5nPWVu"], ["text", "Sign In to BlackBerry ID\nTo access:\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1451.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/crime/2016/12/29/get-out-jail-free-criminal-justice-reform/95748196/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nGet out of jail free, or criminal justice reform?\nThe criminal justice system is in for a big change on Jan. 1, when judges will release the vast majority of defendants before trial.\nPost to Facebook\nGet out of jail free, or criminal justice reform? The criminal justice system is in for a big change on Jan. 1, when judges will release the vast majority of defendants before trial. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2hvLcZP\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n7\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nGet out of jail free, or criminal justice reform?\nJim Norman , Staff Writer Published 6:04 a.m. ET Dec. 29, 2016 | Updated 6:01 p.m. ET Dec. 29, 2016\n.\n(Photo: Getty Images)\nThe criminal justice system is in for a big change in New Jersey on Jan. 1. That\u2019s when \u00a0the state\u00a0will embark on a completely new way of dealing with people\u00a0charged with crimes, allowing the vast majority to remain free without having to pay\u00a0bail.\nAt the same time, new \u201cspeedy trial\u201d rules will take effect\u00a0with the goal of making\u00a0sure that prisoners who are kept in jail\u00a0don\u2019t languish there\u00a0for longer than six months before they're tried.\nIn 2014,\u00a0voters approved a change in\u00a0the state constitution to allow judges to deny\u00a0bail to\u00a0the most dangerous\u00a0defendants,\u00a0which means they will not be\u00a0released before\u00a0trial.\u00a0Previously, only those charged with crimes that could carry\u00a0death sentences\u00a0could be held in jail. The death penalty\u00a0was abolished in New Jersey in 2007.\nUnder the new rules, defendants who are charged with murder or a\u00a0crime punishable by life imprisonment are still held in jail. But the rules also give defendants the right to argue against\u00a0detention\u00a0if they can prove\u00a0that detention is not justified.\n\u201cWe\u2019ve got people waiting in jail for trial for minor offenses for over a year because they can\u2019t raise $2,500 bail,\u201d said one judge who asked to remain anonymous because of rules against speaking publicly,\u00a0\u201cand at the same time, we have defendants accused of serious crimes who have no trouble making even very high bail, and they are released.\u201d\nBudget impacts\nThe requirement for speedy trials will have a significant financial impact because\u00a0counties will have to pay for more prosecutors and sheriff\u2019s officers so that\u00a0legal proceedings can move more quickly. In Passaic County alone, according to one judge, two more judges and six more\u00a0sheriff\u2019s officers\u00a0will\u00a0have to be hired.\nREACTIONS: Read responses to bail reform\nIn addition, there will be a need to more quickly prepare pretrial risk assessments needed by judges to determine whom to release and whom to detain. And more pretrial services officers will have\u00a0to keep track of defendants who are\u00a0released while awaiting trial.\nJohn\u00a0Donnadio, the executive director of the New Jersey Association of Counties, which represents New Jersey\u2019s 21 county governments,\u00a0said it will take an estimated $45 million in\u00a0startup costs\u00a0for\u00a0counties\u00a0to comply\u00a0with the new rules.\n\u201cThere are some significant upfront costs we\u2019re looking at,\u201d\u00a0Donnadio\u00a0said. \u00a0\"The counties will need to hire new staff and pay for videoconferencing technology for the additional hearings. Additionally, they must shoulder the costs of keeping courthouses open on the weekends.\"\n\u201cWe support the concept of bail reform,\u201d he said. \u201cBut we\u2019re just looking for relief from the Legislature, whether from an appropriation or delaying the policy for a year so we can get a better handle on what the costs are.\u201d\nBut Ed Barocas, legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey, disagreed that the state was required to provide funding.\u00a0\"There is\u00a0a constitutional requirement for a speedy trial, and you can't avoid that by saying there's no funding,\" he said.\nBarocas also took issue with the failure of the new law to cover defendants who were charged before Jan. 1 and are already in jail awaiting trial.\n\"They have a constitutional right to a speedy trial as well, and they should be treated no differently than new defendants,\" he said. Barocas said the ACLU would work with public defenders to make certain that previously detained defendants are not left behind as new defendants move ahead of them because of the law.\nIn Passaic County, records show, 669 defendants were awaiting trial for more than a year as of October, though it was not immediately clear how many of them were in jail and how many were free.\nAlthough\u00a0it might look\u00a0on the face of it\u00a0as though counties might actually save money with fewer inmates to care for as they await trials, legal experts point out that initial savings will not be great because it will not be immediately possible to thin the ranks of corrections officers who staff the jails. \"There could be some savings on meals, but that's not significant,\" one judge said.\nInstead of bail, judges will make decisions on who gets freedom and who gets jail based on a three-part risk assessment\u00a0aimed at calculating the risk of flight, the risk of danger to the community and the risk that the accused will try\u00a0to interfere with justice by threatening witnesses or victims.\nEconomic implications\nThe new system is expected to hit the bail bond business especially hard, and people in that business have been lobbying hard against it.\nBail bondsman Kirk Shaw of Hackensack.\n\u00a0(Photo: Viorel Florescu/NorthJersey.com)\nKirk Shaw, who runs a bail bond business in Hackensack, said the new law would \u201ctake away 99 percent of the bail bond business.\u201d\n\u201cThis is not real risk assessment,\u201d Shaw added. \u201cThis is just wholesale release. They just want to do this no matter what.\u201d\nRichard Blender, a Paterson lawyer who has represented criminal defendants and bail bondsmen in 40 years of legal practice, said the new law was the result of a misguided assumption that the only reason a lot\u00a0of people are in jail before trial is because\u00a0they cannot afford bail.\nBlender proposed what he called a \"simple solution: just let those defendants out without bail. But the vast majority of defendants arrested in the state, for violent and serious offenses, many with prior criminal records, should have to post some sort of bail.\"\nInitially, assignment judges expect the new system\u00a0to put a strain on the judicial system. Statewide, it is anticipated that about 20 more judges will have to be appointed to take on the extra load. In addition to that, each newly appointed judge will have to have office space and a support staff, including a legal secretary and a law clerk, and will require a minimum of three county sheriff's officers to ensure\u00a0order in the courtroom.\nAdditionally, according to one judge, courts will have to be in operation on weekends\u00a0to meet the demands of the new rules that risk assessments and criminal complaints be filed within 48 hours after a defendant is first detained in a county jail.\nRelease criteria\nBut judges have been given an extensive list of procedures aimed at making sure they can properly assess the\u00a0risk of releasing\u00a0defendants while they await\u00a0trial.\nThe rules require a pretrial services program to make an assessment, considering\u00a0an arrested defendant\u2019s age, whether the offense\u00a0was violent, whether there have been prior convictions or pending charges,\u00a0whether there have been prior prison sentences and whether the defendant has failed\u00a0to make\u00a0court appearances.\nIf a defendant is released, under some circumstances it will be without conditions, according to the steps outlined in an 84-page directive from the state\u00a0Attorney\u00a0General\u2019s\u00a0Office.\nEven if detention might be\u00a0justified, there are several conditions that can be imposed to allow the defendant to avoid having to await trial behind bars. In less serious cases, the conditions could be as\u00a0simple\u00a0as once-a-month phone contact with a probation officer. In cases where the weight of the factors in the pretrial assessment add up against the defendant, the conditions could range from more frequent phone contact to face-to-face contact\u00a0to electronic monitoring to home detention.\nIn some cases, a judge can decide that the only way to ensure a defendant appears\u00a0in court is to require that\u00a0bail be paid, but those cases are expected to be few and far between, according to judges who asked that that their names be withheld because they are not permitted to speak publicly.\nA judge is not allowed to consider\u00a0race, gender, income, education, home address, history of drug use, family status, marital status, national origin, employment or religion in deciding whether to release a defendant before trial.\nThe\u00a0concept of judging such factors as previous prison sentences, offenses\u00a0and danger to the community, known as a PSA,\u00a0was developed by the Laura and John Arnold Foundation, a Texas-based research organization that studies issues raised by the criminal justice system.\u00a0\u00a0To create the assessment tool, the Arnold Foundation used a database of more than 1.5 million cases drawn from more than 300\u00a0jurisdictions across the country. According to the foundation, the standard is\u00a0being used in 29 jurisdictions, including three\u00a0states: Arizona, Kentucky, and \u2014\u00a0as of Jan. 1 \u2014\u00a0New Jersey.\nAnd if a defendant who is released while awaiting trial violates a condition of release or a restraining order, the judge can either make the conditions of release more stringent or \u2014\u00a0if the judge finds \"clear and convincing evidence\" that no condition of release would ensure the\u00a0defendant's appearance in court, \u00a0protect\u00a0the community\u00a0or that the defendant will attempt to obstruct the criminal justice system\u00a0\u2014 the judge can\u00a0order the defendant\u00a0await trial in jail.\nEmail: norman@northjersey.com\nBail reform and speedy trial: How they work\nNew bail reform and speedy trial rules effective: Jan 1.\nFirst appearance: For a summons (minor violation), within 60 days after arrest. For a warrant (criminal complaint), within 48 hours after arrest and commitment to county jail.\nExcept in unusual cases where nothing else will ensure\u00a0appearance in court, bail is a thing of the past.\nA defendant charged on a summons is released without bail. If the defendant is later arrested for failure\u00a0to appear, the judge must decide within 12 hours whether to release without any conditions\u00a0or release with bail. If the defendant can't post bail, a bail reduction hearing must be heard on an expedited basis.\nA defendant charged on a warrant: \u00a0Risk assessment forwarded to a judge, and the judge decides within 48 hours of arrest whether to release defendant or detain the defendant in jail to await trial.\nIf a criminal defendant is released, conditions can range from being freed on recognizance to being subject to varying levels of monitoring (weekly or monthly phone contact or face-to-face contact with probation officer, electronic monitoring, home detention).\nCriminal defendants are sent to county jail to await trial (with no possibility of bail) \u00a0in cases of:\nFirst or second degree No Early Release Act violations, like murder;\nCrimes punishable by life imprisonment;\nAny crime if defendant has been convicted before under either of the above;\nAny Megan's Law crime or human trafficking of a minor,\u00a0or a crime involving domestic violence;\nAny crime where there is a serious risk the defendant will not appear in court, will pose a danger to another person or will attempt to obstruct justice or threaten, injure or intimidate a witness or a juror.\nSpeedy trial rules apply only to defendants who are in jail awaiting trial. Time limits are: 90 days from detention to indictment; 180 days from indictment to start of trial. Extensions are possible, with an overall time limit of two years. Delays caused by defendants or their attorneys do not count toward the limits. If limits are reached, defendant is released to await trial, either on his own\u00a0recognizance or with conditions.\nNeither speedy trial rules nor bail reform rules apply to defendants who\u00a0were arrested before Jan. 1, 2017, and are awaiting trial\u00a0in county jail because they have not been able to make bail (but this may be subject to subsequent court challenge on constitutional grounds).\n573 CONNECT TWEET 36 LINKEDIN 7 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2hvLcZP\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1458.html"], ["url", "https://twitter.com/pdberger?lang=zh-tw"], ["text", "1\u67087\u65e5\nMatt Arco \u5df2\u8f49\u63a8 Paul Berger\n\"Another was told to wear an adult diaper after complaining about working too far from a restroom.\" https://twitter.com/pdberger/status/817729474330562564\u00a0\u2026\nMatt Arco \u5df2\u52a0\u5165\uff0c\nPaul Berger @pdberger\nGuards at the GWB say terrible work conditions hamper their job of protecting the world's busiest bridge: http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/watchdog/2017/01/07/gwb-guards-say-harsh-working-conditions-hurt-security/95346884/\u00a0\u2026\n1 replies 7 \u5247\u8f49\u63a8 2 \u500b\u559c\u6b61\n\u56de\u8986\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1461.html"], ["url", "http://archive.northjersey.com/news/unindicted-and-anonymous-names-of-possible-co-conspirators-in-gwb-case-could-come-out-at-trial-1.1330469"], ["text", "May 9, 2015, 10:53 PM\nLast updated: Sunday, May 10, 2015, 11:14 AM\n\u2018Unindicted\u2019 and anonymous: Names of possible co-conspirators in GWB case could come out at trial\nBuy this photo\nFile/Amy Newman /staff photographer\nA driver on Sept. 12, 2013, standing outside his car to assess the backup in traffic at the George Washington Bridge tollbooths in Fort Lee.\nBy SHAWN BOBURG\nstaff writer\u00a0|\u00a0\nThe Record\nWhen federal prosecutors charged three former allies of Governor Christie's with orchestrating vengeful lane closures at the George Washington Bridge, they created a series of looming questions: Who are the unidentified \u201cothers\u201d that court papers indicate were also involved in the conspiracy? Why weren\u2019t they charged too? Are they still working in government? And when, if ever, will their names be known?\nLegal experts say that, if the case goes to trial, there\u2019s a good chance prosecutors will have to reveal the identities of those \u201cunindicted co-conspirators,\u201d whom U.S. Attorney Paul Fishman has confirmed exist. And depending on who is on the list, the revelations could carry further political consequences for the Christie administration far beyond the courtroom.\nAn in-depth look at the scandal over the lane closures at the George Washington Bridge and related aftershocks. Click here to launch .\nMarko Georgiev /staff photographer\nU.S. Attorney Paul Fishmanbut wouldn't say who.\nThey could also play into the defense strategy of Bill Baroni, former deputy executive director at the Port Authority, and Christie\u2019s former deputy chief of staff, Bridget Anne Kelly, both of whom have pleaded not guilty to charges that they purposely caused traffic jams in Fort Lee in September 2013 to get back at the borough\u2019s mayor for not endorsing Christie. Another former Port Authority official, David Wildstein, has pleaded guilty.\nKelly said in her first public remarks that it would be \u201cludicrous\u201d to believe she was the only one in the governor\u2019s office who knew about the lane closings, suggesting she is being singled out. And Baroni\u2019s attorneys said they want to know who else the government believes is involved but decided not to charge.\nGWB scandal archive:\u00a0 Click here to read all of The Record's past coverage\n\u201cThe government will not prosecute Mr. Baroni in a vacuum,\u201d attorneys Michael Baldassare and Jennifer Mara said in a statement Thursday. Baroni \u201cwill use every means available to discover who the prosecution thinks was involved,\u201d the lawyers wrote, adding that their client is innocent.\nIt\u2019s not the first time the term \u201cunindicted co-conspirator\u201d has added intrigue to a political scandal. The term is used to describe someone whom prosecutors have \u201cprobable cause\u201d to believe was part of a conspiracy but whom they declined to charge.\nPresident Richard Nixon was tagged with that label in the Watergate investigation when seven administration officials were indicted by a grand jury in 1974. Prosecutors investigating the Whitewater controversy in Arkansas in the mid-1990s described a White House deputy counsel under President Bill Clinton that way.\nIn the indictment unsealed on May 1, Fishman offered few clues about the statement that \u201cothers\u201d beyond those charged were involved in the scheme.\nTwo separate inquiries into the closures \u2014 one by the Democratic-led state Legislature and another commissioned by Christie, a Republican \u2014 have generated any number of candidates. In the wake of the lane closures, several people in the administration and at the Port Authority, which controls the bridge, repeated what prosecutors now say was a \u201csham\u201d cover story: that the lane closures were part of a traffic study. The question is whether prosecutors have evidence that any of those people were aware of the sinister motivations that were allegedly behind the closings.\nAn attorney for Wildstein, who has agreed to be a witness, has said multiple times that \u201cevidence exists\u201d the governor was aware of the lane closures while they were in place. Christie has denied that and said he did not authorize the closures and was not involved in the planning or execution of them.\nWhen he pleaded guilty in federal court on May 1, Wildstein told a judge under oath that \u201cothers, including Baroni and Kelly,\u201d were involved in planning the lane closures in the month before they were put into effect.\nLater that day at a press conference announcing the indictments, Fishman declined to elaborate on who or how many others there were.\n\u201cThe indictment does say Bridget Kelly, Bill Baroni, David Wildstein and others,\u201d Fishman told reporters. \u201cWe don\u2019t identify unindicted co-conspirators in our indictment by name unless they have been previously mentioned in a publicly filed court document, and that is not the case here.\u201d\nReasons not to indict\nThere are a number of possible reasons prosecutors could decide to identify people as co-conspirators but not indict them.\n\u201cIt could be that they are a cooperating witness, it could be someone they don\u2019t have quite enough evidence on, or it could be someone they want to send a message to, that \u2018You might be next,\u2019\u0178\u201d said Michael Koenig, a former federal prosecutor specializing in white-collar crime for the Department of Justice and now a partner at the Albany, N.Y., law firm Hinckley Allen.\nDuring his press conference, Fishman stressed that he would only seek to indict someone he felt confident would be convicted at trial. And he acknowledged that the \u201cothers\u201d may be identified at a later stage in the case. A spokesman for Fishman said last week that prosecutors would reveal the \u201cunindicted co-conspirators\u201d if the judge overseeing the case issued an order to do so after a formal request by defense attorneys.\nThe identities of \u201cunindicted co-conspirators\u201d are typically shielded in the early stages of a criminal case, legal experts say. Department of Justice guidelines state that \u201cfederal prosecutors generally should not identify unindicted co-conspirators in conspiracy indictments.\u201d\n\u201cIt\u2019s universally considered unethical to name someone in an indictment who you aren\u2019t indicting, because you are smearing someone without giving them the opportunity to defend themselves,\u201d said Solomon L. Wisenberg, a partner in charge of the white-collar practice at the Washington, D.C., firm Nelson Mullins.\nIt wasn\u2019t always so. Prominent New Jersey defense attorney Joseph A. Hayden Jr. said that when he started practicing law in the early 1970s, it was customary for prosecutors to name names even if they weren\u2019t charged.\n\u201cHowever, that was very unfair to the named unindicted co-conspirator, who at times could never vindicate their name. So the courts have changed that,\u201d he said.\nThe shift occurred after a 1975 federal appellate court criticized a grand jury indictment that charged seven people \u2014 but also identified by name three others as unindicted co-conspirators\u00a0\u2014 in connection with political demonstrations at the Republican National Convention in Miami in 1972. The seven defendants were acquitted at trial. The appeals court later ordered the names of the three others removed from the indictment.\n\u201cHow would you or how would I or how would any around this room like to have the grand jury come in and name us as a co-conspirator and yet not indict us and give us no chance to be heard,\u201d the appellate judge asked rhetorically in the published opinion.\nSome indictments do include details that make it possible to identify the unindicted co-conspirators. \u201cBut the general rule would be to leave out that detail unless it was a necessary component of the charges against the individual,\u201d said Robert Mintz, a former federal prosecutor and now a partner at the firm McCarter & English in Newark.\nIf the case goes to trial, however, the information is typically turned over to those charged so they can defend themselves.\nDefense requests\nDefense attorneys typically make a formal request for the information in the lead-up to a trial. Some experts said they could see little reason in this case why a judge would not agree that the information should be turned over.\n\u201cThere are cases where witnesses and unindicted co-conspirators should be kept secret until the last moment, such as organized crime or gang cases,\u201d when individuals\u2019 safety may be at risk if they are exposed, said Koenig, the former federal prosecutor. \u201cGenerally, defendants should not have to guess or speculate what the evidence is or who the witnesses against them are, or who the unindicted co-conspirators are.\u201d\nWhether defense attorneys would make that public depends on if it fits into their strategy. The possibility of a wider conspiracy could help the defense, some said.\n\u201cWe may see defense lawyers trying to suggest that others may have been involved, either with or without their clients, in order to ultimately argue to jurors that prosecutors either charged the wrong people or in the alternative have unfairly singled out their clients for criminal conduct that involved a wider circle of co-conspirators,\u201d Mintz said.\nProsecutors may also have an interest in identifying unindicted co-conspirators at trial if they want to include as evidence statements any of those people made that establishes there was a conspiracy. Statements made outside the courtroom by people not involved in the conspiracy would be excluded as hearsay in a trial, Hayden said. But they would be admissible as evidence if prosecutors establish that the person who made the comments was an unindicted co-conspirator, he said.\nAnd in the event that revealing the unindicted co-conspirators does not figure into the strategy of either the prosecution or the defense?\n\u201cIt\u2019s more likely than not that it would never come out,\u201d Hayden said.\nEmail: boburg@northjersey.com\u00a0\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1466.html"], ["url", "http://www.usatoday.com/videos/news/world/2017/01/13/flight-666-makes-safe-friday-13th-landing-hel/96554790/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nFlight 666 makes safe Friday the 13th landing in HEL\nFinnair Flight 666 made it safely to it's destination but some creepy coincidences make for a great Friday-the-13th story. All you need is a little patience.\nA Short Puzzle to Test Your Memory\nBy JASMINE C. Can it work for you?\nTax Chains Try a Sweeter Pitch: No-Fee Loans\nBy STACY COWLEY\nAdvances from tax preparation companies now come with no interest and no fees, but consumer watchdogs remain wary.\nNew York Streets Are Seas of Black as Yellow Cabs Decline\nBy WINNIE HU\nFacing growing competition from ride-hailing apps, taxis are struggling to remain relevant to a generation of digital-minded New Yorkers.\nIn Texas, a Test of Whether Voting Act Still Has Teeth\nBy MANNY FERNANDEZ\nA judge put Pasadena under federal oversight after finding that it had discriminated against Latino voters. But an appeal is likely.\nA Camden Address With a Link to Martin Luther King Jr.\nBy ASHLEY ROSS\nJeanette Lilly Hunt, 85, said she considered the young \u201cM.L. [["name", "new_7/1470.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/new-york/2016/12/09/nyc-horse-drawn-carriages-draw-ire-activists-praise-tourists/95157048/"], ["text", "N.Y.C. horse-drawn carriages draw ire, praise\nBeneath the towering equine statues marking Central Park's southern entrance, the city's carriage horses stand calmly.\nPost to Facebook\nN.Y.C. horse-drawn carriages draw ire, praise Beneath the towering equine statues marking Central Park's southern entrance, the city's carriage horses stand calmly. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2hstiEK\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n9\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nN.Y.C. horse-drawn carriages draw ire, praise\nJohn E Seasly , Staff Writer, @jseasly Published 6:02 a.m. ET Dec. 9, 2016 | Updated 7:56 p.m. ET Dec. 9, 2016\nx\nShare\nWhile people flock to New York City's Central Park for holiday carriage rides, animal rights activists protest the tradition. John C. Ensslin/NorthJersey.com\nCarriage horses along 59th Street on the southern end of Central Park.\n(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Staff Photographer)\nBeneath the towering equine statues that mark the southern entrance to Central Park, the city's carriage horses stand calmly in line.\nWith their bright plumage and patient demeanor, they are beloved by tourists, especially between Thanksgiving and Christmas, their busiest time of year.\nBut the use of the horses to pull hansom cabs is also strongly opposed by animal-rights activists \u2013 and by the city\u2019s mayor \u2013 who contend that Manhattan is no place for them.\nWhile polls show that most New Yorkers support the carriage horses, activists have found a powerful ally in Mayor Bill de Blasio, who pledged to ban the horses on \"day one\" of his term. However, in the nearly three years he's been mayor, none of his efforts to ban or reduce the number of horses has been successful. The horses' owners in turn say the animals are happy and well-tended and that they are carrying on an iconic New York tradition \u2013 even in the face of regular protests.\nHORSE RIDING RING:\u00a0Rockleigh Equestrian Centre appeals board's denial\nCarriage horses have traversed the city's streets since the 1880s, and grew in popularity as a tourist attraction after World War II. Former Mayor Michael Bloomberg was an avid supporter of the industry.\n\"The horses here are supervised by the health department, the ASPCA,\" Bloomberg said in 2011. \u201cThey\u2019re well taken care of. And most of them wouldn\u2019t be alive if they didn\u2019t have a job.\u201d\nCarriage horses have been at work in the city since the 1880s.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Staff Photographer)\nFor de Blasio, the pledge to ban the horses looks increasingly quixotic.\n\"You can't just ban a legal business that isn't doing anything wrong,\" said carriage horse driver Christina Hansen.\nDe Blasio\u2019s attempt at compromise \u2013 to reduce the number of horses and house them in a Central Park stable, rather than at their four stables in Hell's Kitchen \u2013 was shot down by the City Council, which canceled a vote on it in February. His office did not respond to a request to comment.\nFor many of the activists, there can be no compromise. Last weekend, several dozen protesters with the group Empty the Carriages urged tourists not to ride the carriages and shouted for de Blasio to \"Keep your promise!\"\nActivist Edita Birnkrant called the carriage horses' presence in midtown traffic a \"recipe for disaster.\"\n\"We cannot change the industry in any way to make it more humane for horses. We cannot change the fact that New York City is a very chaotic place,\" she said.\nAlong 59th Street, where the horses wait for tourists, angry drivers lay on their car horns, hot dog stands emit acrid smells, and firetrucks blaze past, sirens blaring.\n\"He's obviously so stressed out and spooked by the traffic,\" Hansen said sarcastically\u00a0as her horse, Oreo, quietly nibbled on a carrot.\nBy law, the horses cannot be out of their stables for more than nine hours a day. They are forbidden to travel below 34th Street. They cannot work in temperatures above 89 degrees, lower than 19 degrees\u00a0or in extreme weather. For five weeks a year, they must be on vacation, which they usually spend in Amish country in Pennsylvania, Hansen said.\nA handler gives directions as his horse stands along 59th Street.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Staff Photographer)\nOne hundred ninety-three horses drive 68 licensed carriages. The maximum drivers can charge, as set by the city, is $54 for 20 minutes, not including tip.\u00a0\nThe horses are licensed and subject to inspection by the city's health department, police, the sanitation department and the ASPCA, and are examined twice a year.\nQuinnipiac polls from de Blasio's first year in office showed most New Yorkers opposed his proposed carriage-horse ban. The most recent, from January 2015, showed 63 percent opposed the ban versus 25 percent who supported the plan.\n\"They continue to say neigh to his plan to ban horse-drawn carriages,\" wrote the poll's assistant director, Maurice Carroll, in a press release.\nTourists adore the horses, and said that they assumed the horses were cared for.\n\"Lovely,\" Paddy Ryan of Ireland said. \"Part of the culture of New York City.\"\n\"I think it'd be a nice thing to do,\" said his wife, Breda, of taking a ride.\n\"It was wonderful,\" said Christy Moss of Bismarck, Ill., who had just finished a ride with her husband Eric and their 6-year-old twins, Amelie and Anouk.\u00a0\nBirnkrant rejected the notion that horses should be used for profit or treated \"like machines.\"\n\"I think it's a very backwards, antiquated, medieval way of thinking that literally animals should be our slaves,\" she said. She and other activists with Empty the Carriages plan to protest more this weekend.\nHansen saw the issue differently.\n\"I think that humans are better in partnership with animals,\" she said. She viewed the industry as a group of small family businesses upholding a long-standing city tradition.\n\"People would be upset if we weren't here anymore,\" she said.\nA horse-drawn carriage traveling along 59th Street this week.\n\u00a0(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Staff Photographer)\n133 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 9 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2hstiEK\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1511.html"], ["url", "http://archive.northjersey.com/opinion/opinion-editorials/politics-of-the-gwb-1.1325542"], ["text", "\u00a9 2017 North Jersey Media Group\nMay 5, 2015\nLast updated: Tuesday, May 5, 2015, 8:02 AM\nThe Record: Politics of the GWB\nThe Record\nFORMER PORT Authority of New York and New Jersey Deputy Executive Director Bill Baroni and Governor Christie's former deputy chief of staff Bridget Anne Kelly entered not guilty pleas Monday in Newark. Both were named in a nine-count federal indictment Friday in connection with the access-lane closures at the George Washington Bridge during the week of Sept. 9, 2013.\nTheir lawyers promise to disprove David Wildstein's allegations that they were part of a scheme to create a traffic nightmare in Fort Lee as retaliation against the borough's mayor, Mark Sokolich, a Democrat who did not endorse Republican Christie's 2013 reelection. While it will be many months before details emerge in a trial, what \u2014 or, more accurately, who \u2014 should literally emerge now is the governor of New Jersey.\nLast Friday, Christie was in Virginia. Today he is scheduled to be in Mississippi and Louisiana. When is Christie going to consistently show up at his day job, the one some people were so focused on his retaining in 2013 that they allegedly broke the law?\nChristie's 2016 presidential hopes are fading \u2014 fast. Whether he can succeed in winning a presidential primary is not a concern of New Jersey residents. But whether he intends to govern the state of New Jersey is a concern.\nThe governor does not appear interested in governing, but he is interested in winning one more election. What is clear from the GWB scandal \u2014 particularly now that Wildstein, another former top Christie appointee at the Port Authority, has admitted the lane closures were politically motivated \u2014 is that politics is all that matters to Christie and to the people closest to him.\nBack in 2013, the business of the state and the business of Christie's reelection were being commingled. Wildstein, Kelly and Baroni are alleged to have used the people of Fort Lee \u2014 including schoolchildren \u2014 as pawns in a political game. The message was: Endorse Christie or face the consequences.\nNow Christie wants New Jerseyans to believe that he knew nothing about what was going on and that he has no responsibility for what occurred. On Friday, Christie tweeted that he was vindicated by the indictments because he was not directly tied to the lane closures. There was no Christie tweet expressing deep sorrow that the people of Fort Lee were thrown into weeklong gridlock because of the actions of people in his office and his appointees at the Port Authority.\nFriday's tweets were all about Christie. The governor's so-called Mastro report, a multimillion-dollar whitewash on the GWB scandal, was all about Christie. Where do the people of New Jersey come in?\nNot through two closed access lanes to the GWB, that's for sure. The arrogance of those actions was remarkable \u2014 Christie and his supporters even questioned why Fort Lee had dedicated lanes to the GWB, as if the local lanes were somehow restricted solely to Fort Lee residents and as if the George Washington Bridge were somehow not connected to Fort Lee but to some other place in New Jersey.\nWhether the lane closures were about political payback has been unclear for more than a year. There are still many unanswered questions about the lane closures: who masterminded the scheme and who facilitated its execution. But what is clear is that the lane closures were about politics.\nChristie talks about leadership; a political action committee supporting his possible presidential candidacy is even called Leadership Matters for America. Leadership matters for New Jersey as well.\nIn our democracy, the art of politics is a means to an end \u2014 it is the process that enables candidates to win public office. In the Christie administration, politics appears to have been the means and the end.\nThat may not violate any federal law, but it is a damning indictment nonetheless.\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1538.html"], ["url", "http://www.usatoday.com/videos/news/nation/2017/01/10/raw-car-slides-down-icy-driveway-lands-pool/96390084/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nRaw: Car slides down icy driveway, lands in pool\nIcy conditions in Wake County, North Carolina led an SUV to slide down a driveway, through a garage and into a backyard pool on Monday. [["name", "new_7/1543.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/politics/2017/01/15/trump-tracker-political-influence-new-jersey/95918106/"], ["text", "Search\nBlue state in a red Capitol: How will N.J. fare?\nIf New Jersey had a Facebook page, its relationship status with the White House while Obama was president would be described as \u201ccomplicated.\u201d\nHerb Jackson , Washington Correspondent, @HerbNJDC\nIn this series on:\nHealth coverage for 700,000 at stake in New Jersey\nTSA screening wait times and Homeland Security funds top list of questions\nRepairing, upgrading rail will affect thousands of commuters\nImmigration issues dominated Trump's campaign\nBridges, roads and rail all need funds for repair\nShare This Story\nEmail\nComment\nAbout this series:\u00a0The Record and NorthJersey.com are launching the \u201cTrump Tracker,\u201d a four-year series that will follow 14\u00a0issues important to North Jersey taxpayers, residents and companies \u2013 big and small \u2013\u00a0that could be affected by actions taken by President Donald J. Trump\u2019s administration.\nThe intent is not to characterize whether the actions move a particular issue in a positive or negative direction. Rather, it will chart the results of policies created, modified or discontinued over the next four years and how they affect life in New Jersey.\nThe \"Trump Tracker\" will measure changes and trends on such issues as health care, immigration, transportation, job creation, the military, political influence, energy and the environment, regulations, the Newark seaport, infrastructure, passenger rail, taxes, homeland security and the social safety net.\nWe will update certain topics at least once every three months, offering insights of the new administration, its policies, actions and the trickle-down effects on New Jersey.\n**********\nIf New Jersey had a Facebook page, its relationship status with the White House during the eight years President Barack Obama was president would best be described as \u201ccomplicated.\u201d\nThat\u2019s not likely to change after Donald Trump is inaugurated.\nTrump lost New Jersey to Hillary Clinton by 546,000 votes in November, though how much effort either candidate made to win the state\u2019s 14 electoral votes is debatable since operatives from both parties focused more on neighboring Pennsylvania, which helped decide the national outcome.\nTrump\u2019s loss here showed again that while Gov. Chris\u00a0Christie could win the state twice, his support for other candidates \u2013 he endorsed Trump shortly after his own presidential bid failed \u2013\u00a0did not have much sway with state voters, especially with his own popularity lagging.\nDonald Trump with Gov. Chris Christie at a campaign event in May.\n(Photo: AP Photo/Mel Evans)\nChristie had been serving as Trump\u2019s transition chairman through Election Day, and afterward he was considered a favorite for an influential post , possibly including chief of staff. Instead, Christie was demoted from his transition role, and he did not get any position in the administration.\nSo the state\u2019s overwhelming preference for Clinton over Trump, and the distance the president-elect put between himself and the governor, would indicate the state may be on the outs when it comes to dealing with the administration.\nBut there are mitigating factors, too.\n\u201cDonald Trump certainly knows New Jersey, not only because of his residency in New York but also because of his significant investments in New Jersey,\u201d said Rep. Leonard Lance, a Republican from Hunterdon County. \u201cIt may very well be that Camp David North will be in the congressional district I serve, in Bedminster.\u201d\nLance said that if Trump succeeds in getting manufacturing companies to bring back jobs they shipped overseas, the state could benefit. He noted that top White House aides will include New Jersey resident Kellyanne Conway, who served as Trump\u2019s campaign manager, and Bill Stepien, a top political adviser to Christie until the governor fired him over his connection to the Bridgegate lane-closing scandal.\nIn Congress, New Jersey will no longer have someone with a personal relationship with the president like the one Sen. Cory Booker had with Obama. But Rep. Rodney Frelinghuysen of Harding recently became chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, a post that will help him influence how spending is doled out.\nRodney Frelinghuysen has served in the House of Representatives for 22 years.\n(Photo: Tariq Zehawi/NorthJersey.com)\nThe relationship between the state and the Trump White House also must be considered in comparison to the one it had with Obama.\nObama won New Jersey easily in both 2008 and 2012 , but the state\u2019s Democratic Party organization overwhelmingly opposed him in the 2008 primary. So while there was agreement with Democrats on many major policies, and Obama consistently scored higher in opinion polls in the state\u00a0than nationally, there was also distance between him and the state\u2019s top Democrats until Booker became a senator in 2013.\nA major exception was the response to Superstorm Sandy in 2012, when the state benefited from the joint efforts of Democratic senators and House members from New Jersey and New York, as well as the influence of Christie and Frelinghuysen, then a senior member of the appropriations committee.\nDemocrats who have served in Congress since 2000, the last time a Republican president succeeded a Democrat, say they are much more concerned this time.\nSen. Cory Booker, D-N.J., testified Wednesday against fellow Sen. Jeff Sessions' nomination to be attorney general.\n(Photo: AP FILE PHOTO)\n\u201cMy concern is we're a progressive state and progressive legislation is what helps us,\u201d said Rep. Frank Pallone, a Democrat from Monmouth County. \u201cWe need to have people have health care. We're concerned about the environment. And so far every pronouncement he's made about health and environmental issues has been very negative.\u201d\nAt the same time, Pallone said the incoming administration has left many details vague.\n\u201cI always start with the assumption that whoever's president is someone we can appeal to and basically make our case why he should help the state, so I don't start from the premise that we can't appeal to Trump about New Jersey issues,\u201d Pallone said. \u201cWe don't know exactly what Trump's going to do on any issue.\u201d\nMore Topics\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1574.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/politics/2017/01/13/trump-new-jersey-homeland-national-security-tsa-transportation/95917258/"], ["text", "TSA screening wait times and Homeland Security funds top list of questions\nLong lines at the airport and cyber defense among Trump's concerns\nJohn E Seasly , Staff Writer, @jseasly\nIn this series on:\nHealth coverage for 700,000 at stake in New Jersey\nRepairing, upgrading rail will affect thousands of commuters\nImmigration issues dominated Trump's campaign\nBridges, roads and rail all need funds for repair\nBlue state in a red Capitol: How will N.J. fare?\nShare This Story\nEmail\nComment\nAbout this series:\u00a0The Record and NorthJersey.com launch the \u201cTrump Tracker,\u201d a four-year series that will follow 14\u00a0issues important to North Jersey taxpayers, residents and companies \u2013 big and small \u2014\u00a0that could be affected by actions taken by President Donald J. Trump\u2019s administration.\u00a0\nThe intent is not to characterize whether the actions move a particular issue in a positive or negative direction. Rather, it will chart the results of policies created, modified or discontinued over the next four years and how they affect life in New Jersey.\nThe Trump Tracker will measure changes and trends on such issues as healthcare, immigration, transportation, job creation, the military, political influence, energy and the environment, regulations, the Newark seaport, infrastructure, passenger rail, taxes, homeland security and the social safety net.\nWe will update certain topics at least once every three months, offering insights of the new administration, its policies, actions and the trickle-down effects on New Jersey.\nTransportation Security Administration\nNeeded changes already implemented\nDonald Trump has pledged to end long wait times at airports like Newark Liberty International, though some of the underlying problems are already being addressed.\nTravelers at Newark Liberty regularly saw long waits early last year, to the point that lawmakers and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voiced concern. Some travelers waited more than an hour, due in large part to a shortage of trained staff.\nThe Port Authority in May criticized the Transportation Security Administration, which operates the airport security screening process\u00a0and urged it to take steps to shorten the wait.\n\"Given the adverse customer service and economic impacts, we can no longer tolerate the continuing inadequacy of TSA passenger screening services,\" Chief Security Officer Thomas Belfiore and Aviation Director Thomas Bosco wrote.\nLater that month, Sens. Cory Booker and Robert Menendez announced that the Newark was in the process of hiring nearly a hundred new screeners and deploying bomb-sniffing dogs to speed up the process.\n\"The outrageously long wait times we have witnessed in Newark not only slow down travel, but they also slow down economic growth for New Jersey and the region,\" Booker said.\nThe TSA also created a command center in Washington, D.C., which monitors security screenings at seven airports including Newark.\nAnd while wait times fluctuated over the holiday season, customer outrage seemed to have quieted down.\nOne of Trump's campaign promises is to reform the TSA, and he said on the trail that he would consider replacing current employees with veterans. He also seemed to consider the removal of hijab-wearing Muslim TSA agents, in apparent violation of protected religious freedoms\n\"We're looking at that,\" he said in response to the suggestion. \"We're looking at a lot of things.\"\nHomeland Security Funding\nNew Jersey infrastructure among top targets\nNew Jersey also relies on millions of dollars of federal Homeland Security funding, though it's unclear how a Trump presidency might affect these programs.\nTrump has promised both to increase the size of the U.S. military and eliminate wasteful spending, including \"ending unwanted and unauthorized federal programs,\" according to his campaign website.\nNew Jersey currently receives about $32 million in Homeland Security funding through three federal grant programs. The Homeland Security grant program, with $8.4 million in funding, helps the state and urban areas prevent and respond to threats of terrorism. The Urban Areas Security Initiative, with $20.1 million in funding, provides training for terrorism prevention and response in high-threat, densely populated areas.\nThe Nonprofit Security Grant Program, with $4.3 million in funding, equips qualifying nonprofits with security equipment for their properties.\nFederal funding for these programs has declined in recent years, down from $61 million in 2010.\nA bipartisan group of lawmakers including Booker and Menendez has urged more funding through the Urban Areas Security Initiative to help protect the state from cyberattacks.\n\"The amount of critical infrastructure in New Jersey that must be protected creates a dense digital attack surface,\" the letter reads.\nTrump might look more favorably on this approach to funding. Cybersecurity was a major issue during the campaign, and he pledged to bolster U.S. cyber defenses.\n\"We have to get very, very tough on cyber and cyber warfare,\" Trump said in September. \"It is a huge problem.\"\nMore Topics\n"]]

The original video already has more than a million views.\nPost to Facebook\nMayor's turban-tying lesson goes viral In an effort to promote diversity, Indian author Gurdeep Pandher, went through the step-by-step process of teaching his mayor how to wear a Sikh turban.
