[["name", "new_7/1587.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/education/2016/11/18/transgender-teens-quietly-gain-rights/93897824/"], ["text", "Transgender teens quietly gain rights\nNorth Jersey schools have put policies in place, but they differ greatly from district to district\n8-year-old transgender boy barred from Cub Scouts\nGrowing up transgender\nEmail\nComment\nAlmost 50 North Jersey high school districts quietly passed policies during the past few years spelling out the rights of transgender students, from what bathrooms they can use to the pronouns and names used to describe the student to the definitions of terms such as \"gender expression.\"\nThe process has continued unabated and often without a great deal of public attention, even as a national debate over the issue raged in recent months and the federal government issued mandates.\nThrough a months-long\u00a0examination of public records,\u00a0The Record found that 47 of 62 North Jersey high school districts had transgender policies in place \u2014 \u00a0and that transgender policies were already commonplace prior to a May letter issued by federal justice and education officials laying out requirements for schools to accommodate transgender students.\nBut in the absence of state guidelines, there are vast differences among the region\u2019s policies \u2013 particularly when it comes to one of the issue\u2019s most sensitive questions: Should districts inform parents when their children come out as transgender at school?\nMost policies reviewed by The Record require such notification, but 10 provide some privacy for transgender students even from parents, in some cases requiring the student\u2019s permission to call the home. Some experts said this was an important safety provision, given  high suicide and homelessness rates among transgender children whose families didn\u2019t support them.\nTransgender policy\nHow North Jersey\u2019s high school districts address the needs and privacy of transgender students:\nSpecific policy\nNon-specific policy\nNo policy\nThe fear of rejection often is so strong among transgender students that even those who are close to their parents said they were anxious when they came out.\nGio Leotsakas, 16, of Wayne said he wrote a letter to his mother to tell her he was not her daughter but her son, and was so nervous after reading about transgender children being thrown out of their homes that he packed a bag as a precaution. Another transgender boy, Jonah Elgamal, 15, whose family is Muslim and who lived until recently in West Milford, said he was \u201cfreaking out\u201d when he came out as transgender because he could not imagine going through the pain of hiding his real self any longer.\n\u25baGrowing up transgender: North Jersey kids tell of unease, bullying, acceptance\nIn both cases, the boys said they had been embraced not only by family but also by school officials, who  began calling them by their new names and allowing them to use restrooms and locker rooms based on their gender identity.\n\u201cThey gave me so much more than I expected,\u201d Gio said of officials at Wayne Hills High School, adding that their response made him so happy that he \"wanted to cry so bad.\"\nJonah said he was \u201clucky and grateful\u201d for the way he was treated at West Milford\u2019s Highlander Academy, and that his father\u2019s family, including a grandmother who lives in Egypt, immediately accepted him as a boy. He explained it this way: \u201cThe Koran doesn\u2019t say anything about being born in the wrong body.\u201d\nBoth boys said they knew that not every transgender child got as much support as they did, and that they had read about children committing suicide or becoming homeless after being rejected by their families. Those stories are at the heart of what some experts said is the most pressing question related to transgender policies: parental notification.\nGio Leotsakas and his mom, Nancy, said Wayne Hills High School has been accommodating, allowing him to use restrooms and locker rooms based on his gender identity.\n(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Staff Photographer)\n\u201cWe don\u2019t want schools to be in the business of outing students,\u201d said Aaron Potenza of Garden State Equality, an advocacy group for people who are gay or transgender, citing \u201chigh incidences of family abandonment\u201d for LGBT children.\nThat issue was the focus of a fierce debate when\u00a0Pascack Valley Regional High School\u00a0officials adopted a policy in April amid threat of a lawsuit by a conservative Christian legal group. While some of those opposed to the policy cited religious concerns, others said their biggest issue was its requirement for a student\u2019s consent to call parents.\nHolly Schepisi, a Republican assemblywoman, spoke against the policy in the spring, citing her concerns about lack of parental involvement. In a recent interview, she said that students struggling with gender identity needed the support of their families, but that exceptions should be made in cases where a family did not accept a student\u2019s gender identity.\n\u201cThat is what family units are supposed to be there for: to guide children through those difficult times,\u201d Schepisi said. \u201cIf there are any real concerns where a child says to a teacher or guidance counselor, \u2018My parents will never accept me this way and I\u2019m fearful for what will happen to me at home,\u2019 then I understand case-by-case scenarios where parents wouldn\u2019t participate in decisions such as this.\u201d\nMost of the North Jersey policies appear to have been adopted with little public scrutiny, with districts often approving them as part of a consent agenda, in which school boards take one vote to adopt a larger group of policies. All but a handful of the transgender policies were adopted with unanimous votes, and all but six were approved prior to the federal government\u2019s May letter.\nPastor Marc A. Stutzel of Emerson holds his son George Stutzel, while voicing his approval of the Pascack Valley Regional Transgender Policy during an April 2016 Pascack Valley Regional High School District Board of Education meeting. Pictured are Pamela Baxley, business administrator; Jeffrey Steinfeld, board president; and P. Erik Gundersen, Pascack Valley Regional Superintendent.\n(Photo: Amy Newman/STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER, North Jersey Media Group Staff Photographer)\nThe transgender policies remained so far off the radar last year that Governor Christie seemed unaware of them as he campaigned in New Hampshire and was asked about California transgender policies. CNN reported that Christie said New Jersey had no such issues. His office recently declined to elaborate.\n\u201cMen go to men's rooms, women go to women's rooms, and there really shouldn't be a whole lot of confusion about that \u2013\u00a0public accommodations,\u201d Christie said in December, according to CNN. \u201cAnd I don't think we should be making life more confusing for our children.\u201d\nBy then, more than two dozen North Jersey schools had adopted transgender policies, with the first being approved in 2013.\nThe following year, the U.S. Department of Education said transgender students were protected under Title IX, a federal law prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex. The U.S. Justice and Education departments issued more specific guidelines in May, saying that transgender students must be treated the same as other students of the same gender identity and framing the matter as a civil rights issue. Experts said schools could lose federal money if they did not comply. More than 20 states \u2013\u00a0New Jersey is not among them \u2013\u00a0are opposing the guidelines in pending lawsuits.\nIt is unclear what impact the election of Donald Trump as president will have on the issue, particularly in New Jersey \u2013 where some school officials have said their policies are an extension of state civil rights laws. Trump, earlier this year, was critical of a North Carolina law barring transgender people from using restrooms based on their gender identity, saying that people should \u201cuse the bathroom they feel is appropriate.\u201d He later said the matter should be decided by states and not the federal government.\nPolicies vary on key issues\nSchools disagree on notifying parents\nMost transgender policies reviewed by The Record are based on a model written by Strauss Esmay, a New Jersey company that specializes in creating school policies. But the policies diverge in significant ways.\nFor example, 28 districts list transgender students\u2019 rights, including restroom use, in some detail, while 19 simply list issues to be discussed on a case-by-case basis, without specifying the rights.\nNone of the policies go into detail about what happens when students come out as transgender and their parents disapprove, saying only that school officials would hold a meeting with families. A study by the City University of New York recently found that the risk of\u00a0suicide triples for transgender people who experience a \u201chigh level\u201d of rejection from their families.\n\u201cOf 47 transgender high school district policies across North Jersey, 10 provide some privacy protections for students from parents: Bergen County Special Services \u2022 Bergen County Technical \u2022 Lodi \u2022 Manchester Regional \u2022 North Arlington \u2022 Paramus \u2022 Pascack Valley Regional \u2022 Rutherford \u2022 Tenafly \u2022 Westwood Regional\u201d\nReporting by Abbott Koloff and Andrew Wyrich\nPhilip Nicastro, of Strauss Esmay, said parental consent might be a more significant issue than parental notification. Once students come out at school, he said, their parents are likely to find out from another student\u2019s parents regardless of whether the school calls them. But he said there was no clear guidance from government officials about what should happen next when the transgender student\u2019s parents object. The issue was not mentioned in May\u2019s letter from the federal government.\n\u201cThe letter is silent about non-consenting parents,\u201d Nicastro said. \u201cNew Jersey is silent. Nobody wants to touch it.\u201d\nThe Record asked North Jersey superintendents via email how they would handle it if a parent disagreed with a student\u2019s gender identity. Only a handful of districts responded, and typically said they would consult their attorneys in such cases.\nGio and Jonah, both of whom talked to The Record with the permission of their parents, said parental notification requirements might put some students in danger or hinder them from expressing their true selves. The districts where they came out, West Milford and Wayne, both have parental notification requirements.\n\u201cFor some kids, it\u2019s not safe to come out at home,\u201d said Jonah, who now lives with his family in another part of the state. He said he was unaware that West Milford, which adopted its policy in August, did not have one at the time he came out. Acceptance by school and family, he said, helped him \u201cto be myself\u201d and eased his anxiety and depression.\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1589.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/marijuana-health-benefits-study_us_58784988e4b0e58057fe27c4?ir=Healthy+Living"], ["text", "Marijuana Eases Pain, But Jury's Out On Other Health Benefits, Scientists Say\nResearchers call for more studies to fill the gaps in knowledge about pot use.\n01/13/2017 01:05 am ET\nMary Papenfuss Trends reporter, The Huffington Post\nseanfboggs via Getty Images\nGardening under lights.\nMarijuana has proved to be a powerful aid in easing chronic pain and helping battle nausea, but results are mixed or largely inconclusive on other health benefits, as well as detriments, according to a massive new scientific review of cannabis studies.\nThe report , released Thursday by the National Academies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine, analyzes an astounding 10,000 scientific studies on the drug. \u201cThe Health Effects of Cannabis and Cannabinoids: The Current State of Evidence and Recommendations for Research\u201d\u00a0concludes that marijuana definitely provides some health benefits, though other claims about the drug are far less clear.\u00a0The scientists note that much information could be determined if researchers didn\u2019t have to battle restrictions caused by federal classification of cannabis as a Schedule 1 drug, meaning it \u201ccurrently\u201d has \u201cno accepted medical use and a high potential for abuse.\u201d\n\u201cIt is often difficult for researchers to gain access to the quantity, quality, and type of cannabis product necessary to address specific research questions on the health effects of cannabis use,\u201d conclude the authors, a panel of experts led by Harvard public health researcher Marie McCormack.\u00a0\nFederal attitude aside,\u00a0more than half of all U.S. states have legalized marijuana for medical use, and eight (plus the District of Columbia) have legalized the drug for recreational use.\nThe major conclusions in the study are that cannabis and cannabinoids are effective at \u201csignificantly reducing\u201d\u00a0chronic pain, particularly linked to muscle spasms caused by multiple sclerosis. There\u2019s also \u201cconclusive evidence\u201d that cannabis is effective at preventing and treating nausea related to chemotherapy.\nThere is \u201cmoderate evidence\u201d that cannabis and cannabinoids are effective for improving \u201cshort-term sleep outcomes\u201d for people suffering sleep disturbances linked to sleep apnea, fibromyalgia and chronic pain. The study also finds\u00a0\u201climited evidence\u201d that cannabis and cannabinoids are effective in increasing appetite and improving anxiety and post-traumatic stress symptoms.\nIt is often difficult for researchers to gain access to the quantity, quality, and type of cannabis product necessary to address specific research questions on the health effects of cannabis use. study authors\nThere is insufficient or no evidence, however, to support \u2014 or refute \u2014 use of the drug for several other ailments and problems including cancer, epilepsy, addiction, schizophrenia and Parkinson\u2019s disease, the report concludes.\nOn the negative side, the review finds that use of marijuana may increase the risk of developing mental health issues, such as schizophrenia, anxiety and, to a lesser extent, depression \u2014 though it\u2019s also possible that people with these problems turn to marijuana for help and skew the results, the report notes.\nIt isn\u2019t linked to lung and neck cancers associated with smoking tobacco, but frequent use can cause or exacerbate respiratory problems, the study concludes.\u00a0Smoking marijuana while pregnant may be linked to lower birth weights, but it\u2019s not clear if there are any long-term effects to children born to moms who smoked pot while pregnant.\u00a0\u201cSome evidence suggests smoking marijuana may trigger a heart attack among individuals with diagnosed heart disease,\u201d according to the study review.\nThere\u2019s substantial evidence that driving under the influence causes an \u201cincreased risk of motor vehicle crashes,\u201d the report concludes. It also warns that increasing numbers of children may be accidentally ingesting marijuana now that it\u2019s more widely available.\nThe evidence that marijuana is a gateway drug to trying other drugs \u201cis limited,\u201d the study says. But researchers also found \u201cmoderate evidence\u201d of a link between cannabis use and the development of substance dependence or abuse problems with alcohol, tobacco and illegal drugs.\nThe review of studies was an attempt to pinpoint the gaps in knowledge about marijuana use and call for rigorous research into the drug as it becomes more easily available.\u00a0\u201cThis is a pivotal time in cannabis research,\u201d the report notes.\nPresident-elect Donald Trump \u2019s nominee for U.S. attorney general, Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.), could keep the nation in marijuana suspense. He is known as a steadfast opponent of legalizing marijuana but had only vague answers at his confirmation hearing Thursday about what he\u2019d do about pot if he is confirmed.\nAttorney general nominee Jeff Sessions said \"good people don't smoke marijuana.\" #confirmationhearings pic.twitter.com/LOR4ssgKQk\n\u2014 ACLU National (@ACLU) January 10, 2017\nRelated Coverage\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1591.html"], ["url", "http://archive.northjersey.com/opinion/wildstein-pleads-kelly-talks-and-christie-still-tweets-1.1324836"], ["text", "\u00a9 2017 North Jersey Media Group\nMay 4, 2015\nLast updated: Monday, May 4, 2015, 1:21 AM\nDoblin: Wildstein pleads, Kelly talks and Christie still tweets\nBy Alfred P. Doblin\nThe Record\nTHE PEOPLE of Fort Lee should be overjoyed. On Friday, David Wildstein, the Snidely Whiplash of the George Washington Bridge scandal, appeared in federal court in Newark to plead guilty to two criminal counts relating to the access-lane closure. Hours later, Governor Christie took to Twitter to declare: \"I had no knowledge or involvement in the planning and execution of this act.\"\nMarko Georgiev/Staff  photographer\nDavid Wildstein exits Newark court on Friday, May 1, 2015.\nIn the days of Richard Nixon, a politician under fire would have raised his arms, made victory signs with both hands and proclaimed, \"I am not a crook.\" No one accuses Christie of being a crook, but it is remarkable that the man who is contemplating becoming president of the United States did not face reporters in New Jersey on Friday. He tweeted.\nShortly after Wildstein's court appearance, U.S. Attorney Paul Fishman announced nine-count indictments against former Port Authority of New York and New Jersey Deputy Executive Director Bill Baroni and Christie's former deputy chief of staff Bridget Anne Kelly. Fishman elaborated on a scheme to retaliate against the Democratic mayor of Fort Lee, Mark Sokolich. Baroni and Kelly, with Wildstein, are alleged to have planned the lane closures to punish Sokolich for not endorsing Christie in his reelection campaign in 2013.\nBaroni's lawyer said Wildstein is lying. Kelly, in a press conference, said Wildstein \"is a liar\" and went further, saying it was \"ludicrous\" to suggest she was the only person in the governor's office who had knowledge of the lane closures.\nThere is much dissembling going on, and the upcoming trial will hopefully sort some of this out. But there is nothing for Christie to crow about \u2014 or even tweet. At best, three trusted allies violated the public trust all in his name. The governor wants to divorce himself of the whole affair. He authorized the spending of millions of the public's tax dollars for the so-called Mastro report that talked at length to everyone but the key players. That self-ordered report exonerated Christie, and the governor has tried to use that as a shield against criticism.\nCaptain America Chris Christie isn't; this shield does not work. If we believe Wildstein, the Christie campaign was filled with rogue players willing to toy with the lives of millions of people by closing lanes to the busiest bridge in the United States, all to get back at a Democratic mayor with little statewide influence during a campaign where a Christie landslide victory was all but guaranteed. Christie continues to say he knew nothing about the lane closures before they occurred or after. If that is how he managed an easy reelection campaign for governor, how is he managing a not-so-easy one for president?\nPrimary voters should be taking a look at the possible Christie narratives: Either he was completely uninvolved and trusted key aides ran amok or he knew about the closures sooner than he admits. The first scenario shows a governor with unbelievably bad judgment; the second, an unbelievable governor. Neither instills confidence to hand him the nation's nuclear codes.\nYet confidence was once the entire Christie package. Consider that on Jan. 9, 2014, the day after The Record broke open the GWB story linking the closing to Kelly, Christie held a lengthy press conference in the State House to declare that he had been betrayed by these people, that he fired them and that he was as shocked as all New Jerseyans were.\nOn May 1, Christie was not speaking to the media. For starters, he started the day in Virginia, not New Jersey. When he came back to the state, he didn't schedule a public event. There was a press release and numerous tweets. This is not leadership. This is not confidence. And this is not the end of the governor's problems.\nFishman did not rule out the possibility that other former Christie aides or appointees would be indicted in related issues \u2014 the specter of former Port Authority Chairman David Samson follows Christie like Banquo's ghost. Whether Wildstein is lying, as is being said by Kelly, or whether he is telling the truth, Birnam Wood is moving in on this governor with presidential ambitions.\nThere are too many people in not-good places with ties to the governor. Christie has dismissed Wildstein as a not-so-close former high school classmate, suggesting that he \u2014 Christie \u2014 was too cool to associate with Wildstein back then. That does not explain how Wildstein was given a job at the Port Authority. Kelly's statement about what is and is not ludicrous has more than a little weight.\nAs much as Christie wants to move past the GWB, he cannot. Wildstein, Baroni and Kelly were not nameless state employees far removed from the governor's office. Certainly Baroni and Kelly have a right to state their side of the story in a court of law. Fishman does not offer any rationale for the GWB scheme. Perhaps during a trial, Wildstein will, because even if all of this true, it makes little sense. It is indeed ludicrous.\nStill the people of Fort Lee have someone to blame, and it isn't Chris Christie. That would be a much easier sell if Christie had taken to a podium Friday afternoon. Even diminished, he is still larger than life face to face. But the visage I see on his Twitter account does not make him or his pronouncements look large. In fact, he looks small. Very small.\nAlfred P. Doblin is the editorial page editor of The Record. Contact him at doblin@northjersey.com. Follow AlfredPDoblin on Twitter.\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1592.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/education/2016/12/27/8-year-old-transgender-boy-barred-cub-scouts/95518824/"], ["text", "Search\n8-year-old transgender boy barred from Cub Scouts\nFrom the moment he joined, 8-year-old Joe Maldonado eagerly looked forward to camping trips and science projects with his Secaucus Cub Scout pack.\nAbbott Koloff , Staff Writer, @AbbottKoloff\nIn this series on:\nTransgender teens quietly gain rights\nJoe loses spot in pack\nA month after he joined Cub Scouts, officials told him to leave\nShare This Story\nEmail\nComment\nFrom the moment he joined, 8-year-old Joe Maldonado eagerly looked forward to camping trips and science projects as a member of the Cub Scouts. But his expectations were dashed after his mother said she received a phone call from a Scouting official who told her that Joe would no longer be allowed to participate because he was born a girl.\nKristie Maldonado said she was stunned because her son had been a member of Cub Scout Pack 87 in Secaucus for about a month\u00a0and his transgender status had not been a secret. But some parents complained, an official from the Northern New Jersey Council of Boy Scouts told her \u2014\u00a0even though her son had been living as a boy for more than a year\u00a0and was accepted as a boy at school, she said\nJoe Maldonado, 8, and his mother Kristie Maldonado, of Secaucus, talk about Joe being kicked out of Cub Scouts because he was born a girl.\n(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\n\"Not one of the kids said, 'You don\u2019t belong here,\u2019\u201d Maldonado said of the Scouts in the pack.\n\u201cIt made me mad,\u201d Joe, said. \u201cI had a sad face, but I wasn\u2019t crying. I\u2019m way more angry than sad. My identity is a boy. If I was them, I would let every person in the world go in. It\u2019s right to do.\u201d\nJoe's case could be the first time someone has been barred from participating in Scouting because of transgender identity, said members of the LGBT community. And it comes as the Boy Scouts of America appeared to be emerging from a period of turmoil involving sexual-orientation\u00a0issues, reversing long-standing bans against gay Scouts and gay Scouting leaders over the past few years. Those policy changes were made amid an internal debate that saw at least one local council defy national Scouting decrees by hiring a gay camp counselor\u00a0and pressure brought from corporations that withheld donations from the organization.\nThe Boy Scouts did not address the transgender issue at the time, LGBT advocates said, perhaps because the organization had no written policy related to gender identity. Transgender rights only recently emerged as a national issue, often focusing on the use of restrooms based on gender identity. Dozens of North Jersey school districts, including Secaucus, have granted that right, among others, to transgender students.\nx\nShare\nJoe Maldonado, 8, of Secaucus, was a member of the Cub Scout Pack 87 before he was kicked out due to his transgender status, which had never been a secret. Danielle Parhizkaran/staff photographer\nBirth certificates for 'legal status'\nScouts won't state formal stance, but refer to documents\nThe Scouts declined to say whether they have a written transgender policy. Effie Delimarkos, the\u00a0communications director for the Boy Scouts of America, said in a statement that the organization\u2019s Cub Scouts programs are for boys age\u00a07 to\u00a010\u00a0and that \"the classification on the participant\u2019s birth certificate\u201d would be used to \u201cconfirm legal status.\u201d She did not provide additional details\u00a0and did not specify whether the Boy Scouts have ever examined gender statuses on birth certificates.\n\u201cNo youth may be removed from any of our programs on the basis of his or her sexual orientation. Gender identity isn\u2019t related to sexual orientation.\u201d\nEffie Delimarkos, communications director, Boy Scouts of America\nEarlier this year, the Boy Scouts told The Associated Press that it would admit transgender children to its coeducational programs\u00a0but not to programs that are for boys only, like the Cub Scouts and Boy Scouts. Yet transgender\u00a0advocates said that the issue remained largely under the radar in Scouting.\nEric Chamberlin, an executive with the Northern New Jersey Council of Boy Scouts, based in Oakland, acknowledged calling Kristie Maldonado last month but declined further comment, referring questions to Scouting\u2019s national office and saying the issue involved \"our membership standards.\"\nIt is not known to what extent the Boy Scouts\u00a0leadership has\u00a0discussed the issue of transgender Scouts \u2014\u00a0or even whether the organization's\u00a0top leaders were made aware that Joe was barred from being a Cub Scout. The president of the Boy Scouts of America, AT&T Chief Executive\u00a0Randall Stephenson, who had pressed for an end to Scouting\u2019s gay bans, did not respond to a request to be interviewed.\nDelimarkos said\u00a0in her statement that the Boy Scouts consider membership for transgender children to be a separate issue from that of gay children.\n\u201cNo youth may be removed from any of our programs on the basis of his or her sexual orientation,\u201d she said, but added: \u201cGender identity isn\u2019t related to sexual orientation.\u201d The Boy Scouts declined to directly address the situation in Secaucus or say whether local or state Scouting leaders had consulted the national office about the matter.\nPivotal moment for Boy Scouts\nJoe's case raises a question: Will the organization welcome transgender boys or exclude them?\n\u201cIt\u2019s pretty clear the Boy Scouts as a national organization have a decision to make. Are they going to exclude a transgender boy for the first time, or welcome transgender boys?\u201d\nJustin Wilson, executive director, Scouts for Equality\nThe Boy Scouts of America is not known to have rejected any Scouts over gender identity before the Secaucus case, said Justin Wilson, the executive director of Scouts for Equality.\u00a0His group advocated for Scouting to reverse its bans against gay people. He said that he does not know of any instances in which the Scouts asked for a birth certificate as as condition of membership.\nWilson said he knows of at least two transgender boys who are Cub Scouts about the same age as Joe, one in a southern state that he did not name and the other in New York. He said he did not want to be more specific because of concerns that the national organization might take steps against them.\u00a0The use of birth certificates to determine gender identity, he said, would be \u201ca new, unfair arbitrary standard\u201d for membership.\nThe Boy Scouts, Wilson said, appear to be at a pivotal point. \u201cIt\u2019s pretty clear the Boy Scouts as a national organization have a decision to make,\u201d he said. \u201cAre they going to exclude a transgender boy for the first time\u00a0or welcome transgender boys?\u201d\nOn its face, Wilson said, the use of birth certificates to determine membership eligibility would allow some transgender girls to be admitted. The Boy Scouts did not respond to questions about whether they would accept a transgender girl whose birth certificate indicates she is male.\nThey also did not respond\u00a0when asked whether they would accept a transgender boy whose gender status on a birth certificate was changed from female to male. Making such a change is easier to do in some states than in others. New Jersey, for example, is among more than 20 states that require proof of sex-change surgery to alter gender status. New York and Pennsylvania don\u2019t require surgery.\nAfter the ban on gay scouts\nNational organization reversed longstanding policies during the past three years\nThe Boy Scouts put in place bans against gay Scouts and gay Scouting leaders in 1978 but reversed those policies over the past three years after membership reportedly declined and corporations held back donations. It passed a resolution in 2013 saying \u201cno youth may be denied membership\u201d based on \u201csexual preference alone.\u201d It ended the ban on gay Scouting leaders in 2015\u00a0but allowed religious organizations sponsoring Scouting troops to \u201ccontinue to select adult leaders in line with their religious beliefs on sexual orientation.\u201d\n\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\n\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0\nBut even before those bans were lifted, not all Scouting councils adhered to them.\nRichard Mason, president of the Greater New York Councils of Boy Scouts, said his organization had\u00a0long accepted children regardless of sexual orientation and hired a gay Eagle Scout to be a camp counselor months before the Boy Scouts ended the national ban on gay leaders.\n\u201cWe\u2019ve always thought it is important for Scouting to be in sync with the openness in society,\u201d he said.\nMason declined to discuss Scouting\u2019s transgender policies but said his organization, which covers New York City, would \u201creview our policy\u201d and determine \u201cwhether it needs to be beefed up\u201d in relation to transgender Scouts in light of \u201chow recently this issue has come about.\u201d\nGirl Scouts of the USA, which has no relationship to the Boy Scouts, has accepted transgender girls for years. The Girl Scouts said on their website that any child recognized as a girl by their family and community and who \u201clives culturally as a girl\u201d would be allowed to join.\nKristie Maldonado said that her son, Joe, \u201cwould not be fine if I put him in Girl Scouts.\"\nThe best day of Joe's life\nHaircut, coming out allowed him to live a happier life\nJoe Maldonado lives with his parents, a cat, a dog, and two hamsters in a Secaucus apartment where the curtains in his room are imprinted with Star Wars characters.\nJoe Maldonado, 8, in his room that is filled with Star Wars. Maldonado was kicked out of Secaucus Cub Scout Pack 87 because he was born a girl.\n(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\nWhen he was a little more than 2\u00a0years old, his mother told him he was pretty.\n\u201cNo,\u201d he said, according to his mom. \u201cI\u2019m handsome.\u201d\nHis mother said she thought at first that he was a tomboy because he liked climbing trees and digging in dirt to look\u00a0for worms. But she said she knew it was more than that by the time he was 5\u00a0and she began reading about what it means to be transgender. Last year, she allowed him to cut his hair short and come out as a boy when he began second grade at the Huber Street elementary school. He is now in third grade.\n\u201cLoved it. The best day of my life,\u201d Joe said of the day he had his hair cut.\nJoe plays on a recreational boys basketball team with some of the children who were in his Cub Scout pack. His teachers have referred to him by male pronouns since the second grade.\u00a0Kristie Maldonado said he is a \u201cmuch happier child\u201d since he was allowed to live as a boy.\nSchool pictures of Joe Maldonado, 8, who was kicked out of Secaucus Boy Scout Pack 87 because he was born a girl.\n(Photo: Danielle Parhizkaran/Northjersey.com)\nShe said she was not aware that anyone had a problem with her son being a member of the pack, which is hosted by the Immaculate Conception Church, until she received a phone call from a council official. \u00a0A spokesman for the Archdiocese of Newark said it had nothing to do with the Boy Scouts\u2019 decision, and the pastor of the church just recently learned of it. He declined further comment.\nMaldonado said she was asked whether she would \"testify\u201d that her son was a boy. She asked how the official would know\u00a0her son was born a girl. He told her, she said, that he heard about it\u00a0when \u201csome mothers called.\u201d The official did not ask for a birth certificate, she said.\nJoe said he had been happy as a Cub Scout\u00a0and especially enjoyed a barbecue and participating in a science project. Some people have questioned his gender identity before, he said, adding that it \u201cgot so annoying\u201d having to tell people over and over that he is a boy. He said he was \u201cdisappointed\u201d that he can no longer be a Cub Scout but would not want to go back without receiving an apology.\n\u201cHow dare they judge me?\u201d he said, adding of his gender identity: \u201cI don\u2019t have to explain it. It\u2019s the way I\u2019m born.\u201d\nEmail: Koloff@northjersey.com\n\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 ____________________________\n\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0____________________________\nGrowing up transgender: North Jersey children, teens tell of unease, bullying and acceptance.\nTransgender teens quietly gain rights: North Jersey schools have put policies in place, but they differ greatly district to district.\nCub Scouts should not exclude kids: Editorial says there should be some common sense applied with regard to an 8-year-old child participating in Cub Scouts.\nShare This Story\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1620.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/passaic/woodland-park/2017/01/14/police-identify-man-found-dead-woodland-park/96589158/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nMan found dead in Woodland Park had been reported missing\nAuthorities identified the body of a man found in the Morris Canal as Thomas Kozell, an 85 year old Woodland Park resident.\nPost to Facebook\nMan found dead in Woodland Park had been reported missing Authorities identified the body of a man found in the Morris Canal as Thomas Kozell, an 85 year old Woodland Park resident. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jJPHyr\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n1\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nMan found dead in Woodland Park had been reported missing\nDaniel J Munoz and Jessica Presinzano , NorthJersey Published 3:57 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017 | Updated 8:02 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nEmergency personnel at the scene where a body was found near the Woodland Park American Legion on Friday.\n(Photo: Tariq Zehawi/NorthJersey.com)\nAuthorities identified the body of a man found in the Morris Canal on Friday as Thomas Kozell, an 85-year-old Woodland Park resident.\nKozell was found dead\u00a0behind the American Legion building on Friday afternoon, after he was reported missing around 7 p.m. the night before.\nAccording to the Passaic County Prosecutor's Office,\u00a0police first received a call at around 8:30 a.m. on Friday that the body of a man was found in the Morris Canal. Detectives at the scene followed a trail of blood from midway up the hill to the waterline of the canal.\nAccording to Woodland Park Police\u00a0Detective Lt. John\u00a0Uzzalino, Kozell was suffering\u00a0from dementia and most likely \"fell from the top of a steep hill on the east side of the canal,\" causing head trauma. The family of the man had been searching for him before calling the police, authorities said.\nHis name was initially withheld pending identification by the family, though according to\u00a0Uzzalino, police already suspected the body to be that of Kozell when it was found on Friday.\nAuthorities added that an investigation was on-going, but that they did not believe Kozell's death to be suspicious.\nBody found in Morris Canal in Woodland Park\nHours after Kozell was discovered to be missing, his family led an online campaign to help locate the senior.\nThe Facebook posts seeking help in locating Kozell, who disappeared from his home in Woodland Park on Thursday evening, were shared over 200 times in neighborhood groups and by friends of the family.\nHe was last seen in the area of\u00a0Vetrone\u00a0Drive, off Browertown Road, according to the Facebook post by his daughter-in-law, Amy Kozell.\nAmy Kozell did not immediately respond to requests for\u00a0comment,\u00a0but thanked those who helped spread the word online.\n\u201cWe are beyond grief stricken. I want to thank each and every one of you who shared our plea and helped search for him,\u201d wrote Kozell in a public post Friday afternoon.\nAt 8:30 a.m. Friday, less than 24 hours after he was reported missing, police found\u00a0Kozell in the park, about a half mile\u00a0from his home, according to police reports.\nWandering and becoming lost are common symptoms of dementia in all stages of the disease. Of those who do wander, 94 percent are found within one-and-a-half miles of where they disappeared, according to the Alzheimer\u2019s Association.\nKozell is survived by his wife Alice, sons Thomas (Kathy) of Pequannock and Robert (Amy) of Clifton, four grandchildren\u00a0and nieces and nephews, according to\u00a0Kozell's\u00a0obituary posted on the Marrocco Memorial Chapel website. He is predeceased by his brothers Albert, Robert and Richard.\nHe was born in\u00a0Schenectady, NY and lived most of his life in Woodland Park. For over 25 years he worked as a PSE&G equipment operator and was a Korean War veteran.\nVisiting hours are Wednesday\u00a0from 4 p.m. to 8 p.m.\u00a0at Marrocco Memorial Chapel, at 470 Colfax Ave. in Clifton. A funeral is slated for 10 a.m. Thursday at the chapel with entombment at\u00a0Holy Sepulchre Cemetery in Totowa.\n44 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jJPHyr\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1626.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/bergen/norwood/2017/01/14/norwood-fire-department-puts-out-call-daytime-volunteers/96540110/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nNorwood Fire Department puts out a call for daytime volunteers\nThe Borough's Volunteer Fire Department is battling a\u00a0problem: a lack of volunteers during the day, fire officials said. \u00a0\nPost to Facebook\nNorwood Fire Department puts out a call for daytime volunteers The Borough's Volunteer Fire Department is battling a\u00a0problem: a lack of volunteers during the day, fire officials said. \u00a0 Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2iwrldF\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nNorwood Fire Department puts out a call for daytime volunteers\nMarc Lightdale , Staff Writer, @MarcLightdale 10:31 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nThe Norwood Fire Department needs more daytime volunteers. Here is a picture of their fire house\n(Photo: MarcLightdale/NorthJersey.com)\nNORWOOD \u2014 The Borough's Volunteer Fire Department is battling a\u00a0problem: a lack of volunteers during the day, fire officials said.\n\"It is a massive problem right now,\" Fire Chief Michael Congiusti\u00a0said.\nThe department has 25 members, with about 15 regularly available at night, but during the day,\u00a0sometimes only\u00a0two volunteers are available,\u00a0he\u00a0said.\u00a0\nNorwood residents raise concerns about Northern Valley modular unit\nSix members during the day would be \"ideal,\" Congiusti\u00a0said.\u00a0\"We might not be there one day because we don't have enough people during the day.\"\nFinding daytime volunteers has been\u00a0an ongoing issue over the past several years, and if the department\u00a0does not\u00a0have enough people, they\u00a0rely on the aid of other\u00a0local\u00a0departments, Norwood\u00a0Assistant Fire Chief Kevin McLaughlin said.\nThe department particularly gets help during the day from Harrington Park.\n\"It's manageable. It's rare to get two calls at the same time, [we] usually have enough manpower to send people to both locations,\"\u00a0Harrington Park Fire Chief Robert McElroy said. \"Daytime in any town is rough. We\u00a0have a pretty good number of people available. Every town could use more volunteers.\"\nPart of the challenge of getting\u00a0volunteers is that firefighters are required to complete\u00a0six months of training at the fire academy, which includes two weeknights and four Saturdays,\u00a0McLaughlin said.\nCongiusti\u00a0said a call for volunteers has been\u00a0posted on the department's Facebook page, and the borough also has advertised on a message board outside the fire department.\n\"It was a lot more simple 50 years ago to be a volunteer fire fighter,\"\u00a0Councilman\u00a0Thomas Brizzolara, the former fire commissioner, said, noting being a firefighter requires tremendous time and commitment.\nWith people working more jobs and with longer hours, there is less free time to volunteer, he said.\nInterested volunteers\u00a0can fill out an application at\u00a0the fire department, 602 Broadway, on Tuesday\u00a0nights from 7:30 p.m. to 9 p.m.\nEmail:\u00a0lightdale@northjersey.com\n149 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2iwrldF\n"]]

Any unused credits will carry over to the next month, up to a maximum of nine books and three audiobooks.\nI have an annual membership. When will I receive my credits?\nYou\u2019ll receive three Monthly Reads and one audiobook credit at the start of every month.\nWill my membership automatically renew?\nYes, your membership will automatically renew. You can cancel any time from your Account Settings page to stop it from being renewed.\nCan I cancel at any time?\nYes. Your membership will remain active until the current billing period ends, then your account will convert to a free account. You can purchase a new membership any time to restore access to the full breadth of Scribd's catalog.\nCan I use Scribd for free?\nTo access Scribd's library of thousands of bestsellers and new releases you must purchase a membership. You can also follow your favorite authors and publishers, browse our library by subject, and find specific content using our search feature.\nAre authors being paid when I read books this way?\nYes. [["name", "new_7/1671.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/essex/millburn-short-hills/2017/01/14/millburn-board-ed-urged-address-student-stress/96507542/"], ["text", "Millburn Board of Ed urged to address student stress\nA new committee is formed, but residents and board members question if stress is being addressed.\nPost to Facebook\nMillburn Board of Ed urged to address student stress A new committee is formed, but residents and board members question if stress is being addressed. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jITxYD\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nMillburn Board of Ed urged to address student stress\nHarry Trumbore , Staff Writer Published 9:59 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017 | Updated 1:25 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nDuring the Jan. 9 Board of Education meeting, resident David Harrison questions the Millburn School District's efforts to combat student stress.\n(Photo: Harry Trumbore/northjersey.com)\nBesides announcing assignments to the Board of Education\u2019s established committees, Emily Jaffe, the board\u2019s new president, announced the creation of two new ad hoc committees.\nOne is a Legal Review Committee, headed by Richard Gray, and the other a Health and Wellness Committee chaired by Jaffe.\nDuring her report, Superintendent of Schools Christine Burton said there are many faculty and community members who have expressed an interest in being a part of the initiatives of the Health and Wellness Committee.\n\u201cWe\u2019re looking to kick off this committee with an entire community forum to invite the community to become part of the conversation about health and wellness.\u201d\nBurton did not give a definite date for the forum.\nMILLBURN:\u00a0Despite snow, donors show up at blood drive\nDuring the public comments portion of the meeting, resident David Harrison told the board that stress was a longstanding issue. To explore the problem, a Student Strategic Planning Committee had been formed three years ago. Harrison, a committee member, said the first initiative was a comprehensive survey done in 2015, but he said it took 13 months for the school administration to acknowledge it.\nIn the survey, Harrison\u00a0said, \u201cwere two points, in particular, that are not controversial, at least among students and parents: the necessity to return tests and assignments before the next ones are administered, and secondly, to disallow the practice of teachers assigning homework due the next day after class has been dismissed.\u201d\nHarrison also accused some teachers of not allowing students to keep tests so that they could use them again without having to rewrite the tests.\nHe said the committee has not met this academic year and is awaiting the administration\u2019s \u201cgreen light.\u201d\n\u201cThese are ongoing problems,\u201d Harrison said. \u201cI don\u2019t understand why more analysis is needed.\u201d He suggested the administration is afraid to impose control over teachers.\n\u201cAre we more concerned about protecting a small minority of misbehaving teachers or the mental health of students?\u201d he asked.\nResident Catherine Dorum said the inaction on student stress was frustrating. She said block scheduling should be explored, and added she was hopeful that a forthcoming revised middle school handbook would emphasize the need for quality over quantity with homework. She cited reports that homework should be limited to 10 minutes per grade level \u2014 60 minutes for sixth graders \u2014 and that anything more becomes detrimental to learning. She also urged the district to reevaluate\u00a0the use of laptops for note-taking, saying research shows adolescents may be harming by incorporating too much technology into schoolroom aspects.\nMillburn Board of Education member Richard Gray, right, during the Jan. 9 board meeting, questions the number of committees studying student stress. Sitting with Gray on the dais are, from left, Superintendent of Schools Christine Burton, Board President Emily Jaffe, and Vice President Jesse Liu.\n\u00a0(Photo: Harry Trumbore/northjersey.com)\nJaffe said the issues would be addressed by the new Health and Wellness Committee, but at least one board member wondered whether\u00a0the issue of stress was being divided into too many separate forums.\n\u201cWe seem to have now lots of overlapping committees,\u201d said Gray, who noted that student stress was being considered by the Policy and\u00a0Student Liaison committees, and now Health and Wellness.\n\u201cWho\u2019s going to take ownership?\u201d he asked.\nBoard member Berylin Bosselman took an opposing view, making a point that the problem was bigger than student stress.\n\u201cThe biggest thing we\u2019re tasked with is \u2018the culture,\u2019\u201d Bosselman said. \u201cAll these committees are viable ways to attack this issue from all different directions.\u201d\n\u201cThere has to be a way of coordinating the work,\u201d Gray said.\n\u201cThat\u2019s where I come in,\u201d said Burton, making the point that she has to oversee the work of all of the committees.\n3 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jITxYD\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1686.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/bergen/englewood-cliffs/2017/01/13/democrats-republicans-sound-off-council-shift-englewood-cliffs/96399046/"], ["text", "Dems, GOP sound off on Englewood Cliffs council's makeup\nThe divide along party lines has residents and officials criticizing members of both parties\nPost to Facebook\nDems, GOP sound off on Englewood Cliffs council's makeup The divide along party lines has residents and officials criticizing members of both parties Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jFfyra\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\n3\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nDems, GOP sound off on Englewood Cliffs council's makeup\nMichael W. Curley, Jr. , Staff Writer, @MCurleyGannett Published 1:15 p.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017 | Updated 5:40 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nMayor Mario Kranjac spoke to the borough at the reorganization meeting, calling for an end to the \"politics of personal loyalty.\"\n(Photo: BernadetteMarciniak/NorthJersey.com)\nENGLEWOOD CLIFFS \u2013 The divide along party lines has residents and officials criticizing members of both parties, with Republicans on the Borough Council saying there should be no \"personal politics\" in governing the town\u00a0and Democrats expressing hope for a stronger voice in council matters.\nThe November election\u00a0changed the council makeup from a 4-2 Republican majority to a 3-3 split, with\u00a0Republican Mayor Mario Kranjac holding the tying vote. Kranjac exercised that vote twice at the Jan. 1 organization meeting to break ties in party-line votes\u00a0and once at Wednesday's \u00a0meeting, both times siding with Republicans.\nAt Wednesday's meeting, some in the audience chastised Kranjac and borough Republicans for their decisions \u2013\u00a0such as ending the borough's relationship with the Englewood Public Library in favor of Fort Lee and removing former Mayor Joseph Parisi\u00a0Sr.'s name from the municipal building \u2014 while others praised those\u00a0decisions and chastised Democrats for the \"barrage of attacks\" on Kranjac.\nTwo council newcomers sworn in Englewood Cliffs\nToward the end of the meeting, which saw council members of both parties arguing with residents and with one another, Borough Attorney Anne Marie Rizzuto chastised\u00a0officials and the public for their behavior.\n\"I've been at a lot of public meetings and represented a lot of towns, and my firm represents a lot of towns, and I'm just going to say, both to the council members and members of the public, there needs to be a better respect and a better decorum for the process,\" she said. \"The talking back and forth and the talking over each other, all you members of council, is not appropriate.\"\nDemocrats seek voice\nDemocrats said they hope\u00a0the additional representation on the council will help give them more voice in the government.\n\"I just wish and hope that he's not going to just go along party lines,\" Democrat Councilwoman Ellen Park said of Kranjac, adding she feels there is a lack of transparency and that council\u00a0Democrats\u00a0are kept \"in the dark.\"\nPark referred to the advertisement for a borough administrator , which she said she should have had advance notice of as part of the personnel committee. Council President Carrol McMorrow, a Republican, said last week that it's normal for the borough clerk to prepare and post such an ad without alerting the council.\n\"We just ask for the same notice and transparency,\" Park said. \"[Mayor Kranjac] needs to treat us the same as he would the Republican Party.\"\nWhile there will be conflicts of opinion on the council, Park said, meeting halfway on issues would go a long way toward keeping relations amicable.\n\"I hope we get a little more consensus on the council this time around,\" Democratic\u00a0Councilman Ed Aversa said. \"Maybe having an extra difference of opinion will influence the Republicans to see things a little more open-mindedly.\"\nSpecifically, he said he wants the Democratic members to have a greater sayt\u00a0on the budget process.\n\"I don't think it'll be any easier [to get issues resolved], I just think having another voice up there might help,\" Aversa said. He added he and others on the council, such as\u00a0fellow Democrat\u00a0Gloria Oh, feel they are not listened to by the mayor when they offer\u00a0opinions and recommendations.\nAt the organization meeting, Oh had said the mayor had not spoken to her about his appointments.\n\"We are not part of the discussion, and we should be part of the discussion,\" Oh said at the meeting.\nPrevious mayors, Aversa said, spoke to members of both parties before\u00a0the organization meeting to discuss appointments and borough professionals, something he said did not happen this year or last.\n\"Give us information and let us make an informed decision that's best for Englewood Cliffs,\" he said.\nRepublicans say they're open\nKranjac said the shift on the council will not have an effect on the town, adding while he has been mayor, all council members have had a voice and ability to communicate their concerns with him.\n\"Whether or not they took the time to do that is not something I can control,\" he said, adding politics should be kept out of the borough as a workplace.\n\"If everyone does their job on the council properly and for the best interests of the borough, rather than their political party, we should never have a tie vote,\" Kranjac\u00a0said. \"The days of politics of personal loyalty are over, and it is the borough that we all must be loyal to.\"\nMcMorrow said she welcomed the\u00a0new council members and\u00a0looks forward to working with members of both parties, adding she was \"very disappointed\" when the three Democratic council members voted no on her nomination for council president, with Oh voting, \"absolutely not.\"\n\"Clearly that action is not reflective of their words that they want to work together, but regardless of their actions, I will continue to be here for them and to work for our residents,\" she said.\nShe said the Democrats on the council receive the same notice and correspondence as the Republicans.\n\"They are receiving all the information we are receiving,\" McMorrow said. \"They are being given every opportunity to participate and they are not participating.\"\nAll the policies and procedures for the town are being followed, she said, adding she is \"more than happy\" to help the new council members, William Woo and Park, learn the borough's policies and procedures.\nCouncil members Oh, Woo and Mark Park could not be reached for comment.\nEmail: curley@northjersey.com\n1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 3 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jFfyra\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1710.html"], ["url", "http://archive.northjersey.com/news/lawmakers-who-led-gwb-scandal-probe-call-criminal-findings-sickening-1.1323573"], ["text", "May 1, 2015, 12:58 PM\nLast updated: Friday, May 1, 2015, 11:15 PM\nLawmakers who led GWB scandal probe call criminal findings 'sickening'\nBuy this photo\nMarko Georgiev / Staff Photographer\nState Sen. Loretta Weinberg and Assemblyman John Wisniewski at the U.S. Attorney's press conference in Newark on Friday, May 1, 2015.\nBy DUSTIN RACIOPPI and SALVADOR RIZZO\nState House Bureau\u00a0|\u00a0\nThe Record\nHearing that former Port Authority officials and a top deputy to Governor Christie allegedly caused widespread traffic jams in 2013 by closing access lanes to the George Washington Bridge was \u201csickening,\u201d said the state lawmakers leading a separate investigation into the scandal.\nBut it was also a reminder, some lawmakers said, that there is more work for them to do.\nAn in-depth look at the scandal over the lane closures at the George Washington Bridge and related aftershocks. Click here to launch .\nRelated: \u00a0 Feds: Christie allies used public resources for political vendetta; no one else to be charged in 'scheme'\nAssemblyman John Wisniewski, the Middlesex County Democrat who is co-chairman of the special legislative committee investigating the lane closings, said that \u201cthere\u2019s more to come for our committee,\u201d and added that lawmakers in New Jersey and New York should revisit their efforts to reform the Port Authority.\nRelated: \u00a0 David Wildstein pleads guilty in GWB scandal; Bridget Kelly, Bill Baroni indicted\n\u201cIt was sickening to know that there were people who were in jobs, people with great responsibility, that chose, as we suspected, the first day of school \u2026 to punish residents of the state of New Jersey for the lack of their mayor endorsing this governor,\u201d said state Sen. Loretta Weinberg, the committee co-chairwoman. The Teaneck Democrat\u2019s district includes Fort Lee, the borough at the center of the traffic jams.\nBut it was unclear on Friday how the legislative committee would proceed, and a Republican member of the panel said it should stay on the sidelines while the federal charges play out. Otherwise, she said, legislative proceedings could turn into a \u201cwitch hunt.\u201d\nRelated: \u00a0 Christie maintains he had 'no knowledge or involvement'\n\u201cTo what end is our panel going to do anything?\u201d said Assemblywoman Holly Schepisi, R-River Vale.\nDavid Wildstein, formerly a top executive and Christie ally in the Port Authority, said that the traffic jams on five weekday mornings were done by closing access lanes to the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee. Wildstein pleaded guilty to two charges in the case in federal court in Newark.\nWeinberg said the timing of the closures \u2014 overlapping with the first week of school, Yom Kippur and 9/11 remembrances \u2014 added insult to injury. Wisniewski said the scheme undermined democracy and added to public skepticism of elected officials.\n\u201cWhat\u2019s also wrong is the admission here that the Office of Intergovernmental Affairs \u2014 part of the governor\u2019s office \u2014 was engaged in seeking political endorsements for the governor\u2019s reelection campaign. These are very troubling admissions,\u201d Wisniewski said. \u201cThere\u2019s more to come for our committee.\u201d\nAssemblywoman Valerie Vainieri Huttle, D-Englewood, said the charges proved that the Port Authority is in urgent need of reform. She said Christie should \u201cstop hiding\u201d and sign a bipartisan reform bill that passed in the New Jersey and New York legislatures last year. Christie vetoed the bill, but lawmakers are planning to renew their efforts.\n\u201cWhile the U.S. Attorney\u2019s Office pursues justice for the residents of Fort Lee and the surrounding area who were victimized by the lane closures, the Legislature must work simultaneously to enact real reforms to end this culture of corruption once and for all,\u201d Huttle said. \u201cIt\u2019s time for Governor Christie to get onboard as well.\u201d\nA Republican member of the legislative committee, Assemblywoman Amy Handlin, R-Monmouth, agreed on that point.\n\u201cIt\u2019s so painfully obvious that until we can identify the clowns, then the Port Authority is going to continue to be a circus,\u201d she said.\nSenate President Stephen Sweeney, D-Gloucester, said: \u201cThese are serious charges that include the abuse of power and the betrayal of public trust. They should continue to be pursued thoroughly and those found to be responsible must be held accountable.\u201d\u00a0\nTags:\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1730.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/bergen/bergenfield/2017/01/13/bergenfield-robert-gillman-ethics-violation/96351758/"], ["text", "Ethics case appears shut against ex-Bergenfield councilman\nCostly legal defense of Robert Gillman due to five years of twists and turns in court.\nPost to Facebook\nEthics case appears shut against ex-Bergenfield councilman Costly legal defense of Robert Gillman due to five years of twists and turns in court. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jFGwit\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nEthics case appears shut against ex-Bergenfield councilman\nPhilip DeVencentis , Staff Writer, @LocalNewsPhil Published 3:18 p.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017 | Updated 9:52 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nSome Bergenfield officials want former Councilman Robert Gillman will keep his part-time job as recreation director.\n(Photo: Tyson Trish/NorthJersey.com)\nStory Highlights\nIt is unlikely that case will be pursued to the Appellate Division of state Superior Court.\nBorough Council still has not filled part-time position of recreation director.\nBERGENFIELD \u2014 The legal defense of a former councilman who was found to have violated a state law governing ethical conduct has cost the borough thousands of dollars, although his penalty amounted to just $100 \u2013 and\u00a0it was waived.\nAfter five years, the case against Robert Gillman appears to have drawn to a close. His attorney, Joseph Monaghan, said he does not \u201cbelieve there will be any further appeals.\u201d Meanwhile, Gillman's\u00a0part-time job as recreation director \u2013 a $22,500 annual appointment\u00a0he has held for three years \u2013 is hanging in the balance.\nA review of invoices obtained from the Borough Clerk\u2019s Office through the state Open Public Records Act shows $12,945 was spent to defend Gillman, who did not return a call seeking comment.\u00a0He lost a Democratic primary election in 2012.\nThe case stems from Gillman\u2019s vote in November 2011 to introduce a bond ordinance to cover the cost of constructing a proposed community center \u2014 a project that never materialized \u2014 at the PAL complex, a park off Rivera Way. He was president of the organization at the time. Gillman also voted as councilman that year to approve paying more than $15,000 in vouchers submitted to the borough by PAL. The bills were to reimburse the PAL for coaches\u2019 safety courses, field maintenance and fees to sponsor youth sports.\nArchive: Ex-Bergenfield councilman loses state ethics ruling\nWhen the bond ordinance came up for adoption, Gillman recused himself.\nJohn Smith, a local government watchdog, filed an ethics complaint against Gillman with the now-defunct local Ethics Board in April 2012. He claimed Gillman\u2019s standing with PAL, and the affirmative votes he cast, created the perception that the councilman had a conflict of interest.\nLaura Sanders, acting director and chief administrative law judge for the state Office of Administrative Law, affirmed on Nov. 1 a prior decision by the state Local Finance Board that Gillman broke a specific part of the ethics code prohibiting government officers from acting in their official capacity in any matter where they, their families or their businesses have an interest, or a direct financial or personal involvement.\n\u201cBecause he was president of PAL,\u201d Sanders said in her eight-page opinion, \u201c[Gillman\u2019s] judgment might be affected because of a desire to help that organization further its policies through continued use of the borough\u2019s facilities.\u201d\nThe board, which is a function of the state Department of Community Affairs, adopted that judgment as its final decision on Dec. 14.\n\u201cI\u2019m happy it\u2019s over with,\u201d Smith said. \u201cI didn\u2019t win \u2013 the people of Bergenfield won.\u201d\nLast week, officials threw their support behind Gillman, saying his alleged violation was based on a \u201ctechnicality\u201d and that it was \u201cde minimis\u201d in nature.\n\u201cI understand the ruling,\u201d said Borough Attorney John Schettino, whose tenure as counsel overlapped the timing of Gillman\u2019s questionable votes. \u201cWith respect to his participation, I didn\u2019t believe it rose to the level of being a conflict.\u201d\nBorough Councilwoman Ora Kornbluth, who joined the council in 2011, likened the case against Gillman to a \u201cwitch hunt.\u201d\n\u201cHe didn\u2019t derive any benefit from it,\u201d Kornbluth said, referring to Gillman's action.\nKornbluth, liaison to the Joan Schaefer Recreation Committee, said Gillman's reappointment as recreation director was among those held over when the council reorganized on New Year\u2019s Day. Councilman Christopher Tully had announced plans to resign, and Kornbluth said\u00a0she and her colleagues wanted\u00a0his successor to be part of the vote.\n\u201cI can\u2019t guarantee he\u2019ll be reappointed,\u201d Kornbluth said, \u201cbut if it was up to me, I would reappoint him. He has brought amazing new programs to town. He goes above and beyond.\u201d\nMayor Norman Schmelz, who broke a tie to reappoint Gillman as recreation director last year, said he would do the same this year if he had to.\n\u201cNo one told him not to vote,\u201d the mayor said. \u201cAll he was trying to do was get a community center for children. He wasn\u2019t going to get rich from that.\u201d\nSchmelz credited Gillman for boosting participation in last year\u2019s Halloween parade at Cooper\u2019s Pond and drawing more attractions than ever before to Family Fun Day at Veterans Memorial Park. The mayor said the former councilman also has been instrumental in growing the Lou Harris Challenger program for children with special needs.\n\u201cThey all mean good,\u201d said Smith, the government watchdog.\u00a0\u201cIt\u2019s just that, sometimes, they put the blinders on.\u201d\n1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jFGwit\n"]]
