[["name", "new_7/1833.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/08/05/vegan-big-mac-ribfest-macinnes_n_11353376.html"], ["text", "Vegan Big Mac Sells Out At Ontario Ribfest\nThe Huffington Post Canada \u00a0|\u00a0 By Zi-Ann Lum\nADVERTISEMENT\nThe show-stopping item at an Ontario festival celebrating meat didn\u2019t have any meat at all.\nThousands of people lined up for the Big MACinnes \u2014 a vegan riff of McDonald\u2019s iconic burger \u2014 at Ribfest in London, Ont. last week.\nA woman tastes a Big MACinnes at London's Ribfest.\n\u201cThe whole point of it was to illustrate we can make something out of plants and still have it taste amazing,\u201d said James McInnes of his namesake burger.\nIn the Big MACinnes, two meat patties are replaced with ones made from a mix of chickpeas, onion, and bread crumbs bound with tamari and flax flour.\nThey\u2019re thrown onto a griddle for a nice sear before being topped off with creamy homemade mayo, shredded iceberg lettuce, dairy-free cheddar cheese, and onions and pickles inside a three-part sesame bun.\nCloseup of the Big MACinnes vegan burger. (Photo: Globally Local)\nDemand was so strong for the vegan Big Mac, the burgers were sold out before the end of the five-day BBQ festival.\nMcInnes told The Huffington Post Canada he and his team went through 300 kilograms of dried chickpeas to satisfy hungry customers.\nA vegan himself, McInnes said the last time he had a McDonald\u2019s Big Mac was about four years ago. So to fine-tune his recipe, he turned to omnivore friends and family for help in taste-testing his versions.\n\u201cVegan food can really be more popular than animal-based products \u2014 even at a meat festival.\u201d\nMcInnes owns Globally Local , a business that works with farmers and suppliers to delivers organic produce and vegan products to area residents.\nAfter the success at Ribfest, he told HuffPost Canada there are plans to open a fast food vegan restaurant in London that will sell the burger.\nIt just goes to show how \u201cvegan food can really be more popular than animal-based products \u2014 even at a meat festival,\u201d McInnes said.\nAlso on HuffPost:\nBest Sources Of Protein For Vegans\nof\n\ue000\n\ue001\n\"The great Canadian hemp seed packs a whopping 10 grams of protein into a three tablespoon serving, alongside anti-inflammatory omega-3 fatty acids and calming magnesium,\"  says Vancouver-based register dietitian Desiree Nielsen. Add hemp seeds to smoothies, cereals and dips.\nAbout a quarter package of extra-firm tofu contains 11 grams of protein, in addition to a hefty dose of calcium and iron \u2014 two other minerals vegans need to pay attention to. \"Choose organic to avoid genetically modified organisms and hexane-extracted soybeans,\" Nielsen says.\nTempeh is a fermented soybean cake that is richer in flavour than tofu \u2014 seriously, you should try tempeh on a sandwich or in a rice bowl. \"A half-cup of tempeh contains 16 grams of protein. Try it crumbled in tacos or chili,\" she adds.\n\"Lentils are great for those who don\u2019t want to spend time soaking beans as they cook up quickly from a dried form,\" Nielsen says. Three-quarters cup of lentils contains 13 grams of protein and almost 5 mg of iron. Add it to soups, casseroles or puree for a creamy dip.\nThere is a reason why hummus is a powerful protein-packed food for veggies and vegans alike. \"Chickpeas are an essential part of a plant-based pantry because they are so versatile,\" Nielsen adds. Three-quarters of a cup of chickpeas contains 11 grams of protein. Enjoy them with soup, roasted with spices or even on top of a salad.\nNielsen notes edamame makes a great snack or addition to stir-fries, and contain 23 grams of protein per cup of shelled beans and almost as much calcium as a glass of milk!\nQuinoa is often touted as an excellent protein source as the protein is \"complete,\" meaning that there are no limiting amino acids, Nielsen says. \"However, it isn\u2019t as high in protein as you might expect. One cup of cooked quinoa contains 6.5 grams of protein, which is not enough to carry the whole meal. Pair it with a bean or nut for a protein-rich meal.\"\nA great snack choice or gluten-free baking ingredient, one-quarter of a cup of almonds contains 7.5 grams of protein, almost 100 mg of calcium and plenty of filling fibre. \"A cup of almond meal/flour contains 25 grams of protein,\" she says.\nDon\u2019t overlook peanuts! \"They make a great snack, or as butter, dip for fruit or baking ingredient. One-quarter of a cup of peanuts contains nine grams of protein and is a source of folate, important for women ready to start a family,\" Nielsen says. Two tablespoons of peanut butter contains 7.5 grams of protein.\nMillet, a tiny grain, cooks up fluffier than quinoa with a \u2018wheat-like\u2019 taste. \"You can even pop it as a snack. One cup of cooked millet contains 6.5 g of protein per cup; make millet porridge or serve like rice.\"\n\"Not many veggies contain a significant amount of protein but green peas are a standout, with 4.5 grams of protein per half cup,\" Nielsen says. Enjoy green peas by pureeing them into dips or soup or serve as a side dish with your favourite rice bowl.\n\"Many clients are surprised to hear that most vegetarian milk alternatives don\u2019t contain the same protein as the foods they are made from. However, soy milk made from whole soybeans, not soy protein isolates, contains eight grams of protein per cup, making it the perfect milk substitute,\" Nielsen notes. For the best amount or protein, avoid sweetened varieties of soy milk. And besides having it with cereal, you can also add it to smoothies or use it for baking. We suggest some oat, banana and soy milk pancakes!\nNot all seeds are high in protein, but sunflower seeds contain 7.5 grams of protein per quarter cup. Eat as a snack or add it to baked goods and cereals (just watch out for the salted versions).\n\"Greens are incredibly nutritious, just not necessarily for their protein content,\" Nielsen says. However, broccoli comes out on top: one cup of cooked broccoli contains four grams of protein in addition to cancer-protective phytonutrients.\nBuckwheat has nothing to do with wheat; it is a gluten-free seed that is related to rhubarb. \"It is fantastic for baking and cooking. Cooked buckwheat contains six grams of protein per cup. Add to salads, pilafs or eat as you would rice.\"\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1836.html"], ["url", "http://archive.northjersey.com/news/gwb-probe-n-j-lawmakers-subpoena-at-t-for-christie-aide-s-phone-records-1.1076835"], ["text", "\u00a9 2017 North Jersey Media Group\nAugust 27, 2014, 4:09 PM\nLast updated: Thursday, August 28, 2014, 2:42 PM\nGWB probe: N.J. lawmakers subpoena AT&T for Christie aide's phone records\nBy SHAWN BOBURG\nstaff writer\u00a0|\u00a0\nThe Record\nLawmakers investigating the George Washington Bridge lane closings are going after the telephone records of a top Christie aide, employing a new tactic in an apparent challenge to the aide\u2019s earlier sworn testimony.\nMitsu Yasukawa / Staff photographer\nRegina Egea testifying before the legislative committee in July 2014.\nDozens of subpoenas issued by the state legislative panel thus far have been directed at current or former government employees or offices, ordering them to go through their own files and produce documents related to the scandal.\nRelated: Read the subpoena\nBut the latest demand for records, issued on Monday, was sent to the telecommunications company AT&T, requesting a month of phone data \u2014 including text messages \u2014 sent or received by a Christie staffer who previously testified that she had erased a communication sent to the governor at a crucial time during the unfolding scandal.\nAT&T\u2019s response to the subpoena is likely to test the legislative panel\u2019s legal authority to obtain otherwise private text messages from a third-party telecommunications company. Such information, when sought by law enforcement, sometimes requires a search warrant. AT&T representatives did not respond to a message left at their National Subpoena Compliance Center in Florida asking if they would comply with the demand for a month of text messages sent by Regina Egea, chief of Christie\u2019s authorities unit.\nAsked about any potential legal concerns, Assemblyman John Wisniewski of Sayreville, the panel\u2019s Democratic co-chairman, said, \u201cWe have been guided by our counsel who advised us this was an appropriate way to seek information.\u201d\nThe subpoena requests all Egea\u2019s incoming and outgoing calls and text messages for December 2013.\nOn Dec. 9, Port Authority Executive Director Pat Foye and two agency employees who manage the bridge testified that a Christie loyalist at the agency had ordered the lane closings. Egea told lawmakers during her hearing in July that she recalled sending Christie a text while watching the December testimony and commenting on how \u201cprofessional\u201d the Port Authority employees seemed, but she said she believed it had been erased.\nThe governor has said he doesn\u2019t recall the text message.\nDemocratic leaders of the legislative panel said on Wednesday that the phone logs and messages, if turned over by the company, would confirm whether Egea was accurate in her description of the erased communication and whether there were other text messages.\n\u201cThis is the one and only time the head of the authorities unit texted the governor about Bridgegate?\u201d asked state Sen. Loretta Weinberg, D-Teaneck, co-chairwoman of the panel. \u201cIt just doesn\u2019t sound very forthcoming.\u201d\nWisniewski said that the committee had only received two e\u00admails involving the governor in response to a subpoena requesting all office communications related to the lane closings. The messages, already released, concerned a statement issued about former Port Authority executive David Wildstein\u2019s resignation.\n\u201cFor someone who quite visibly uses his hand-held device to communicate, it\u2019s remarkable to have only those two communications,\u201d Wisniewski said.\nThe governor\u2019s office declined to comment on the subpoena.\nState Sen. Kevin O\u2019Toole of Cedar Grove, a Republican lawmaker on the panel who often defends the administration, also did not return a request for comment.\nThe subpoena signaled that the panel intends to continue to gather information despite its stalled efforts to call more witnesses.\nWeinberg said that the U.S. Attorney\u2019s Office in New Jersey as recently as a week and a half ago requested that the panel refrain from calling 13 people identified as potential witnesses. Federal prosecutors are conducting their own grand jury investigation.\nWisniewski and Weinberg said the committee\u2019s attorney has instead been conducting informational interviews with undisclosed people.\nWeinberg said she would also like to issue a subpoena to the governor\u2019s office, demanding a list kept by Christie staffers of 100 towns that were the focus of extensive outreach.\nOne Christie staffer, Matt Mowers, testified that the list was composed of \u201cpolitically intriguing\u201d towns, but documents turned over also show that staffers volunteering for Christie\u2019s campaign tracked endorsements from some of the officials in towns on the list.\nThe governor\u2019s office previously provided the list, referred to as the T-100 list, but all towns except Fort Lee were blacked out, she said. Democrats want to know if the Christie administration, during regular government work hours and using public resources, used the list to court political endorsements leading up to the voting last November, when the governor was reelected.\nWisniewski said the committee intended to wrap up its work \u201chopefully over the fall,\u201d before recommending legislation to reform the Port Authority. Another Democrat, state Sen. Bob Gordon of Fair Lawn, said on Wednesday that he hoped New Jersey lawmakers would act sooner on two other bills aimed at making the Port Authority more transparent, including one he co-sponsored.\nWisniewski is holding up those bills in the hope of passing a broader package of reforms, including changes in how the Port Authority is governed.\nLegislation affecting the Port Authority is subject to the approval of the legislatures of New York and New Jersey and the governors of both states. The bill proposed by Gordon, and already passed by New York lawmakers, includes a package of reforms that would impose new transparency and ethics requirements, among other things.\nEmail: boburg@northjersey.com\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1839.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/bergen/dumont/2017/01/13/dumont-schools-chromebooks-stem-initiatives/96352810/"], ["text", "Dumont school officials tout Chromebooks, STEM programs\nPublic forum at high school on Jan. 17 will give progress report on both initiatives.\nPost to Facebook\nDumont school officials tout Chromebooks, STEM programs Public forum at high school on Jan. 17 will give progress report on both initiatives. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jG4ryr\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nDumont school officials tout Chromebooks, STEM programs\nPhilip DeVencentis , Staff Writer, @LocalNewsPhil Published 6:28 p.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017 | Updated 10:14 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nHoniss School fifth-grader Isalia Paulino fact-checked her assignment before she turned it in on a Google Chromebook last week.\n(Photo: Marko Georgiev/NorthJersey.com)\nFifth-grade class, numbering 182 students, part of one-to-one laptop initiative.\nStudents at Honiss and Selzer schools engaged in STEM courses that teach coding.\nDUMONT \u2013 School officials are reporting positive returns from a one-to-one laptop program introduced this year to fifth-graders and STEM courses offered for the first time to older students.\nThe K-12 district will hold a public forum at 7 p.m. Tuesday to share with parents how those pilot initiatives are progressing. The event will be in the high school auditorium, at 101 New Milford Ave.\n\u201cThe school system continues to prepare our children for the world they will enter in high school, college and beyond,\u201d Superintendent of Schools Emanuele Triggiano said in a recent letter to parents.\nDr. Maria Poidomani, the district\u2019s director of curriculum, instruction and supervision, said 182 fifth-graders were equipped with Google Chromebooks this year.\nA separate program has sixth-, seventh- and eighth-graders enrolled in science, technology, engineering and math\u00a0courses, she said.\nBoth programs are covered under the district\u2019s budget for this year.\n\u201cThere are many positive things coming out of this pilot,\" Poidomani said of the Chromebooks program. \"It\u2019s a digital tool they can use all day long.\u201d\nFifth-graders were selected to roll out the program because they will have benefited from two years of technology instruction, Poidomani said. Students at that grade level also have online textbooks, making their use of laptops more conducive, she said.\nHoniss School seventh-graders, from left, Samantha Mullins, Matthew DiGirolamo and Eric Cueto tested robots they made out of Legos during a STEM course.\n\u00a0(Photo: Marko Georgiev/NorthJersey.com)\nPoidomani said the program fosters collaboration through Google Classroom, a free web-based platform in which teachers can check the status of students\u2019 assignments and give real-time feedback.\nGoogle Classroom also is used at the high school, Poidomani said, although students there do not have individual laptops.\n\u201cHaving a one-to-one program obviously increases opportunities,\u201d Poidomani said, \u201cbut whether we can afford to expand it has to be discussed.\u201d\nThe STEM courses, which Poidomani called \u201cmarking-period specials,\u201d are 10-week-long classes that officials see as pathways to similar lessons being taught at the high school.\n\u201cThese courses were put in place very economically,\u201d Poidomani said. \u201cThere was no new staff. We bought some Legos, some robots \u2013 they went in at a very low cost.\u201d\nThe courses focus on different topics, depending on grade level. Among other subjects, sixth-graders concentrate on computer programming; seventh-graders, robotics; and, eighth-graders, three-dimensional design.\n1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jG4ryr\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1841.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/08/04/yoga-first-nations_n_11289522.html"], ["text", "Yoga May Be The Medicine Aboriginal Communities Have Been Looking For\nPosted:\nADVERTISEMENT\nIt was December 2012, and John \u00e2\u0080\u009cRedbear\u00e2\u0080\u009d Terrance was thinking seriously about killing himself.\nAfter a childhood marked by physical and sexual abuse, he became an introvert. He ate cheap, packaged foods and hid in his home on the Mohawk Nation at Akwesasne, on the border between New York state and Ontario.\nHe didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t see his family for 10 years. He became extremely unhealthy, and weighed 620 pounds.\nAfter a childhood of abuse and an adult life full of unhealthy habits, John Terrance eventually weighed 620 pounds.\nOne night, \u00e2\u0080\u009ca spark went off\u00e2\u0080\u009d in his head. \u00e2\u0080\u009cI didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have the courage to kill myself, but I didn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t have the strength to live,\u00e2\u0080\u009d Terrance told The Huffington Post Canada in an interview. \u00e2\u0080\u009cI thought \u00e2\u0080\u0098OK, I need to do something about this.\u00e2\u0080\u0099\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nTerrance was too heavy for gastric bypass surgery. So, he started doing long cardio workouts three times a week and lost 70 pounds in order to qualify. In 2013, he underwent the operation and began to change his life.\nAt one point, Terrance complained to a friend that his back was always sore. She suggested yoga.\nTerrance learned the basics from an instructor he knew, and then developed his own routine to do at home. He made yoga a regular part of his workout routine, which by then he was doing six days a week.\nIt was tough at first, taking a toll on his knees and joints. But he stuck with it. And then, \u00e2\u0080\u009cthe weight just melted off.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nTerrance has now lost an unbelievable 380 pounds.\nAfter undergoing gastric bypass surgery and discovering a new passion for yoga, John Terrance has lost almost 400 pounds.\nWhen many people think of medicine, they think of pills, cough syrup \u00e2\u0080\u0094 the items easy to grab at a pharmacy.\nBut to Aboriginal communities, medicine has a completely different form and definition.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWhat medicine means is something that makes you feel good,\u00e2\u0080\u009d explained Mitch Baird, a communications manager for the Southern Ontario Aboriginal Diabetes Initiative (SOADI). \u00e2\u0080\u009cGoing for a walk in the forest is a medicine, listening to music is a medicine.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cIn native culture you look at the whole person, you don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t compartmentalize their mental health and physical health,\u00e2\u0080\u009d Baird said.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWhat medicine means is something that makes you feel good.\"\n\u00e2\u0080\u0094 Mitch Baird\nThat holistic approach of assessing mental, physical, spiritual and emotional health as one mirrors much of what\u00e2\u0080\u0099s practised in yoga. The ancient Indian discipline is \u00e2\u0080\u009cculturally appropriate\u00e2\u0080\u009d for native people, Baird said, and holds much promise for healing the illnesses plaguing them.\nDiabetes, in particular, is three to five times more prevalent in Canada\u00e2\u0080\u0099s Aboriginal communities than it is in the rest of the population, according to the Canadian Diabetes Association. In some First Nations communities, up to 26 per cent of people have the disease.\nDiabetes was extremely rare among Aboriginal people before 1940, but diet, poverty, and poor living conditions all contribute to the problem, said the association.\nFragmented health-care options and high staff turnover rates on reservations make matters even worse.\n'We need to go back to another way'\nElders have described diabetes as \u00e2\u0080\u009cthe physical manifestation of the loss of a way of life,\u00e2\u0080\u009d Baird said. In the past 100 years, Aboriginal peoples\u00e2\u0080\u0099 habits and diets have been turned upside down by colonization, he said.\nRather than hunting and eating traditional meals \u00e2\u0080\u0094 \u00e2\u0080\u009cwhat the Earth provides\u00e2\u0080\u009d \u00e2\u0080\u0094 many people now only have access to highly processed foods.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cA lot of these communities are really far away from grocery stores, so their grocery store is usually the corner store,\u00e2\u0080\u009d Baird pointed out. \u00e2\u0080\u009cWell, try eating healthy from there.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cOur bodies are saying, \u00e2\u0080\u0098We need to go back to another way.\u00e2\u0080\u0099\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nMitch Baird, standing at far left, has certified dozens of yoga instructors to bring the practice back to their remote aboriginal communities.\nTwo years ago, Baird started offering a course to train instructors after reading about the benefits of yoga for people with diabetes.\nStudies have shown that yoga can decrease a patient\u00e2\u0080\u0099s body mass index (BMI) and blood sugar levels, while increasing levels of vitamin C and glutathione, an important antioxidant.\nTo date, SOADI has certified 40 yoga teachers in remote First Nations communities in southern Ontario, and is now heading to northern parts of the province.\nYoga is ideal for remote communities because it doesn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t require expensive equipment, Baird said. All you need is a mat.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cYou don\u00e2\u0080\u0099t see fancy 24-hour fitness gyms opening in Kashechewan,\u00e2\u0080\u009d he said with a laugh.\nYoga is \u00e2\u0080\u009ca new way of returning to a traditional way of life,\u00e2\u0080\u009d said Baird.\nRen\u0102\u0160e Thomas-Hill believes yoga can bring life back to traumatized First Nations communities. (Photo: Mitch Baird/Vimeo )\nIn fact, yoga\u00e2\u0080\u0099s slow bends and stretches recall the feelings of gathering, harvesting, and paddling a canoe, said Ren\u0102\u0160e Thomas-Hill, a respected elder of the Mohawk Nation Turtle Clan from the Six Nations of the Grand River Territory.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a different word for body language,\u00e2\u0080\u009d she explained in a video interview with Baird. \u00e2\u0080\u009cIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a language we all understood a long time ago.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nIf something feels good, it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s good for you, she said. \u00e2\u0080\u009cWe are taught that our bodies are sacred. Our bodies know what we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re supposed to have.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nAfter losing two nephews, Thomas-Hill said that yoga helped her move past grief. \u00e2\u0080\u009cLife came back into me,\u00e2\u0080\u009d she said.\nAnd it could do the same for others. Many of the communities Baird visits have been traumatized, and yoga could bring them \u00e2\u0080\u009clife: real, true life.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nEvery two weeks, Baird visits the maximum-security Niagara District Detention Centre in Thorold to teach yoga.\nThomas-Hill helped him create a document explaining how the philosophies of yoga line up with traditional Anishinaabe teachings. And Baird tailors his sessions to the men based on what nation they\u00e2\u0080\u0099re from, adding phrases in their language rather than closing with the traditional Sanskrit \u00e2\u0080\u009cnamaste.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nIndigenous people are drastically overrepresented in prisons, a reality the national correctional investigator has called \u00e2\u0080\u009cdisturbing.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nWhile only 3.8 per cent of Canadians are First Nations, M\u0102\u0160tis, or Inuit, they make up more than 23 per cent of the inmate population. Indigenous Canadians are incarcerated at a rate 10 times higher than that of non-indigenous citizens.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s a language we all understood a long time ago.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n\u00e2\u0080\u0094 Ren\u0102\u0160e Thomas-Hill, Elder\nSome of the inmates in Baird\u00e2\u0080\u0099s sessions combine yoga with rituals and ceremonies from their upbringing \u00e2\u0080\u0094 making it a spiritual practice, and not just exercise.\nThe biggest success he hopes for is to see a man in prison find peace for 10 minutes, he said.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cTo see them, for maybe once in a long time, calm down and chill out \u00e2\u0080\u0094 that\u00e2\u0080\u0099s the big one for me.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nA screengrab from an online video created by Mitch Baird so people can exercise at home.\nYoga holds great promise for people struggling with grief and trauma \u00e2\u0080\u0094 especially the young, said Brittany Biedermann, a community wellness clinician and counsellor with Moose Cree First Nation. \u00e2\u0080\u009cThe things we do in counselling are almost the same as what yoga can accomplish.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nBiedermann moved to Moose Factory, a reserve about 850 kilometres north of Toronto, in 2011 after the community experienced a rash of youth suicides and needed a new counsellor. Many people still carry deep sorrow from that time, Biedermann said.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cThe things we do in counselling are almost the same as what yoga can accomplish.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nIt\u00e2\u0080\u0099s difficult to get young people to open up to a counsellor, Biedermann said. They often struggle to trust health workers, especially in remote communities where they may not stick around for long.\nBiedermann completed Baird\u00e2\u0080\u0099s yoga training in January and it \u00e2\u0080\u009cignited a passion.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cI can see yoga as being able to reach youth in ways that talk therapy can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t,\u00e2\u0080\u009d she said. \u00e2\u0080\u009cIn my sessions, we talk about stress management and healthy ways of coping, self-care, how to redirect our thoughts and manage our emotions. And all this stuff can be learned through yoga.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nTerrance, too, pointed to yoga\u00e2\u0080\u0099s mental and spiritual benefits. Even though it helped him lose hundreds of pounds, Terrance\u00e2\u0080\u0099s favourite thing about the practice is the resulting mindset.\nJohn Terrance practices yoga at the fitness centre on his reservation in northern New York state.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cIt strengthens your focus, gives you more clarity, helps with remembering. There\u00e2\u0080\u0099s so many benefits, I can\u00e2\u0080\u0099t even list it all,\u00e2\u0080\u009d he raved. \u00e2\u0080\u009cThe most noticeable one is just feeling good.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nTerrance practices at the fitness building on his reservation. Now when he goes to work out \u00e2\u0080\u0094 which is six days a week \u00e2\u0080\u0094 people are waiting for him. Between three to seven regulars follow along with his yoga routine. He even teaches private classes to a few elders, who want to improve their mobility or ease aches and pains.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cIt strengthens your focus, gives you more clarity.\"\nThis fall, he is signed up to take Baird\u00e2\u0080\u0099s course to become a certified instructor. Then, he hopes to start \u00e2\u0080\u009ca new journey\u00e2\u0080\u009d travelling across the United States and Canada, teaching yoga to other indigenous people.\nNot only did yoga transform Terrance\u00e2\u0080\u0099s body, it also altered his brain.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cMy mind is clear, I have more confidence, I feel a spiritual connection,\u00e2\u0080\u009d he said. Yoga teaches you to breathe and relax, Terrance added, even when your body is twisted into unnatural positions.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cI take that same mentality now into the outside world,\u00e2\u0080\u009d he said. \u00e2\u0080\u009cBefore I was an introvert, I was really insecure. But now when I go out, that courage is my yoga pose \u00e2\u0080\u0094 it\u00e2\u0080\u0099s holding an uncomfortable position.\u00e2\u0080\u009d\nAlso on HuffPost:\n11 Facts About Canada's First Nations\nof\n\ue001\nThe word Canada comes from the Iroquois word kanata meaning village, settlement or land.\nThere are currently over 60 First Nations languages in Canada grouped into 12 distinct language families, according to Statistics Canada.\nBefore European Settlers came to Canada, it was not uncommon for Aboriginal women to hold equal power to men, and even had to ability to take the power away from the chief, reports UBC. Women\u00e2\u0080\u0099s suffrage in Canada was not granted until 1918.\nThe North American headdress was earned, each feather representing an act of bravery.\nThere are over 600 different tribes in Canada each with their own culture and belief system.\nThe High King of France commissioned Giovanni da Verrazzano to reach Asia by sailing around North America in 1523. He described the coastline as densely populated and full of bonfire smoke, saying it could be smelt from hundreds of miles away at sea. Some academics place the American Aboriginal population at 50 million while some argue it to have been 100 million. Today\u00e2\u0080\u0099s First Nations population of Canada falls around 1.4 million.\nDuring the early days of colonization, Britain saw Aboriginal people as essential to protecting their colonies and considered them powerful allies who helped battle the French during the Seven Year War and fought off American invasion during the War of 1812.\nFirst Nations people played a major role during the fur trade between the 17th and 19th centuries, which attracted merchants from around the world.\nArchaeology tells us that aboriginal people have lived in the Maritimes provinces of Canada for at least 11,000 years.\nAfter the decline of the fur trade and the end of the War of 1812, more settlers came to Canada, creating a large enough population to protect their own borders. First Nations were seen as impeding on economic development and were sent to live on isolated reserves, while more land was set aside to accommodate new settlers.\nAboriginal people have the youngest demographic in Canada, with a median age of 28, while the median age for non-aboriginal Canadians is 41.\nConservative leader Stephen Harper's wife Laureen dances with Vinay Virmani as they attend a campaign event in Brampton, Ontario on Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2015.\nLiberal Leader Justin Trudeau makes a funny face with a young child during a campaign stop at a restaurant, Oct. 14, 2015 in Welland, Ont.\nNDP leader Tom Mulcair and his wife, Catherine help their grandson, Raphael, onto a giant pumpkin while visiting a farm, Oct. 14, 2015 in L'Assomption, Quebec.\nConservative Leader Stephen Harper is photographed by a supporter as he attends a campaign event at the J.P. as he and his wife Sophie step off the plane Friday, October 9, 2015 in Yellowknike.\nNDP leader Tom Mulcair boards the bus with his grandson, Raphael, Friday, October 9, 2015 in Thursday, Oct. 9, 2015.\nLiberal Leader Justin Trudeau delivers remarks during a campaign event at a grocery store Friday, October 9, 2015 in Toronto.\nNDP leader Tom Mulcair speaks to supporters as he arrives at a town hall meeting Friday, October 9, 2015 in Montreal.\nMembers of the RCMP grab a protester during a campaign event by Conservative leader Stephen Harper in Surrey, B.C. Watson adopted Beatrice from Iqaluit.\nNDP Leader Thomas Mulcair takes a selfie with a supporter in Winnipeg on Aug. 20, 2015.  His speech in front of almost 1,000 NDP supporters was interrupted by environmental protesters chanting \"Stop Energy East,\" referring to the proposed pipeline that would carry one million barrels of oil daily from Alberta to the East Coast.  \"Listen, I'm more than willing to put up with your screaming but I'm talking about First Nations,\" he said to loud cheers from supporters. \"Can you show a little bit of respect please?\"\nThomas Mulcair, centre, picks up a young boy during a campaign stop in Surrey, B.C., on Aug. 19, 2015.\nJustin Trudeau greets people while attending the 20th Annual Mela Gadri Babian Da cultural festival in Surrey, B.C. on Aug. 20,\nProtesters block a media bus emblazoned with Conservative logos as it arrives to Stephen Harper's rally in London, Ontario on Aug. 19.\nBloc Quebecois Leader Gilles Duceppe talks to reporters as he takes a lunch break after a press conference in Montreal on Aug. 19.\nJustin Trudeau speaks to kids at Le Centre Culturel Franophone de Vancouver during a campaign stop on Aug. 19, 2015.\nNDP Leader Thomas Mulcair gets off a float plane in B.C. on Aug. 19, 2015. If his party is elected, he promised to create more than 100,000 child-care spaces for B.C.\nLiberal Leader Justin Trudeau takes a selfie with a supporter following a campaign stop in Mount Pearl, N.L., Sunday, September 20, 2015. In a speech there, Harper took aim at the federal and Ontario Liberals over the province\u00e2\u0080\u0099s retirement pension plan, nicknaming it the \u00e2\u0080\u009cJustin-Wynne-Kathleen-Trudeau\u00e2\u0080\u009d tax hike.\nA Conservative supporter, who wouldn't divulge his name, expresses his frustrations to reporters before calling them \"pieces of shit\" in Toronto on Aug. 18, 2015.\nGreen Party Leader Elizabeth May campaigns in Sidney, B.C. on Aug. 18, 2015.\nNDP Leader Thomas Mulcair speaks to a crowd in Courtenay, B.C. on Aug. 18. 2015. Marie, Ont. on Aug. 18. 2015. On a campaign swing through northern Ontario, he said a Liberal government would invest millions to support a clean technology initiative.\nConservative Leader Stephen Harper pledged to cut red tape for small businesses at an event in London, ONt. on Aug. 19, 2015.\n\"Took some time with Ben today to have a little fun!\" (Posted on Aug. 17, 2015)\nLiberal leader Justin Trudeau gives a high-five to a young boy on his father's shoulders as he arrives for a rally Friday, August 28, 2015 in Montreal.\n\"Thank you to the Royal Canadian Legion in Fredericton for hosting Laureen and me this 17, 2015.\nLiberal Leader Justin Trudeau sits for a photo-op about the Canada Child Benefit with the Vahidy family in Ajax, Ont.\nBloc Quebecois Leader Gilles Duceppe greets supporters during a while Erika Golem, right, laughs during a campaign visit to the Regina Farmers' Market in Regina on Aug. 12, 2015.\nNDP Leader Tom Mulcair, left, announces during a press conference that former Saskatchewan finance minister Andrew Thomson, right, will run as an NDP candidate in the Toronto riding of Eglinton-Lawrence against Conservative incumbent Joe Oliver in Toronto on Aug. 14, 2015.\nNDP Leader Tom Mulcair speaks to supporters at a campaign rally in Vancouver on Aug. 9, 2015.\nLiberal Leader Justin Trudeau addresses a Liberal rally in Ottawa on Aug. 9, 2015.\nLiberal Leader Justin Trudeau calls his wife after the first federal leaders debate in Toronto on Aug. 6, 2015.\nNDP Leader Tom Mulcair speaks to reporters during a press conference following the first federal leaders debate of the 2015 Canadian election campaign in Toronto. The often passionate orator kept \"Angry Tom\" at bay, but in so doing kept a near-constant smile on his face \u00e2\u0080\u0094 a look some viewers on social media described as \"creepy.\"\nGreen Party Leader Elizabeth May speaks to reporters during a press conference following the first federal leaders debate on August 6, 2015. Many viewers felt May stole the spotlight.\nLiberal Leader Justin Trudeau speaks to reporters. He admitted during the leaders' debate that his stance on Bill C-51 was perhaps \"naive.\" But he also wasted little time going after his political opponents, keen to shed the charge that he\u00e2\u0080\u0099s not ready to lead the country.\n\"I am sure if you have teenagers you'll agree with me - these two are well-practiced debaters!\" Stephen Harper posted a photo with his children on Facebook before the first federal leaders' debate in Toronto.\nConservative Leader Stephen Harper and his wife Laureen are greeted as they arrive for the first federal leaders debate of the 2015 Canadian election campaign in Toronto on Aug. 6.   Harper was attacked on the economy, his environmental record, the Senate scandals,\nHere are the best 10 quotes from the leaders' debate.\nNDP Leader Tom Mulcair arrives to meet reporters for a press conference in Toronto on August 6, 2015.\nNDP Leader Tom Mulcair waves to supporters as he arrives for the first federal leaders debate.\nGreen Party Leader Elizabeth May greets dignitaries as she arrives for the first federal leaders debate. During the televised event, she attacked Tory leader Stephen Harper on his economic record and pushed NDP Leader Thomas Mulcair on his pipelines position.\nLiberal Party Leader Justin Trudeau greets supporters as he arrives for the first federal leaders debate.\nLiberal Leader Justin Trudeau warms up in the ring with Paul Brown during a photo op at Paul Brown Boxfit in Toronto on August 6, 2015 prior to the first election debate.\nNDP Leader Thomas Mulcair Mulcair speaks at a press conference in Toronto on August 6, 2015.\nLiberal Party leader Justin Trudeau leaves a rally as he begins campaigns for the upcoming federal election in Mississauga, Ont., on Tuesday, August 4, 2015.\nNDP Leader Tom Mulcair delivers a speech during a campaign stop in Montreal on Tuesday, August 4, 2015.\nConservative leader Stephen Harper picks up chicken wings while grocery shopping with his son Ben Tuesday, August 4, 2015 in Toronto.\nAn anti-Stephen Harper protester blocks the party's campaign bus during a Conservative party federal election rally on Westbury Avenue in Montreal on Sunday, August 2, 2015.\nAnti-Stephen Harper protesters block the party's campaign bus during a Conservative party federal election event on Westbury Avenue in Montreal on Sunday, August 2, 2015.\nAnti-Stephen Harper protesters block the party's campaign bus during a Conservative party federal election event on Westbury Avenue in Montreal on Sunday, August 2, 2015.\nAn anti-Stephen Harper protester is detained by police prior to a Conservative party campaign event on Westbury Avenue in Montreal on Sunday, August 2, 2015.\nNDP Leader Tom Mulcair launches his campaign at the Museum of History in Gatineau, Que., after Prime Minister Stephen Harper called an election on Sunday, August 2, 2015.\nLiberal Leader Justin Trudeau speaks during his election campaign launch in Vancouver, B.C., on Sunday August 2, 2015. A federal election will be held on October 19.\nPrime Minister Stephen Harper visits Governor General David Johnston, along with his wife Laureen, to dissolve parliament and trigger an election campaign at Rideau Hall in Ottawa on Sunday, August 2, 2015.\nConservative Leader Stephen Harper gets instructions on how to operate a machine that puts the finishing touch to a radiator while touring a industrial parts manufacture Monday, August 3, 2015 in Laval, Que.\nLiberal Leader Justin Trudeau, right, greets supporters during a campaign stop in Calgary, Alta., Monday, Aug. 3, 2015.\nNEXT: 10 Best Quotes From The Maclean's Leaders' Debate\nUP NEXT: Politicians Who've Switched Allegiances\nNDP Leader Thomas Mulcair has faced some criticism for reportedly talking to the Conservatives in 2007 about advising their team.  Mulcair, a former Quebec Liberal, denies he ever intended to run for the Tories.  However, several other prominent Canadian politicians have changed their political stripes.  (Information courtesy of The Canadian Press' Stephanie Levitz)\nAccording to several biographies of the current Conservative prime minister, when he was in high school in the 1970s, he ran in Liberal circles.  The prime minister of the time was Pierre Trudeau, and Harper was recruited by one of his classmates to join his high school Liberal club.  But soon after graduation, Harper moved west and as the story goes, lost respect for the elder Trudeau over the implementation of the national energy program, beginning his long road to leader of the Conservative party.\nTrudeau also prompted Rae to get involved in politics, where he got his first taste of the life volunteering for the Liberals.  After returning from studying in England, he joined the New Democrats, eventually being elected as an NDP MP before leaving Ottawa to lead the provincial NDP and becoming premier of Ontario.  In 1998, he resigned from the NDP but didn't sever political ties with them until 2002.  That year, he argued in an essay published by the National Post that he no longer supported the party's approach to the Middle East and its opposition to the World Trade Organization.  \"This is not a vision of social democracy worthy of support,'' he wrote at the time.  In 2006, he declared his allegiance to the Liberals, running for its leadership but losing.  He became a Liberal MP in 2008 and the party's interim leader following the 2011 election.\nMulcair named former Conservative cabinet minister Lawrence Cannon as the one who approached him to join the Conservatives.  The duo knew each other from their days with the Quebec Liberals; Cannon represented that party in the Quebec National Assembly for nearly 10 years before Mulcair joined their ranks.  And Cannon backed Sheila Copps when she ran for leadership of the federal Liberals in 2000.  But he then left the party for the private sector, reportedly disillusioned over Jean Chretien's handling of the 1995 Quebec referendum and the subsequent sponsorship scandal.  He went back into municipal politics for a time and then joined the Conservatives.  \"The decision of Lawrence Cannon to join the Conservative party will help us build a new, clean federalism in the province,'' Harper told a 2005 press conference announcing Cannon's candidacy.  He was elected in 2006, serving in two cabinet posts before losing his seat in the 2011 election and being appointed ambassador to France.\nThe chance to represent Canada abroad also appeared to lure David Emerson across the aisle.  The long-time businessman was wooed by the Liberals to join their party for the 2004 election and he was elected in a Vancouver riding that year, going on to become industry minister.  In the 2006 election he ran for the Liberals again, repeatedly attacking the Tories, and won his seat. That campaign saw the Harper Conservatives eke out a minority government victory.  When Harper and his team showed up at Rideau Hall to be sworn in, Emerson was with them and was named international trade minister.  The Toronto Star had reported that while in the Liberal cabinet, Emerson had objected to a softwood lumber deal the government was close to disclosing. Emerson told reporters he made the partisan switch to serve his constituents better.  \"I am pursuing the very agenda that I got involved to pursue when I was in the Liberal party supporting Paul Martin. I'm continuing to pursue it,'' he said in 2006.  He did not stand for re-election in 2008.\nThe Nova Scotia MP was first elected in 1997 as a Progressive Conservative and in 2003 ran for the leadership of that party, losing to Peter MacKay.  Though later that year he voted in favour of the PC's merging with the Canadian Alliance to form the new Conservative party, only days after the merger he announced he was going to sit as a Liberal.  In later interviews, he said he was told by those in the Canadian Alliance, including Stephen Harper, that the fact he was gay wouldn't hold back his political career within the new party.  But he said he was also told the Conservatives would continue to champion issues that were important with its socially conservative base.  \"I could not run for a party that I did not want to win the election,'' Brison said in a 2006 interview.\nThe Toronto-area Tory sent a shock through political circles when she showed up alongside Liberal Leader Justin Trudeau at a news conference earlier this year and announced she was joining his team.  Adams had long ties to the Conservatives dating back to the Mulroney days, and had been elected for the party as an MP in 2011, winning a coveted suburban riding away from the Liberals.  Eventually, she became romantically linked with Dimitri Soudas, Harper's former director of communications who went on to become executive director of the party.  He lost that position after being accused of meddling in her nomination campaign for the 2015 election, which eventually led to both of them being excommunicated from the party.  When Adams announced her decision to join the Liberals, she said it was because she no longer supported the Conservatives' policy approach, specifically their income splitting policy.  \"I cannot support mean-spirited measures that benefit only the richest few,'' she said.  She has yet to be formally nominated as a Liberal candidate for the upcoming election.\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1842.html"], ["url", "http://archive.northjersey.com/news/legislative-panel-wants-13-more-to-testify-in-gwb-investigation-1.1042385"], ["text", "June 26, 2014, 7:39 PM\nLast updated: Friday, June 27, 2014, 2:02 PM\nLegislative panel wants 13 more to testify in GWB investigation\nState Assemblyman John Wisniewski and state Sen. Loretta Weinberg at an earlier joint investigative committee hearing.\nBy SHAWN BOBURG\nstaff writer\u00a0|\u00a0\nThe Record\nThe leaders of a legislative panel investigating the George Washington Bridge lane closures want to call 13 more people to provide sworn testimony, including members of Governor Christie\u2019s office and top officials at the Port Authority, according to a document obtained by The Record on Thursday.\nThe list signals Democratic lawmakers\u2019 intention to carry on with the inquiry \u2014 which has faced Republican resistance \u2014 well into the summer and possibly beyond. It includes a top political strategist for Christie, Michael DuHaime; Christie\u2019s former chief counsel, Charles McKenna; and the director of the unit that oversees independent authorities, Regina Egea. Top Port Authority officials and the Fort Lee mayor are on the list.\nIt was compiled by the two Democrats who together head the joint legislative committee, state Sen. Loretta Weinberg of Teaneck and Assemblyman John Wisniewski of Sayreville, and has been circulated to other members of the committee.\nBut it remains to be seen if federal prosecutors, who are conducting a criminal probe, will object to any of the individuals testifying.\nNew Jersey U.S. Attorney Paul Fishman\u2019s office requested last month that previously scheduled testimony by Port Authority Executive Director Pat Foye be postponed. Democrats remain interested in calling on Foye, who is on the list, as is his New Jersey counterpart at the Port Authority, Deputy Executive Director Deb Gramiccioni. Gramiccioni worked in Christie\u2019s office as a deputy chief of staff at the time of the lane closures.\nThe committee has tentatively scheduled its next meeting July 8.\nWeinberg said the committee\u2019s attorney was waiting to hear from Fishman\u2019s office whether it had any objections. After that, the committee leadership expects to decide the order of the potential witnesses, she said.\nThe Democratic-led committee has used its subpoena power to gain access to documents and compel testimony, but some of the central figures in the scandal have refused to turn over records or testify before the committee, asserting their constitutional protection against self-incrimination.\nRebekah Carmichael, a spokeswoman for Fishman\u2019s office, declined to comment on the list Thursday. The governor\u2019s office did not immediately respond to a request for comment Thursday evening. Neither did a Port Authority spokesman.\nThe explosive e-mails and text messages, obtained and first reported by The Record, sparked a political firestorm that extended far beyond New Jersey and Fort Lee. For full coverage, click here .\n\u201cWe\u2019ve gone overboard at this point,\u201d said Assembly Minority Leader Jon Bramnick. \u201cIf you have politicians investigating politicians, it will never end.\u201d\nAn attorney for one of the individuals, Port Authority police union President Paul Nunziato, said his client would be willing to come before the committee. Nunziato has already spoken with federal prosecutors.\n\u201cPaul Nunziato has and will continue to cooperate with all valid investigatory bodies,\u201d said Charles Sciarra.\nOthers on the list: Fort Lee Mayor Mark Sokolich; Philippe Danielides, former senior adviser to former Port Authority Chairman David Samson; Phillip Kwon, deputy general counsel at the Port Authority; Nicole Crifo, former senior counsel in Christie\u2019s Authorities Unit and currently Gramiccioni\u2019s chief of staff; Evan Ridley, an aide to the governor; Christopher Porrino, governor\u2019s chief counsel; and Paul Matey, governor\u2019s deputy chief counsel.\nWeinberg said she would like to see the legislative committee\u2019s inquiry finished by September.\n\u201cI\u2019m hoping that\u2019s when we\u2019ll be ready to say whatever we\u2019re going to say about this,\u201d she said.\nRepublicans on the committee have criticized the investigation as an attempt to score points against Christie instead of fixing the Port Authority. A report commissioned by Christie\u2019s office found the governor had no prior knowledge of the lane closures.\nEmail: boburg@northjersey.com\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1846.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/07/27/christy-clark-fentanyl-health-emergency_n_11233398.html"], ["text", "B.C. Premier Christy Clark Calls For Federal Help As Fentanyl Deaths Climb\nCP \u00a0|\u00a0 By                                                                      Camille Bains, The Canadian Press\nPosted:\nreddit\nADVERTISEMENT\nVANCOUVER \u2014 Overdose deaths have climbed to such an urgent level in British Columbia that the province needs help from the federal government to deal with a public health emergency, Premier Christy Clark says.\nClark told a news conference Thursday she wants Ottawa to restrict access to devices involved with drug production, such as pill presses and tableting machines, and to pursue stronger penalties against people who import and traffic fentanyl.\nClark also called on the federal government to ask the Canada Border Services Agency to search small packages, including envelopes, for fentanyl in order to stop the drug from entering the country.\nRecent statistics from the coroners' service in B.C. show there were 371 deaths in the first six months of this year, about a 74-per-cent increase compared with the same period last year.\nChristy Clark during a news conference where the government announced a joint task force on overdose response, in Vancouver, July 27. (Photo: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press)\nThe service said the proportion of deaths where toxicology tests detected fentanyl jumped to about 60 per cent and that the drug was either used alone or in combination with other drugs.\n\"That scope is alarming. It's frightening and it's something that all of us should be concerned about,\" Clark said at St. Paul's Hospital in Vancouver, where she was flanked by police, ambulance and firefighting officials, as well as addiction experts.\nHealth Minister Terry Lake said various federal agencies would join forces to deal with other public health crises, which he said needs to happen as B.C. fights a rising death toll that prompted the province to declare a public health emergency in April.\n\"If this were SARS or Ebola, Health Canada and border security and immigration would all be focused on this as a health issue that is essentially like a pandemic,\" Lake said. \"I think when we put our minds to it we can do these things even though they appear to be difficult.\"\n\"If this were SARS or Ebola, Health Canada and border security and immigration would all be focused on this as a health issue that is essentially like a pandemic.\"\nClark said B.C. is forming a joint task force involving the provincial health officer and the director of police services to identify ways to prevent and respond to overdoses.\n\"They'll have two main goals: to get those deadly drugs off our streets and to get people the help that they need,\" she said.\nClark said the province will improve access to treatment regimes, including its opioid substitution program, and will launch a public education campaign to draw attention to the dangers of laced drugs.\n\"Drug overdoses are absolutely senseless deaths. Every one of them is a preventable tragedy that families feel in the worst possible way,\" she said.\n\"Some have lost their lives to a tainted pill at a party. They didn't know what they were taking. Others were taken by that needless burden of addiction that they can't kick. We need to support all of them.\"\nThe B.C. Centre for Disease Control also released measures on Wednesday it believes will help tackle the problem after meeting with public health officials and the coroners' service.\n\"Drug overdoses are absolutely senseless deaths.\"\nIt wants to expand the availability of naloxone to reverse overdoses, expand access to opioid substitution treatments like suboxone and methadone and increase checks on street drugs, among other things.\nLeslie McBain, whose 25-year-old son Jordan Miller died in February 2014 after becoming addicted to prescribed oxycodone for a workplace back injury, said she's hoping the task force will consider the efficacy of safe-injection sites and more services to keep vulnerable people alive.\n\"We couldn't find the support that he needed, either medical support or psychological support and so on,\" McBain said of her son, who relapsed after going into detox.\nBetter training needed for family doctors: expert\nDr. Keith Ahamad, an addictions specialist, said more family doctors must be trained in recognizing and preventing addiction, similar to other chronic conditions such as high blood pressure and diabetes.\nThat's the only way people dealing with addictions will stop bouncing in and out of emergency departments where staff are overwhelmed, he said.\nAhamad said St. Paul's Hospital will open an addiction medicine clinic in the coming months to treat patients from throughout British Columbia.\n\"We're going to be helping stabilize patients and transitioning them back to their doctors' offices with very comprehensive plans in place.\"\nAlso on HuffPost:\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1848.html"], ["url", "http://archive.northjersey.com/news/gwb-scandal-u-s-attorney-discounts-rumors-of-imminent-indictments-1.1053394"], ["text", "\u00a9 2017 North Jersey Media Group\nJuly 17, 2014, 5:14 PM\nLast updated: Thursday, July 17, 2014, 5:19 PM\nGWB scandal: U.S. attorney discounts rumors of imminent indictments\nBy KAREN SUDOL\nStaff Writer\u00a0|\u00a0\nThe Record\nThe U.S. attorney investigating the George Washington Bridge scandal today discounted reports that said indictments are imminent.\nCarmine Galasso/Staff Photographer\nU.S. Attorney Paul J. Fishman\n\"As you probably know, I rarely, if ever, comment on ongoing investigations by my office and I'm not going to comment on that investigation,\u201d U.S. Attorney Paul Fishman said after an event in Newark this afternoon.\n\u201cI will say this - reports in the press that purport to describe what I might be thinking or what the people who are working on that matter might be thinking or contemplating have been almost entirely incorrect. You should be wary of reports that attribute - are for attribution or otherwise - what we're thinking or what we're doing.\"\nFishman\u2019s office is one of several agencies investigating the lane closings at the foot of the bridge in Fort Lee last September.\nA former Port Authority official appointed by Governor Christie appears to have arranged the lane closings and discussed the issue with one of the governor\u2019s deputy chiefs of staff. Christie fired that aide once emails between her and the Port Authority official were made public in January.\nEmail: sudol@northjersey.com\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1850.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/07/07/bc-death-midwives_n_10866552.html"], ["text", "B.C. College Serves Cease And Desist Letter To 'Death Midwives' Group\nCP \u00a0|\u00a0 By                                                                      Camille Bains, The Canadian Press\nPosted:\nreddit\nADVERTISEMENT\nVANCOUVER \u2014 When a close family friend died last August, Satwinder Bains got a call asking her to help give the dead woman a bath.\n\"It was such an honour, such a privilege to be able to do it,'' said Bains, a professor of Sikh studies at the University of the Fraser Valley in Abbotsford, B.C.\nThe Sikh tradition of joining others to pray for a deceased loved one and bathing the person entering \"a new journey\" is a sacred rite and has nothing to do with religion, she said.\n\"At the time of death, both prayer and person will be by your side,\" said Bains of the simple ritual that is similar to practices in other cultures and involves dressing the deceased and combing his or her hair before cremation.\nBains said the tradition is highly personal and she finds it tough to consider it as part of a so-called death midwifery service.\n\"I think to take away that privilege and give it to a death midwife or whatever is so difficult to get around.\"\nMidwifery subject to regulations\nThe College of Midwives of British Columbia is also challenging use of the word midwifery because it's regulated as part of a profession with certain education and training standards, regulations and a complaints process.\nRegistrar Louise Aerts said the college has issued a cease and desist letter to the Canadian Integrative Network for Death Education and Alternatives for using the title midwife for people who are not registered with the college and to remove it from its website and any advertising.\nAerts said midwifery is regulated in 10 provinces and territories, with Newfoundland and Labrador and New Brunswick in the process of regulating it and the Yukon involved in preliminary discussions to do the same.\n\"The reason that it's a protected title is that the colleges have the legislated mandate to protect the public,\" she said.\n\"We do have an expectation from the Ministry of Heath that we will take action on this type of thing.\"\n\"Personally, I think the terminology doula is clear. It makes more sense.\"\nThe website for the Canadian Integrative Network for Death Education and Alternatives says a death midwife offers support such as bathing the \"death journeyer\" and guidance to families regardless of whether they use a funeral home. It also compares the role of a birth midwife to a death midwife.\nA spokesperson for the network could not be reached for comment.\nAerts said those who call themselves death midwives could instead go with the term death doulas.\n\"Personally, I think the terminology doula is clear. It makes more sense. I understand the parallels to midwifery and why they're using it, but doula connotes that supportive role and it's not a restricted title.\"\nSarah Kerr, a death midwife in Calgary, said the College of Midwives of Alberta has not contacted her about using the term.\nHowever, Sheila Harvey, registrar of the College of Midwives of Alberta, said the college does not support anyone's use of the title midwife without specific training for the job but that the college is not yet an independent body under the Health Professions Act so it can't take action against people who use the title.\n'We're all on the same team'\nKerr said she opted to call herself a death midwife instead of a death doula when she started her business three years ago because \"the sound of it appealed to me more.\"\n\"I'm not so concerned about titles,\" she said. \"I'm more concerned that families have options. This is a whole new field and right now it's calling itself death midwifery and it's a lay person's movement of people stepping forward and offering different services and support to dying people and their families.\n\"We're all on the same team, birth midwives and death midwives. Birth midwives fought very hard decades ago and even more recently to make options available for families. And death midwives are doing the same thing.\"\nKerr said she provides a variety of services depending on a family's wishes, such as facilitating a storytelling circle about the dying person or a \"living funeral\" where people gather to say goodbye.\nAlso on HuffPost:\n\ue001\n\"One of the most wonderful doulas there is!\"\n\"Her voice grounds you to the present, centers you, supports you and encourages you to surrender.\"\n\"The doula in the photo also serves in the National Guard. When she got the call that the mother was in labor, she left drill to be at her side, and didn't have time to change out of her uniform.\"\n\"A doula in training witnessing the power of this mother in labor.\"\n\"In the Philippines, community is a big cultural value, and I love witnessing how a team of midwives, doula and family members come together to support the woman in labor.\"\n\"A gentle cesarean. The doula is using essential oils to help mom relax and better cope with nausea. Doulas are a great support for families needing C-sections, before, during and after the cesarean.\"\n\"This mama had the support of her husband and doula as she welcomed her third daughter.\"\n\"Doula, Djifa Jones, has just arrived at her client's home on the day of her baby's birth. She would support her client for another 12 hours before her baby girl was born.\"\n\"This stunning mama braces herself through transition contractions,  almost ready to meet her sweet baby.  Her doula,  not leaving her side,  calms and steadies her all the while knowing she will be holding her baby in her arms soon.\"\n\"Sometimes just being quietly present is more than enough support.\"\n\"In Venezuela most of the births occurs in the OR -- that's why the doulas are wearing scrubs.\"\n\"Let the tears flow.\"\nThis photo was taken at a birth in Brazil.\n\"While this mother unleashes her power in the final moments before baby comes, her doula tenderly holds her hand.\"\n\"This was an HBAC, home birth after cesarean. Her first birth did not go as planned and for her second birth she was determined to do everything possible to have a better experience. During the pushing phase, she received amazing encouragement, telling her she is strong and capable.\"\n\"While doulas are providing physical support and comfort measures to the laboring mother they also can be a calming presence and provide emotional support to the entire family.\"\n\"I love the way the doula is mirroring Mama in this image, just being in the moment with her.\"\n\"The attentive Doula assists mother and baby in nursing.\"\n\"This was the third time the mom, doula, and myself walked around the neighborhood. Mom\u2019s contractions were getting stronger and much closer together and she was getting closer to transition.\"\n\"Mom was close to birthing her baby. The warm water on her back, and her husband applying counter pressure helped make mom more comfortable during contractions.\"\n\"As a Doula, one of the sweetest moments of birth is when you gaze upon that fresh baby for the first time. You have imagined what that little babe was going to look like for so long.\"\nHome birth in Venezuela.\n\"This mother submitted to the birth process so beautifully, with her wonderful doula by her side.\"\n\"Mom's labor was very quick and intense. We arrived at the birth center and her beautiful babe was born less than 30 minutes later.  She relied heavily on the strength of her Doula to help her through her intense contractions.\"\n\"You are not alone.\"\n\"Mom's Doula was helping her through a series of contractions that were coming right on top of each other, explaining that squatting down into the contraction might help ease it up a bit and allow her body to work with it. Through the toughest part of her labor she had continual support of her birth team, relying heavily on her doula.\"\n\"In the moments just before these parents met their baby, this doula's reassuring and peaceful presence held a safe and sacred space. She was a mother figure of the most ancient kind.\"  OR \"Attending a birth where doula support is involved never ceases to amaze me. The skilled way in which a doula is able to remind a woman of her own power with just a touch, a word, or a look is an incredible thing to witness.\"\n\"An amazing Doula lovingly looks at this sweet girl for the first time in her daddy's arm and so many emotions are running through her, not only are these her clients but also her close friends. The feeling is so overwhelming.\"\n\"As labour intensifies this mama holds on tightly to her doula and they slow dance in the hall, breathing together in perfect unison. She is her safe space.\"\n\"This mama had such an powerful birth team that consisted of her husband, sister, midwives and doula. The support was astounding, It truly does take a village.\"\n\"Extra comfort and reassurance that your body can handle birth.\"\n\"Helping mom and baby find a comfortable position and latch shortly after birth to begin their breastfeeding journey.\"\n\"Moments before her baby is born, mom takes a moment to focus during an intense contraction assisted by her doula and husband. \"\n\"A doula helps siblings understand what's happening and how they can support their mama in the birth tub.\"\nDoula-assisted birth in Venezuela.\nBabywearing doula assists mother.\n\"Surrounded by love and support of her doula (who happens to be her best friend), husband and midwife, she finds her inner strength and brings her daughter into the world peacefully.\"\n\"The calm before the most intense, beautiful, emotional moment in your life. When you don't think you can do it anymore but your doula is there to say that you CAN and you ARE.\"\n\"A doula supports mom in the kitchen as labor picks up.\"\nDoula at a C-section birth in Brazil.\n\"Mamma had just given birth moments prior and mum dad and doula sat down to soak in baby. it was a glorious moment of all that hard work. It was a reflective and celebratory moment.\"\n\"One of the greatest things a laboring women can feel during labor is love and support.\"\n\"Time to let mom get out of the pool so we can try nursing!\"\n\"After the birth of her first child left this mom feeling defeated and without choices. she decided to hire a doula for her second birth.\"\n\"Centering might just be the only thing that a doula can do to help a mother. As this doula places one finger on the mom's third eye chakra she centers her into her focus.\"\n\"C-sections rates in Venezuela are super high (70 to 90 percent) -- that\u00b4s why their work as doulas supporting mammas to have vaginal births are very important.\"\n\"In the final hours of a long and intense HBAC (Homebirth After Cesarean) journey that ultimately inspired both women to become professional doulas themselves.\"\n\"A busy delivery room: keep me focused.\"\n\"Laboring mother surrounded by her doulas: electrifying joy.\"\n\"A mother's hands holding onto the support of a doula: I trust you, hold me through this wave.\"\n\"Doula Sarah Mills helping her client relax prior to her caesarean birth.\"\nHands clutched during a water birth in Brazil.\n\"A doula is like a trail guide, familiar with the path, she keeps you hiking through the hard parts, knowing the view at the end is incredible.\" -- Mother Strong Doula\n\"Just moments after being placed on her mother's chest, the excitement is felt by all. After over 12 hours side by side, this connection between mother and doula is absolutely heartwarming.\"\nDoula assists mom during a birth in Brazil.\n\"Doula Kimberly Davis, applies counter pressure during the mother's contraction while a nurse check's the baby's heart rate.\"\n\"The laboring mother was nearing transition, her body took over they turned off her Pitocin and she labored naturally with the help of her awesome doula and husband.\"\n\"This photograph shows the doula continuing support after baby is born. Postpartum support from doulas is very common, and moms appreciate it greatly.\"\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1851.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/bergen/saddle-river/2017/01/14/saddle-river-day-hosts-annual-sandy-hook-basketball-games/96456302/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nSaddle River Day hosts annual Sandy Hook basketball games\nThe Threes for Sandy Hook program raises $3 for every three-pointer hit for those affected by the 2012 school shooting\nPost to Facebook\nSaddle River Day hosts annual Sandy Hook basketball games The Threes for Sandy Hook program raises $3 for every three-pointer hit for those affected by the 2012 school shooting Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jK0oRB\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nSaddle River Day hosts annual Sandy Hook basketball games\nSvetlana Shkolnikova , Staff Writer, @svetashko Published 5:14 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017 | Updated 6:55 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nThe Saddle River Day School hosted Threes for Sandy Hook, a program that raises $3 for Newtown, Conn., every time a three-pointer was hit during a basketball game between Ridgewood and Newtown on Saturday. At left, Ridgewood's  No. 11 Quinn Daly reaches for the ball as, from right, Drew Bradley and Marcus Gerace, both 9 and both from Newtown, watch.\n(Photo: Michael Karas/Northjersey.com)\nThis is the fifth annual game in fundraising series\n$3 donated for every three-pointer\nSADDLE RIVER \u2013\u00a0When the rebuilt Sandy Hook Elementary School opened its doors for the first time last\u00a0summer, the only reported reference to the 2012 shooting rampage in the school\u2019s former building was a refrigerator magnet with the words:\u00a0\u201cWe\u2019ll always remember.\u201d\nA less obvious symbolization of the Newtown, Conn., tragedy, which left 20 children and six school staff members dead, was in the basketball courts, built and maintained with funds raised by schools participating in the Threes for Sandy Hook\u00a0basketball program.\nThe fundraising program, which donates $3 for every three-pointer hit during a varsity, junior varsity or freshman game to a fund for Newtown, celebrated its fifth annual Sandy Hook Benefit Games at Saddle River Day School on Saturday with matchups between New Jersey and Connecticut girls basketball teams, including Newtown's, and a weekend of bonding activities.\n\u201cWe had no idea when we started this what it would be or what it would become,\u201d said Jeremy O\u2019Connell, coach of the Newtown girls basketball team. \u201cIt\u2019s now formed such a huge bond between Newtown and Saddle River Day School that we consider them part of our family and we look forward to this every year.\u201d\nThe relationship between Saddle River Day and Newtown was born from the persistence of Danny Brown, athletic director and coach of the Saddle River Day girls basketball team, who called Newtown High School \u201cabout 8,000\u201d times to contact O\u2019Connell about a partnership.\nBrown decided to reach out after reading about O\u2019Connell\u2019s Threes for Sandy Hook\u00a0program online while searching for ways to help the Newtown community shortly after the shooting.\n\u201cI saw that our kids were desperately looking to be involved with something and they weren\u2019t sure how to react emotionally or what would be good for them to do,\u201d he said. \u201cI was just searching for something to help them understand what happened and help them be involved.\u201d\nWithin two minutes of speaking to each other, Brown and O\u2019Connell said they knew they had something special.\nThe Saddle River Day School hosts \"Threes for Sandy Hook,\" a program that raises $3 for Newtown, Conn. every time a three-pointer is hit during a basketball game between Ridgewood and Newtown on Saturday, Jan. 14, 2017. (left) Ridgewood's Head Coach Karen Keyes shakes hands with Newtown's Head Coach Jeremy O'Connell.\n\u00a0(Photo: Michael Karas/Northjersey.com)\n\u201cIt was an instant friendship and it\u2019s been built on from there,\u201d Brown said.\u00a0\u201cBasketball is the driving link, but it\u2019s never been about basketball, we never really prepared to play each other. It\u2019s way more than a game, it\u2019s lifelong relationships that the girls have now built with each other.\u201d\nThe girls playing in this weekend\u2019s games were to spend the\u00a0night at Saddle River Day School, have dinner together and participate in other group festivities, Brown said. In prior years, the Newtown and Saddle River Day School varsity teams would\u00a0stay in a hotel together for the weekend.\nThe location of the benefit games alternates from Saddle River Day School to Newtown High School from year to year.\nNewtown resident Brian Shaker, who watched his daughter Natalie play with the rest of the Newtown High School varsity team against Ridgewood High School on Saturday afternoon, said\u00a0Threes for Sandy Hook\u00a0has become a meaningful annual event not just for\u00a0the players but the entire Newtown community.\nThe Saddle River Day School hosted Threes for Sandy Hook, a program that raises $3 for Newtown, Conn., every time a three-pointer was hit during a basketball game on Saturday between Ridgewood and Newtown. Newtown's Rylee Mulligan drives to the basket. Karen Keyes, Ridgewood's head coach, is in the background at left.\n\u00a0(Photo: Michael Karas/Northjersey.com)\n\u201cIt\u2019s just a wonderful thing to be able to go to another community and invite another community into our homes and share the gift of basketball,\u201d he said.\nFor more information on the Threes for Sandy Hook\u00a0program, visit threesforsandyhook.org .\nEmail: shkolnikova@northjersey.com\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1852.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/06/27/healthy-food-alternatives-snacks_n_10488734.html"], ["text", "Healthy Food Alternatives: How To Snack Smarter With Charlotte Singmin\nThe Huffington Post Canada \u00a0|\u00a0 By                                                                                                                  Brian Vinh Tien Trinh\nPosted:\nADVERTISEMENT\nSometimes all we want in life is a two-litre tub of ice cream.\nBut on the days when we know we shouldn't, it's worth noting there are healthier alternatives. Take coconut ice cream for example. What it lacks in dairy and refined sugar, it makes up with  fats found in natural oils and sweeteners like agave. The treat is one of wellness expert Charlotte Singmin's favourites.\n\"I know I'm not alone when I say I'm a sucker for sweet and salty snacks,\" says Singmin.\nHer biggest tip? It's not about giving up snacking \u2014 picking up a mindful treat can help curb hunger, restore blood sugar levels and maintain energy levels and focus.\nInstead, it's about knowing your vices and finding healthier alternatives to swap them out for. Interested? Then you'll want to listen up to what she has to say in the video above.\nRelated on HuffPost:\n21 Healthy Snacks To Take On The Go\nof\nHomemade Almond Crackers Get the recipe from Eating Bird Food.\nCurry Spiced Cashews Get the recipe from the Minimalist Baker.\nApricot Almond Energy Bites Get the recipe from Family Food Forum.\nBaked Plantain Chips Get the recipe from Grain Changer.\nChocolate Chip Cookie Dough Energy Bites Get the recipe from Jar Of Lemons.\nCitrus Kiwi Pineapple Homemade Fruit Roll Ups Get the recipe from Cotter Crunch.\nMatcha Green Tea Power Balls Get the recipe from Fit Cakes.\nPaleo Gummies With Raspberry Dust Get the recipe from Paleo Diet And Fitness.\nSweet Potato Skin Fries Get the recipe from Cotter Crunch.\nHappy Trails Goji Berry Snack Mix Get the recipe from Veggies By Candlelight.\nCherry Fruit Snacks Get the recipe from Desserts With Benefits.\nHoney Roasted Chickpeas Get the recipe from Allergy Girl Eats.\nHoney Roasted Pecans Get the recipe from Trial & Eater.\nEasy, Cheesy Vegan Kale Chips Get the recipe from To Live & Diet In L.A.\nMaple Sesame Almonds Get the recipe from Beaming Baker.\nPita Chips Get the recipe from Picklebums.\nSimple Quinoa Crackers Get the recipe from Amy's Healthy Baking.\nRoasted Creole Edamame Get the recipe from That Skinny Chick Can Bake.\nBrain-Boosting Breakfast Trail Mix Get the recipe from Healthy Helper Blog.\nTurmeric Roasted Pumpkin Seeds Get the recipe from Good Dinner Mom.\nOven Baked Beet Chips Get the recipe from Light Orange Bean.\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1856.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/06/10/b-c-bans-e-cigarette-sales-to-youths_n_10410012.html"], ["text", "B.C. Bans E-Cigarette Sales To Youths\nCBC British Columbia\nreddit\nADVERTISEMENT\nNew legislation restricting the sale and use of e-cigarettes in B.C. is coming into effect on Sept. 1, the government has announced, but it won't apply to people vaping pot.\nAccording to officials, the use of vapourizers is highest amongst young people, and the new rules aim to limit their access in the same way as tobacco.\nThe new rules include:\n- Sales limited\u00a0to adults aged 19 and above.\n- No retail displays targeting\u00a0youth.\n- No retail advertising for e-cigarettes where youths can see it.\n- No sales in public buildings.\n- Use banned on all public and private school grounds, inside public spaces and in workplaces.\n- Use banned on health authority properties, except in designated smoking and vaping areas.\nCloseup of woman smoking e-cigarette and enjoying smoke. (Photo: Getty Stock)\nCannabis exempt\nAlong with setting out rules limiting who can buy e-cigarettes and where they can be used, the legislation also defines what they are.\nThe new act defines an e-cigarette as a product or device, whether or not it resembles a cigarette, containing an electronic or battery-powered heating element capable of vapourizing an e-substance for inhalation or release into the air.\nBut the act\u00a0also has two exemptions which\u00a0means it won't apply to either medical marijuana or illegal cannabis products.\nOne exemption says it does not apply to \"prescribed medical products.\"\nThe other exemption specifically excludes controlled substance listed in the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act (Canada), which currently includes cannabis and all its derivatives.\nSmoking marijuana with a vapourizer has become increasingly popular in recent years, in part because it is perceived to be healthier than inhaling smoke.\nThe new legislation also permits the use of tobacco on health authority properties for ceremonial use in traditional aboriginal cultural activity.\nAlso on HuffPost:\n"]]
