[["name", "new_7/1861.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/05/24/alberta-drug-abuse-w-18_n_10121536.html"], ["text", "W-18 Overdoses In Alberta May Not Be Curable With Naloxone Kits\nThe Huffington Post Alberta \u00a0|\u00a0 By Sarah Rieger\nreddit\nADVERTISEMENT\nAlberta has rolled out thousands of overdose kits to help combat a growing fentanyl crisis in the province, but the kits may be powerless against an even more dangerous new opioid on the market.\nLast week, Calgary police confirmed a 35-year-old man's overdose may have been due to the presence of W-18 in his system.\nW-18 is 100-times stronger than fentanyl.\nAn official cuts a fentanyl pill in half. W-18 is a similar opioid that has recently been found in Alberta. (Photo: Getty)\nIn 2015, fentanyl was to blame for 274 overdose deaths in Alberta, according to the province's government.\nAlberta Health distributed nearly 10,000 naloxone overdose kits designed to temporarily reverse an opioid overdose, in an effort to fight back against fentanyl's growing hold on the province.\nThe take-home kits are available at harm-reduction agencies, as well as pharmacies and walk-in clinics with a prescription.\n\"We don't know if W18 is binding to the same receptors in the brain that... naloxone bind to.\"\nThe kits, however, might not reverse a W-18 overdose, largely because the way the drug works is unknown.\n\"There is very limited information on the pharmacology of W-18 so we don't know if W-18 is binding to the same receptors in the brain that opioids, such as heroin and morphine, and opioid antagonists, such as naloxone, bind to,\" harm reduction specialist Ashraf Amlani told the Globe and Mail.\nAnother issue is the drug's strength. The B.C. Centre for Disease Control believes W-18 may be too powerful for naloxone to work, Global News reported.\nMay be a potential cure for overdoses\nThere is one small piece of good news. The formula behind the drug might also hold the key to an equally strong cure.\nUniversity of Alberta scientists first developed the drug in the 1980s, according to the National Post.\nThose scientists, who never tested the drug on humans, looked at both opioids and antidotes.\n\"In addition to the ones that had varying degrees of analgesic activity there were also compounds that were developed in that series which were actually antagonists , they would actually block the actions of things like morphine at the receptor, so it had no effect,\" retired U of A professor Ed Knaus told the Calgary Sun.\nNaloxone option for now\nUntil another cure is developed, health officials say the current best option for W-18 users is still naloxone.\n\"If people are exposed to W-18 and they have symptoms of overdose , same as fentanyl, they should take naloxone and call 911,'' Dr. Laura Calhoun of Alberta Health Services told The Canadian Press.\n\ue000\n\ue001\nHardy and Amelia Leighton, both in their 30s, were found dead July 20, 2015, leaving behind their two-year-old son Magnus. Toxicology testing confirmed that the couple ingested toxic levels of fentanyl in combination with other drugs.\nFrom January to May 2015, 54 deaths were linked to fentanyl. From July 7 to Aug. 7, 2015, fentanyl was detected in at least 12 deaths, said the BC Coroners Service.   In 2012, there were a total of 15 deaths related to the narcotic.\nJack Bodie, 17, and a 16-year-old friend were both found unconscious in a Vancouver park on Aug. 1, 2015 in a suspected fentanyl overdose.   The teens were rushed to hospital where Bodie was placed on life support but he died a day later. His friend recovered and was released from hospital.   Police believe the pair took fake Oxycontin.\nPolice in Delta, B.C. said it's a miracle that no one died after nine people overdosed within a 20-minute period on what are believed to be drugs laced with fentanyl.  Emergency crews responded to a series of nearly simultaneous calls from four locations about recreational drug users who thought they were taking cocaine.\nFake Oxycontin pills containing fentanyl are displayed during a news conference at RCMP headquarters in Surrey, B.C., on Sept. 3, 2015. Fentanyl is 50 to 100 times more toxic than morphine.\nThe cheap synthetic opioid often added in drug labs to heroin or Oxycontin to make it more potent and fast-acting, according to police.   (Pictured is a photo released by Vancouver police of packages of fentanyl which users thought were heroin.)\nNorth Vancouver RCMP said they suspect the death of a 31-year-old man on July 31, 2015 is also linked to fentanyl. A relative found the man in distress and called police, but he died at the scene.\nOn Aug. 9, 2015, 16 people overdosed in Vancouver \u2014 including six in one hour \u2014 from pink heroin that police suspect was laced with fentanyl.\nMounties showed off equipment, pills, money and weapons seized from a counterfeit Oxycontin production facility in Burnaby in 2015. They said there was enough fentanyl pills to put 200 to 300 people's lives at risk.  Riley Goodwin, 26, of Vancouver, has been charged with production and possession for the purposes of trafficking.\nRCMP Cpl. Derek Westwick shows off seized pill making equipment during a news conference at RCMP headquarters in Surrey, B.C. on Sept. 3, 2015. Among the gear was a pill press capable of producing 18,000 tablets an hour, said police.\nA member of the RCMP Clandestine Laboratory Enforcement Team is framed by pill manufacturing equipment while standing in a protective suit, of the type worn when dismantling drug production facilities containing fentanyl, during a news conference at RCMP headquarters in Surrey, B.C., on Sept. 3, 2015.\nRCMP Cpl. Derek Westwick of the RCMP Clandestine Laboratory Enforcement Team, holds genuine Oxycontin pills, left, and seized fake Oxycontin pills containing fentanyl, right, during a news conference at RCMP headquarters in Surrey, B.C., on Sept. 3, 2015.\nIn October 2014, Vancouver police issued a warning about fentanyl masquerading as heroin. It caused more than 30 overdoses and one death that month.\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1862.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/05/12/b-c-health-minister-predicts-record-drug-overdose-deaths-this-year_n_9942202.html"], ["text", "B.C. Drug Overdose Deaths Expected To Reach New Record In 2016: Health Minister\nCP \u00a0|\u00a0 By Geordon Omand, The Canadian Press\nPosted:\nreddit\nADVERTISEMENT\nVICTORIA \u2014 British Columbia's health minister says he's hopeful the rate of drug overdose deaths will\u00a0start dropping this month as a result of action taken by the province to curb a disturbing spike in opioid-related fatalities.\nSo far, last month's declaration of a public-health emergency doesn't appear to have slowed the number of overdose deaths, said Terry Lake, who\u00a0noted fentanyl appears to be playing an increasingly central role.\nFentanyl pills appear to be playing a central role in the increase of drug-related fatalities. (Photo: The Associated Press)\n\"The numbers are continuing to be extremely high,\" Lake said. \"We're on track for a record year.\"\nUpdated numbers released Thursday by the BC Coroners Service showed the deadly opioid was linked to nearly half of more than 250 overdose deaths tallied for the first four months of this year.\nThat's compared to about a third of the 480 overdose fatalities for all of last year.\n\"Definitely, fentanyl is a big, big part of what's going on,\" Lake said.\nThe emergency declaration\u00a0made in\u00a0April allows health officers to collect information in real time\u00a0to identify patterns and respond with preventative measures by targeting certain areas and groups of people.\u00a0The step reduces the lag of waiting for data from the coroner's office.\nNumber of deaths increasing despite emergency declaration\nBut the\u00a0number of deaths has continued to grow, despite increased outreach initiatives, aggressive awareness campaigns and the rapid distribution of the overdose-reversing drug naloxone.\n\"With the declaration of the public-health emergency, with increased availability of naloxone (and)\u00a0with the increased number of first responders available to administer it, I'm hopeful that this month we'll start to see those numbers come down,\" said Lake.\n\"But it really is something that we have to continue to talk about, to make sure people are very aware.\"\nB.C.'s medical health officer Perry Kendall said he wasn't surprised by the update.\n\"(Overdose deaths) haven't gone down yet, but I didn't really think that they would have,\" he said on Thursday.\n\"This obviously means we need to work on them.\"\nKendall predicted last month that if the number of fatalities continued to rise\u00a0at this rate, the total could exceed 800 by year's end.\nThe Fraser Valley region leads the province\u00a0with a total of 76 overdose deaths in the first four months of 2016. That's followed by 66 deaths in Metro Vancouver and 54 on Vancouver Island. There have been 45 overdose fatalities in the Interior and 15 in Northern B.C.\nAlso on HuffPost:\n\ue000\n\ue001\nHardy and Amelia Leighton, both in their 30s, were found dead July 20, 2015, leaving behind their two-year-old son Magnus. Toxicology testing confirmed that the couple ingested toxic levels of fentanyl in combination with other drugs.\nFrom January to May 2015, 54 deaths were linked to fentanyl. From July 7 to Aug. 7, 2015, fentanyl was detected in at least 12 deaths, said the BC Coroners Service.   In 2012, there were a total of 15 deaths related to the narcotic.\nJack Bodie, 17, and a 16-year-old friend were both found unconscious in a Vancouver park on Aug. 1, 2015 in a suspected fentanyl overdose.   The teens were rushed to hospital where Bodie was placed on life support but he died a day later. His friend recovered and was released from hospital.   Police believe the pair took fake Oxycontin.\nPolice in Delta, B.C. said it's a miracle that no one died after nine people overdosed within a 20-minute period on what are believed to be drugs laced with fentanyl.  Emergency crews responded to a series of nearly simultaneous calls from four locations about recreational drug users who thought they were taking cocaine.\nFake Oxycontin pills containing fentanyl are displayed during a news conference at RCMP headquarters in Surrey, B.C., on Sept. 3, 2015. Fentanyl is 50 to 100 times more toxic than morphine.\nThe cheap synthetic opioid often added in drug labs to heroin or Oxycontin to make it more potent and fast-acting, according to police.   (Pictured is a photo released by Vancouver police of packages of fentanyl which users thought were heroin.)\nNorth Vancouver RCMP said they suspect the death of a 31-year-old man on July 31, 2015 is also linked to fentanyl. A relative found the man in distress and called police, but he died at the scene.\nOn Aug. 9, 2015, 16 people overdosed in Vancouver \u2014 including six in one hour \u2014 from pink heroin that police suspect was laced with fentanyl.\nMounties showed off equipment, pills, money and weapons seized from a counterfeit Oxycontin production facility in Burnaby in 2015. They said there was enough fentanyl pills to put 200 to 300 people's lives at risk.  Riley Goodwin, 26, of Vancouver, has been charged with production and possession for the purposes of trafficking.\nRCMP Cpl. Derek Westwick shows off seized pill making equipment during a news conference at RCMP headquarters in Surrey, B.C. on Sept. 3, 2015. Among the gear was a pill press capable of producing 18,000 tablets an hour, said police.\nA member of the RCMP Clandestine Laboratory Enforcement Team is framed by pill manufacturing equipment while standing in a protective suit, of the type worn when dismantling drug production facilities containing fentanyl, during a news conference at RCMP headquarters in Surrey, B.C., on Sept. 3, 2015.\nRCMP Cpl. Derek Westwick of the RCMP Clandestine Laboratory Enforcement Team, holds genuine Oxycontin pills, left, and seized fake Oxycontin pills containing fentanyl, right, during a news conference at RCMP headquarters in Surrey, B.C., on Sept. 3, 2015.\nIn October 2014, Vancouver police issued a warning about fentanyl masquerading as heroin. It caused more than 30 overdoses and one death that month.\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1863.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/passaic/ringwood/2017/01/11/ringwood-ryerson-middle-school-students-hit-robotics-circuit-first-lego-league/96460416/"], ["text", "Ringwood students hit robotics circuit\nRingwood middle school students are rocking the region\u2019s LEGO robotics circuit.\nPost to Facebook\nRingwood students hit robotics circuit Ringwood middle school students are rocking the region\u2019s LEGO robotics circuit. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jx5Ua8\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nRingwood students hit robotics circuit\nDavid M Zimmer , Staff Writer, @dzimmernews Published 7:45 p.m. ET Jan. 11, 2017 | Updated 6:03 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nRingwood middle school's Team Ignition participated in the Dec. 10 FIRST Lego League competition in Flanders.\n(Photo: Courtesy of Ellen Gay)\nStory Highlights\nProgram utilizes LEGO-brand robot kits to teach students coding\nStudents competed on Nov. 19 in Clifton and Dec. 10 in Flanders\nRINGWOOD \u2013 Local middle school students are rocking the region\u2019s robotics circuit.\nM.J. Ryerson Middle School has two teams competing in area\u00a0FIRST Lego\u00a0League competitions this school year, Ryerson Robotics, a.k.a. Team Ignition, and Red Hot Robotics.\nThe teams of 10 face counterparts from\u00a0local schools in two main tasks. They must define and solve problems related to human-animal interaction as well as program and manipulate\u00a0self-built and super-cool Lego\u00a0robots.\n\u201cProgramming the Lego\u00a0EV3 robots is a fantastic opportunity for students to put science and math skills into practice utilizing the design process,\u201d\u00a0said Ellen Gay, a teacher in the district\u2019s gifted and talented program. \u201cIt takes skills out of the classroom and applies them to real situations and problems.\u201d\nThe 20 students participating this year must understand ratios and circumference to select proper gearing, and use creativity to design and maneuver their creations, Gay said. Moreover, they must apply\u00a0logic and physical science concepts in what\u00a0happens to be a\u00a0fun environment.\nRingwood middle school's Team Ignition participated in the Dec. 10 FIRST Lego League competition in Flanders.\n\u00a0(Photo: Courtesy of Ellen Gay)\nMembers of Lakeland Regional High School\u2019s robotics team, Xtreme Heat, serve\u00a0as team mentors.\n\u201cIt is a tremendous opportunity to have access to the FIRST program during middle school, as a steppingstone to the high school robotics team for those students interested in science and engineering,\u201d Gay said.\nThe competition is judged on three components. The first is a project to define\u00a0and solve\u00a0a real-life problem. Team Ignition focused on a way to increase the dwindling bee population. Red Hot Robotics wanted to raise healthier chickens and even visited a local farm to get some firsthand experience.\nThe second judged component tasks\u00a0them to manipulate models in a competitive setting using self-built robots. The third focuses on team cooperation and independence.\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1867.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/04/27/daybreaker-toronto_n_9789296.html"], ["text", "Daybreaker Toronto: An Inside Look At The Daytime Rave Scene\nThe Huffington Post Canada \u00a0|\u00a0 By                                                                                                                  Brian Vinh Tien Trinh\nPosted:\nADVERTISEMENT\nTime to rise and shine dance!\nThat's the idea behind Daybreaker , a series of raves hosted in several cities, including Toronto. It's got the usual hallmarks of raves: bumping music, crowds of hundreds of people and lots of strobing lights.\nBut there's a few key differences. For starters, there's no booze. Just freshly brewed coffee and pressed juice. The attire's changed up too, with participants trading in typical clubbing outfits for athletic gear. Oh and forget the late-night/early morning after mission to get back home.\nThat's because Daybreaker takes place around 6:00 a.m. on weekdays.\nIts current iteration comes courtesy of a New York group of friends who wanted to combine mindfulness, wellness, self expression, camaraderie and mischief with the vibe of a late-night party.\nCurious? You can check out the video above for a taste or relive the Toronto session here.\nRelated on HuffPost:\nMorning, Afternoon And Evening Stretches\nof\n\ue001\nStart Your Day With These 5 Simple Stretches\nThere are different variations of this stretch, but because it's still morning and we want to be gentle with our bodies before our muscles are warmed up, let's start by lying on our backs.   With arms spread out to each side, keep your feet flat on the floor with your knees bent to 90 degrees. Now, slowly let your knees fall to one side. Take a few deep breaths and relax into this position. Hold for 15 seconds and repeat on the other side.\nSitting up, either on the floor, a chair or on the side of your bed, take a deep breath and reach one arm overhead. Let your body create a nice big arc as you go into a side stretch. Hold for about 15 seconds and repeat on the other side.\nThis is one of my personal favourite stretches, because your whole body is active and you feel it from the top of your head right down to your toes.   Start by standing tall at the foot of your mat. Slowly roll forward and walk your hands forward until your body is in an inverted V position. Spread your fingers while you press your palms into the floor. Shoulders are lengthening down your back and away from your ears. Feel your glutes reach up toward the ceiling as you stretch your hamstrings and reach your heels to the floor. If you have to bend your knees slightly, that's okay. Hold for 20 seconds and repeat three times.\nThis stretch can be done standing or lying down, but let's take it easy since it's the morning.   Lying face down on your mat, gently engage your abdominals while pulling your left heel toward your glutes. Feel your hips opening into the mat as you get a stretch in your left quadriceps. If you aren't flexible enough to reach back with your hand, simply use a belt or a stretch band to help yourself out. Hold for 20 seconds on each side.\nLying on your stomach, legs about hip distance apart and hands under your shoulders, gently press your torso up while opening your chest toward to the ceiling. Keep your stomach muscles engaged so that you don't put pressure on your lower back. Hold for 15 seconds and repeat three times.\nNext: Stretches To Get You Through The Afternoon Slump\nSitting up straight on a chair, plant your feet on the floor. Gently tilt your head to the right side toward your shoulder. Place your right hand on the left side of your head and gently press down to deepen the stretch. Hold for about 30 seconds, and then repeat on the opposite side. Next, clasp your hands behind your head and very gently press your chin down toward your chest. In order to target the back of your neck, it's important to keep your spine as straight as possible.\nSitting up tall, clasp your hands and reach them up above your head. Gently arch your back, while maintaining the feeling that you are getting taller and longer. Keep breathing in and out through your nose as you hold this stretch for about 10 seconds. Now, gently arch your body to the right, hold for 10 seconds, and then to the left for another 10 seconds. Repeat as necessary throughout the day. Another great option is to clasp your hands behind your back, as you open your chest toward the ceiling.\nStart by sitting tall at the edge of your chair with both feet on the floor. Cross your right ankle over your left knee. Now without rounding your back, reach your body as far forward as you can. Hold for about 20 seconds, and then repeat on the other side.\nReach your right leg forward into a lunge, dropping your left knee toward the ground without making contact. Keep your upper body straight and tall as you hold the lunge for about 15 seconds. Use your desk or the back of your chair for support if needed. Repeat on the other side.\nReach your legs out in front you, rock back on your glutes and curl your body forward while keeping your gaze just past your toes. Hold for 20 seconds and repeat.\nNext: Easy Evening Stretches The Will Relax Your Mind And Body\nBegin on all fours with hands shoulder-width apart and knees beneath your hips. Bring your right knee forward between your hands and rest it next to your right wrist. Your right heel should be beneath or close to your left hip. Stretch your left leg straight back behind you. Keep your hips facing forward and square with the front of your mat. Hold your body in an upright position for 10 counts, and then reach your body forward and feel it relaxing into the floor. Hold for 20 seconds and repeat with the left leg forward.\nThe very name of this exercise makes me happy! Lying on your back, lift your legs and bring your knees toward you. Reach your arms between your knees to grasp your big toes or the outsides of your feet if you can. Bring your tailbone back down to the floor. Let your knees fall down to the sides wider than your shoulders, and breathe deeply for 20 seconds. Rock gently from side to side to help release your back.\nLying on your back with your arms to the side (palms facing the floor), bend your knees so that your feet are on the floor, hip distance apart, and your toes are pointing forward. Take a deep breath and gently lift your hips toward the ceiling, keeping your body in a straight line. Hold for about 15 to 20 seconds and repeat.\nLying on your back with your glutes against the wall, stretch your feet and legs up against the wall. Take a deep breath and simply relax. You can rest your hands and arms wherever feel comfortable. You will love this restorative post if you are on your feet all day. Remain in this pose for as long as you need.\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
