It engulfed New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie\u2019s administration in scandal after it was revealed an aide ordered the closures, apparently for political retribution. The U.S. attorney\u2019s office is investigating.\nIn an email released later as part of a legislative investigation, Foye wrote that he wasn\u2019t initially told about the closures and ordered the lanes reopened.\nFoye said Thursday he took action because he \u201cdidn\u2019t want someone dying in the back of an ambulance.\u201d\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1898.html"], ["url", "http://archive.northjersey.com/news/port-authority-to-cover-legal-bills-for-15-employees-in-gwb-probe-1.1024902"], ["text", "\u00a9 2017 North Jersey Media Group\nMay 28, 2014, 5:55 PM\nLast updated: Wednesday, May 28, 2014, 10:54 PM\nPort Authority to cover legal bills for 15 employees in GWB probe\nBy SHAWN BOBURG\nstaff writer\u00a0|\u00a0\nThe Record\nIn the latest indication that the public will bear an ongoing and significant financial burden for the multiple probes into the George Washington Bridge lane closure scandal, the Port Authority has agreed to cover the legal bills of 15 employees \u2014 including the agency\u2019s executive director \u2014 who have turned to outside attorneys for counsel, an agency official said Wednesday.\nMichael Karas / staff photographer\nPort Authority Executive Director Pat Foye.\nThat is on top of the five law firms hired by the New Jersey Attorney General\u2019s Office to represent public employees who have been embroiled in the lane closure scandal. Those firms are being paid $340 per hour.\nAnd it is in addition to the money spent by the Christie administration on its own probe of the lane closures, which concluded that the governor did not know of the plan. The final tally for that probe has not been released, but bills for work by the Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher law firm in less than three weeks in January totaled nearly $1.1 million.\nPlus, the state legislative committee probing the lane closures has been billed more than $200,000 by its counsel, Reid Schar, for his work in January alone.\nAt the Port Authority, officials on Wednesday said it is not yet possible to determine what the cost will be to the agency, which is supported largely by tolls on the Hudson River crossings.\n\u201cThis is an ongoing process and it will be impossible to predict the total cost at this time,\u201d said spokesman Steve Coleman.\nThe agency\u2019s executive director, Pat Foye, who has testified before a federal grand jury that is investigating the lane closures, confirmed during a news conference after the agency\u2019s monthly public meeting on Wednesday that his representation would be paid for by the agency.\nAs of two weeks ago, federal prosecutors had summoned up to a half-dozen Port Authority employees to testify or cooperate with their criminal probe, but their identities have remained a secret. An agency spokesman said later Wednesday that the agency would not identify the others who had made requests for indemnification.\nTwo Christie aides at the Port Authority who were involved in the September lane closures and also requested indemnification are not among those who are covered, the agency spokesman said. A request by David Wildstein, who ordered the September lane closures, was denied earlier this year. And agency officials have remained undecided on a request by former Deputy Executive Director Bill Baroni, who had prior knowledge of the lane-closure plan.\nFoye had been scheduled to testify publicly next week before the New Jersey legislative committee that is investigating the lane closures. But federal prosecutors have requested that Foye\u2019s testimony before the panel be delayed, according to a source close to the investigation. Unlike federal prosecutors, the lawmaker panel does not have the authority to prosecute crimes, but, through its subpoena power, it has uncovered some of the most explosive information to surface publicly in the scandal.\nFoye and New Jersey Commissioner Pat Schuber have both received subpoenas to testify before the panel.\nUnder agency bylaws, the executive director must approve a request for indemnification after a determination by the agency\u2019s general counsel that an outside attorney is appropriate and necessary. Current and former employees and commissioners are eligible for indemnification if the actions that give rise to their legal assistance were within the scope of their job duties.\nIn this case, Foye\u2019s request was approved by Deputy Executive Director Deb Grammiccioni and General Counsel Darrell Buchbinder.\nThe New Jersey Attorney General\u2019s Office in April confirmed that five law firms had been retained by the state to represent employees. However, officials declined to release the names of the employees, citing attorney-client privilege.\nHowever, Bill Stepien, a former deputy chief of staff in Christie\u2019s office who left the state to work for the governor\u2019s reelection campaign, will be represented by the state-funded lawyers specifically for his time when he was deputy chief of staff and employed by the state and not for his later role as campaign manager, according to a letter from the Attorney General\u2019s Office to the firm.\nStepien is being represented by Kevin Marino, a partner at Marino, Tortorella & Boyle. Christie cut ties with Stepien after it became known that Stepien had knowledge about the lane closures.\nOther firms being paid by the state according to documents released in April include:\nIacullo Martino LLC, the representation for Christie spokesman Michael Drewniak.\nKrovatin, Klingeman LLC, who has Christina Genovese Renna as a client. Renna was Christie\u2019s director of intergovernmental affairs before resigning.\nRiker, Danzig, Scherer, Hyland & Perretti LLP, the representation for Evan Ridley, a Christie aide.\nRobert G. Stahl of Westfield was also listed as an attorney being paid for by the state, but his client is unknown.\nStaff Writer Michael Phillis contributed to this article. Email: boburg@northjersey.com\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1901.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/bergen/franklin-lakes/2017/01/12/franklin-lakes-school-redistricting-report-delayed/96463598/"], ["text", "Franklin Lakes school redistricting report delayed\nResidents had raised concerns about the proposal, which would change how students are assigned to schools.\nPost to Facebook\nFranklin Lakes school redistricting report delayed Residents had raised concerns about the proposal, which would change how students are assigned to schools. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2ioNqLk\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nFranklin Lakes school redistricting report delayed\nMarsha A Stoltz , Staff Writer Published 1:48 p.m. ET Jan. 12, 2017 | Updated 5:50 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nResidents had raised concerns about the proposal, which would change how students are assigned to schools.\nThe High Mountain Road Elementary School is one of three grade schools where redistricting is being considered.\n(Photo: Chris Peters/NorthJersey.com)\nCONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nFRANKLIN LAKES \u2013 A\u00a0report\u00a0on possible redistricting of the borough's elementary\u00a0schools\u00a0has been delayed\u00a0a\u00a0month\u00a0after residents raised concerns about the proposal.\nThe\u00a0school\u00a0board\u00a0had\u00a0asked\u00a0Superintendent of Schools Lydia\u00a0Furnari\u00a0in\u00a0December to\u00a0provide details on\u00a0the\u00a0impact\u00a0of\u00a0reorganizing its three\u00a0kindergarten-to-fifth-grade\u00a0schools at its\u00a0Jan. 24\u00a0meeting.\u00a0The request came after\u00a0the board\u00a0reviewed a report indicating that decreased\u00a0enrollment\u00a0was leading to\u00a0educational\u00a0challenges\u00a0such as\u00a0space\u00a0under-utilization, grade and gender imbalance\u00a0in the\u00a0three schools.\nhttp://www.northjersey.com/story/news/education/2016/12/29/franklin-lakes-boe-study-school-redistricting/95956816/\nThe board moved\u00a0Furnari's\u00a0report\u00a0to Feb. 28, however, after\u00a0questions\u00a0were raised\u00a0by residents\u00a0at the\u00a0board\u2019s reorganization meeting earlier this month.\n\"After discussion at this meeting, the\u00a0presentation\u00a0was moved to Feb.\u00a028 to allow Dr.\u00a0Furnari\u00a0sufficient\u00a0time to\u00a0gather\u00a0the necessary information and put together a\u00a0comprehensive\u00a0presentation,\" Board President Jackie\u00a0Veliky\u00a0said\u00a0in an\u00a0email. \"This includes potential improvements that can be made to our current\u00a0school\u00a0structure.\"\nResident\u00a0John\u00a0Butto, who spoke at the\u00a0meeting, said he was concerned that\u00a0\"the status quo was not one of the options.\"\n\u201cI wanted to know who would have access to the process, what committee would be set up.\u00a0Many questions and concerns,\u201d\u00a0Butto\u00a0said in a telephone interview.\nCurrently, the district\u00a0assigns\u00a0students based\u00a0on\u00a0their geographic location to one of three\u00a0kindergarten-to- fifth-grade schools: High Mountain\u00a0Road, Woodside\u00a0Avenue and Colonial Road. The High Mountain Road School also has a prekindergarten class.\nThe\u00a0redistricting proposals being considered:\nOne school for all prekindergarten through first-graders, one school for second- and third-grade students, and one school for fourth- and fifth-graders;\u00a0\nOne school for prekindergarten through first-grade students and two schools for the second\u00a0through fifth grades; or\u00a0\nTwo\u00a0schools for the prekindergarten through third grades and one school for the fourth and fifth grades.\u00a0\nAll students attend sixth- to eighth-grade classes as Franklin Avenue Middle School, and no changes are proposed for this school.\n\"The board discussed the need to include potential improvements to our current structure, adding this to the original request\u00a0for information,\u201d\u00a0Furnari\u00a0said in\u00a0an\u00a0email.\u00a0\u201cThe expansion of the task was the reason for rescheduling the date of my presentation of pros and cons for each option until the Feb. 28 meeting.\u201d\nThe district previously\u00a0proposed\u00a0redistricting in January 2012 after a yearlong study by a 20-member committee of administrators, teachers and parents.\u00a0The recommendation was for two kindergarten-to-third grade schools and one fourth- to fifth-grade school.\nResidents objected, however, to eliminating neighborhood schools in which students are assigned based on their geographic location.\u00a0The proposal was tabled a month later.\nEmail: stoltz@northjersey.com\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1902.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/04/25/blackheads_n_9772828.html"], ["text", "8 Questions You Have About Blackheads, Answered\nThe Huffington Post Canada \u00a0|\u00a0 By Joy D'Souza\nADVERTISEMENT\nPuss filled pimples are pretty darn gross, but blackheads might actually be worse.\nThe dark coloured dots, which are found on your face, back, chest and arms, are actually a mixture of oils, proteins, bacteria and hair trapped beneath your skin's surface. Once exposed to oxygen, the concoction turns its signature dark colour, dermatologist and founder of Compass Dermatology Julia Carroll tells The Huffington Post Canada.\nAs tempted as you may be, Carroll insists you refrain from popping and pressing on your blackheads as it could lead to scarring. Instead, look for cleansers that contain salicylic acid and retinoid creams which can prevent and eliminate the spots.\nYou can even try this all-natural face mask which contains pore tightening lemon juice and moisturizing honey.\nFor more tips on getting rid of blackheads check out the slideshow below. And let us know, how do you banish blackheads?\nAlso on The Huffington Post\nClose\nEverything You Need To Know About Blackheads\nof\n\ue000\n\ue001\nBlackheads, A.K.A. open comedones, are a type of acne, says dermatologist Julia Carroll, founder of Compass Dermatology.  This type of acne typically has larger than normal openings and are filled with a plug containing sebum (oil), keratin (protein), hair follicles and sloughed off skin cells.\nBlackheads are caused by excess production of sebum (oil), says Carroll. \"The usual cause of increased sebum production is hormone changes especially during puberty.\"  There are also special blackheads known as solar comedones, which are caused by chronic sun damage, Carroll explains.\n\"The black colour is caused by a chemical reaction known as oxidization,\" says Carroll.  \"When the melanin contained in the sebum is exposed to oxygen in the air it turns black.\"\nWhile blackheads can get better or worse, they are not infectious and thus do not spread.\n\"Cleansers with acids such as salicylic acid or glycloic acid can help dislodge the plug which will improve the blackheads,\" says Carroll.  Cleansing brushes and pore cleansing strips can also help clear skin and reduce blackheads.\nPrescription retinoid creams are best for eliminating existing blackheads.  In extreme cases an oral medication may be prescribed.  Carroll suggests using pore strips for temporary removal and microdermabrasion performed in a dermatologist's office.\nWith the regular use of cleansers containing salicylic acid as well as regular use of a retinoid cream, blackheads can be prevented, says Carroll.\nWhen it comes to healing scars, it really depends on the size, says Carroll. \"For an isolated scar I will often do a small excision. For multiple scars I turn to my lasers.\"  To prevent scarring all together, Carroll says you should avoid squeezing and frequently extracting them, as this can cause pores to become enlarged over time.\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1910.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/04/18/bottled-water-soda_n_9723776.html"], ["text", "Bottled Water To Overtake Soda Among U.S. Consumers\nThe Huffington Post Canada \u00a0|\u00a0 By Jesse Ferreras\nreddit\nADVERTISEMENT\nAmericans are on the verge of consuming more bottled water than sugary soft drinks per capita for the first time ever.\nU.S. residents have steadily been drinking more bottled water concurrently with a drop in pop consumption, says data released by Euromonitor .\nThis year, Americans can be expected to drink approximately 102 litres of bottled water, compared to about 98 litres worth of soft drinks.\nAnd that trend is only likely to continue, as these charts show.\nConsumption of bottled water is set to overtake that of soda in the U.S. for 1st time https://t.co/AwXTrTuaCI pic.twitter.com/7gPXRx5a3y\n\u2014 Quartz (@qz) April 18, 2016\nBloomberg noted that Nestle SA, which owns brands such as Perrier and Poland Spring, could see a nice profit from this trend .\nBut it also said prices for bottled water are falling. Price pressure reduced Nestle's first-quarter growth by half a percentage point, the business news outlet said.\nThe upward tick for bottled water comes as soft drink companies such as Pepsico turn to healthier beverages to boost their earnings, Quartz reported.\nPepsico's Aquafina bottled water. (Photo: Michael Loccisano/Getty Images)\nPepsico's Naked Juice products grew by 60 per cent in the first quarter of 2016, while its Lipton tea products grew by 10 per cent, CEO Indra Nooyi said in a Monday earnings call.\nOnly 12 per cent of Pepsico's North American beverage revenue comes from the Pepsi soft drink, she added.\nThe real cost of bottled water\nBut bottling water also comes with an environmental cost.\nA 2009 study out of the Pacific Institute found that long-distance transport of bottled water can \"lead to energy costs comparable to, or even larger than, the energy to produce the bottle.\"\nThe cost is also as much as 2,000 times larger than it is to produce tap water.\nCases of Great Value brand bottled water are displayed for sale at the grand opening of a new Wal-Mart Stores Inc. location in Torrance, Calif. on Sept. 12, 2012. (Photo: Patrick Fallon/Bloomberg via Getty Images)\nBottled water is restricted in over 80 Canadian cities and towns. The City of Toronto, for example, bans the distribution and sale of bottled water in all city facilities, parks and civic centres , with some exceptions.\n\"While water bottles are recyclable, they still require a significant amount of energy to manufacture, transport and eventually recycle,\" the city says.\nMontreal is also looking at restricting bottled water. Mayor Denis Coderre says the city \"needs to have that debate on plastic.\"\nTricks To Drink More Water\nof\n\ue000\n\ue001\nThe trick to this is pouring yourself a glass of water before bed and then drinking it as soon as you get up. Even if the thought of pouring water down your throat right away feels overwhelming, try it for four days in a row and see if you don't start doing it automatically after that.\nThere's are plenty of apps out there to keep track of your water intake, if you like that kind of reminder (Daily Water Free, picture here, is a favourite). But a another option is to set an alarm on your phone or calendar to remind you to drink every two hours or so.\nYes, that's right \u2014 your caffeinated (or decaf, if you're so inclined) morning beverage also has plenty of water in it, so you can include that in your count. According to WebMD, their diuretic effects do not take away from also hydrating you.\nThere's no science here, just pure superficiality that somehow still works. If you have a nicer water bottle, you may just be more inclined to use it. We love this Lifefactory glass option that holds one-quarter of your daily water intake in one go!\nThere are plenty of fruits and veggies that contain a fair amount of water, including cucumbers, iceberg lettuce, watermelon (obviously), strawberries, grapefruit, zucchini, radish and celery. Plus, of course, the many other nutrients this produce contains.\nWhen you're bogged down at work, even the 20-foot walk to the kitchen can feel too far, so set yourself up for the day with a big bottle \u2014 or even a pitcher \u2014 in the morning so you can dip into it all day.\nWe know, you've heard enough about \"infusing\" your water to last you a lifetime. But it really does make it taste better \u2014 and has the bonus effect of even more water, if you use some of those hydrating foods we mentioned. Some other good options: kiwi, lemon, strawberries or grapes.\nIt's so easy to make ice pops at home \u2014 all you need is a mold, some water, and the fruit of your choice. That way, you get to control what goes in it (i.e. the sugar), eat a delicious snack, and you're upping your water intake at the same time. Check out these recipes for homemade popsicles at Real Simple.\nNo one's expecting you to give up other drinks entirely in lieu of water, either sugar-filled or alcoholic. Instead, make yourself a deal \u2014 for every \"other\" kind of drink you have, drink a glass of water.\nIf you've gotten out of the habit of rinsing out your mouth after brushing your teeth, now's the time to start setting that glass by your sink again. A rinse, a refill, then a few gulps \u2014 and like that, you're hydrated before bed.\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1912.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/04/08/psychopaths-manipulate-online-ubco-study_n_9647704.html"], ["text", "Psychopaths Can't Manipulate As Easily Online: UBCO Study\nThe Huffington Post Canada \u00a0|\u00a0 By Jesse Ferreras\nADVERTISEMENT\nPsychopaths and narcissists are adept at manipulating you when you're face-to-face.\nBut their control is significantly diminished online, according to research out of the University of British Columbia in the Okanagan .\nA study titled \"The Dark Side of Negotiation\" worked with over 200 Canadian university students between October 2013 and February 2014.\nNumerous students had personality traits on the \"Dark Triad\" (DT) spectrum, which encompasses narcissism, psychopathy, and Machiavellianism.\nNarcissists tend to be grandiose personalities who love themselves, while psychopaths lack empathy. People who are Machiavellian are known for being \"calculated manipulators.\"\n\u201cWhile there has long been a fascination with DT personalities and how they can impact \u2018ordinary\u2019 people, little has been studied as to how these people behave online,\u201d psychology professor Michael Woodworth, who led the study, said in a news release.\nThe UBC Okanagan campus. (Photo: Facebook )\nSubjects were assigned to groups that either met face-to-face or using computers. Then, they were tasked with negotiating for concert tickets, with the aim of making as much money as possible.\nThe study showed that people with \"Dark Triad\" traits were more successful at negotiating in person than online.\nIn fact, those who ranked lower on the DT spectrum did 12.5 per cent better in online negotiators than those who showed darker psychological traits.\n\"The results of this study are pretty clear \u2014 once you remove non-verbal cues such as body language from the question, the ability to smoke out narcissists and psychopaths becomes easier,\" Woodworth said.\n\"Once you remove non-verbal cues such as body language from the question, the ability to smoke out narcissists and psychopaths becomes easier.\"\nThis is far from the first study to offer insight into a psychopath's mind.\nLast year, the University of Montreal published research showing that psychopaths can't learn from their crimes due to their brain structure.\nResearchers found that they can't process punishment the same way as other people because of \"structural abnormalities in both gray matter and specific white matter fiber tracts.\"\nGray matter is associated with traits such as guilt, embarrassment, and empathy, while white matter is linked to learning from rewards and punishment.\nPsychopaths in that study showed \"abnormal responding\" to punishment. Researchers concluded that they may only think about the positive, and not the negative outcomes of their actions.\nEleven Ways To Tell If Your Boss Is A Psychopath\nof\n\ue000\n\ue001\nPsychopaths are social chameleons and can change their psychological spots in the blink of an eye if they think they can benefit from doing so. Playing on sympathy is a favourite weapon of choice.   Make no mistake: psychopaths are confident, outgoing and mentally resilient, hardly ever, in reality, feeling sorry for themselves. But they are also master manipulators and have no qualms whatsoever about tugging on our emotional heartstrings if it works to their advantage.   Sympathy is a powerful motivator \u2013 a fact not lost on psychopaths even though they never feel it \u2013 and they are extremely adept at eliciting pity and compassion.   WARNING LIGHT: Consistently poor behaviour with frequent appeals to mitigating circumstances and pleas for support and understanding is one of the psychopath\u2019s most recognizable kitemarks \u2013 in both the corporate realm and that of everyday life.\nPsychopaths are emotional chess players and a psychopathic boss sees his employees merely as pieces on an invisible psychological chessboard: disposable, dispensable, superfluous.   Psychopaths love to pick people up, move people round, make people jump just for the sake of it - even if, sometimes, it\u2019s not to their immediate benefit. Unnecessary rearrangements of workspace, the sudden imposition of unsocial working hours, and the promise of favours for dishing the dirt on colleagues are just a few psychopathic favourites.   WARNING LIGHT: If you\u2019re left scratching your head on yet another occasion as you try to figure out the rationale for your boss\u2019s behaviour \u2013 then the answer might be simpler than you think.\nPsychopaths are past masters at making scintillating first impressions and possess an innate gift for making you feel as if you\u2019re the only person in the room.   They are brilliant psychologists. They know that, through evolution, our brains are programmed to put a lot of store in initial encounters and so they bank substantial emotional \u2018capital\u2019 early in a new relationship by turning on the charm.   One psychopath I interviewed put it like this: \u201cCharm is the ability to roll out a red carpet for those you cannot stand in order to fast-track them, as smoothly and efficiently as possible, in the direction you want them to go.\u201d   WARNING LIGHT: If you suddenly find that the red carpet is rolled up and that the charm fades quickly during subsequent meetings with your boss leaving you feeling confused and vulnerable, you may well have a psychopath on your hands.\nIrrespective of whether they play the charm, manipulation or sympathy cards, psychopaths are corporate vampires and are second to none in their ability to take you into their confidence and suck out valuable new ideas that may have been months in the planning.   A typical ploy is the use of reciprocity \u2013 a powerful tool of influence. A psychopath might open the bidding and \u2018confide\u2019 in you some low-level idea of his own in order that you follow suit with something better. Once in the psychopath\u2019s possession however, the idea is then \u2018confiscated\u2019 and, somewhere down the line, suddenly becomes \u2018theirs.\u2019   WARNING LIGHT: If your boss has a habit of taking the credit for work done by others, it might be time to look for work elsewhere.\nPsychopaths simply do not live by the same moral code as the rest of us, and experience little guilt or anxiety over telling lies \u2013 either to big themselves up, or to dump on others, or both.   In fact, it\u2019s their consummate lack of remorse for misrepresenting the facts that is the single biggest contributor to their inordinate capacity for fabrication. They appear plausible and reasonable and their webs of deceit frequently contain a modicum of truth which they rely on as a safety net should their spurious cover stories come under too close a scrutiny.   WARNING LIGHT: If your relationship with your boss has been plagued by \u2018misunderstandings\u2019 and \u2018false assumptions\u2019 it might be time to face the real truth.\nPsychopaths are completely driven by their own hard-nosed self-interest. Though they may feign concern for others, appearing warm, considerate and even helpful, such interest is shallow and superficial and merely serves as the foreplay for future exploitation. For psychopath, read \u201cps-I-chopath.\u201d   Psychopathic relationship patterns  - in both personal and corporate settings - are stormy and transient. \u201cFriendships\u201d are often terminated without warning, and ties mercilessly severed once an individual ceases to \u201cbe of any use.\u201d   Add to this an arrogant, grandiose and egocentric interpersonal style and you have on your hands a ruthless ambition machine with no \u201coff \u201cswitch.   WARNING LIGHT: If your boss has been known to fire people for no apparent reason, or has an ostentatious and extravagant profile out of keeping with a more objective assessment of their standing, or has a habit of stealing the limelight\u2026it\u2019s time to leave them to it.\nPsychopaths make expert defence attorneys and are supremely skilled at getting themselves off the hook should accusations of incompetence be leveled at them.   Not only do they never accept culpability, but they are also extremely adept at manufacturing evidence that lays the blame for their misdemeanours firmly at someone else\u2019s door.   Psychopathic bosses have no qualms whatsoever in using their employees as \u2018reputation shields\u2019 to safeguard their own status within the company.   WARNING LIGHT: If your boss has landed you in it through no fault of your own, start asking questions.\nThe brain of the psychopath is wired up in a different way to the rest of ours.   In particular, the part of the brain responsible for emotion \u2013 the amygdala \u2013 is turned down, meaning that psychopaths do not experience the everyday feelings of fear, regret and disgust so familiar to normal folk.   But that doesn\u2019t stop the psychopath acting scared, sorry or surprised in order to manipulate others. They are perfectly adept at putting on shows of emotion if it helps them get ahead.   A common example is extreme anger in response to a perceived personal insult, an alleged betrayal of trust, or the insufficient demonstration of respect for their authority. But such emotional pyrotechnics are purely for shock-and-awe purposes - coolly calculated psychological bombing raids aimed at minimizing the chances of any future \u201ctransgressions.\u201d   WARNING LIGHT: If your boss is prone to extreme displays of emotion then quickly returns to normal as if nothing has happened, you should start to question whether he really feels anything at all.\nImagine someone who has a warped perception of speed: someone who, through some weird trick of nature, perceives things happening at a much slower rate than they actually do.   You wouldn\u2019t want to get in a car with them, would you? Well, it\u2019s exactly the same with psychopaths \u2013 except for speed, read danger.   The neural power-cut in the fear zip code of psychopaths\u2019 brains means that things that would scare the hell out of the rest of us just don\u2019t have the same impact on these ice-cool emotional androids.   This, of course, gives psychopaths their enviable sang-froid, their composure under fire \u2013 and explains why they often do quite well for themselves in high-wire professions such as the media, finance and certain echelon areas of the military.   But it can, at times, also lead to unnecessary risk-taking \u2013 and, to return to the speed analogy, can often result in the car veering out of control and crashing off the road as opposed to a speedier journey time (as if we need any reminding with the global financial crisis.)   WARNING LIGHT: Risky investments, unwise alliances, inappropriate behaviour, risqu\u00e9 comments\u2026 if this sounds like your boss you may want to look for another one.\nPsychopaths are attracted to positions of influence in which they can satisfy their need to control and manipulate others.   Last year, I launched the Great British Psychopath Survey. The survey is unique: the first of its kind to assess the prevalence of psychopathic traits within an entire national workforce. What would turn out to be the UK\u2019s most psychopathic profession? I wondered.   The results made interesting reading. CEOs, media folk, lawyers, surgeons, police officers, the clergy\u2026any line of work which boasts a definitive hierarchical infrastructure and affords a position of power over others which may be wielded with relative impunity is ideally suited to the psychopathic personality.   WARNING LIGHT: If your boss has a tendency to step on those beneath him but goes out of his way to impress those above him, it\u2019s time to move sideways\u2026to another department or company.\nHollywood movies typically portray the psychopath as an intense, menacing figure who makes the hairs on the back of one\u2019s neck stand on end \u2013 and there\u2019s evidence to suggest this is true.   Psychopaths often do give out a certain \u2018aura\u2019 and folk sometimes report experiencing unnerving physical sensations in their presence such as \u201che sends a chill up my spine\u201d and \u201che makes my skin crawl.\u201d   WARNING LIGHT: If you sometimes feel uneasy around your boss, and are uncomfortable being on your own with him for any length of time, trust your gut instinct: GET OUT WHILE YOU STILL CAN!\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1913.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/bergen/paramus/2017/01/13/paramus-board-approves-primrose-school-application/96528266/"], ["text", "Primrose testimony continues in Paramus\n\"Certainly, I understand the concern of the neighbors,\" said Carmine Alampi, the attorney representing Primrose School.\u00a0\"I recognize\u00a0when I look at the property that it's 400 feet deep and it penetrates so many houses on either side.\"\nAlampi argued before the board that the site plan proposed would vastly\u00a0improve the conditions that exist\u00a0on the property by providing more green area and moving parking to the front of the property.\nAlampi said\u00a0the Children's Day School, which is licensed for more than 120 students, was able to operate under a current use variance that his client is proposing, and with many fewer spaces. The applicant proposed 53 parking spots at the new site, while 55 are required under zoning regulations. The existing property only has 24 parking spaces, but was able to supplement its\u00a0parking through an agreement with the church across the street.\nOriginally, the applicant proposed that as many as 190 students be enrolled at Primrose. But\u00a0after much\u00a0back-and-forth between the applicant and the board, one of several conditions\u00a0for approval\u00a0included dropping the student count to 160. By the Thursday hearing, the applicant had already dropped the number to 168 students by reducing the square footage of the property, thus shrinking the number of parking spaces required by statute. Other conditions included not allowing certain activities to take place on-site, such as graduations, since they draw more people who might park on residential streets.\nThe site plan for the Primrose School on Paramus Road on display during Thursday night's Board of Adjustment hearing.\n\u00a0(Photo: Melanie Anzidei/NorthJersey.com)\nRaghav \u201cRocco\u201d Varma, the owner of the property and\u00a0of\u00a0Primrose School of Florham Park, said the school would be one of his smaller operations. Most average about 190 students, as originally proposed, he said.\nPrimrose School is a national chain of accredited private preschools. According to its website, there are five Primrose locations in New Jersey. In addition to its future Paramus location, the company also anticipates two more openings in the future, including one in Wayne.\nMore than a dozen residents attended the Thursday night hearing.\nHalf\u00a0those residents, when testifying before the board,\u00a0cited concerns such as increased noise from children at the school, limited buffers between their backyards and the new development, and traffic that could trickle onto their already-crowded\u00a0streets.\u00a0The board proposed an 8-foot\u00a0vinyl\u00a0fence between the facility and abutting properties as another condition of approval.\nMany residents also expressed concerns that the facility would increase traffic at an already-congested section of Paramus Road.\n\"I grew up in the neighborhood. I've been living there constantly for the last 20 years,\" said Bill Doukas, who lives on Seneca Court. \"There's times literally, if I want to pull out of Seneca Court to go north on Paramus Road \u2013 you can't do it. There's no break in traffic. I end up pulling out to the right.\"\nAlampi, however, said that \"a percentage\" of people who would be driving into the facility would already be driving on Paramus Road.\n\"This is not a traffic generator. This is not a supermarket that is drawing people that wouldn't already otherwise be there,\" Alampi said during the hearing. \"There are people who are going to travel this road\u00a0past the site, and go to another day care as they drop their kid off and go to work. That volume, that flow\u00a0exists.\"\nThe construction of the new school likely will start in mid-March, with hopes of opening in January 2018, Varma said\u00a0after the late-night meeting.\n\u201cWe\u2019re excited to be in Paramus,\u201d said Varma.\u00a0\u201cWe know there is demand in the area.\u201d He added that\u00a0Primrose\u00a0was able to home in on the\u00a0borough location after parents shared their hopes of having a more modern facility in that region.\n2 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jEpFwe\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1914.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/04/04/miscarriage-disability-ontario-human-rights-tribunal_n_9613990.html"], ["text", "'Miscarriage Is A Disability,' Ontario Human Rights Tribunal Rules\nThe Huffington Post Canada \u00a0|\u00a0 By Maham Abedi\nADVERTISEMENT\nThe emotional distress caused by a miscarriage constitutes a disability.\nSo says an interim decision by the Ontario Human Rights Tribunal in the case of Winnie Mou.\nIn 2013, Mou suffered a series of unfortunate events including an injury from a bad fall, the death of her mother-in-law and then a miscarriage. In February 2014, she was fired from her job at MHPM Project Leaders for performance issues.\nAdjudicator Jennifer Scott ruled in her favour on March 14, defining miscarriage as a disability and thus allowing Mou to move forward with a wrongful termination suit against her former employer.\n\"I also find the applicant\u2019s miscarriage is a disability,\" Scott wrote in her decision. \"It also is not a common ailment, and it is certainly not transitory. It is clear from the applicant\u2019s testimony that she continues to experience significant emotional distress from the miscarriage even today.\"\nDecision sets precedent, lawyer says\nScott's decision may have far-reaching effects, Mou's lawyer Morgan Rowe told CBC News.\n\"It should make it easier for the next woman who comes along who feels like an employer has relied on her miscarriage to penalize her in some way,\" the lawyer said.\nThe ruling is also in line with the Canadian Human Rights Code, which says women are entitled to workplace accommodation amid a series of \"pregnancy-related conditions,\" such as miscarriages, stillbirths and abortions, and conditions that result from these losses .\nMental health after miscarriages\nOne such condition is emotional trauma.\n\"By labeling it as a traumatic loss, we validate the experience.\"\nA 2012 study by the American Psychological Association found that women who suffer from pregnancy loss experience mental trauma for years , often even after the birth of a healthy child.\n\"By labeling it as a traumatic loss, we validate the experience,\" said Martha Diamond, an expert cited in the study.\nAlso on HuffPost:\nHow To Help A Friend Through Miscarriage\nof\n\ue000\n\ue001\nWhile not everyone is as open to talking about their feelings as I am, I think everyone loves to receive a bright bouquet of flowers \u2013- it\u2019s a nice way to say that you\u2019re there for her, and you care, without forcing her to talk about her feelings.\nIf you\u2019ve gone through a similar experience, share your story with your grieving friend. While it\u2019s unfortunate that miscarriage is so common, your friend can take comfort in not being alone. Knowing that others in their own network of friends have experienced the same thing makes it easier to work through the grieving process.\nThere\u2019s no better time for your friend to focus on taking care of themselves. A restful body will help to heal the mind. Gift your friend with a massage or a pedicure so she is forced to take time out to enjoy a little pampering. And if you can, join her!\nUnfortunately, there isn\u2019t really anything you can do to reassure your friend that they\u2019ll feel better in a few weeks or months. It\u2019s a grieving process \u2013- one that affects everyone differently. All that you can do is lend an ear, hold a hand and wait it out with them.\nWhile you may be wondering what the doctors discovered or if your friend is going to try again -- wait for your friend to share those details with you. Don\u2019t try to pry it out of her. She might not be ready to discuss the details with you yet, but if you let her know that you\u2019re there for her and available if she wants to talk, then she will come to you when she's ready.\n10 Fertility Facts You May Not Know\n1. Your fertility is mostly determined by genetics, which influences how many eggs you are born with.   Doctors believe that the number of eggs you have at birth determines the length of time you will remain fertile. At birth, women have about two million eggs in their ovaries. For every egg ovulated during your reproductive life, about 1,000 eggs undergo programmed cell death. Other things, such as smoking cigarettes and certain types of chemotherapy, can accelerate egg cell death and promote an earlier menopause.\n2. Regular menstrual cycles are a sign of regular ovulation.  Most women have regular cycles lasting between 24 and 35 days. This is usually a sign of regular, predictable ovulation. Women who do not ovulate regularly have irregular menstrual cycles. Those who do not ovulate at all may have a genetic condition called polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).\n3. Basal temperature charting does not predict ovulation.  An older method of tracking ovulation involves taking your oral body temperature each morning before getting out of bed. This is called basal body temperature. This method is used to spot a rise in basal temperature, which is a sign that progesterone is being produced.   The main problem with using this method is that your temperature rises after ovulation has already occurred. This makes it more difficult to time intercourse at an optimal time for conception.   A better method is to use over-the-counter urine ovulation predictor test kits such as Clearblue Easy. These kits test for the hormone that prompts ovulation, which is called luteinizing hormone (LH).\n4. Most women with blocked fallopian tubes are completely unaware they may have had a prior pelvic infection.  About 10 percent of infertility cases are due to tubal disease, either complete blockage or pelvic scarring causing tubal malfunction. One major cause of tubal disease is a prior pelvic infection from a sexually transmitted disease such as chlamydia. These infections can cause so few symptoms that you may be completely unaware your tubes are affected.   This is why fertility physicians will order a dye test of the tubes, called a hysterosalpingogram (HSG), if you have been trying and failing to conceive for 6 months or longer.\n5. In most cases, stress does not cause infertility.   Except in rare cases of extreme physical or emotional distress, women will keep ovulating regularly. Conceiving while on vacation is likely less about relaxation than about coincidence and good timing of sex.\n6. By age 44, most women are infertile, even if they are still ovulating regularly.   Even with significant fertility treatment, rates of conception are very low after age 43. Most women who conceive in their mid-40's with fertility treatment are using donated eggs from younger women.\n7. Having fathered a pregnancy in the past does not guarantee fertility.   Sperm counts can change quite a bit with time, so never assume that a prior pregnancy guarantees fertile sperm. Obtaining a semen analysis is the only way to be sure the sperm are still healthy!\n8. For the most part, diet has little or nothing to do with fertility.   Despite popular press, there is little scientific data showing that a particular diet or food promotes fertility. One limited study did suggest a Mediterranean diet with olive oil, fish and legumes may help promote fertility.\n9. Vitamin D may improve results of fertility treatments.   A recent study from the University of Southern California suggested that women who were undergoing fertility treatments, but had low vitamin D levels, might have lower rates of conception. This vitamin is also essential during pregnancy. At Pacific Fertility Center, we recommend our patients take 2,000-4,000 IU per day.\n10. Being either underweight or overweight is clearly linked with lowered levels of fertility.   The evidence in recent years is that obesity is clearly linked with a longer time to conception. Having a body mass index less than 18 or over 32 is associated with problems ovulating and conceiving, as well as problems during pregnancy.\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1915.html"], ["url", "https://get.adobe.com/flashplayer/"], ["text", "Are you an IT manager or OEM?\nAbout:\nAdobe\u00ae Flash\u00ae Player is a lightweight browser plug-in and rich Internet application runtime that delivers consistent and engaging user experiences, stunning audio/video playback, and exciting gameplay.\nInstalled on more than 1.3 billion systems, Flash Player is the standard for delivering high-impact, rich Web content.\nOptional offer:\nTerms & conditions:\nBy clicking the \"Install now\" button, you acknowledge that you have read and agree to the Adobe Software Licensing Agreement .\nNote: Your antivirus software must allow you to install software.\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1917.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/03/29/belly-button-facts_n_9564976.html"], ["text", "10 Things You Didn't Know About Dirty Belly Buttons\nThe Huffington Post Canada \u00a0|\u00a0 By Joy D'Souza\nADVERTISEMENT\nPascal Broze via Getty Images\nWhen was the last time you cleaned your belly button? If you don't remember, chances are you're not alone.\nIf you aren't cleaning out that tiny crevice on a regular basis, you may want to reconsider. In the video above, Dr. Travis Stork of The Doctors explains the average belly button is home to more than 60 different types of bacteria in addition to lotions, dirt, sweat and soap.\nBelly button dirt can actually build up so much, people have mistaken it for skin cancer, dermatologist Alexandria V. Booth explained to Women's Health.\nIn the slideshow below, we reveal 10  fascinating facts about your belly button, from how it's formed to the infections you can get and most importantly, how to keep it squeaky clean.\nClose\n10 Facts About Your Belly Button\nof\n\ue000\n\ue001\nDr. Curtis Cetrulo Jr. tells NBC News, your belly button is created by the way the umbilical cord is cut at birth. He notes it gets its appearance from the way the cord dries up and falls off.\nAccording to researchers at North Carolina State University, the average belly button is home to 67 different types of bacteria.\nYep, in 2013 biologist Christina Agapakis teamed up with odour artist Sissel Tolaas to make craft cheese from bacteria found on the human body, Wired reported. But we suggest just buying your block of cheese from the local grocery store.\nBelly button yeast infections can affect both genders at any age. According to Livestrong, newborns can develop infections from a mother's yeast infection during childbirth.   Symptoms of belly button yeast infections include itching, redness and odour. If you notice discharge or if you feel pain, nausea or a fever, contact your doctor immediately.\nUnlike your ears, which are self-cleaning, your belly button needs a little help to stay clean. Use cotton swabs and a bit of rubbing alcohol to wipe away the dirt hiding inside your navel. Alcohol should be used sparingly however, as it may dry out the area. Regular soap and water should do the trick on a daily basis.\nThe lower abdomen is a very sensitive area for both men and women, and the belly button is a major part of that area. According to Intimate Medicine, stimulation of the belly button can result in a tingling sensation on the clitoris for women and on the penis for men.\nBut not all. According to researchers in Singapore, small, oval shaped navels with a ratio of 46:54 and a \"hood\" are the prettiest.\nThough it is uncommon, some people don't have belly buttons as a result of umbilical hernias and gastroschisis being born with their stomach and intestines poking through a small hole in the abdominal wall, reports BBC News. Model Karolina Kurkova lost her belly button to this type of condition and surgery as a child.\nResearchers in Australia found over weight men with body hair on their stomach were more likely to develop belly button lint, because the hair on their stomach tends to rub against clothing fibres creating and trapping lint.\nDuring pregnancy, a growing belly can actually pop out an \"innie\", Dr. Karen Marie Jaffe tells Everyday Health. After childbirth, the belly button tends to return to its normal shape.\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1918.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/03/16/bubble-baby-quinn_n_9475028.html"], ["text", "Modern-Day 'Bubble Baby' In B.C. Fights To Beat The Odds\nPosted:\nWhen Quinn was born in January, she seemed like a perfectly healthy baby.\nBut when she was a few weeks old, she caught a cold and didn't recover.\nParents Robert Shirley and Dawn Roberts took Quinn to the hospital in their hometown of Victoria, B.C. There, the baby was subject to a slew of tests.\n\"Our doctor at the time had this funny feeling, thinking something wasn't right with her,\" Robert said.\nQuinn and her mom, Dawn Roberts. (Photo: Robert Shirley)\nBlood tests helped doctors figure out that Quinn had a rare genetic disorder called adenosine deaminase\u2013deficient severe combined immunodeficiency , known as ADA-SCID, or SCID.\nBecause of the condition, Quinn's immune system doesn't work as it should. Any infection \u2014 be it a serious virus or a bout with the common cold \u2014 could kill her.\nQuinn. (Photo: Robert Shirley)\n\"She produces all the white blood cells she needs to fight infection, but when her body reproduces those cells, the old cells that her body leaves behind aren't being filtered out,\" Robert explained in an interview with The Huffington Post B.C. \"So when those old cells break down, they produce a toxin that's killing some of her new white blood cells that she needs.\n\"As soon as you get exposed to germs, [patients] don't have the immune system to fight it off. Her body doesn't react to seeing a cold \u2014 it'll just let the virus do its thing. She won't get fevers or anything like that,\" he added.\n\"Babies that have SCID, a lot of them don't make it to the hospital because parents just don't know they're sick,\" Dawn added. \"So it was actually a blessing that she happened to catch that bug.\"\n'Bubble babies'\nNo SCID case is better known than David Vetter's. Born in Houston in 1971, Vetter spent his entire life \u2014 save two weeks \u2014 inside what was essentially a big, plastic balloon.\nIt was a sterile space that acted as a barrier between life and death.\nHe became known as \"the boy in the bubble,\" living inside the plastic walls until he died at the age of 12 .\nVetter was a phenomenon, because back then, babies with SCID just didn't live as long as he had.\nMost didn't even come close.\nNowadays, children like Quinn \u2014 commonly known as \"bubble babies\" \u2014 have treatment options.\nThe first is a bone marrow transplant. Robert and Dawn are testing to see if they're a match, although it's not likely. A sibling would be a better candidate, but Quinn doesn't have any.\nThe second option, if a transplant is ruled out, would be an experimental gene therapy treatment available at the University of California in Los Angeles (UCLA).\nDoctors would extract one of Quinn's defective cells, repair it, and then put it back in the baby's body . That cell would then reproduce, slowly building a functioning immune system.\nIf successful, Robert and Dawn say Quinn would have a chance at a \"normal\" life.\n\"We've have an amazing medical team working with us to get Quinn and get her on the right path,\" Robert said.\nNewborn Quinn with her parents before being diagnosed with ADA-SCIDS. (Photo: Painted Barn Photography)\nAs of November 2014, 18 children with SCID had been cured through treatment at UCLA.\nOne Toronto boy that underwent the procedure is \"well on his way\" to recovery, and Dawn said she's in touch with his mom to chat about what happens next.\nDoctors from Vancouver General Hospital have applied to see whether Quinn is eligible for the treatment, but haven't heard back.\nCostly cures\nQuinn's parents face heavy costs, no matter which route they take.\nIf the baby undergoes a bone marrow transplant, Dawn and Robert will have to cover the cost of living in Vancouver, prepping their home for long-term recovery, and their daughter's post-op medication.\nIf they go for gene therapy, the family will likely have to cover travel costs to California. On top of that, it's not clear whether the experimental U.S. treatment will be covered by B.C.'s Medical Services Plan.\nRobert and Dawn say they're not sure how much they'll have to shell out for treatment at UCLA, but they're certain it won't be cheap.\nWith both options, the couple would leave their jobs to care for Quinn in her own \"bubble\" while she recovers.\nThe process could take several years.\n\"It\u2019s been quite a process ... But we\u2019re willing to do anything to keep her healthy.\"\nIn March, Quinn's extended family launched a GoFundMe campaign to pay for the anticipated bills.\nThey've raised nearly $20,000 \u2014 a number Dawn said is overwhelming.\nQuinn is currently in hospital, fighting off an unrelated problem with her bowels. When she's able to eat properly again, her parents will be able to bring her home while they wait for a decision on a treatment for her condition.\nWhile they wait, the family will have strict rules to follow.\nRobert Shirley, Dawn Roberts, and baby Quinn. (Photo: Robert Shirley)\n\"We'll be sent home to live in isolation,\" Dawn said. \"No visitors ... our dog won't be allowed in the same room ... and I'm not able to breastfeed, because I could catch a cold and pass it onto her.\"\n\"It's been quite a process ... But we're willing to do anything to keep her healthy,\" the first-time mom added.\n\"What we just have to do is stay positive for Quinn. She's been extremely strong, and she's been through a lot for only two months on the planet.\"\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1920.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/03/11/beijing-vancouver-flight-measles_n_9443432.html"], ["text", "Beijing-Vancouver Flight Passengers May Have Been Exposed To Measles: VCH\nThe Huffington Post B.C. \u00a0|\u00a0 By Jesse Ferreras\nreddit\nADVERTISEMENT\nDid you fly from Beijing to Vancouver on an Air China flight that landed at 9:30 a.m. on March 3?\nThen you may have been exposed to the measles.\nA passenger on that flight developed symptoms of the illness after disembarking, and was \" infectious during the flight ,\" Vancouver Coastal Health (VCH) said in a Friday news release.\nPassengers on March 3rd flight from Beijing at risk of measles https://t.co/7xprByTb2j #YVR pic.twitter.com/c7wUPWwMpF\n\u2014 VCH Healthcare (@VCHhealthcare) March 11, 2016\nThe health authority is asking anyone who was on this flight to ensure they are \"up to date with measles vaccinations.\"\nThey should also keep an eye out for measles symptoms such as a red rash, cough, fever, runny nose or pink eye until March 24.\n\"Measles is highly infectious and spread through the air [when] someone who is infected coughs or sneezes,\" the statement said.\n\"Measles can be a serious illness with complications such as inflammation of the brain (encephalitis), convulsions, deafness or brain damage.\"\nAir China flight sits on a tarmac at Changshui Airport in December 2015. (Photo: Zhang Peng/LightRocket via Getty Images)\nThe alert comes amid concerns about low vaccination rates throughout the Vancouver area.\nLast year, CBC News compiled VCH data to look at which schools throughout the region fell below the 95 per cent herd immunity rate for measles shots.\nThe Vancouver Waldorf School in North Vancouver, for example, only had a measles vaccination rate of 27 per cent, while Grandview Elementary School in East Vancouver had a vaccination rate of 47 per cent.\nThe provincial government last year sent out a mailing reminding parents to have their children vaccinated.\n\"Not immunizing children puts all of us at risk\" the letter said.\nEverything You Need To Know About Measles\nof\n\ue000\n\ue001\nThe measles, also known as rubeola, is spread through coughing, sneezing\u00a0and breathing. Symptoms include fever, cough, runny nose, red eyes\u00a0and sore throat. This is then followed by a red, blotchy skin rash.\u00a0\nAlthough the measles are highly contagious, they are not common in Canada and the U.S., which is why the recent outbreak is so worrisome. Today, the measles are common in Europe, Asia, Africa\u00a0and the Pacific. The virus spreads when infected people travel abroad.\u00a0\nIf your child\u2019s fever lasts for at least three days and they have a cough, catarrh (nose and air passages are filled with mucus), or conjunctivitis (pink eye), then they likely have the measles.  Tiny white spots on the inside of the mouth, known as Koplik spots, will also appear, usually two days before the measles rash occurs.\u00a0\nThis is because the measles can lead to serious complications, including pneumonia, encephalitis (swelling of the brain), and death. According to Mayo Clinic, the measles kills more than 100,000 people a year, most are under the age of five.\u00a0\nThere is no specific treatment for the measles because it\u2019s caused by a virus. When someone is infected with the measles, their symptoms don\u2019t show until 10 to 14 days after exposure.  The infected individual is then kept isolated and treated for things like lack of vitamin A, protein deficiencies, respiratory tract infections, eye-related complications\u00a0and dehydration through diarrhea.  Most people will recover from the measles within two to three weeks. However, between five and 20 per cent of people who contract the disease die from complications.\u00a0\nThe measles vaccine is known as the MMR shot (measles-mumps-rubella) or the MMRV shot (measles-mumps-rubella-varicella). Two doses of the vaccine can protect you for life as the first has 85 to 95 per cent efficacy and the second is almost 100 per cent.\u00a0\nThe second shot is then given between the ages of four and six.\u00a0\nThis is because pregnancy changes your immune system. Thus, pregnant women who have not yet received the vaccine should wait until after they give birth.\nInfectious disease specialist Dr. Michael Gardam recommends receiving the second vaccination within 72 hours of exposure to the virus. \u201cIt is really incredibly contagious and it's spread through the airborne route,\u201d he says. \u201cSo I don't have to touch you, or come even close to you -- if you're breathing the air that I just exhaled, you can get infected.\"\nSo far there have been six confirmed cases of the measles in Toronto -- four adults and two kids under the age of two.  Thankfully, this is significantly lower than last year\u2019s outbreak in British Columbia, where 433 cases were reported.\u00a0 Additionally, there is one case of the measles in the Niagara region. The infected individual is an unvaccinated,\u00a0female adult who had recently visited Toronto.\u00a0 One case has been reported in Manitoba.\n\ue002 Share\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1923.html"], ["url", "http://archive.northjersey.com/news/gwb-investigation-port-authority-executive-director-foye-testified-before-grand-jury-1.1018059"], ["text", "\u00a9 2017 North Jersey Media Group\nMay 16, 2014, 7:55 PM\nLast updated: Friday, May 16, 2014, 11:36 PM\nGWB investigation: Port Authority executive director Foye testified before grand jury\nBy SHAWN BOBURG and STEPHANIE AKIN\nstaff writers\u00a0|\u00a0\nThe Record\nPort Authority Executive Director Pat Foye \u2014 a New York appointee who reopened the Fort Lee access lanes to the George Washington Bridge in September and called the decision to close them potentially illegal \u2014 has testified before a federal grand jury investigating the closings, a knowledgeable source said.\nRECORD FILE PHOTO\nPatrick Foye, executive director of the Port Authority.\nFoye had been scheduled to appear before a panel of New Jersey lawmakers investigating the bridge scandal earlier this week, but federal prosecutors in New Jersey requested that his appearance be postponed so that he could first testify before the grand jury, another source said. The legislative committee, which does not have the power to level criminal charges, agreed late last month to push back Foye\u2019s appearance until June and said that he had a \u201cscheduling conflict.\u201d\nBoth sources requested anonymity because they are not authorized to publicly discuss the grand jury proceedings.\nOne of the sources said Foye testified before the grand jury early this month, but details about that testimony were not available. Foye declined to comment on Friday.\nFoye is among up to a half-dozen current Port Authority officials who have been summoned by federal prosecutors from the office of New Jersey\u2019s U.S. Attorney, Paul Fishman, suggesting that the pace of the investigation has quickened in recent weeks.\nOne of the employees called to testify is Arielle Schwarz, who was a special assistant to David Wildstein, the former Port Authority executive and onetime ally of Governor Christie who oversaw the lane closures, two sources said. Phillip Kwon, the agency\u2019s first deputy general counsel, has also been subpoenaed, although it is unclear if he has testified.\nJust because a grand jury is hearing testimony about the lane closures does not mean federal prosecutors will charge anyone with a crime. But its sustained focus on the closings suggests that prosecutors have cleared a preliminary investigative hurdle \u2014 identifying a federal law that may have been broken when two of three local lanes were shut, possibly for political reasons, creating massive traffic jams in Fort Lee for parts of five days.\n\u201cWe can\u2019t comment on grand jury matters,\u201d said Rebekah Carmichael of the U.S. Attorney\u2019s Office in New Jersey.\nFoye, the top executive at the Port Authority, has said he was not notified that the access lanes would be closed and found out four days later. On the morning of Sept. 13, he reopened the lanes and sent an angry email calling the decision to shut them \u201cabusive,\u201d adding that he believed state and federal laws had been broken. The controversy that followed has hurt Christie\u2019s standing as an early front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination leading up to the 2016 election.\nWeeks before the lane closures, a deputy chief of staff in Christie\u2019s office, Bridget Anne Kelly, sent Wildstein an email, \u201cTime for some traffic problems in Fort Lee.\u201d The two also exchanged derisive messages about Fort Lee Mayor Mark Sokolich, a Democrat who did not endorse Christie for reelection. Christie fired Kelly a day after The Record broke the story about the email and has insisted he had no prior knowledge or involvement in planning or authorizing the closures.\nChristie\u2019s chief spokesman, Michael Drewniak, also testified before the grand jury last month and appeared before the legislative panel this week.\nOn Friday, a left-leaning political action committee released more than 1,000 pages of documents that it had requested from the Port Authority. The records provide a rough outline of former Deputy Executive Director Bill Baroni\u2019s activities leading up to and after the lane closings.\nBaroni, a former Republican state senator, was appointed by Christie to be New Jersey\u2019s top executive at the agency. He resigned in December, weeks after he told state lawmakers that the lane closures were the result of a traffic study, an account that has since been undermined.\nThe records show that Baroni scheduled two meetings with Sokolich in the mayor\u2019s Fort Lee office in December 2012 and April 2013, during the height of the Christie administration\u2019s alleged attempts to woo Sokolich and other Democrats for an endorsement.\nIn January, Sokolich\u2019s name appeared on a list of 21 Democratic mayors the Christie campaign had targeted, according to a report issued in March by the law firm Christie hired to look into his office\u2019s role in the lane closures. Sokolich ultimately declined to endorse the governor.\nThe documents include two years of daily calendar entries and several expense records and were released in response to a public records request filed by American Bridge 21st Century, a liberal super PAC that conducts opposition research to aid Democratic candidates and causes.\nBaroni did not respond to messages Friday. A person who answered the phone at Sokolich\u2019s law firm said he was unavailable.\nThe calendar entries also show Baroni had scheduled meetings with two other figures who have emerged in connection to the lane-closure scandal but whose roles remain unexplained.\nBaroni\u2019s schedule indicates he planned to meet with Rabbi Mendy Carlebach in July, August and October 2013.\nThose meetings coincide with the period that Carlebach, a Port Authority police chaplain, allegedly upset Wildstein, his colleague and adviser. Wildstein wrote that Carlebach had \u201cpissed me off,\u201d in a text message with Kelly in August, and Wildstein and Kelly exchanged jokes about causing traffic jams in front of Carlebach\u2019s house and orchestrating delays for flights to Tel Aviv.\nCarlebach has said he had never spoken to Wildstein and only exchanged pleasantries with Kelly.\nThe records show that Baroni also scheduled a meeting in February 2013 in his office with lobbyist Jeff Michaels and representatives of the security firm Allied Barton, five months before the Port Authority secured a four-year, $221 million contract with the company for guards at its airports.\nMichaels\u2019 brother, Chip, is the Port Authority police officer who escorted Wildstein on a tour of the traffic tie-ups in September. The Michaels brothers, Wildstein and Christie grew up together in Livingston.\nEmail: boburg@northjersey.com and akin@northjersey.com\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1925.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/transportation/2017/01/14/road-warrior-distraction-crackdown-coming-spring/96505362/"], ["text", "SAFETY:\u00a0Mixed news for highway safety in '16\nResearch supports the need for this approach. From 2011 to 2015, driver inattention contributed to 875 fatal crashes \u2013 more than drunken driving (506), speeding (451) and pedestrian violations (605), according to State Police figures.\nBut can a two- to three-week crackdown really hold back the tidal wave of perilous in-car activities that have become second nature to thousands of motorists who read, eat, drink, groom themselves\u00a0and use hand-held devices to either talk, text or find their way?\nMaybe so. After all, the fine for a first offense is now $200 to $400. But let\u2019s first examine last year\u2019s crackdown.\nA total of 355 police departments participated, but they issued fewer than 7,000 distracted-driving summonses. (Speeding netted more citations \u2013 8,000.) And the campaign seemed to lack\u00a0follow-through:\u00a0By year\u2019s end, statewide\u00a0summonses for violations of\u00a0NJSA 39:4-97.3\u00a0had slipped to 55,832 \u2013 17 percent fewer than in 2015, according to court records.\nBut this year will be different, promised Poedubicky.\nHis reasoning hinges on funding. Last year\u2019s campaign -- called \"U Drive U Text U Pay\" -- lacked\u00a0a federal grant. So traffic cops simply squeezed distracted drivers\u00a0into their daily routines.\u00a0But this year, police in New Jersey, Connecticut and Maine \u2013 the only states to receive federal grants \u2013 will be paid time-and-a-half to focus\u00a0on the drivers\u00a0who cause 25 percent of all serious crashes, according to federal authorities.\nThis plan matches similar crackdowns for seat-belt and drunken-driving violations.\nSome\u00a0believe this approach is less than serious. It\u2019s \u201crent-a-cop,\u201d said Ramsey motorist J.P. Tristani, who called the system \u201covertime pay for junior officers not yet at the maximum\u201d just so they can \"increase yearly pay.\u201d\nBut as one lawmaker noted, few strategies are as effective as enforcement.\n\u201cThere\u2019s nothing like the shock of a ticket to send a message to people who are tempted to reach for a phone,\u201d said Assemblyman Declan O\u2019Scanlon, a Monmouth County Republican. \u201cAnd we\u2019re all tempted, so we all need enforcement.\u201d\nTraffic enforcement and road maintenance declined during and after the Great Recession. But road crashes, injuries and deaths plummeted anyway as technology improved driving safety and motorists cut back on expenses by driving less. In 2008 alone, statewide traffic deaths fell 18.5 percent, from 724 to 590.\nBut since then,\u00a0fatal\u00a0crashes in some\u00a0categories continued to climb. Deadly distracted-driving crashes\u00a0during\u00a0the 2011-to-2015 period exceeded the\u00a0previous five-year total by nearly 9\u00a0percent. Fatal\u00a0pedestrian crashes for the same period rose\u00a0nearly 4 percent.\u00a0Statistically, young people remained as vulnerable to road carnage as they were to deadly drug abuse, an issue that generally garners much more attention.\u00a0In 2015, for example, New Jersey road crashes killed 56 people under the age of 21, exactly the same number of New Jersey deaths attributed to drug overdoses in the same age cohort, according to National Safety Council figures.\nIn an\u00a0informal poll last week, readers said they welcomed more police presence. After years of stomach-churning excursions on highways like 17, 23, 46, 208 and 287, for example, my lawyer pal Grumpy John\u00a0proclaimed that he welcomed a return to \u201cthe era of Broderick Crawford,\u201d who played a grumpy police chief in the 1950s TV series \u201cHighway Patrol.\u201d\n\u201cHe and his men actually ventured onto highways,\u201d Grumpy recalled. \u201cIf police did that here, their mere presence would have a calming effect on traffic.\u201d\nThe timing seems ripe for this approach because increased fatalities are no longer confined to a few categories. Besides last year\u2019s spike to 607, overall\u00a0road deaths also rose in the two previous years from a base of 542 in 2013. If you ask the bean counters in the State Police Fatal\u00a0Accident Investigative Unit for the last time fatalities shot up three years in a row, they can\u2019t answer because there\u2019s no precedent since they began keeping track in 1968.\nSo we\u2019ve lived through what statisticians consider a bona fide three-year trend. How can we keep it from infecting 2017?\nWhen asked, readers came up with much more than a cellphone crackdown.\nAlan Appel wants periodic vision testing. \u201cIt\u2019s a bit harsh,\u201d said the Mahwah motorist, \u201cbut it has to happen.\u201d Alan might know something; he\u2019s 77.\nKate Wade wants a crackdown on drivers and pedestrians who wear headphones. \u201cHow can they hear a horn or siren?\u201d asked the Leonia reader.\nCiting too-frequent crashes involving pedestrians and bicyclists after dark, Carol Lotito wants free distribution of reflective bracelets and shoe bands. \u201cThank God I haven\u2019t hit somebody at night,\u201d said the Cresskill motorist.\nRutherford\u2019s Tony Sobieski wants a resumption of auto-safety inspections, which were halted in 2010.\u00a0Walter Thomassen of Fair Lawn wants the street lights and the electronic speed indicator restored at the dangerous \u201ctanker turn\u201d where routes 95 and 80 meet in Ridgefield. Bob Green of Ho-Ho-Kus thinks police should ticket fellow cops.\nUnrealistic? Maybe so, but the state itself adopted a Vision Zero road-safety goal that might seem unrealistic, too. Its Division of Highway Traffic Safety pledged to reduce traffic deaths to zero by 2030. The pledge was made in 2015 based on the previous year\u2019s death toll of 556. But now that deaths have reached 607, all New Jerseyans have plenty of catching up to do.\nWe could start by putting down our phones in the car.\n46 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2ivyvil\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1938.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/03/02/more-ugly-fruit-and-vegetables-coming-to-loblaw-stores-across-canada_n_9369378.html"], ["text", "Loblaw's Ugly Produce Is Expanding Because It's Selling So Well\nCP \u00a0|\u00a0 By                                                                      Aleksandra Sagan\nADVERTISEMENT\nTORONTO \u2014 Ugly food can mean a pretty profit.\nAt least, that's the bet Loblaw is making with its ugly duckling line of produce aimed at shoppers looking to save money on the sky-rocketing cost of fresh food.\nThe company launched its Naturally Imperfect line last March, offering ugly apples and potatoes to Ontario and Quebec shoppers as part of a trial run that later expanded to select stores in other provinces.\nMore types of cheaper, but blemished and misshapen, produce will soon be available across the country, the company announced Wednesday.\n\"It really went well above and beyond what our expectation was,\" said Dan Branson, the company's senior director of produce.\n\"I think it really spoke to the fact that Canadians are out there really looking for some options around driving value into their weekly shop and having greater accessibility to that healthy eating product of value.\"\nBased on the program's success, Naturally Imperfect will now include unsightly peppers, onions and mushrooms for consumers in Quebec and Ontario.\nMeanwhile, Loblaw's Real Canadian Superstore, Your Independent Grocer and most No Frills stores in B.C., Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba started stocking less-than-perfect apples and peppers Wednesday, and Atlantic Superstore and Your Independent Grocer locations in the Atlantic provinces started stocking Naturally Imperfect apples.\nThe line's produce is now also available at Your Independent Grocer and Real Canadian Superstore in Whitehorse, Yukon.\nThe uglier version of a fruit or vegetable costs up to 30 per cent less than its good looking counterpart.\nThat can be appealing to consumers who have been smacked with sticker shock on the produce aisle over the past year due to the low Canadian dollar and other factors, including shortages caused by a drought in California.\nBetween January 2015 and 2016, Canadian food prices rose four per cent, according to Statistics Canada's consumer price index. But fresh fruit and vegetables showed some of the biggest increases, shooting up 12.9 and 18.2 per cent respectively.\nIn the fourth quarter of 2015, Loblaw's internal food inflation outpaced the CPI's 4.1 per cent jump, according to the company's financial reports.\nAnd while it has managed to pass most of this cost on to the consumer, shoppers started choosing cheaper products when some foods surpassed a certain price point, president and executive chairman Galen Weston said during a conference call with investors last week.\nConsumers, especially those in Alberta where the economy is struggling, have flocked to Loblaw's discount offerings, he said.\nBranson said Loblaw looks to deliver great value regardless of the economy, but thinks that with the way things are now the offerings may be benefiting Canadians more than when Naturally Imperfect was first launched.\nIt plans to expand the program even more over the coming months.\nFollow @AleksSagan on Twitter.\n"]]
