[["name", "new_7/1940.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/passaic/woodland-park/2017/01/14/woodland-park-wont-renew-contract-energy-supplier/96575920/"], ["text", "FacebookEmail Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nWoodland Park won't renew contract with energy supplier\nWoodland Park did not renew its pact with a 3rd-party energy supplier that had assured residents they would save money.\nPost to Facebook\nWoodland Park won't renew contract with energy supplier Woodland Park did not renew its pact with a 3rd-party energy supplier that had assured residents they would save money. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jJ9nCC\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nWoodland Park won't renew contract with energy supplier\nLindsey Kelleher , Staff Writer, @LindseyKelleher 12:05 p.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nThis letter was sent to Woodland Park residents in 2016 regarding an energy aggregation program the borough entered into with a third-party energy supplier. Woodland Park did not renew its contract with Constellation Energy this year because its rates were not 5 percent lower than PSE&G's.\n(Photo: Lindsey Kelleher)\nWOODLAND PARK \u2014 The borough did not renew its contract with a third-party energy supplier that assured residents last year that they would save money on their electric bills.\nThe contract between Constellation Energy Services and the municipality expired in December, and now that the contract is up, Public Service Electric & Gas will go back to charging residents for the supply portion of their electric bills. PSE&G is the primary electric service provider for Woodland Park.\nVerizon pushed to extend FiOS service in Woodland Park\nThe borough entered into a contract with Constellation Energy last winter in an effort to provide residents with some savings. Constellation offered residents a flat, fixed rate for their energy supply.\nUnder the contract, residents were expected to pay 5 percent less for the supply portion of their electric bills compared to what PSE&G would have charged them, according to Borough Clerk Kevin Galland. Regardless of supplier, PSE&G still is responsible for the delivery of energy to homes, billing and administrative functions.\nHowever, when bid prices for energy suppliers came back this past fall, the prices were higher than what PSE&G was willing to provide, Galland said.\nAs a result, the borough defaulted back to PSE&G.\nWhether or not the borough will enter into a contract with a third-party supplier in the future, Galland said, \u201cWhen the opportunity is presented to the governing body, it will weigh the pros and cons of going into a contract and make its decision based on the pros and cons.\u201d\nWoodland Park entered into the contract with Constellation Energy last year because the municipality was participating in an energy aggregation program called the Passaic County Energy Cooperative Pricing System.\nThe Passaic County Energy Cooperative Pricing System was formed in 2010 to offer joint purchasing opportunities for energy suppliers that would provide counties and municipalities with energy savings and to help taxpayers save money on their electric bills.\nEmail: kelleher@northjersey.com\n21 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jJ9nCC\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1949.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/03/01/democratic-front-runner-hillary-clinton-attacks-valeant-for-predatory-pricing_n_9359952.html"], ["text", "Hillary Clinton Attacks Valeant Pharmaceuticals Over 'Predatory Pricing'\nCP\nreddit\nADVERTISEMENT\nHillary Clinton has stepped up her battle against predatory drug pricing in her bid to become the next U.S. president \u2014 and she is setting her sights on Valeant Pharmaceuticals.\nIn a new campaign ad on her YouTube page, the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination vows to go after the Quebec-based drugmaker.\nValeant has been accused of gouging patients on drug costs \u2014 allegations it has denied.\nHillary Clinton at \"Get Out the Vote\" event in New Hampshire on Feb. 6. (Photo: Dennis Van Tine/Star Max/IPx)\nThe ad posted Monday cites the case of a woman who has been taking a brand name medication since the 1980s that, at one time,\u00a0it says cost about $180 for 10 shots.\nThe name of the medication is not disclosed in the ad, which\u00a0appears to have been filmed at a town hall-type campaign stop in January.\nThe ad shows Clinton waving a letter\u00a0and saying the cost of the woman's\u00a0latest refill\u00a0has shot up to $14,700 for the same 10 vials.\n\"The company is called Valeant Pharmaceuticals. I am going after them,\" Clinton tells the meeting to a round of applause.\n\"This is\u00a0predatory pricing and we're going to make sure it is stopped.\"\nMichael Pearson, chairman and chief executive officer of Valeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc., speaks during an interview at the Bloomberg Canada Economic Summit in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Thursday, May 21, 2015.\nValeant said after it became aware of the patient's story in January, it contacted her to determine whether it could help cover the costs of the medication as part of a patient assistance program.\n\"She informed us that her insurance provider covers the drug, so it is not a significant out-of-pocket expenditure for her,\" Valeant said in a statement Tuesday.\nValeant also said there has been a generic version of the drug available since 2003 and that its share of the overall market for the medication has declined to less than one per cent.\n\"Whenever the sales volume of a drug declines, manufacturers must consider pricing adjustments to keep production of the drug viable,\" Valeant said. \"Patients are able to choose generic versions of the drug, however, at significantly lower prices.\"\nThe company, one of\u00a0several companies under investigation as the U.S. Congress looks at price increases for certain specialty drugs, has seen its share price plummet to well under $100 from above $346 last summer. On Tuesday, the stock\u00a0fell $6.55 to settle at $87.94 on the Toronto Stock Exchange.\nAlso on HuffPost:\n\ue000\n\ue001\nNEW YORK, NY - MARCH 07:  Former United States Secretary of State Hillary Clinton arrives at the event 'Equality for Women is Progress for All' at the United Nations on March 7, 2014 in New York City. The event was part of the United Nations International Women's Day, which is celebrated tomorrow, March 8.  (Photo by Andrew Burton/Getty Images)\nNEW YORK, NY - MARCH 07:  United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon (L) and Former United States Secretary of State Hillary Clinton attend the event 'Equality for Women is Progress for All' at the United Nations on March 7, 2014 in New York City. (Photo by Andrew Burton/Getty Images)\nMIAMI, FL - FEBRUARY 26:  Hillary Rodham Clinton, Former Secretary of State flashes a U symbol before speaking speaking during an event at the University of Miamis BankUnited Center on February 26, 2014 in Coral Gables, Florida. Clinton is reported to be mulling a second presidential run.  (Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images)\nCORAL GABLES, FL - FEBRUARY 26:  Hillary Rodham Clinton, Former Secretary of State (L) speaks with Donna E. Being of the same bias I would not normally complain, but how is the average person supposed to build an informed opinion without both sides of an argument? Dissenting opinion is few and far between.\nMichael Frampton\nApplication disappeared then... WTF guys??? The huffpost app widget posted a pop-up that said \"no associated application\". ALL I did was change microsd card for different music via dismount in General settings. When I went back to huff post to finish article I was reading the above happened. If it didn't uninstall where did it go. I had to reinstall HP from play store.\nRichard Powell\nNew Low in Journalism I like the breadth of topics covered and it does have some good news.  More recently HuffPo has sunk to new lows in Yellow Journalism AKA Hearst Bias.  HuffPo used to represent news.  More recently, it has adopted a patently biased profile taking positions rather than reporting news.  Unfortunately this shift makes papers like National Enquirer and Star look like serious journalism by comparison.  Come on guys, try to be a little less blatantly biased and just report.  It's getting really hard to read.\nRichard Flom\nMeh The app works okay if opening directly. But opening from a Facebook link - fails and says no connection. Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest\nSouth Hackensack looks to improve street, sidewalks\nSOUTH HACKENSACK \u2014\u00a0This year, township\u00a0officials\u00a0hope\u00a0to improve a heavily travelled street and begin an ambitious project to rehabilitate streets and sidewalks for students to walk to and from school. \u00a0\nPost to Facebook\nSouth Hackensack looks to improve street, sidewalks SOUTH HACKENSACK \u2014\u00a0This year, township\u00a0officials\u00a0hope\u00a0to improve a heavily travelled street and begin an ambitious project to rehabilitate streets and sidewalks for students to walk to and from school. \u00a0 Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2iwoi5h\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nSouth Hackensack looks to improve street, sidewalks\nRodrigo Torrejon , Staff Writer, @rod_torrejon 10:27 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nLeuning Street in South Hackensack is in need of repairs.\n(Photo: Tariq Zehawi/NorthJersey.com)\nSOUTH HACKENSACK \u2014\u00a0This year, township\u00a0officials\u00a0hope\u00a0to improve a heavily travelled street and begin an ambitious project to rehabilitate streets and sidewalks for students to walk to and from school.\n\"There was a lot of safety concerns for getting back to school,\"\u00a0said\u00a0Committeman\u00a0Gary\u00a0Brugger, who served as mayor in 2016. \"I drove around\u00a0town\u00a0with our grant writer and engineer and identified areas that needed improving.\"\nOne\u00a0grant\u00a0is the state Department of Transportation Local Aid Grant and would be used to repave\u00a0Leuning\u00a0Street, which\u00a0is a narrow street\u00a0lined with a mix of industrial buildings, one-family homes and small business fronts.\nMany businesses that use trucks, including a forklift company,\u00a0are based along\u00a0the street, which\u00a0is in\u00a0frequent\u00a0need\u00a0of\u00a0pothole\u00a0repair.\nBorough Clerk Donna Gambutti said the street was chosen as one of three streets determined to be in deteriorating condition. The street was chosen through a traffic study conducted by\u00a0Neglia\u00a0Engineering.\u00a0Township officials must demonstrate a need for the grant. If selected, the award would be determined later.\nAn aerial view of the proposed project area for the Safe Routes To School project.\n\u00a0(Photo: Neglia Engineering Associates)\nThe other grant, which\u00a0officials\u00a0applied for in June, is the\u00a0federal\u00a0Safe Routes\u00a0To\u00a0School grant, which\u00a0encourages municipalities to create safer and more accessible paths to school for students walking and biking\u00a0by providing funding for sidewalks.\nThe\u00a0proposed project area extends from East Grove Street to Hoffmann Street and would comprise sidewalk construction, creation of pedestrian walkways and intersection safety improvements.\u00a0The total project would cost $417,390\u00a0of which the grant could cover\u00a0\u00a0$347, 825.\u00a0Township officials would likely make up the difference by\u00a0borrowing\u00a0the money by issuing municipal bonds, officials said.\nTownship officials applied for two reasons:\u00a0to double the number of students walking to and from school from 75 to 150 per day and to make their walks safer, according to the application.\u00a0If the grant is awarded and the project completed, an estimated 60 percent of all Memorial School students would be walking to and from school.\n\"We feel it\u2019s a needed project,\"\u00a0Brugger\u00a0said. \"It\u2019s a well qualified project under what this grant affords.\"\nBoth\u00a0grants have\u00a0yet to be awarded. The Safe Routes To School grant response is expected sometime in February. For the DOT grant,\u00a0the final amount to be requested\u00a0is dependent on if it is awarded or not.\nEmail: torrejon@northjersey.com\u00a0\nLeuning Street in South Hackensack is in need of repairs.\n\u00a0(Photo: Tariq Zehawi/NorthJersey.com)\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1971.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/morris/parsippany-troy-hills/2017/01/13/parsippany-office-space-turned-into-apartments/96370088/"], ["text", "Will Parsippany office space be turned into apartments?\nParsippany office space being looked at for possible residential apartments\nPost to Facebook\nWill Parsippany office space be turned into apartments? Parsippany office space being looked at for possible residential apartments Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jFYqBJ\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nWill Parsippany office space be turned into apartments?\nGene Myers , Staff Writer, @myersgene Published 5:29 p.m. ET Jan. 13, 2017 | Updated 10:27 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nThe vacant Mack-Cali-owned building at 7 Campus Drive may be considered for conversion to residential apartments. Building pictured Jan. 7, 2017.\u00a0\nAdam Anik/NorthJersey.com\nThe vacant Mack-Cali-owned building at 7 Campus Drive may be considered for conversion to residential apartments. Building pictured Jan. 7, 2017.\u00a0\nAdam Anik/NorthJersey.com\nThe vacant Mack-Cali-owned building at 7 Campus Drive may be considered for conversion to residential apartments. Building pictured Jan. 7, 2017.\u00a0\nAdam Anik/NorthJersey.com\nThe vacant Mack-Cali-owned building at 7 Campus Drive may be considered for conversion to residential apartments. Building pictured Jan. 7, 2017.\u00a0\nAdam Anik/NorthJersey.com\nLike this topic? You may also like these photo galleries:\nReplay\nLast Slide Next Slide\nParsippany officials won't say if empty Mack-Cali office building is being considered for housing complex\nThe vacant Mack-Cali-owned building at 7 Campus Drive may be considered for conversion to residential apartments. Building pictured Jan. 7, 2017.\n(Photo: Adam Anik/NorthJersey.com)\nWill an empty office building in Parsippany be converted into residential apartments and retail space?\nIt's hard to tell since township officials won't confirm or deny that talks have taken place with representatives of a business complex off Route 202. The plan, according to some, is\u00a0to turn one of the\u00a0Campus Drive Mack-Cali building into 97 apartment units and store-fronts at the main level.\nCarlos Guzman, president of the 300-member Sedgefield Civic Association said he was told by Mayor James Barberio of the plan in September. He said the mayor didn't specify which Mack-Cali building would be used, but did say the talk left him worried that such a deal would worsen traffic in an already congested area.\nThe mayor has not returned repeated calls and emails seeking information.\n\u201cThe mayor told me that Mack-Cali was planning to put in one building of about 97 apartments with high-end retail stores,\u201d said Guzman.\nParsippany business gets EPA kudos for recycling\nGuzman shared the information with Brian Tappen, who heads the 300-member Glacier Hills neighborhood association. Tappen said he reached out to the mayor and said he was told town officials \u201cwere in confidential talks with Mack-Cali.\u201d Tappen said the mayor wouldn't say more, but added if \"anything happened\" that would affect the neighborhood associations they would be notified.\nTappen said he believes the plan is also to make the apartments fit the affordable housing requirement, but has not been able to confirm that information.\nIlene Jablonski, senior vice president of Marketing for Mack-Cali said:\u00a0\u201cWe\u2019re currently looking at best uses for our assets in Parsippany.\u201d\nThe building at the center of the discussions sits near Glacial Hills and the Sedgefield homes near routes 10, 202 and 53. It\u2019s already a busy traffic area with backups during commuting times, said Tappen.\n\u201cThere is already a traffic problem caused by people cutting from Route 202 to Route 53,\u201d Tappen said. \u201cIf this apartment complex is built it will be a thousand times worse.\u201d\nTappen asked the township for more information regarding the possible project, when he was denied he filed for the information through the Open Public Records Act in early November 2016. On Friday, after a number of requested extensions, the township emailed two documents to Tappen containing hundreds of pages of old emails, some dating back to 2012, between township and Mack-Cali officials, nothing pertaining to residential housing at Campus Drive. Tappen said the information he received is incomplete and said he is being kept out of the loop.\nCouncilmen Robert Peluso and Paul Carifi Jr. said they, too, often feel out of the loop.\n\u201c\"I can\u2019t discuss items from closed sessions unless approved by township attorney.\"\u201d\nRobert Peluso, Parsippany council member\nWhen asked about the possibility of the Mack-Cali building being converted to residential apartments, Peluso said: \u201cI can\u2019t discuss items from closed sessions unless approved by township attorney.\u201d\nCarifi said he is aware of talks about housing in that location but he was advised by township attorney John Inglesino not to speak about specifics. \u201cUnfortunately, the town attorney has advised us not to discuss it,\u201d he said. \u201cOtherwise I would like to.\u201d\nCarifi said he shares Tappen\u2019s concerns that too much of the deal will be done in back rooms. He said it wouldn\u2019t be out of character for the mayor to present it at the last second, leaving him not enough time for research and not enough time to get proper input from the public. Carifi said he thinks time might be on his side this time, however, because it\u2019s an election year.\n\u201cHe is going to try to push this off until after June [elections] because of the uproar from residents,\u201d Carifi said.\nCarifi said he has been \"flooded\" by emails sent to him by residents concerned with the apartment plan.\n\u201cAfter emails from Carlos and Brian were sent to their associations, all of the residents who live in those areas were definitely quite upset,\u201d Carifi said. \u201cThey had a lot of questions. Everyone that I spoke to was definitely upset.\u201d\nAn initial request for information to the mayor was forwarded to the township attorney who called and said they were not violating any open records requests because the town had sought and received extensions.\nCouncil Member Michael dePierro deferred all calls to the township attorney and wouldn\u2019t confirm any information other than to say \u201cthere\u2019s not much going on right now.\u201d\nCouncil members Louis Valori and Loretta Gragnani did not respond to requests for information.\nA woman who identified herself as being with the zoning board, but would not give her name said the building is currently zoned as SED 10 and that the planning board would have to get involved before it could be converted to residential apartments - a process she said \u201cwould take several months.\u201d\nThe Record has requested the information via OPRA.\nEmail: myers@northjersey.com\u00a0\n3 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jFYqBJ\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/1983.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/essex/montclair/2017/01/14/montclair-considers-late-artists-home-historic-landmark/96505564/"], ["text", "Montclair considers late artist's home as historic landmark\nMontclair may soon add another home to its list of historic properties.\nPost to Facebook\nMontclair considers late artist's home as historic landmark Montclair may soon add another home to its list of historic properties. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2iwepER\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nMontclair considers late artist's home as historic landmark\nMollie Shauger , Staff Writer, @MollieShauger 10:17 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nThe municipal council will consider an ordinance designating this home at 48 Walnut Crescent as a historic landmark.\n(Photo: Mollie Shauger/NorthJersey.com)\nMontclair may soon add another home to its list of historic properties.\nThe Montclair Township Council will consider an ordinance at its next meeting that would designate the home at 48 Walnut Crescent,\u00a0near HackensackUMC Mountainside hospital,\u00a0as a historic landmark, the Lawrence Carmichael Earle House, named for the late artist who briefly resided there.\nHe was among a group of artists who were part of an\u00a0artist\u2019s colony in Montclair during the late 19th century.\u00a0Another prominent resident of that circle was landscape painter\u00a0George Inness.\nHawthorne Dutch historic house slated for improvements\n\u201cThese are artists who had homes here and had their studios in New York,\u201d said Kathleen Bennett, chair of Montclair\u2019s Historic Preservation Commission. The artists and their families became integrated in the community, she said.\nBennett, along with Montclair Planning Board member Carmel Loughman, drafted a report on the home in their pitch to make it a historic landmark.\nBennett said the local designation would put the onus on the homeowner to retain the home\u2019s exterior in\u00a0its original architectural style.\nTax records show the home was built in 1850. Its last owners are listed as James R. and Elizabeth Donald.\nAccording to records in\u00a0the Montclair Public Library, the Earle house\u2019s style was described as \u201clate 19th century/2nd Empire element\u201d in a survey conducted in 1981 for the state\u2019s historical site inventory. Its condition at the time was rated \u201cexcellent.\u201d\nThe exterior at that time was described as stucco, with a mansard roof and interior center chimney.\n\u201cWe don\u2019t have many mansard Second Empire examples in Montclair,\u201d Bennett said, noting that the style was popular in Europe at the time and was considered \u201chigh standard.\u201d\nThe home\u2019s significance is described as \u201cone of the last survivors from the 19th century in this neighborhood,\u201d in library records.\nEarle lived at the home from 1897 to 1903, and was among the members of the Montclair Art Colony, from 1895 to 1908, the records indicate.\nEarle was originally from Grand Rapids, Mich. He lived in\u00a0the Montclair home with his wife, Nellie, and sons John H. and Lawrence H., according to lcearle.com, a website dedicated to the artist. His family became \u201cvery involved\u201d with the Montclair Dramatic Club, and Earle was a founding member of the Montclair Art Museum, the website says.\nAmong his well-known paintings was one for the Liberal Arts Building at the Columbian Exhibition of 1893. He is also known for his \u201cDutch Boy Painter,\" which became the logo for the Dutch Boy Paint Company.\nThe HPC had recommended the historic designation of Earle\u2019s home to the municipal Planning Board, which approved it in December. The ordinance would go before the Township Council on Jan. 24 for a first reading.\n\u201cWe have artists and architects in town that people are losing the knowledge of, so I think it\u2019s important to promote this, to let people to know what we had in town and still have,\u201d Bennettt said.\nEmail: gray@northjersey.com\n16 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2iwepER\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1989.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/bergen/emerson/2017/01/14/emerson-borough-hall-murals-added-national-new-deal-registry/96563464/"], ["text", "Emerson Borough Hall, murals added to national New Deal registry\nResident Jill McGuire had sought inclusion in the registry in an effort to preserve Borough Hall\nPost to Facebook\nEmerson Borough Hall, murals added to national New Deal registry Resident Jill McGuire had sought inclusion in the registry in an effort to preserve Borough Hall Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2jIStDX\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nEmerson Borough Hall, murals added to national New Deal registry\nBrett Carroll , Staff Writer, @Neva_4Brett_ME 9:51 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nResident Jill McGuire had sought inclusion in the registry in an effort to preserve Borough Hall\nEmerson's Borough Hall and seven murals in its basement have been added to a national historic registry dedicated to preserving the art and architecture of the New Deal era.\n(Photo: Amy Newman/NorthJersey.com)\nEMERSON \u2014 Emerson's Borough Hall and seven murals in its basement have been added to a national historic registry dedicated to preserving the art and architecture of the New Deal era.\nBorough resident Jill McGuire had sought their inclusion in the registry, known as The Living New Deal, in an effort to protect the municipal building from demolition. She said the\u00a0registry does\u00a0not\u00a0provide any\u00a0protections, but it does at least document the murals and front\u00a0of the building in a national registry\u00a0and brings attention to the building. McGuire also stated that this was just the first step to seeing if the building could be preserved.\nEMERSON: Borough 'history' a mystery\nThe borough\u00a0is\u00a0considering renovating, or outright replacing\u00a0Borough\u00a0Hall.\u00a0According to Mayor Louis\u00a0Lamatina, a 2014 study was done that suggests\u00a0that the building would need to increase from approximately 8,000\u00a0square\u00a0feet to approximately 20,000\u00a0square\u00a0feet in order to accommodate\u00a0the borough's needs.\nCurrently, Borough Hall houses the town's administrative offices, as well as the municipal court and the police department. One of several options borough officials are considering is\u00a0consolidating its ambulance corps into the building.\nThe Borough Council has reviewed architectural proposals for the Borough Hall project, as well as potentially building a new,\u00a0separate\u00a0ambulance corps or emergency services building and\u00a0a\u00a0community\u00a0center. The council is expected to discuss the selection of an architect at their meeting Tuesday, according to the meeting agenda.\nMcGuire started looking into\u00a0the\u00a0historical registry after a Dec. 6 council meeting\u00a0in which several architects presented\u00a0their plans. Several of the architects suggested either substantial add-ons to the front of\u00a0Borough\u00a0Hall, or\u00a0constructing a\u00a0new building.\nMcGuire, who lives\u00a0next to\u00a0Borough\u00a0Hall, stated\u00a0at that meeting\u00a0that she didn\u2019t want to see the building\u00a0taken\u00a0down, and that she felt that at least the front of the building was\u00a0too\u00a0integral to the town\u2019s history to be replaced.\n\u201cI understand that the building needs to be renovated, I just want to make sure that we keep the building\u2019s historical significance intact as well,\u201d McGuire said.\nIn response,\u00a0Lamatina\u00a0said, \"The murals can certainly be preserved. As far as the front of the building, again, we will listen to the architect's recommendation and decide accordingly.\"\nBorough Administrator Robert Hoffman\u00a0stated that he is looking into ways to preserve the murals, and had even\u00a0researched\u00a0a program at the University of Texas that specializes in preserving paintings and murals.\nThe seven murals\u00a0are believed to have been\u00a0painted\u00a0when\u00a0Borough Hall was built as part of a Works Progress Administration project in 1939.\u00a0The murals range from wacky to thoughtful, each unique to the time period and art style of the late\u00a01930s.\nEmail: carroll@northjersey.com\n26 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nRead or Share this story: http://northjersy.news/2jIStDX\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/1998.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/bergen/emerson/2017/01/14/archive-emerson-history-mystery/96582322/"], ["text", "Archive: Emerson 'history' a mystery\nThis article was originally published on June 1, 2016.\nPost to Facebook\nArchive: Emerson 'history' a mystery This article was originally published on June 1, 2016. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2iw3ryQ\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nArchive: Emerson 'history' a mystery\nNorthJersey 9:48 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\nThis article was originally published on June 1, 2016.\nEMERSON \u2014 There is a giant sea monster lurking in a shadowy corner in the basement of Borough Hall.\nThe 77-year-old painting \u2014 which shows the creature clutching a topless woman in one tentacle and a pitcher of beer in another \u2014 is one of several New Deal-era murals that adorn the basement\u2019s cinder block walls.\nTheir provenance remains something of a mystery to borough officials, who plan to consult with an art expert later this year as a first step toward ensuring their long-term preservation.\nThe prevailing belief is that the surreal, and somewhat risqu\u00e9, murals were painted when Borough Hall was built as part of a Works Progress Administration project in 1939.\n\"I\u2019ve never found anyone older than me \u2014 and I\u2019m 87 \u2014 who knows much about them,\" Bill Wassmann, the chairman of Emerson\u2019s Historic Preservation Commission, said of the murals. \"But these paintings are part of an important era of our country\u2019s history.\"\nBorough Hall was built as a multipurpose building. It housed the Fire Department\u2019s headquarters and even a stage where the council chambers are now, Wassmann said.\nIt is less clear if the murals were commissioned under the Federal Art Project, a section of the WPA in which hundreds of artists were hired to create more than 100,000 paintings, including murals, across the country during the Great Depression. Much of the artwork produced under the program was in government buildings.\nIn Emerson, most of the New Deal-era murals are scattered throughout the seldom-used basement in a conference room, in a police radio equipment room, and in old jail cells now used to store evidence.\nWhile the sea monster mural is perhaps the most striking, several others have tongue-in-cheek themes \u2013 and are not the usual decorative fare chosen for government buildings. Many are signed by someone named \"Haring\" and are dated as having been painted in 1939.\nIn the conference room, one mural depicts a police officer approaching an older man in a bowler hat surrounded by brightly colored, cartoonish elephants and other strange figures. The caption below the mural reads, \"All right you guys, break it up!\"\nIn a small room off the conference room, another mural shows a group of rowdy people \u2013 including one woman with an exposed breast \u2013 on a boardwalk as a flag with \"Emerson\" written on it flies in the background.\nThe murals on the walls of the old jail cells are the most thematically appropriate. These were the \"drunk tanks,\" where people arrested for public intoxication or drunken driving could sober up under close supervision.\n\"Don\u2019t mix alcohol and gas: modern conditions demand clear thinking,\" says the message accompanying one mural. \"The world\u2019s meanest: the hit and run driver. Will your home be next?\" asks another.\nNew Deal-era art programs were conceived to help lift artists out of poverty while serving the larger purpose of giving ordinary Americans wider access to art and culture. Diana L. Linden, an art historian and an expert on WPA murals, said that they tended to be painted in schools, community centers, jail, libraries and post offices.\nWhile she wasn\u2019t familiar with Emerson\u2019s murals, she said it is uncommon for paintings commissioned under the Federal Art Project to depict nudity or other outlandish things \u2014 for instance, a sea monster hoisting aloft a nude woman and a frosty mug of beer.\n\"They tended to be very safe in terms of imagery with upbeat messages,\" Linden said. \"Though they did tend to tailor the message to whatever building\u2019s function was. So imprisonment in a jail cell makes sense.\"\nDespite what they may depict or whether they were definitively commissioned under the Federal Art Project, Linden said it is important to preserve any artwork from that period. Many New Deal-era paintings and other artwork were destroyed or lost in the 1950s, when Cold War fears led some people to conclude that they represented \"communist propaganda.\"\n\"To get rid of murals like this, it goes against most preservation and historical rules,\" Linden said. \"The New Deal was a unique moment, and in terms of artists it was the first time the government really made a stand, saying artists matter to society and gave them a role in society and helping to heal the effects of the Great Depression.\"\nBorough Administrator Bob Hoffmann said that after Borough Hall flooded in June 2015, he became concerned that humidity was causing the murals to deteriorate. Several of the murals have begun to fade, and paint has started to chip around the edges.\nSince then, Hoffmann said, the borough has fixed the flooding problem and the air conditioning system in the basement, making it \"noticeably less humid.\"\nLater this year a professional specializing in art restoration will inspect the murals, Hoffmann said, and recommend techniques to preserve them.\nBorough officials have begun discussing the possibility of renovating Borough Hall since the purchase earlier this year of two properties across the street from the municipal building. Regardless of what happens, if anything, Hoffmann said he is committed to making sure the murals are preserved.\n\"No matter what renovations happen or whatever happens here, we can preserve them,\" he said. \"It\u2019s a piece of Emerson\u2019s history and U.S. history. We walk by history every day in Borough Hall.\"\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/2000.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mythic-bridge/nonprofit-mythic-bridge-c_b_12443708.html"], ["text", "Non-profit MYTHIC BRIDGE Celebrates National Coming Out Day 2016\n10/13/2016 02:41 pm ET\nMythic Bridge Hands-on filmmaking programming for at-risk youth, NYC\nImagine having a major realization about who you are and feeling like you can't share it with anyone, not even your best friend. Imagine having this realization with the knowledge that because of this part of yourself, your parents may never talk to you again, you'll lose your job, lose your housing, or your physical safety may be threatened.\nNational Coming Out Day is a reminder that for many LGBTQ youth, the idea of coming out is intimidating, anxiety-inducing, and even downright scary. The rejection and hatred that may be waiting for them on the other side of such an important, personal confession can be paralyzing and isolating. All of our youth face enormous challenges, but with the additional obstacles faced by LGBTQ youth, they are 4 times as likely as their straight peers to attempt suicide. It doesn't have to be this way.\nMythic Bridge supports at-risk youth through the transformative power of filmmaking. We enable them to actualize their potential through filmmaking workshops. In honor of National Coming Out Day, we are promoting our LGBTQ filmmaking programs. This series of workshops were created specifically for LGBTQ youth and their supportive straight peers.\nThrough our programming, kids are able to share their stories in a safe, accepting environment and learn that their voices have value and the power to break through to the community. Man to Man is a short film produced during our July LGBT Workshops which tells the story of a young man struggling to come out to his brother during a game of 1-on-1 basketball:\nWe have teamed up with creative agencies Happy United and Rabbit Rabbit & Partners to help us start the vital conversation that we need to support LGBTQ youth. Our goal is to raise awareness about this issue and our work at Mythic Bridge. To this end, our Change the Script campaign celebrates a supportive, creative community that has the power to change the lives of LGBTQ youth.\nLast month, we launched our first spot, Change the Script : LGBTQ Suicide PSA.\nOur Change the Script campaign has continued with a portrait series made up of people who support LGBTQ youth and our filmmaking workshops. Participants in the series share their personal stories on how they would like to \" Change The Script .\" Transgender super-model Geena Rocero has partnered with us and is a champion for this campaign. She says...\nOther luminaries from the film community such as actress Alysia Reiner, director Pamela Romanowsky and actor Christian Campbell, along with Mythic Bridge mentors, workshop participants and other supporters of LGBTQ youth have participated in the series.\nThere are many ways to lend your support. This is ours. Alongside our effort to promote awareness, we've launched a CrowdRise to raise the money necessary to continue our efforts. We are asking you to donate to \" Change the Script \" for LGBTQ youth.\nOur campaign is on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram, we'll continue to share the stories of our LGBTQ teens and their vocal supporters as they Change the Script for our youth. Please help us make a difference and donate here:\nFollow Mythic Bridge on Twitter: www.twitter.com/MythicBridge\nMore:\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/2003.html"], ["url", "http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/essex/bloomfield/2017/01/14/bloomfield-hopes-new-public-works-building/96508396/"], ["text", "Bloomfield hopes for new Public Works building\nBloomfield seeks to build a new Public Works building this year.\nPost to Facebook\nBloomfield hopes for new Public Works building Bloomfield seeks to build a new Public Works building this year. Check out this story on northjersey.com: http://northjersy.news/2iw5PG9\nCancelSend\nA link has been sent to your friend's email address.\nPosted!\nA link has been posted to your Facebook feed.\nJoin the Conversation\nTo find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs\nBloomfield hopes for new Public Works building\nErin M Roll , NorthJersey Published 9:24 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017 | Updated 9:24 a.m. ET Jan. 14, 2017\n(Photo: file photo)\nCONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENTEMAILMORE\nBloomfield wants to build a new Public Works facility, as part of its list of goals for 2017.\nDuring the Township Council reorganization meeting on Jan. 5, Mayor Michael Venezia said that the township intends to build a new \"state-of-the-art\" facility\u00c2\u00a0for the Public Works crews.\nOn Friday, Township Administrator Matthew Watkins said that the idea is still in its early stages, and that the township does\u00c2\u00a0not have very many specifics laid down. [["name", "new_7/2005.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/richard-kronick/10-powerful-ways-successful-people-overcome-fear_b_12414162.html"], ["text", "10 Powerful Ways Successful People Overcome Fear\n10/10/2016 01:53 pm ET | Updated Oct 10, 2016\nRichard Kronick Author, teacher, speaker, coach. Self-proclaimed luckiest man alive.\nOne thing that most successful\u00a0people have in common is that they have managed to overcome the paralyzing effects of fear. To become successful in anything we have to take action despite being scared, to be courageous in the face of fear. So how can we develop the ability to bulldoze our way through fear? It turns out there are some simple techniques that we can practice that will help us do just that. Try these 10 ways successful people overcome fear and see for yourself\u00a0how anxiety, worry and doubt can melt away in the shadow of your own inner power.\n1. Stand Up Straight\nIt turns out one of the easiest ways to feel more confident and strong is to simply stand up straight. In her incredible TED talk , Harvard researcher Dr. Amy Cuddy has shown that by standing or sitting in a \"power pose\" ( see the poses here ) you actually increase hormones which make you feel more confident and decrease hormones which makes you nervous and stressed. It's simple yet effective.\n2. Smile\nYep, this too is simple. There is a lot of\u00a0 research showing that smiling can not only make you feel better, but it can also reduce your stress levels too. Lucky for you, there's no need to even read the research because you can try it anytime you want!\n3. Take a Cold Shower\nThe thought alone of taking a cold shower may fill you with anxiety, but it's all about asserting control over your life. Facing a fear and overcoming it is a surefire way to develop greater self-confidence. If you've succeeded in taking a cold shower, then the next time you face a challenge, you can say to yourself, \"If I can power through an ice cold shower, surely I can do this too.\"\n4. Embrace\u00a0What You Cannot Change\nWe cannot always control what happens to us, but we can choose how we react to what happens. Though it isn't always easy, we do have the power over our mental and emotional states, if we choose to assert our authority. Nobody else feels your fear, only you do. It exists within you.\u00a0One way to increase your personal power is to recognize that which we cannot change and embrace it. Accepting what we cannot change is, paradoxically, very empowering, because we then realize that we don't need to waste our time trying to change what cannot be changed and instead work on changing ourselves and our reaction to what is happening around us.\n5. Don't Think, Don't Try, Just Do\nSometimes all we need to overcome fear is to just take the first step. It is easy to get caught up in over-analyzing something and by simply jumping in and taking some action we can gain momentum. Before we know it the obstacles we feared have long been overcome.\n6. Deep Breathing\nIn moments of stress or fear, taking a few slow, deep breaths has been shown to relieve mental and physical stress and enhance decision-making abilities.\n7. Overwhelm Negativity With Positivity\nFear comes from negative thoughts; worries of what might happen. Most fears in life never actually materialize, yet we spend\u00a0so much time thinking about\u00a0'what ifs'. The next time you find yourself overwhelmed by all the scary things that might happen, try bombarding your mind with positive and empowering thoughts and affirmations. Affirmations\u00a0really do work, but they take time and persistence.\n8. Gratitude\nFew emotions are as powerful as gratitude. There is no room for fear or\u00a0doubt inside a grateful mind, for the feeling of gratitude takes up the entire emotional space of our being. Gratitude banishes fear. How can we induce the feeling of gratitude? One way is to start listing off all of the things you are grateful for. Life itself is a gift, your heart is a gift, the air you breathe is too. Another way is to use this powerful Zen affirmation .\n9. Get\u00a0a Power Rock\nGo outside and wander around until you find a rock or crystal that you like and is small enough to keep in your pocket. In the morning, afternoon and before sleeping hold the rock for about a minute. While you do, imagine that the rock is emanating enormous strength, power and courage and filling your entire being with radiant power. Carry the rock with you and turn to it as needed. The rock itself may not have any inherent power, but you imbue it with great power.\n10. Imagine and Rehearse Success\nIn moments of fear, step back and imagine yourself successfully overcoming the obstacle you face. Picture yourself having already succeeded. Imagine the pats on the back and the handshakes. Really let yourself feel how it will feel when you succeed. Rehearse it over and over in your mind. This should give you a surge of confidence and direct your focus on achievement, rather than fear.\n\u00a0\nA Final Word on Fear\nIn the end, it helps to remember that we are the source of fear, not our circumstances. Sure, fear is usually a reaction to something happening\u00a0around us, but the feeling of fear arises within you. Remember, if you created it, you can take it away.\n\u00a0\nThis article originally appeared on Completed Thoughts . The author shares his joy and gratitude creating birthday wishes and anniversary wishes .\nFollow Richard Kronick on Twitter: www.twitter.com/Richard_Kronick\nMore:\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/2009.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michelle-zarrin/human-being-versus-human-_b_12193570.html"], ["text", "Human Being Versus Human Doing\n09/26/2016 04:16 pm ET\nMichelle Zarrin Speaker on Internal Strength, Author, Spiritual Guide\nThere are two ways we can function in this world. We can navigate using the spirit, or using the mind. The spirit will put us into contact with soul expression and expansion, while the mind will put us into contact with schemes and strategies.\nAlthough most people live their lives from a place of doing, in other words living through the mind, the quality of our life resides in our being, or living through the spirit. Taking it one step further, living through the mind is fear-based while living through the spirit is love-based. When we conduct our lives from a place of being rather than doing, we walk into uncertainty. We surrender to the outcome. The act of surrender may sound fearful, but in this case it is actually rooted in love and belief.\nWhen we plan, organizing every step and making sure we've covered all bases, the core of these actions is fear. True fear comes from wanting to protect ourselves instead of wanting to let go. Generally, people have it backwards: They think to surrender is fearful. And while we are not sure of the exact outcome, one thing is certain: The outcome will be far more miraculous than that of any plan we could have prepared.\nIt is when we release our angst and stop striving, pleading, worrying and doing \"as much as we can\" that we tap into pure flow. Pure flow comes from our spirit, from love, from the essence of the universe. Nature does not hurry, strive or worry, yet everything happens in due time. All growth, blossoming and withering gently occur. Nature does not have a mind. However, it has something vaster than the mind, and that is the intelligence of the universe. If we allow our lives to come from a place of being, we open ourselves up to infinite intelligence as well.\nThe mind is very powerful. When you set your mind on something, you can definitely achieve it, and manifest your desires into reality. Such a statement would generally be associated with a lot of doing and striving. However, once a person sets their intention, and surrenders the final outcome to the universe, their results will be spectacular. When we know what we want, but surrender the process of achieving it to the intelligence far greater than anything our mind can perceive, we begin living lives beyond our wildest dreams.\nSo how does one achieve this kind of life? First of all, set an intention for what you'd like your future to look like, in your career or personal life or both. The fact is, if something is brewing within you, it is meant to be a part of your destiny. The first step to living out your purpose is to imagine a specific life that makes you happy. People do not want the same things. If you have a specific desire within you, then it is time to start giving it more energy and taking small steps towards it.\nThe next step towards living with purpose is to ask yourself if what you are doing, at each moment of your day, is coming from a place of love or fear. There are no other options. Human beings function on the essence of those two emotions. If you feel excited, happy or hopeful about something, you are functioning on love. If you feel dread, worry or resistance towards something, you are functioning on fear. The energy of love expands our life to encompass more possibilities. The energy of fear constricts our life within a box. So, to move forward with love in your heart is to live with your being. This mentality will put you in touch with the flow of life.\nThese two steps - setting an intention for the life you want, and taking small steps towards it with love each day - are the most profound things you can do to tap into your being. It sounds simple. However, it takes courage and work. The mind loves to control; that is its job. But with control comes a domino effect of other hindrances, such as worry and fear, that end up blocking our vast potential.\nThe choice is always yours. If you feel you've done all you can do, yet feel there is more that can be attained, then let it go. It takes courage, faith, belief and trust to surrender. Attaining these traits requires training the mind. But when you do so, and live from being rather than doing, then you are actually living. You are moving towards Oneness with all that is. You are opening yourself up to the greatness that resides within you, waiting to be released. The intelligence of the universe can provide us with a life far grander than the intelligence of our minds ever could. Our function is to know what we want, believe we can get it, surrender to the process and wait for the miracles to unfold.\nMore:\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/414.html"], ["url", "https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/npr-news/id324906251?mt=8"], ["text", "\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\nby                    drstevenj\nI'm surprised there are not many five star reviews. I use this app every day. At the end of the day I can listen to all things considered or morning edition and listen to all of the stories sequentially in my car. It doesn't use any Data to download all of these episodes from the program for that day. By Saturday at 2 o'clock, I listen to Saturday edition as I'm driving. I can listen to each story sequentially. Doesn't get better than that. If I want a change I can listen to this American life, the hidden brain, the moth, or any of their excellent programs.\nIt's free, and you get to choose what you want to watch versus NPR one which attempts to choose stuff for me. Don't like that. I've never had the app crash. It does occasionally stop when my radar detector goes off but otherwise it has been rock stable.\nAddendum: it's 2017 and this is still the best NPR app there is. I don't particularly like NPR one because it's like the Pandora of NPR podcasts. I don't like having podcast chosen for me by an algorithm. This wonderful app allows me to choose the program I want to, select from all available episodes and run them sequentially, and appears to use no cellular data when I listen to it in my car. I have two words: Cades!, And two more words use it! You won't regret it.\nNPR. Delivered through an app. Could use a makeover, though.\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\nby                    partaypooper\nI usually use the NPR One app while I'm commuting, but around the house, or during my downtime, I like to use the NPR app (branding is hard; I feel you, devs). Fantastic for casually browsing a stylized feed and whatnot.\nSo functionally, the app is nigh perfect; it's easy to use, and additional features are clearly thought-out and implemented well. However (yep, there it is)....I mean, the UI looked dated two years ago; at this point it belongs in the NPR Archives.\nAll kidding aside, though, this is a great app. I'd also recommend the NPR One app for a much simpler (albeit less comprehensive) app for your commute, workout, etc. *But* I'm rating 4 stars for now because, c'mon guys; the thing's already perfected, let's give it a new paint job (self-plug: I do happen to be a registered iOS dev; write me if you're open to contractual work).\nNPR Always\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\nby                    indigo ebony\nMobile platform has worked very well for me, living in a rural area of the Midwest out of range, most days, of reliable radio reception for city stations of NPR.  I appreciate the exposure to an impressive variety of programs - in-depth news that is more balanced than most commercial news, music that includes jazz, classical, Latino and World as well as lesser-known artists.  There is abundant food for thought and personal growth - from \"The Splendid Table\" to \"The TED Radio Hour\", from \"Invisibilia\" to \"The Best of Car Talk\" plus locally-produced programs varying state to state.  Thanks for making NPR available anywhere my phone has reception!\nCustomers Also Bought\n"]]

It\u2019s a grand endeavor, and Adams, at the center of it all, brings pluck and smarts and a deep-seated sorrow to her role. This is her movie, no doubt. show more\n88\nPeter Travers Rolling Stone\nAdams, her face a reflection of conflicting emotions, is simply stellar in an Oscar-buzzed performance of amazing grit and grace. Without her, Arrival might be too cerebral to warm up to. With her, the film gets inside your head and emerges as something intimate and epic, a linguistics odyssey through space and time. It's the stuff that dreams are made of. show more\n"]]

Time and again, she rejects him, leading him to steal her journal and make a plan: to kidnap Holly. After Seth takes Holly, she wakes up in a cage beneath the animal shelter and is being treated like the dogs living above her.\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/750.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-washington-dc-hotel-gsa_us_587947bfe4b0e58057fed977?ir=Politics"], ["text", "Trump Is Set To Violate His D.C. Hotel Lease And The Agency Holding It Has No Plan\n\u201cIt does appear that GSA is out of the loop on this.\"\n01/14/2017 07:01 am ET | Updated 1 day ago\n2.8k\nPaul Blumenthal Money in Politics Reporter, The Huffington Post\nWASHINGTON \u2015 When explaining how he would (somewhat)\u00a0 extricate himself from his myriad conflicts of interest \u00a0this week, President-elect Donald Trump and his tax lawyer completely ignored what would happen to the Trump International Hotel in Washington, D.C. It looks like he also failed to discuss that with the government agency that holds the hotel lease.\nTrump\u2019s deal with the General Services Administration to operate a hotel in the Old Post Office building specifically states that the lease cannot be held by an elected official . And the clock is ticking down to Trump\u2019s inauguration.\nYet the GSA released a statement on Wednesday, after the president-elect\u2019s press conference, indicating that it was not aware of his plans for the Trump Organization until he announced them to the public.\nThis is a legitimate international scandal and they\u2019re not part of the conversation. Procurement law expert Steve Schooner, on the GSA\n\u201cGSA understands that an announcement has been made to change the business structure of the Trump Organization,\u201d\u00a0the agency said in a statement . \u201cWe are seeking additional information that explains and describes any new organizational structure as it applies to the Old Post Office lease. Upon receipt, consistent with our treatment of any contract to which we are a party, we will review this new organizational structure and determine its compliance with all the terms and conditions of the lease.\u201d\nThe agency\u2019s apparent lack of knowledge is \u201cextraordinary,\u201d according to Steven Schooner, a government procurement law professor at George Washington University.\n\u201cIt does appear that GSA is out of the loop on this,\u201d said Schooner, a former government contracting official at the Department of Justice and the Office of Management and Budget. \u201cThis is a legitimate international scandal and they\u2019re not part of the conversation.\u201d\nThe GSA did not respond to a request for comment.\nThe lease for the D.C. hotel was signed in 2013 and Trump announced his presidential campaign in June 2015. That means the agency has had nearly two years to come up with a plan on what to do if Trump won the presidency. So far, it has refused to state publicly whether it thinks Trump will be in violation of his lease the moment he takes the oath of office on Jan. 20.\nOn Wednesday, Trump announced his plans to hand over control of his business \u00a0to his two adult sons, Donald Jr. and Eric, while still maintaining his ownership stake. Such an arrangement does little to nothing to resolve any conflicts related to the business. Walter Shaub, director of the Office of Government Ethics, called the plan \u201cmeaningless\u201d and far short of the steps that every other modern president has taken to eliminate financial conflicts upon taking office.\nMANDEL NGAN/AFP/Getty Images\nEric, Donald and Melania Trump cut the\u00a0ribbon at\u00a0the grand opening of\u00a0the Trump International Hotel in Washington, D.C., on Oct. 26, 2016.\nThe hotel lease with the GSA clearly states, \u201cNo member or delegate to Congress, or elected official of the Government of the United States or the Government of the District of Columbia, shall be admitted to any share or part of this Lease, or to any benefit that may arise therefrom.\u201d\nSince Trump will keep his ownership in the Trump Organization, he will inevitably remain a beneficiary of the lease.\nThe GSA has another Trump-related problem looming. As president, Trump can and probably will name a new head of the agency. That person will be in charge of annual lease negotiations with the president\u2019s sons.\n\u201cThere\u2019s an imbalance of power,\u201d Schooner previously noted to HuffPost. \u201cIn a 60-year, complicated contract, we\u2019re going to ask a civil servant at GSA to negotiate annually with the president\u2019s children.\u201d\nThe fact that the GSA was left out of the loop on Trump\u2019s business plans fits with how the president-elect and his company lawyers have treated the Office of Government Ethics.\u00a0Shaub has said he lost touch with the Trump team after the election and attempted to get their attention with a stream of tweets calling on the president-elect to fully divest his business holdings.\nRep. Elijah Cummings (D-Md.), the ranking Democrat on the House Oversight Committee, told HuffPost that he is \u201cvery concerned\u201d in light of the latest GSA statement.\n\u201cI think they were reluctant to give a decision early on,\u201d Cummings said. \u201cIn other words, before he violates it.\u201d\nCummings added, \u201cWe\u2019ll see what happens, I guess, see next Monday after he\u2019s sworn in. I expect that there will be a decision on [Jan. 20].\u201d\nThe GSA\u2019s current silence on the hypothetical violation of the lease is consistent with its past public assertions.\nBack in December, Cummings and Rep. Peter DeFazio (D-Ore.), ranking Democrat on the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, sent a letter to the agency asking whether it believed Trump would violate the lease agreement if he did not divest his holdings. The letter, released by Cummings, stated that Michael Gelber, deputy commissioner of the GSA\u2019s Public Buildings Service, had said the new president would indeed be in violation.\nThe GSA, however, refused to comment, insisting that it could not make any determination until Trump assumed office.\n\u201cWe can make no definitive statement at this time about what would constitute a breach of the agreement, and to do so now would be premature,\u201d the GSA statement said in December. \u201cIn fact, no determination regarding the Old Post Office can be completed until the full circumstances surrounding the President-elect\u2019s business arrangements have been finalized and he has assumed office.\u201d\nCongressional Republicans have held no hearings on the issue.\nMore:\n"]]

[["name", "new_7/753.html"], ["url", "https://www.moviefone.com/movie/in-a-valley-of-violence/20084305/main/"], ["text", "DVD Release Date: December 27th, 2016\nR|1 hr 44 min\nPlot Summary\nA mysterious drifter (Ethan Hawke) and his dog journey toward Mexico through the barren desert of the Old West. Hoping to shorten their trip, they cut through a large valley, landing in the forgotten town of Denton -- a place now known as a valley of violence. The once-popular mining town is nearly abandoned and controlled by a group of misfits and nitwits, including the seemingly untouchable Gilly (James Ransone), the troublemaking son of the town's difficult marshal.\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/756.html"], ["url", "http://m.huffpost.com/us/entry/us_587b9be8e4b0e58057ff493e/amp?ir=Politics"], ["text", "Reince Priebus Warns Ethics Chief To 'Be Careful'\nThe director has called for Donald Trump to fully divest his assets before he assumes the presidency.\n15 hours ago\nIgor Bobic Associate Politics Editor, The Huffington Post\nRick Wilking/Reuters\nIncoming White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus warned that he felt the head of the government ethics office was getting very political.\nWASHINGTON \u2015 Incoming White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus warned the head of the Office of Government Ethics on Sunday to \u201cbe careful\u201d in his criticisms of President-elect Donald Trump .\nOGE Director Walter Shaub last week panned Trump\u2019s plan to address his business conflicts as \u201c meaningless ,\u201d marking the second time the director called on the president-elect to fully divest his assets before he assumes the presidency this week.\u00a0\n\u201cThe head of the government ethics ought to be careful because that person is becoming extremely political,\u201d Priebus said on ABC News\u2019 \u201cThis Week.\u201d\nThe outgoing chairman of the Republican National Committee further suggested that Shaub supported Hillary Clinton in the presidential election.\n\u201cSo I\u2019m not sure what this person at government ethics, what sort of standing he has any more in giving these opinions,\u201d he said.\nShaub\u2019s extraordinary decision to speak out drew the ire of Republicans. Rep. Jason Chaffetz (R-Utah), the chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, accused Shaub of \u201cblurring the line between public relations and official ethics guidance\u201d in a letter Thursday.\nDuring a separate appearance Sunday on \u201cThis Week,\u201d Chaffetz further called into question Shaub\u2019s statements,\u00a0claiming he had \u201cnever done an investigation and never looked at the paperwork in the point where he can actually come to a reasonable conclusion.\u201d\nAsked whether he, as chair of the House Oversight Committee, would look into Trump\u2019s conflicts of interest around the world, Chaffetz said he had \u201cno plans to do that at this point.\u201d\n\u201cI\u2019m not just going to go on these fishing expeditions,\u201d he said. \u201cI didn\u2019t do that with President Obama. We didn\u2019t go through this with President Obama. I think the world and certainly the American voters understand that Donald Trump has mass holdings. He\u2019s worth billions of dollars. He\u2019s been very successful in business. And I think the American voters understood that when they voted him in.\u201d\u00a0\nAlso on HuffPost\n"]]
[["name", "new_7/758.html"], ["url", "https://www.moviefone.com/movie/american-honey/20085016/main/"], ["text", "Joe Morgenstern Wall Street Journal\nI don\u2019t know how Ms. Arnold works the magic she does with her actors, whether amateur or professional \u2014 Mr. LaBeouf inhabits his role with sly charm and explosive ferocity \u2014 but it\u2019s an expansion of what she started doing more than a decade ago in her remarkable \u201cWasp.\u201d show more\n70\nDavid Rooney The Hollywood Reporter\nThe film works best as a poignant character study, observing Star as she settles into her independence and figures out who she wants to be, framed by a vast physical landscape that stretches socioeconomically from privileged wealth to squalid poverty. Police attacked Lewis and hundreds of peaceful voting rights activists at the event, known as \u201c Bloody Sunday .\u201d Lewis was beaten so badly he suffered a fractured skull. [["name", "new_7/793.html"], ["url", "https://www.moviefone.com/tv/rectify/278568/main/"], ["text", "It\u2019s a breathtaking work of immense beauty and a thought-provoking meditation on the nature of crime and punishment, of identity and solitude, of guilt and absolution. [["name", "new_7/795.html"], ["url", "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-john-lewis-tweet_us_587a3d30e4b0e58057ff1eb3?ir=Politics"], ["text", "Lawmakers Are Not Happy That Donald Trump Attacked John Lewis\nThe president-elect's claim that the civil rights icon is \"all talk\" did not go over well.\n01/14/2017 11:11 am ET | Updated 16 hours ago\n3.2k\nPaige Lavender Senior Politics Editor, The Huffington Post\nA slew of lawmakers rushed to criticize President-elect Donald Trump after he criticized Rep. John Lewis (D-Ga.) in a series of tweets Saturday morning.\nAfter Lewis said he doesn\u2019t think Trump is a \u201c legitimate president ,\u201d Trump went after him, tweeting that the civil rights leader is\u00a0\u201cAll talk, talk, talk \u2015 no action or results.\u201d Lewis organized a series of sit-ins, protests and events to help raise awareness for voting rights in the 1960s. At one point, he suffered a fractured skull after being beaten by police \u00a0following the Selma march .\nHouse Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) tweeted that Lewis could not be silenced:\nAhead of #MLKday2017 , let us remember that many have tried to silence @repjohnlewis over the years. In addition, he has attacked Gold Star parents, veterans such as John McCain and now civil rights icon John Lewis.\u201d\nLieu had said earlier that he would not partake in the ceremonies because he would be fulfilling his duties as a colonel in the Air Force reserves, but in his Saturday statement he cited Trump\u2019s comments about Lewis as one of his reasons for not attending.\nRep.
